The only good thing about this movie is Zooey Deschanel's blistering blue eyes. Everything else smells like the bathroom after I've gone poo.

title: What is wrong with you people?
review:
I always come to IMDb to read reviews by other users before seeing the actual movie. The Happening was one that I have wanted to see from the moment I had heard about it. So, when I heard and read the negative reviews from everybody, I was a little discouraged (especially since Lady in the Water was beyond terrible). But it turns out that you are all on crack.

As you can see from my rating, I really enjoyed this film. It was a comeback in my opinion for Shamalamadingdong. I thought the script was funny, and Wahlberg's seemingly bad acting was his interpretation of this script and I thought he nailed it as did the rest of the cast. I do not think that the actors were here to win Ocars. It seems they came out to have fun with it and it worked. That is why it shocks me to hear such bad things. The tension was there. The comedy was there. The classic Shamalan ending was there.

It just seems that the kind of people who went to see this movie are the ones who are probably pure horror and gore fans and were expecting more and more people to die in this film. Shamalan only had a few deaths shown in this film and then in other scenes he let us assume what was happening. Not everything has to be handed to us on a silver platter.

If you are a true Shamalan fan, then see this movie. It is a film like Unbreakable and Signs where action is not happening all the time but it still keeps you gripping on for more.

title: awful!!
review:
worst movie ever, I feel so cheated. I want my money back. Night's ego is higher then his movies. and specially the end "s--- happens". Thats all just s--- happens!!!

Worst dialogs, poor acting. some smart tricks but done to death by many Asian horror filmmakers. Might be new here in USA but nothing fresh.

I would save my money!!! do not watch this film -its a fake "nature-spiritual" movie without soul. Its sad that Night is becoming Deepak Chopra of film world -egocentric and empty!!!

Why would someone invest so much of money in creating an in-important filmmaker? In The Happening everything happens except a great movie.

Just avoid. I feel so frustrated. Now I take wow that Night has disappointed me three times in a row. Never again I will watch his movies !!!

title: Even if it's Shyamalan's worst yet, it's still excellent.
review:
M. Night Shyamalan. A man with a unique mind and an amazing talent for film-making. Many reviews of "The Happening" disagree with the aforementioned statement, so let me take a moment to attempt to solidify it.

First, Shyamalan's movies are thought-provoking. The movie world in 2008 is not the same as it was when his "The Sixth Sense" was in theaters. Audiences have different expectations for movies, with all of the banal action-packed superhero movies being make left and right, especially in the summer. You cannot go into "The Happening" expecting it to be something it is not. There is no Hulk smashing buildings, nor are there high-speed car chases or tragically predictable love stories. I truly believe that mindset is the most important thing to enjoying a movie.

With that said, I had extremely high expectations for this movie, especially after the disappointment of "Lady in the Water." In many cases, "The Happening" fulfilled these expectations, while in a few other ways, it did not.

The script and the pace make this film outstanding. When watching "The Happening," just place yourself in the role of the main characters. How would you react to the events taking place? How each of the characters reacts is extremely realistic, showing just how frightening the truth can be. The fact that this movie takes place over such a short period of time really captures its moments well. Even faced with much larger concerns, the characters do not forget about their personal lives and problems.

Now what is wrong with this movie is the direction--namely its casting of Mark Wahlberg. His character shows far less emotion than he should, and his acting seems so forced it is almost pathetic. The easiest way to put this is that Wahlberg's character says the right things, but in the wrong manner. Throughout the whole movie, as I watched, I pictured Mel Gibson with his masterful and moving performance in "Signs" in Wahlberg's place. With Gibson, the movie definitely would have been at least an 8/10.

On a final note, I would like to add that Shyamalan again manages to bring about real world concerns in a fantastical scenario, bringing at least some enlightenment and concern to those who care to listen. Do not go in expecting a gigantic twist; do not go in expecting a little boy to see dead people; "The Happening" is a very solid movie. People who appreciated "Signs" will almost definitely enjoy Shyamalan's latest installment.

title: SO BOOOOOOOOOOOOORING don't go see it
review: i looked at the trailer and though wow that looks like it could be a really good movie and its by the director of the sixth sense and unbreakable (thankfully i had not seen lady in the water although i had heard it was meant to be bad) and when i actually saw the happening i though god he really is not building up the suspense enough to make me scared i actually laughed at the part where all the bodies start falling of the building its just stupid because you think shouldn't they run not just stand there and look at all the bodies falling i also hate that it only happens in America it seems and then at the end it moves to Italy and although millions of people must have been killed because they must have been travelling in groups mainly just three months later everything thing seemed to go back to normal and all the millions of people who died suddenly seem to reappear and no one seems to be scared at all that the same infection could happen again

title: Do not waste money
review: I just saw this movie and I feel that it was not worth the money I spent on it. The plot dragged for the entire movie and it had no suspense. I also feel that it should not have been advertised with the point of it being rated R as there was close to no attributes of an R rated movie. You will find that in this movie there are many completely unnecessary scenes and at other times will question whether this is a comedy or a horror. There are many points in which you will want to fall asleep during meaningless conversations or parts where truly nothing is happening. With rising gas prices I recommend saving your money for gas.

title: Not QuiteThe Sixth Sense But Still Good
review:
This movie was much talked about before its release and why not since it was by the same gentleman who brought "The Sixth Sense" on to our screen. To some extent, this has lived up to its hype.

People, walking through New York's Central Park, start to get confused - repeating their words, standing still and then shooting themselves and this is believed to be a terrorist attack. In the meantime, a science teacher, Elliot Moore, is called out of his classroom and is informed that due to the incident in Central Park, the school is closing down and so Elliot and his wife flee the town in a train with their friend and his young daughter, Jess, who starts crying for her mother. Here they are informed by other passengers that the attacks are not just in one place but several and is spreading in the North East area or the country only. The train then comes to a halt in a remote town and everyone on it is informed that this would be the last stop as they had lost communication with everyone else. However, at dinner that night they hear on the news that these suicides are not caused by terrorist attacks but is a natural phenomena.

The movie stars Mark Wahlberg, Zooey Deschanel, John Lequizano and Ashley Sanchez. This is directed and written by M. Night Shyamalan.

Though not so good as "The Sixth Sense," this movie is a gripping thriller which has involved some very good special effects. There are scenes of some gruesome nature involving blood and in some scenes, the director very cleverly leaves the imagination to the audience.

Conclusion: A good thriller to watch but don't compare it to "The Sixth Sense.

title: Intense
review:
This move is creepy, morbid, violent, and disturbing, but it's also like a car accident; people can't help but watch. There are those who will want to lower there gaze. There are those who will think this movie is made for senseless shock value alone, but these people are the ones missing the point. This movie isn't about sugar, and spice, and everything useless unless you're baking. It's about life, the tress, the flowers, and what we are doing to it, how we are destroying it. We humans have become a force of destruction, and the earth taking notice, finally fights back, killing us just as we kill the plants. Just as the flowers drop dead, we drop dead.Just as the grass turns brown and dies, we die. In this movie humans get what's coming to them.

Some of the scenes are uniquely engaging, almost like a nightmare, and they will stay with you. I mean the opening scene alone is a handful of people jumping off a building committing suicide. I had a hard time turning the way people die off in my head at first, but a good movie does that it stays with you.

The movie in its simplest form is a campfire story with a lesson to be learned. The moral of it is to remember "The Golden Rule" do onto others as you would have them do onto you.

title: The last Shyamalan film
review:
Context: I really liked Sixth sense and the village. Lady in the Water and Signs I didn't like but thought they were watchable. Unbreakable was painful to watch but the ending made it worth the effort.

Review: To begin with the characters are unbelievable and shallow. I don't blame the actors, this is in my opinion clearly the fault of the director/screen play. You can see that there is potential but it is never brought forth. One ends up having no emotional connection to the film because one really doesn't care that much if a character lives or dies. They are hollow empty shells whose only use seems to be to give a running verbal dialog of what is visually happening on the screen.

The plot seems to be used solely as a mechanism for the director to give voice to his anti-human political stance. The devices he uses to drive the story forward are crude and intellectually insulting. It seems the director has an exceedingly low opinion of the IQ of his audience, or perhaps it is a simple lack of imagination. As one generally shouldn't blame malice when incompetence will do, I will simply state that I think Mr Shyamalan has lost his talent for story telling.

In certain scenes the visuals in the film seem designed to shock by their graphic nature. As a rule I don't mind this but there seemed to be no point other than to try to 'amp up' what is in reality a very long, drawn out, and rather pointless plot. It is so poorly done that it is in fact almost comical in certain scenes. None of the director's other films rely on gore and one gets the distinct feeling that the director is in desperation trying to rely on a cheap trick rather than put in the effort to tell an entertaining story.

The one redeeming quality of the film is in fact that it is so poorly done. Often when one initially becomes aware of a new film by a director that has done ground-breaking work in the past, one is almost compelled to see it even if their recent films "haven't worked out" (we all have bad days). The anticipation mixed with fear can be annoying. This film shows me very clearly that I can now safely ignore any further work from M. Night Shyamalan. I now feel a sense of release and so I am in a perverse way grateful to the director for making this film.

Thank you Mr Shymalan for making some truly wonderful films! Having now finished your movie-making career in style I wish you the best in whatever new field of endeavor has captured your interest.

title: Can a natural given talent vanish completely ?
review: After watching "The happening" tonight i'm afraid that the answer must be "YES". As a warning: This film is a total waste of time. The story is absolute nonsense. The only thing to it are a few mildly shocking scenes, but that's surely not enough to make up 90 Minutes of filming. The acting is terrible too, some scenes are even - unwillingly - funny ( for example Marky Mark talking to a rubber plant ). The only bright spot is John Leguizamos performance, but he appears only in a few scenes. After Shyamalans marvelous films "The sixth sense", "Unbreakable" and in my opinion even "The Village" and "Signs" it becomes obvious that Shyamalans days are over even before he turns 40... "Lady in the water" could have been a temporarily blackout in his career ( even though LITW has still a better script than "The happening" ), but this film absolutely marks the pitiful end to his career as a writer and director. I had really hoped for another ingenious movie from Shyamalan, but alas, all my hopes were destroyed by this piece of absolute rubbish. Please understand one star of my voting as a mere gesture of respect to his former work and the other as a tribute to John Leguizamos appearance.

title: Weak would be an understatement
review:
To be honest i'm shocked and appalled at how terrible this movie was, even more shocking is i came out thinking that i had actually allowed myself to think that it might have been good despite the fact that bar his first two i hate all his movies.

The problems with this movie are innumerable(Script, acting,Outright storyline) but quite simply the only way that matters where it fails is that its not at all entertaining. I can sit back and enjoy a silly movie as much as everyone else but this had nothing, in fact id go as far as to say it has zero redeeming qualities which is a shame because the skeleton of the story is intriguing.

Mr. Shyamalan you can make movies, we've seen and liked them but please for all our sakes stop writing.

title: Pointless Happening
review: This weak mass of a film is a major disappointment from M.Night Shyamalan, director of classic films including The Sixth Sense, Unbreakable and Signs. The central premise is that nature is striking back at the plague of humans on the planet by releasing an airborne toxin that causes people to kill themselves(the film has a very heavy-handed environmental subtext). While this premise provides for some striking images - dozens of people hurling themselves off building, or hanging like strange fruit from the trees - the film unravels shortly after the opening scenes. Mark Whalberg is horribly miscast as high school science teacher Elliot and Zooey Deschanel, who plays his wife Alma is better at comedy than horror. The movie follows the basic format of a zombie movie, except when people get infected, they kill themselves. The lack of any tangible menace means the film mainly consists of the protagonists running through fields as Shyamalan tries desperately to make shots of grass and trees rustling the wind seem horribly threatening. Try as he might, he can't do it. Worse still, the film doesn't follow any logic - if there's an airborne toxin, surely the first thing you would do would be to find a gas mask or seal yourself up in a relatively airtight building? What Shyamalan does manage to produce here is the world's most sustained suicide - glorifying film.

title: Good story, average film-making, bad actors
review:
Well, I really like Mr. Night Shyamala.. Shamyla... errr, his movies so far. I liked The Village despite its obvious plot flaws and I liked Lady in the Water as well, but this time..

It is safe to say that the story itself has some potential. It could have been a really scary, entertaining, creepy movie - and it was at least sometimes, the opening sequences were actually really frightening, and Mrs. Jones really made my flesh creep.. But then, bad acting, especially Deschannel, really turned me off. She looked like a small child with wide eyes ALL the time. I felt that her acting resembled that of C-class TV-series actors.

Anyway, the camera did a good job, but the editing sometimes appeared to be quite disrupting and jumped from scene to scene seemingly unmotivated, leaving me behind feeling like only taking glimpses at the story and what happened.

And then there are the countless implausibilities and very "unlikely" events - and I'm not speaking of the story itself which was as I said not bad, better to say, promising.. No, the events as presented in the movie more than once let me think "yeah, right..."

Overall it was, despite the flaws in and the criticism on the movie-making handicraft and acting, an interesting movie, unconventionally and sometimes quite surrealistically filmed (as always with Mr. Night S. - I guess this times the unconventional and unsteady editing contributed to that feeling) and some good ideas and really good and scary scenes, but it seemed to be done in a rush, not very caring, not really a work of heart but a remittance work.

BUT: I can't help but somehow I can't stop thinking about the movie.. It still works in my brain, and not in a bad way. Hmmmm.....

title: Excellent Movie!!! (if you can get it)
review:
The first thing that strikes me about this is how original the story is as well as its developments.

For what its worth, we have to give credit to new ideas, a great idea in this case. I have to admit I have never seen anything quite like this, it definitely caught a lot of people by surprise.

We are living on times that almost every movie that comes out is a sequel or at least look like one. We've seen so many tsunamis of pre-fabricated clichés, copies and plain rip-offs that we forgot the real meaning of what is really a "new movie".

It is true, this one is not for everybody. Unfortunately, in order to really "get" this movie it is required to whoever is watching it to have a brain.

If your thing is movies that just tells you how to think or even better, does not require that you do any thinking at all, this is not the right choice for you.

Not even the awful performances of the leading actors was enough ruin this movie. Whoever gave Marky Mark and Zooey Deschanel these parts must have been suffering from mental diarrhea and spiritual gonorrhea.

A great original story that gives the viewers a lot to think about the understanding of our selves and our way of living.

title: UMM... What the F*%&??
review:
"You feel like you're not watching the end of the world but the end of a career."-Boston Globe A review of this movie could not have been more dead on. I did like Sixth Sense (even though it had no rewatchability what so ever), and Unbreakable, and Signs had its good moments. But his last two movies were terrible, and I really didn't think anyone could make a worse movie than Lady In The Water. But leave it to M. Night to top that. Usually he at least has good cinematography or some sort of suspense, but no you get none of that. I suggest you stay for the first 10-15 min. and walk out and ask for your money back you will have seen all the merit-able footage this movie has to offer even the suicide scenes are terrible. This was a D-movie with worse acting and probably one of the worst scripts I have ever heard. But I will give it one thing it is probably the best comedy of the year so far, I could not stop laughing, while the whole time trying to figure out if M. Night had tried to make a bad film or not because I really don't think if you were trying to make a good film this is what you would settle for. I honestly can not believe that M. Night could sit there and watch this and say "Yes this is my masterpiece, this is what i want the public to see"

DO NOT GO SEE THIS MOVIE STOP SUPPORTING BAD DIRECTING WHILE GOOD DIRECTING GOES UNDER THE RADAR.

title: Why bad?
review:
I do not understand the bad reviews of this movie.. I saw it after hearing about how bad it was - its not! I think the opening sequence is stunning! The story hasn't been told before, and Mark Wahlberg does a great job of not acting like your regular Hollywwod hero..! His character is quite strange and fragile, and he is not really brave or anything..

The ending might be a little thin, but I like the fact that it didn't end in your typical action-packed, hero-has-to-save-the-day-by-fighting-the-terrible-monster climax! All in all a good and underrated movie..!

title: Close your window ... but open your mind
review:
For me this was a terrific movie. Though I can understand a lot of people did and will not like it. Why? Most movies handle about extraordinary situations combined with extraordinary people: they have special powers, are very creative, show strong leadership. What about a movie where you have an extraordinary situation with 'ordinary' people? That's what the happening is all about. The situation is really extraordinary: flora is doing some nasty teamwork that threatens mankind! But there's no hero! Elliot Moore is not the biologist that goes in counter attack (i.e. by finding some cure that makes us resistant against this act of nature) nor is he the creative leader that comes up with a brilliant plan to 'bewilder' plant life.

After seeing such an intense trailer for some months it can be quite a disappointment having to cope with the above (only regular hesitant people in a remarkable situation). Maybe I was influenced by reading some bad reviews upfront and was therefore surprised with this subtle thriller.

I'm asking myself: if this movie was not promoted as a blockbuster, would it then get better critics? Maybe, but it's hard to say afterward. 'I am legend' was not your typical blockbuster movie  even though it was put forward as such  and still it became a hit.

As I see it, Mr. Shyamalan wanted to let the situation be the main actor and did his utter best not to let anything take over (Mark Wahlberg definitely could have  if the script allowed it). Even though this movie was working just fine for me, I'm sure it would score better if [1] the trailer had not made us think this would be a fast paced and powerful movie from head to toe or [2] let mankind be more in control.

title: Well done film, EXTREMELY funny
review:
This movie was obviously not meant to be taken seriously. The characters, story, and places are all satires on Shyamalan's previous movies; he's making fun of his own corniness.

The fact that wahlberg's character is a science teacher is hilarious. He tells his students, "there are some things in nature we will never understand and we have to accept that..." The most obvious point to make here is that this is not science. No science teacher would ever believe such a statement. So why was wahlberg's character a science teacher? To further highlight the absurdities in this film. And probably to make the scene in the field possible. (where upon facing gunshots and plant-induced death, he recites the scientific method to himself)

The stops on the characters' journey throughout the movie represent different films done by Shyamalan. The old lady's house, for example, is very reminiscent of the end of Signs. And the way she invites them into her home ('i suppose i should let you stay the night,' etc...) is playing on the ridiculous characters we often encounter in these types of movies, living on their own in the woods, etc. And you may notice that the first thing she says to her guests is that there is a speaking tube between the main house and the slave quarters. This is a not-so-subtle foreshadowing that pays homage to the same technique often used in horror movies.

I could go on, but i would rather be watching The Happening, a fantastic movie. And that is all it is. There is no hidden message here, just somelighthearted fun on Shyamalan's part, which he does very very well.

Another thing he did very well is fool all of you. Congratulations, M. Night Shyamalan got the best of you. He built his career around hidden messages, pulling the audience closer and closer to look for meaning in his works. Then with this most recent piece, he got himself an R rating (to complete the comedy) and has had all of you stumped for months trying to find meaning where there is none.

Think of it as a comedy, and it's brilliant.

title: Offensive and been done before.
review: There is nothing scary about this movie except that it has an audience of some fans out there who find it entertaining. Is this M. Night Shyamalan's entry into the current genre of torture porn? These comments come from a seasoned (42 years old) horror fan who found this movie more offensive than anything else, and I have defended "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" for over 30 years to people from all walks of life. TMC is certainly sedate to the genre films of today, but I am making the point that I am not a squeamish. I have found worth in a lot of extreme cinema. Suicide is not scary it's pathetic and sad. There is NO possible way plant produced neurotoxins could make people kill themselves. I can maybe see zombied people being unable to prevent being killed in accidents and hurting others, but doing it. The explanation is stupid. M. Night needs to read more about the human brain. Suicide is a thought related process, meaning they need to be aware on some level of the act. His self preservation malfunction is no excuse. The creative ways these victims commit suicide is an exercise in tasteless cinema. Did M. Night see the Japanese movie "Kairo" (Pulse)? In this movie, there was a mysterious global happening of mass suicides being caused by dead people luring the living to the other side. You may ask, isn't that as impossible as plants making people commit suicide? Maybe so, but it was certainly less gruesome not focusing on gore. I just read that Stephen King liked this movie. I can believe that since much of his work is recycled ideas. Sorry M. Night you lost most of us with "Signs." It was the sign to us that you were on your way out as our future Hitchcock. Here's an idea, mass groups of theater goers all walk in front of cars after see a movie because they feel ripped off. It could be a global happening.

title: The worst movie I watched in a long..long.. time.
review:
I'm new here in IMDb, and I'm not use to post comment for movies, but yesterday I watched The Happening (thanks god I haven't pay for it), As everyone knows now from the critics all around the world the film is crap, but when my friend wikipedia tall me that the director compare his movies with the bird (1963) of Hitchcock, and that the project costs $57 millions. That yeah upset me. Please Mr. Night Shyamalan, we all make mistakes but at least don't insult the industry of cinema, comparing the happening with a master piece such as the bird, and please don't trow $57 Millions in the toilets.

1/10

title: It is all about HEART
review:
Shyamalan's movies are always about heart. The human's heart. To understand his story, and the implication that he wishes to convey with his movies, one just have to LET GO of his mind, go back to his heart, just watch.

Same with this movie, The Happening. There is no intellectual. There is no logic or illogic. There is no cleverness. There is no brain. There is no mind. There is no thinking. There is nothing. Yeah, I sound like a mystic. But Shyamalan understand the mystical way of the world. His movies are always not about the brain, it is all about the heart. If you use your brain, just cannot let it go, just keep on thinking and thinking and thinking and arguing and arguing, non-stop, you will not understand.

I know, letting go of the brain to watch this movie sounds like an idiot. But remember one thing. All mystics, all religious masters ever existed, having existed and existing, know one thing that is very important but ordinary guys like you and me simply love to ignore, that is, to let go of the mind, eventually.

Most people just cannot let go of their mind. Therefore they find it very difficult to understand this movie, treating this movie like trash. All because, they live in the mind for so long, just cannot let go, cannot trust their heart to simply feel and understand the movie.

Do you know why those people in the movie can't help but killing themselves? Because they, like you and me, live in the mind and rely too much on it. Too much relying on the mind, sooner or later, you may feel like you want to kill yourselves to end all this misery, because the MIND is the only source of misery. Nothing else. It is because of the mind, you want to kill yourselves, simple as that. But can you get it?

Do you know why the 3 main actors can survive in the Happening? Because they are PURE. They are in the HEART. There is goodness in them. There is LOVE in them. Innocent is with them. All the goodness I mentioned above, trust me ,most people simply just have lost them. That is why, they do not understand. They just rely to much on their brain.

Yeah, in the movie, the Act of Nature kills. Why it kills we never know. But one thing that I know, or understand, is that, the nature won't hurt another nature. So why hurt those people? Because those people, like you and me, keep themselves away of the nature, and live in the brain. In other words, they become no longer part of the nature. Because they choose to do so. They choose to over-rely their brain.

The Act of Nature do not kill the main actors, simply because, they are still with the mother nature. They are love, innocence, heart, pure. The nature treats them as their own, that is why they survive. They are survive because they are NATURE. Never part from the nature.

If you do not understand, you have to find ways to do so, because living all the time in the mind and over-dependent on it is not life. Letting it go is.

title: B-Movie + Philosophy = this nice and entertaining movie
review: The Happening is a very nice movie. Here Night M. Shyamalan did not his best ("Signs" is my favourite and "The Sixth Sense" is a little masterpiece), but he did a very nice and entertaining thriller movie. Like all his other works, Shyamalan starts with one of the fundamental philosophical questions of this time and he tries to answer with a B-Movie theme. In "Sings" the fundamental question was "Does God exists?" and the B-Movie theme was an alien's invasion. In this case, the fundamental question is: "Is man the cancer of our planet?" and the B-Movie theme is an unstoppable pandemic deadly disease. The plot is a typical pandemic movie, but this is not a B-Movie at all: complex characters, realistic situations and shocking scenes of massive suicides give great depth to this movie. There is something wrong with acting: all actors (Zooey Deschanel, Mark Wahlberg and all the others) are always astonished, sometimes they act as alienated people. This is a characteristic of all Shyamalan's works, but in this movie it could be a bit disturbing. Shyamalan creates suspense. And he re-creates very well a desperate situation where humanity is struggling against an unknown, invisible and very powerful enemy. In this struggle there are no heroes, but only victims or lucky people, like in ordinary reality. And all this stuff is really, really entertaining! His plot is very coherent with the fundamental question "Is man the cancer of our planet?". He answers in the very end of the movie. Personally I don't agree with Shyamalan's answer. But I don't want to reveal it. Go to theater and watch it!

title: The planet can destroy us!
review:
I have heard many bad reviews about this movie. I do not see why. Sure the deaths were not original. Take a minute and tell me how plants can make someone kill themselves in a McGiver (I do not know how to spell that) manner. People pause, walk backwards and become truly dead meat for some lions or paper to a industrial sized John Deer. Those two suicides were my favorite because they were original and not to mention hilarious.

Throughout the movie there were also clever funnies added in. When Walhberg talked to the plastic plant changed the tone from a suspenseful feeling into a joyful and humorous one.

To maintain a serious plot, Shamalan added some key "sad" points such as the death of the little lassie's father.

Another great factor was the many hints that plants were making the 70's hit "Raining Men" come true. I also loved that he pointed the planet upon us and devoured the humans and not anything else. It goes to show that were are not at the top after all.

title: The invisible danger
review: Most of us don't want to admit it and don't want to be defeated by such an invisible, powerful and gentle threat. Our puffy egos claim to control what's bigger than us, fail and mess all around... Who is making us think that we have threats, that we must get guns, fight, and erect barriers and camps. Who? We are trained, by film industry, to see actors with 19 century theatrical faces, to expect the devil with bloody rotten teeth, or a psychotic dirty beast or 10 Muslims with beards and turbans, as major threats to western nightmare, sorry democracy. Not the case here, no adrenalin shoot, junkies; That's why this movie has strong IMDb rates at 10 and 1 levels. I enjoyed it because I followed the characters as if I was there with them. It's very human, simple, natural, realistic. A form of docu-movie. It has a slow-fast pace, as the threat itself. A bit of satyajit Ray and Hitchcock in it. The little girl, though a latina child looks more like and Indian child, with her necklaces. Some questions: why large groups are killed, why boys are killed, why angry people die, why major cities are touched. I let you find the answer in the movie. Great movie.

title: Great Movie
review:
I know I'm not one of many, but I thought it was a great movie. With good actors, especially Mark Wahlberg, and a good storyline, I don't know why so many people hate this movie.

Yes, maybe there is no plot-twist at the end, but who cares? Not EVERY movie of M. Night has to contain a plot-twist! Without the plot-twist, it's still a very good watchable movie!

I noticed that many people find M. Night Shyamalan a bad director, because he made a terrific movie, The Sixth Sense, and after that he only made 'crappy' movies. I totally disagree with that! I never saw The Village, but I will very soon, but I liked all his other movies. I thought Signs was pretty good, Unbreakable great, I even really enjoyed watching Lady in the Water! I just hope M. Night Shyamalan continues making this sort of films and not listen to the critics to much.

title: One of the Worst Movies Ever
review: It only gets a 2 because..well I'm just not cruel enough to go any lower, but this movie deserves the lowest possible value. For this movie I have a few questions. First off, the script? I don't know if it was the actors who stopped caring or that the script was so poorly written, but almost every line of that movie was entirely unconvincing. Mark Wahlberg is a good actor, but even his lines were given in dead fragments and statements, lacking any quality of suspense expected from an R rated horror film. Secondly, was there really a full plot? So the movies starts, the 'happening' starts to happen, and then the movie ends. There is no conflict resolution what-so-ever. People start killing themselves then they stop killing themselves. It all turns out to be a ghastly attempt of Shymalan's to try and raise awareness of global warming. Last question, why did people clap after I saw this movie? Some people just like to see blood and some gruesome deaths, which is about the only thing this movie had (but something that still could have been improved.)

title: The Happening
review: Before We saw this film we had read the horrible reviews posted throughout almost all movie sites. After seeing the film I firmly believe that these negative comments and ratings spawn from individuals that hate to be forced to think. While this film does force a willing suspension of disbelief, it serves as a very poignant social and political commentary. It should encourage all viewers to stop, take one moment, and think. If you are not willing to allow yourself to think then you should not view any of his films. Why? Because all of his films receive the same negativity in the beginning until viewers take a step back and think outside of the realm we are used to. We are handed plot lines and action on a silver platter. We are not expected to sit still and contemplate the texts sunk into the greater picture. We are handed everything and only expected to buy more popcorn and be content with the information being handed to us. To those who feel that you can "do better" or feel that it was "a waste of time and 7.00" challenge yourself. Think. Or better yet.... get out of your computer chair and try it yourself.

title: Thoughtful but Improvable
review:
The Happening provides a view of an apocalyptic world and the aftermath of an area after something "happens." M. Night Shyamalan delivers a message to the viewers about the possibilities of this world and how much we still do not know about the potential it has to destroy humanity. The story starts off with mysterious "happenings" that continually occur throughout the Northeast section of the United States. Elliot Moore (casted by Mark Wahlberg) is a science teacher that is faced with these harsh situations where people are dying from unknown causes. He works together with Alma Moore (casted by Zooey Deschanel) to protect themselves and Jess, daughter of fellow teacher Julian (casted by John Leguizamo).

Shyamalan delivers the message in a thoughtful way to continually question ourselves as to what may happen since nature is an unpredictable force. With this harsh reality in view, it may be sensible to question our own actions as to what we are doing to this world and how we may be hurting it. Too many people live each day without worrying about consequences after throwing out emissions from our gas-guzzling cars and pollutants. Shyamalan delves into one of those possible consequences, and that would be nature fighting back to survive.

With an open mind and the ability to go past some of the horribly written lines and awkward acting by Mark Wahlberg, a viewer can experience a possible horror in this world that may become a reality someday in the future. Shyamalan seems to tell us that the unlikely and the seemingly impossible is actually quite possible, but only if we are able to see them happening before our very eyes. However, with this horror film, it is better to question our own actions before horrid consequences may arise.

title: Eddie Van Halen Syndrome......MNS has got it! ='(
review:
Okay you are a young frustrated person with a tremendous amount of creativity and you say to yourself "I need something to set me apart from all the rest!"....then BOOM, it hits you, you've come up with a gimmick, a trick, a twist on how things are done and WA-BAM! You hit the world with one BIG SMACK right between the eyes, ERUPTION!....or in M. Night's case "The Six Sense"... and everyone LOVES YOU!.........."Oh gee M Night, you are so brilliant!!"..........

THEN.........it's time for act 2!...........Um.......hello ?...........um Act 2?......um duh......um let's see well we could a duh........um.........hmmm.....how about some um.....Aliens ? Ah no.....How about that little Ronnie Howard's Daughter she's hot, let's use her......um.....hmmm that didn't work =(

Moral of the story boys and girls, it is very very hard to re-invent the wheel and in the case of M Night and Eddie best to go down in history as a breakout creative talent then as a has been tormented by the ghost of yourself.

title: McCheesy's take on "The Happening"
review:
I don't know what the hell is up with the people saying that this film sucked bigtime or M. Night losing his touch, going downhill blah blah blah. This film was good that's that. Some people just hate M. Night so much that when they entered the theaters, their minds is set for one thing: this movie is bad. They didn't even give the film a chance, those Night haters weren't looking for the good things, they're looking for the bad. "Mark Wahlberg's weakest performance" this, "where the hell is the twist?" that. Okay, this may not be Night's best film ever (Sixth Sense for life) but this isn't his worst either (Lady in the Water still holds the title). This film is good, it may have its fair share of gaping plot holes or absurd sequences, but the film as a whole is good. Here's why: first, the acting. Mark's performance wasn't that bad, the critics had it all wrong. His performance was supposed to be that way, childish, immature and a guy who freaks out a lot. Remember the scene where he's teaching a class and then ducks when he sees the vice principal? Then there's this scene about the cough syrup thing which sounds like it came from a 10 year old and then there's the part where he freaked out and he says "Just give me a minute!", its all intentional. His character is supposed to be childish and immature because in the end, it will be a big factor for their survival. The same thing can be applied to Zooey Deschanel's character Alma. Alma is as childish as Mark's character Elliot.

So you see, the people who saw the performance and disliked it got it all wrong, it was actually pretty good. Second, the whole "Where's the twist?" bit. Okay, when Night made "Sixth Sense", the audience dug the whole twist in the end and they wanted more twists out of him, and so he did in three more films. They got pretty bored with the twists so Night stopped and made two twist-less films. And then when he made this film, with his infamous twist being a no-show, the people didn't like it mainly because the juicy twist isn't present. I swear when I saw the film when the credits rolled, I heard this guy saying: "Where the hell is the twist? Oh my, this movie is ----". A bit of advice to Night, don't listen to other people. Just follow what's in your gut because the people have different tastes and you can't satisfy them all so follow your instincts.

And lastly, the plants did it. In case you were wondering who killed those people. The plants were releasing toxins that's blocking some neurotransmitters in the human brain doing some bad stuff, fatal stuff into your body. I thought the plot was really good. Nobody has ever done a film about killer plants in the past 25 years, 50 years maybe. An original concept but people are just too busy bashing Night and putting his head in the gutter. I'm not a fanboy of his or whatever, I just wanted to straighten some things about this film. I know a bad film when I see one and this one isn't. Its too bad the majority of the people are Night haters.

7/10

title: All the hype aside, still a good show
review:
M. Night Shyamalan's hype and standard probably did him little justice in this film. The ratings I saw on IMDb seemed on target with how I felt with the movie.

The acting seemed a little uneasy at times, I just found it hard to see Mark Wahlberg as a school teacher. Betty Buckley's character in the film was one of the stronger performances and really moved the opening day crowd I saw at the theater.

The movie keeps you on edge at times and has some very interesting and creative death scenes.

This is one of those movies, that after you watch it, you ask your friends, "wow, what if that really happened? What would you do?".

title: Thrills, chills, people standing still...
review: So far, I think viewers have been a little tough on this movie, perhaps because of Shymalan's reputation. A good amount of people who went to see "The Happening" loved "The Sixth Sense" and hoped for something of that caliber. However, Shymalan may have peaked a bit early -- and you can't hold that against him. Though not as fantastically terrifying and mind-bending as "The Sixth Sense", "The Happening" holds its own as a decent (but not terrific) horror film. Compare it to most horror films you'd see in theaters now. I would recommend "The Happening" to any horror buff or individual simply seeking a gore fix/adrenaline shot. It does have its graphic death scenes, and it does have its "jump" moments. They were mostly shoved into the first half of the film, but still... prepare to hold onto your popcorn. While the elements we always seek in the horror films (suspense, violence, scariness) are all pretty much there, "The Happening" also brings definite creepiness to the table. Get used to the hairs raising on your arms whenever the phenomenon strikes another population... The unsuspecting residents of whichever city being hit with the strange effects of... well, I won't tell you... stand perfectly still, frozen in whatever they were doing. And then they end their own lives. Not gracefully. It creeped me out in a manner unlike that of any horror film I've seen. It struck an emotional chord no films have gotten to, for me. While I did expect a Shymalan twist, and was slightly disappointed by the last half hour, it was all worth it for those genuinely disturbing moments. Say what you will. For me, "The Happening" definitely happened.

title: The Crap-pening!
review: I hope you are entertained by the title of my summary because it is far more clever than anything you will see in this movie. The acting is terrible. The direction is terrible. The script is terrible. The dialog is so terrible many of us in the theater laughed out loud and yet the movie wasn't quite bad/good enough for the "so-bad-it's-at-least-funny" pile, which Lady in the Water was bad/good enough for. This movie is a complete disappointment on every level. The trailer looked decent so I thought I'd give M Night another chance but this movie sucks and I now have officially given up on him. I don't even like Sixth Sense any more now that I've seen it three times and realize it was overrated even by myself somehow! One last note, why on earth does M Night Shyamalan keep putting himself in his own movies? He really truly can't act at all. He couldn't act his way out of a paper bad. Why is he ruining his own movies? If he's not good enough to get parts in other people's movies he should give up his acting dream.

title: Worst movie i've seen in a while.
review:
Alright, i'm not much of a fan of M. Night Shyamalan but this was the only new release that i hadn't seen this week, so i thought i'd give it a shot. This movie is plain and simply horrible, the plot has no substance, the actors are clearly not convincing in their roles, the explanation for the events that occur are predictable, the ending is mediocre and the movie is poorly made.

I counted three shots in which the boom was clearly on camera (when the character Zooey Deschanel- Alma Moore is ignoring the phone in the living room in one of the first scenes and one of them is on the model home they find while talking).

Save yourself the horrible disappointment of watching this "horror" movie and rent the orphanage if you haven't seen it yet which is a great scary movie.

title: Utterly disappointed
review:
After seeing this movie, I left the movie theater thinking "What happened?". That's it, just so utterly confused. I mean, seriously. What happened?! I wanna start off by saying: this is not a bad movie. That is, by conventional means. If you have no idea who Shyamalan is, if you don't care, or you just like over-the-top gory movies and you go into it expecting nothing you could watch this movie. You might even enjoy it. It was a very good idea that was just not executed to its potential. If you're a loyal Shyamalan fan expecting his comeback, don't even bother. You'll be greatly disappointed.

The movie starts out very promising. The opening scene is gorgeous, appropriately and unsuspectingly haunting, and most importantly, shocking at the last minute. Graphic enough to shake you but not too gory so as to disgust you, which is very much Shyamalan's style. Which is exactly what leads to confusion later on. As early as the second scene, they're at it again. Another shock, except this one lingers far too long and is way too intrusive. Wait, this is a Shyamalan movie right? Okay, no biggie, a fumble, that's all, I figured. They give us a break in the third scene, and the fourth scene, guess what? There it is again! Blood! Gore! Graphic violence! Okay, now I'm getting suspicious. And it really just goes downhill from there. While I do applaud the grotesquely creative ways in which he imagines people killing themselves, by the time the scene with the lions came, it was just enough. I don't need to see this. No one does. It's offensive and condescending to his fans. The best Shyamalan movies show you only what you absolutely need to see, they trust their audience to be smart enough to surmise the outcome on their own. The movie itself is smart. But not here. We get every single detail of every gory death, hints thrown in our faces every 5 seconds (the writing on the blackboard takes the cake, they just told you the whole damn story!), but no discernible plot, characters, or story to speak of. I was scared throughout the movie, but for all the wrong reasons. I was scared what I was gonna see next!

The acting is beyond unbelievable. Wahlberg just doesn't seem to care, Deschanel looks and acts like she's stoned half the movie, and Leguizamo stumbles through his words like he just got around to reading the script the night before. No one delivers a good or even decent performance. The characters are shallow; the romance subplot is laughable at best, and the synergy of collaboration is completely nonexistent. Where's Bruce Willis or Joaquin Phoenix? Why couldn't he get one of them?

Lastly, there's the environmentalist pitch. I never would have pegged Shyamalan for an environmentalist, if that even is his doing, but while the message is indeed a good one, the whole delivery of it is blatantly on the nose. "If you don't stop destroying the planet, this is what's gonna happen to you *shaking finger*". Again, offensive and condescending! Enough of this!

All in all, this is really not a bad movie- if you expect nothing. And I do mean NOTHING. As in, not good acting, not good screen writing, and not good storytelling. Nothing at all. Just a lot of pointless violent deaths. If you're a die-hard Shyamalan fan like myself, this is absolutely unacceptable. The Sixth Sense was excellent, and Unbreakable was absolutely superb. Signs and The Village were good. Lady in the Water was just tolerable. With The Happening, it may be time for us to finally accept that our revered god of directing has peaked. This just never feels quite like a Shyamalan movie. I can't believe that it is. What happened?

title: No more directing Mr Shyamalan
review:
M, can I call you M? Here is some advice - Don't ever direct any of your scripts again...please. I really wanted to enjoy this film. A really cool conceit about nature fighting back, and some of the dialog was pretty bad, but salvageable, but with you directing it, you just couldn't hack your own material into shape, nor could you direct the actors to do more than mug for the camera. Jeesh M, you are an interesting screenwriter with cool ideas, but please let someone else direct them - so we can enjoy them

sincerely,

R Day Extrolanolin

title: Funny, Scary and Entertaining
review: The Happening is a great departure from Shyamalan's previous films. Many have talked about this film getting an R rating but I found the most noticeable difference to be the black humor in it. I have always been a Shyamalan fan but must admit that his films often seem to be taking themselves too seriously. Not so in this film! There is plenty of comic relief between the scares (Elliot talking to a plant, a man who brings a load of hot dogs with him in the evacuation) as well as humor in the violence itself. Let's face it: It's hard to take a movie seriously when a man feeds his own arms to a lion or a woman stabs herself with a knitting needle. You have to laugh at that, but that is intentional. The point of this movie to be an entertaining B movie and I'd say it succeeds. The concept is original and generally the film is fun to watch.

title: A little disappointing
review:
Overall this movie wasn't too bad. My problem, was it too short. There was one comment I felt I partially agreed with and that was this was rushed. It was a little under 1 hour and 45 minutes long, when it probably should of been about 2 hours, but no longer the 2 hours and 15 minutes.

I'm not going to reveal what is the cause of the events in the movie, but be prepared for a disappointment. And then at the end of the movie I get the impression that this movie was a warning about global warming. I don't know if anyone else got that impression, but I did. I won't tell you not to waste your money, but I'm also not going to tell to you not to see it.

Dialouge-5/10, acting 6/10, plot, 10/10, directing, 8/10, overall 7/10.

title: The Hypening...
review:
Let me start by saying i was super excited to see this movie. NOT because of the extensive advertising, proudly proclaiming this to be "Shyamalans first R rated film," but because i hold this film maker in very high regards. From the 6th sense to the village, he wrote and directed 4 truly great films, establishing himself as the new master of suspense. The Hitchcock of our time. What made these films so effective was the way they worked on multiple levels - signs wasn't REALLY about aliens, but it was a way into a deeper story. He has a very natural ability to suck an audience in...

Then came lady in the water. Even though i knew next to nothing about the movie, i saw it in theaters. Unfortunately it turned out to be one of the WORST movies I've ever seen at the multiplex. However, i have been able to forgive M Night of this one self-indulgent flop. A Hollywood film for your little girls. Well, glad you got it out of your system...

SO, that brings us to the Happening, M Nights return to form it seemed. Well... yes and no. As with his earlier films, its not REALLY about what it seems. One big problem I had, which isn't necessarily Mr Shyamalans fault, is SO much was given up in the previews to the movie. The first half hour has little shock value due to what we've already seen on TV, and many more events later in the film are seen a mile away, again, because of our previous knowledge from the previews. Also, the supernatural element of the movie (which actually isn't too supernatural this time around) isn't shrouded in nearly as much secrecy as his previous works, which makes it harder to build suspense.

As with every one of Shyamalans efforts, you couldn't ask for a better or more appropriate cast. In a complete 360 from his roles in films like the Departed, Wahlberg plays a gentle, even goofy high school science teacher. Its nice to see a character in a horror situation keep his wits and not be reduced to over reacting (or over ACTing) or going mad. His wife is a interesting enough character, but isn't really given enough material to run with. All supporting actors fit their characters to a T, especially the scared military man and the weird plant guy.

The conclusion doesn't go for the knockout, as several of Shyamalans movies do, but thats OK. The story ends gracefully, and lingers for a bit, never really being wrapped up tightly. An appropriate ending given the nature of the story. Still, it will leave some audience members upset and feeling empty.

All in all, it was a satisfying experience, and the film makes good use of its R rating without using mindless gore. Still, i find myself waiting for M Night to return to top form...

title: I "Happened" to fall for another terrible M. Night Shymalan film
review: I just watched an early showing of this movie at my local theatre and paid $5 instead of going last night to the midnight showing and paying roughly double that and I couldn't be happier. I'm only happy about the fact that I saved myself $5. This movie was awful! I want to like this director, but he has lost it in my opinion. His past three movies have all been terrible! The village was stupid. Lady in the Water was weak. This one takes the cake, though. The only reason I gave this movie any rating at all was for two reasons. When the chick stabs herself in the throat, that was badass. Also, Mark Wahlberg was funny in the movie. It may as well have been a comedy. All they did was promote the gore and the fact that Shymalan had never went hard-core enough to get an R rating. It didn't matter. This movie was terrible. Once is a aberration. Twice is a coincidence. Three times is a pattern.

title: M Night Shyamalans downward spiral continues
review:
I think M Night Shyamalan has lost his Sixth Sense, I can see the Signs, its clearly Happening.

I think there must be a reason why you want to spook people, some message you want to get across. If suddenly people start killing themselves, and it spreads like an epidemic throughout the north-east of USA, then for sure it spooks you. Also people finding different innovative ways of killing themselves doesn't make for pleasant watching in the best of times / movies. And it drags  more people kill themselves, we get exposed to some of the classic American nut-cases, then more people kill themselves. And we still don't know why Mark Wahlberg, as a science school teacher, plays his part pretty convincingly. Somehow, recently, I've had an overdose of him, having seen him in 'The Invincible', and 'The Shooter' apart from 'The Italian Job' (the remake, one of my favourite movies). Maybe it's a sign ? He was good in this movie as well, trying to manage his wife and a kid while trying to figure out whats happening amidst the bewildering going-ons. It's a well made film, as far as the art of film-making goes. Some nice jokes, a lot of tension, some emotion etc. But you cant help but wonder what was the point of it all !? I loved Sixth Sense, didn't think much of Signs and successfully dodged his other movies (Village, Lady in the Water). I think the director is on a non-stop downward spiral. I was proud of myself for predicting the ending, for predicting the way he would end the film. Until my wife cattily remarked it could be because I've started thinking like him. After watching the Happening, that wasn't a compliment For more reviews, read apurvbollywood at blogspot Thx

title: Once again M. Night disappoints.
review:
This is only one man's opinion, but i can't see anyone enjoying this pile. Don't get me wrong, this movie isn't the worst he's made (lady in the water, the village) but it sure makes me wonder why he's still getting work. There are tons of flaws to be found in 'The Happening', even the name doesn't make sense (much like the rest of the film) or the R rating for that matter.

For the life of me, I have no idea why this movie had an R rating, every time someone kills themselves the viewer either got to see some feet and hear a gunshot or the picture cut away to others characters reactions. The one scene that could have given this movie an R rating was the one with the lions, but still it was probably the worst death scene in the movie and probably should have been cut out. they didn't even swear once throughout the entire movie which brings me to my next point.

The dialog is horrendous! I don't care who you are, where your from, what you think and like, nobody acts the way that the characters in the movie do. for example, the little girl in the movie cries once when she knows her parents died, yet about 5 minutes later she seems relatively fine, no bad thoughts in her brain. the amount of calm in the movie makes me wonder in Mr. M. Night has ever truly been scared in his life, because his screen writing suggest that he hasn't.

I could go on about this for pages, but my fingers would get tired, so to sum this up.... The acting is sub-par Marky Mark gives one of his worst performances, and even johnny Legs (one of my favorite actors) disappointed. The dialog is horrible. The cinematography is completely lack luster. There is not one scary part in this movie, not even a cheap thrill, in fact the spookiest part of the movie was the mirrors trailer before it. Also, if your into gore and are hoping to find a rated R gore fest, look somewhere else. And the final kicker, this entire film made Absolutely no sense, and had Absolutely no point for the most part. The idea the plants cause people to kill themselves is just plan stupid. If you really want to see, I cant stop you. but if you go, you should probably sneak in, I know i would be pretty angry if I had to pay to be bored for 2 hours.

title: Better than the Reviews
review:
Don't understand the hate this movie seems to generate - it isn't amazing, but it's unique and entertaining. I do find Zooey's character in this one pretty obnoxious - that was one thing I didn't like at all but otherwise wasn't put off by any of the characters.

People can't seem to get past the plot, that plants could kill everyone earth. OK it's a silly plot, but so Superman and any number of other equally entertaining movies. If you can suspend your disbelief and just roll with it, the movie is shot well, has a great cast, and continues to built a marvelous feeling of suspense and anticipation. I really enjoyed the way the movie was shot as well, the cinematography was quite good.

title: Yes, it's bad. Really bad.
review:
First of all, I have nothing against Shyamalan, so I'm not a "hater", whatever that is. I thought Sixth Sense was good and I enjoyed Signs, even though I didn't think it was particularly good.

This movie though.. Everything about it is pretty awful. The script, the acting, the plot. Awful. So bad in fact it made me wonder whether or not it was on purpose. I mean Wahlberg and Deschanel are competent actors normally, not awesome, but competent enough. Not here. Admittedly they have little to work with as the dialogue is horrendous, but even their facial expressions are just bad.

Best performance of the movie goes to the random construction-worker at the beginning.

It made me feel weird watching this movie as it's all so out of joint. Take the opening scene. A woman on a park-bench looks off into the distance and says "my god, are those people clawing at themselves?". Nobody is clawing at themselves in this movie... At all. Just weird.

Maybe OK for a lazy Sunday afternoon, high on pot. Otherwise, avoid at all costs.

title: Trees Have Feelings Too, You Know.
review:
I missed the first half hour of this, a production to which my TV Guide gave only one star out of four. That often make me anxious to see it.

By the time I tuned it, it was clear that this was one of those extended "Twilight Zone" episodes with some unseen force following a horde of refugees seeking safe zones somewhere in the Northeastern United States before they suddenly stand stock still, get all paranoid, begin repeating themselves like deranged robots, and finally commit suicide. (One guy lies down and gets himself run over by a mobile wood chopper or some similar device.) The force, whatever it is, seems connected to plant life and is carried by the wind.

It's a ridiculous movie. I've seen Mark Wahlberg in other films and thought he was fine, and at least in one case ("The Departed") outstanding. Here, as the central figure, he seems to go out of his way to prove that he can't act. The other performances are okay, and Zooey Deschanel is quite appealing.

I was surprised to find it was all written and directed by M. Night Shyamalan, who is a thoughtful and intelligent movie maker. Man, does he make mistakes in judgment here. Enormous close ups of faces are frequent, and a wide-angle lens turns the features into those of a porpoise. It's especially painful when Wahlberg is staring directly into the camera and shouting entreaties to an unseen listener.

Otherwise, the photography passes muster. The weeds, the trees, the flowers are all furiously green. It was shot largely in the suburbs of Philadelphia. One scene is supposed to take place in Princeton, New Jersey, an area I'm familiar with, but the placid and empty residential streets we see resemble Princeton as it was fifty years ago. Today it's a bustling industrial park full of glitz and commotion.

Anyway, as it develops, plants can communicate with each other and some can even secrete substances that repel others of their species. That's why, when you see a desert with creosote bushes, they're all so evenly spaced that they look as if they were planted. And, if attacked by parasite, some plants secrete a vapor that attracts predators that feed on the parasite. In Polynesia there is a plant called a mile-a-minute vine, and when you touch one of its miniature leaves, they all shrivel up as if afraid they'll be eaten. Oh, they're canny alright, smarter than we give them credit for.

Can I quote a stanza from Karl Shapiro's poem, "A Cut Flower"? Is it permitted? Because it's relevant to the film's message.

She tended me and held me by my stalk. Yesterday I was well, and then the gleam, The thing sharper than frost cut me in half. I fainted and was lifted high. I feel Waist-deep in rain. My face is dry and drawn. My beauty leaks into the glass like rain. When first I opened to the sun I thought My colors would be parched. Where are my bees? Must I die now? Is this a part of life?

The gleaming thing that's "sharper than frost" is a pair of scissors. It's the problem that underlies the film and provides it with a message. We're cutting down too many trees and other plants and they're responding defensively. But, don't think of this as unambiguous, or some kind of eco-leftist tract. It's not explained until the end, and then only in a TV interview hosted by a skeptic, and the argument is explained by a professor who looks and acts like a neural shambles. You wouldn't buy a potted African violet from this man, let alone a botanical and moral theory.

title: This must be a joke!!!!
review: Quite simply, this is the worst film I have ever watched (and I am not exaggerating). Writers must be really 'scraping the barrel' to come up with this drivel. When the film came to an end I stared at the screen in disbelief muttering 'that can't be it?' after which I burst into fits of laughter at the absurdity of it!! I won't spoil the film for others by giving away the ending (although that definitely doesn't mean I advise ANYONE to watch it), but it is ridiculous. A farce from beginning to end. I find it unbelievable that this film was made by the same hand as 'The Sixth Sense', a film I have thoroughly enjoyed numerous times. Where has it all gone wrong Shyamalan??

title: This is definitely in my top 10...
review:
Worst Films ever! I get this film I really do – I understand that this is Shyamalans' take on the 9/11 attacks but it is just a terrible film.

The time counter that appears every now and again is running along a timescale that is the same as the 9/11 attacks, the scenes have tried to be too clever in portraying this with bodies falling from buildings and mass paranoia & confusion along with an unknown enemy throughout.

The problem iswelleverything! Firstly I must just say that I have seen a lot of films in my time and I am a fan of B-movies and low budget horror films as much as the next guy so I know a bad film when I see one but bad films can be good if they know their limits.

'The Happening' could have been made with a budget a tenth the size of the $60million allocation that it received and it most likely would have been better. How on Earth they spent $60m on this picture I'll never know?! The Director said that it should be viewed as a B-Movie as that is what he intendedthen he should have used the budget of a B-Movie and made it exactly what it isbut he has failed.

The acting is terrible from the likes of Mark Wahlberg & John Leguizamo that is not really to be expected & even the delectable Zooey Deschanel turns in her worst performance to date. There is no real emotion or feeling put forward from any of the actors in the film and you need to have some strong emotions dealing with potentially the end of the Human race surely.

Okay so plants killing people is not the most logical or best of ideas but it has been done well before – see 'The Ruins' & 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers', original or even remakes. Even 'The Invasion' was better than this failure and that is saying something.

Shyamalan tries to scare us with the threat of the plants byyep you guessed itshowing the wind breezing through the canopy of trees and the blades of grass on the ground. If he was trying to make a parable about the way we disrespect our planet then there are a million better ways to do it. This just doesn't work in any way whatsoever.

The special effects or complete lack of them for a $60m dollar movie are terrible. A highlight of bad effects is when the car crashes into the tree in fast motion and people fly out of the front windowcringe worthy.

I had read the reviews of this film previous to watching it and it seemed like it could be okay so I gave it a chance with an open unbiased mind and to be honest I almost turned it off halfway through.

It would have been a much better film if the old lady at the end were the cause of The Event but that risk is never taken sadly. One of the worst films ever made. 1/10

title: This is a good movie, don't listen to the haters
review:
That M. Night Shyamalan is perhaps the most hated and slammed film-maker of the present day is a fact beyond any debate. I have to admit that I was very disappointed at the movies he made after "The sixth sense", and that I didn't like any of them. However, I can't understand why so many critics and anonymous viewers of all kinds seem to have this negative prejudice against him. Perhaps it's because he doesn't send out an especially likable vibe, and because his former work sometimes came across as too pretentious. It's true that with every one of his movies, he always tries to deliver some deeper message and that he constructs his movies as parables, with the focus usually set on some universal situation or crisis rather than on the more particular conflicts that most dramas, thrillers or mysteries have us accustomed to. I can't say I think he's been very successful at delivering these messages in a viewer-friendly, non-pretentious way, but I respect the fact that he has never given up on his personal view of movie-making, and that he stays true to himself, much critic and -in my opinion, unjustified and too harsh- bashing this might have fostered. Having said this, like I stated at the beginning, I think his career has been objectively quite erratic.

Well, having said that, I think that "The happening" is, simply put, a good and entertaining movie. I have to admit I didn't expect to like it as much as I did, precisely because I regrettably chose to listen to all the many holier-than-thou critics who state their opinions as scientific fact, and also, dare I say it, to my own prejudice. I was proved wrong, and I am happy to say that I'm now looking forward to watching Shyamalan's next movies.

The movie is not perfect by any means, but it is thoroughly enjoyable, and it's based on a basic idea and a script that are just as smart as anything reasonably smart that you get to see on the big screen any of these days. The acting is also good. I honestly believe that, had this movie been made by any other household name or "promising" new director, it wouldn't have been slammed as relentlessly and sometimes scornfully as it did. This movie isn't at all the disaster that it has been described as by many critics. You might like it or not, but I would recommend watching it if you like dramas with a supernatural element, decent character development, and thrillers.

Another thing that I enjoyed about "The happening" is the modesty and, might I add, the lack of self-consciousness from which it was made. Especially at some sequences (and you will know which ones they are), you can tell that Shyamalan was probably not taking himself all that seriously, and that he was perhaps even making fun of the reputation that he's earned throughout most of his career, as a very intellectual, serious, and sometimes cold movie-maker. The movie has some tongue-in-cheek bits that I appreciated very much.

title: Saw it on video ... Was worth it.
review:
For those who went to the theater - sorry if it didn't work out; for the audience that will see this movie on TV through DVD and/or pay movie channels where it's not as big a deal - it's definitely a cut above generic/junk sci-fi.

Plus... it's well acted, intense at times and serious throughout. Whether you do or don't like where it's going, you'll feel compelled to watch to the end.

If you haven't seen the trailer, the movie is essentially about a mysterious occurrence that "happens" in the northeast section of the US: masses of people are going into a dazed stupor ... and then killing themselves.

Since it's a typical M. Night movie, the above story is what's going on in the background. In the foreground, the story is about a couple struggling through marital problems. Mark Wahlberg and Zoey Deschanel do a great job of portraying the husband and wife characters who have very different personalities.

Again, if you watch the film on TV, I don't see how you can really go wrong. The demands are much lower than if you were at a theater. It's got decent acting, drama, and medium-fare sci-fi.

title: The most skilled and most pointless film I have seen this year.
review:
The day I began to watch the movie, I was in the most brilliant of moods. I had a cup o' hot chocolate my right hand, a cigarette in my left and a mind at complete peace and harmony with the world around me.

As this disaster epic neared the hour mark however, I began feeling distraught. Why? Because it's a thin story, plain and simple.

A plague of initially unknown origins (duh!) starts killing off eastern America, manipulating people in to murdering themselves in the fastest and often most brutal manner possible. An interesting premise, you say? I would tend to agree. But with a running time of 90 minutes, it is hard to find it interesting at all after a certain point, because you know it will go no further.

The characters are dry, and somewhat lifeless (excluding Whalberg and Leguizamo). Their reactions to their impending doom are somewhat too subdued at times, which is how most of us would most likely react. That's right, Shyamalan goes too far. In pursuit of realism he sacrifices suspense, a mistake he made in The Village.

Needless to say, it is visually and musically perfected, but that has never been Shyamalans Achilles heel. His weakness lies in convincing his audience to give a damn about the fate of his characters, who he more often then not, treats as puppets caught in the storm of his creativity.

We feel the power of the storm sure, but do we really want to go through it, without any characters to cheer for? Think about it.

title: A good movie if you can suspend disbelief
review:
Like everyone else, I thought "Sixth Sense" was brilliant - the twist at the end made this a magnum opus. With such a debut, the level of expectation for Shyamalan has been set very high. I've been disappointed with most of his films since, but I did like the atmosphere he created with "The Village".

Now to "The Happening": The beginning of this movie conveys a completely gripping and horrifying crisis. It has a sense of immediacy, and grabs your throat: what's going on? When you finally get the reason, it seems very far-fetched. If you can suspend disbelief for that part, I think you'll enjoy the rest of the movie, as I did.

title: Ain't no plot Happening here.
review:
Well, this sucks. M. Night Shyamalan is not a director I've been very familiar with over the years, having only seen his much-lauded and much-overrated The Sixth Sense, but he seems absurdly pretentious and smug. And all I have to say to that is, if this fecal matter is the best he can do these days, then he had better start learning some god damned humility.

The Happening is another one of those fashionable natural disaster movie, only about ten times worse than you'd usually expect. This movie boasts deplorable writing, awful acting, plastic characters that try and fail to get you to care about them, and THE LAMEST DISEASE EVER. I won't spoil it for those of you who have not seen it yet, but this disease and the "plot" constructed around it are absolutely laughable. It seems to be TRYING to build up, but it doesn't work, and mostly this just comes off as a bunch of suspenseful (haha) scenes strung together on a clothesline with no punch line or climax or anything of the sort. Oh, and why do all the characters in this movie have to say "happening" so much? Annoying as Hell. This is basically a shitty 80s B movie with a modern sheen, and that is more horrifying than anything Shyamalan could conjure up in his writing.

Oh, and have I mentioned how delightfully retarded this is? I mean, we have people talking to plants, the main character and his fiancée arguing about their petty problems in the middle of a train station where everyone is trying to escape the virus, and worst of all, the frighteningly dumb jab at the Americans with all of the references to "terrorists." Nice one, Shyamalan. All Americans are like that, indeed. F*ck you all the way to the bank.

So basically, all the viewer can really do, deprived of any visible plot or hook to grab onto, is sit in awe of the puerile dialogue and attempts at characterization, which are so bad they're funny, and I actually found myself laughing at this more than real comedies like Death to Smoochy and Tropic Thunder, which leaves something to be said for those, as well. I'll chuck a few points onto the rating here, as it did make me laugh a few times, but really, The Happening is an awful movie and I would not recommend it.

title: An apocalyptic classic
review:
I'm really not a big Shyamalan fan. But I've always respected his Kubrick-like pursuit to make his own style of movie rather than adopt the usual Hollywood formula.

I thought 'the 6th Sense' was interesting but I've never understood the hoopla surrounding it. I did find the Village to be an interesting film. But I thought Signs and the Lady in the Water were absolutely boring.

But 'the Happening' is easily his best film, IMO. In fact, I think its a classic and far superior to unrealistic and silly apocalyptic films such as Will Smith's "I am Legend" and Spielberg's 'War of the Worlds'.

The mystery of a mass suicidal apocalypse infesting the northeast cost of the US was very creepy and very realistic. The characters were sympathetic and often tragic-- especially the little girl's situation. And you actually felt for their safety rather than rooting for their demise.

And Shyamalan's usual ironic twist at the end had a great sense of poetic justice.

So I'd place this amongst the great apocalyptic films like:

Night of the Living Dead, The Stand, The Omega Man, Dawn of the Dead (both versions), Testament, Panic in the Year Zero, Invasion of the Body Snatchers (the original), 28 Days Later, The Day of the Triffids (BBC mini-series), The Mist,

title: Not So Bad
review:
Well let me start by saying I understand why so many didn't like this movie and I can't really argue their points. But for my viewing I must say I was intrigued the entire time and especially during the old woman's house scenes I was really on edge.
