Considering the genre I can't really ask for more than that out of the movie. It was certainly a strange idea but I can't down-rate for originality. My only real two complaints are that one, in the explanation, I don't really get that a gas that breaks down our naturally defense to not hurting ourselves would automatically cause us to hurt ourselves, also I have come to expect more from an M.N.S. ending. It could have used some fireworks to wrap things up. All that said I really can't recommend this movie to anyone because I see the strong potential for them to be disappointed. I guess as always it's up to each viewer to decide but it kept my interest.

Logan Lamech

www.eloquentbooks.com/LingeringPoets.html

title: parable on love
review:
Director Shyamalan is the most Christian of all popular directors working in Hollywod, and the most thoughtfully Christian in Hollywod's history. Even though I'm not a Christian, I respect his thoughtfulness and faith.

This not a horror film but a kind of post-modern "Pilgrim's Progress" parable. The difficult question of the film is not "what is happening?" but rather, why are the lead characters innocent enough to survive it? And the answer is rather odd and rather bold. Although recently married, they are still in the process of 'falling in love.' That's important because in a truly Christian universe, love is a practice, not a feeling. "Feeling" love or "being in love" does not redeem, only the active process of it.

Is Shyamalan successful in portraying this? No; and the effort to do so actually requires considerable maturity, more than Shyamalan has right now. By the time John Ford was able it pull it off in "the Quiet man," he had some 25 years film-making experience, and had lived an adventurous life.

But I am willing to give Shyamalan points for effort here. Constructing a parable of this sort in this time and place took considerable nerve. Hopefully the commercial failure of this film will not deter him from continuing to take such risks. Thoughtful films are hard to come by these days.

So it's an admittedly weak film - parables lend themselves to beautiful visuals, but not to great acting, and the best dialog is on the theme and not the plot. But its reputation will grow in time, as Shyamalan's reputation grows and his handling of such themes matures.

Oh, a last word - on the violence depicted in the film. It actually has to be taken with a tablespoon of salt. Much of it involves a student filmmaker's conceit, indicating Shyamalan is still concerned with learning his craft. But, to put it bluntly, much of the violent acts are insiders' jokes - 'it's raining construction workers,' get it? and the guy feeding his arm to the lions is a nod back to - Monty Python. Further indication that we are dealing with a parable on a theme rather than a well-constructed plot.

Hopefully in the future, Shyamalan will learn, as John Ford learned, how to marry the two.

title: Mediocre Film that needed a better ending.
review:
"The Happening" seemed to start off with an interesting and mysterious plot, but falls flat from act 1. Two things bothers me, the first is the $60 million budget, because there have been much better films made for less than $20 million, and second is an underlying theme that unexplained events, such as the bees dying off, are caused by "nature" as an acceptable answer.

In my opinion, the audience needs to have more questions answered in order to buy into the story. In "The Happening" the plot failed to ever provide an explanation for what was really happening. We were told that "nature" could be fighting back by plants giving off some new toxin, but how could plants control the wind? Which plants were producing the toxin and why did it spread? Why did the toxins start one day and stop the next? There were some guesses that the toxins sensed a group of people and attacked based on some size group, but then that idea was contradicted by the old woman getting poisoned while alone.

Without any established limits, it is hard to buy into the idea of "nature" attacking at random, and requiring the wind to blow up at the same time. Is this a paid propaganda project to plant the idea that the problems with use of genetically modified plant seeds, and spraying aluminum compounds into the air is an unexplainable act of "nature", I don't know? Could it be? Yes, it certainly lacks other value.

In the extra materials on the DVD, the director states that he needed a home run at the end, and unfortunately, it was a bunt. The ending added more questions, instead of wrapping things up.

It wasn't the worst movie I have seen, but not up to what I expected either, and basically middle of the road by today's standards. "Tremors" proves you can do a lot more with a much smaller budget, but see "Cloverfield" if you gave this movie a "1".

title: Waste of Time & $! - I Want My $1 Back From RedBox!!
review: Once again, much like The Village, I thought this movie was quite horrible and a waste of time. The way things fit together was OK as was the acting but the movie's intensity wasn't much at all like the preview trailer exaggerated it to be. There were maybe 2 or 3 parts where the suspense had built up to make you think "ooh!" but the sad part is that these scarce moments were TOWARDS THE END of the movie (around the last 20 minutes or so). The ending of the movie leaned towards having a part 2 but the rest of the movie was quite bland - like bean soup made with plain water. I think I was more glad once the movie had ended although it was a so-so movie. The acting was OK but not very believable and I'll be returning this crappy film to the metal RedBox machine today (THANKFULLY!). Definitely NOT going to see this one again!

title: Good premise, but low production values
review:
The premise is good for a "seemingly unexplained phenomenon" type of horror movie. The images of people stopping in motion or hanging or killing themselves are riveting, but you kind of expect to see it there.

The two main problems I found with this movie is the acting by supporting cast and production values. There are no high-quality gimmicks that could have been attempted with plants trees. Instead, we see grass and trees stirred by blower fans. As for acting, the supporting cast speak their dialogue like that of a school play. Only Wahlberg and the two boys make it bearable.

title: What's "Happening"???
review: What is it with M. Night?? His movies keep getting worse!! This movie has to be one of his biggest disappointments to date. It sure was not scary, there wasn't much of a thriller element when you find out what supposedly is going on, and who knows why it got an R rating. Sixth Sense was awesome, Signs was OK, The Village was barely passable, but The Happening was awful. The "plot" the acting was not even anything to write home about and it had some decent named actors. I hope he turns things around with future projects, but he needs to stop doing weird pointless movies!! Just my personal opinion. One of the problems I saw with this film was things were never properly explained at any point in the movie and nothing is more irritating to watch a movie for 90 minutes or more to only be scratching your head at the end because it just made no sense and didn't frighten, shock, scare or any other emotion that a thriller is supposed to do. Sixth Sense did ALL of that! I hope he gets his touch back for doing movies like that again!! I only give this movie 1 out of 10 and it is not one I would recommend to others.

title: M Night Shame-on-you!!
review:
Most of the reviews here have already covered this pile-o'-crap fairly well, so I'll try not to repeat any previous comments, but it's so hard when you're talking about this lame effort from the wunderkind of Hollywood.

One thing that I haven't seen mentioned is the lion-mauling scene. I was unaware that an animal can pull off a man's arm with only a slight tug, AND that man can continue to stand so that another lazy lion can coax the other one off! WTF? The plot holes are big enough to drive Jupiter through and yes, the acting was bad! Marky Marks wife, played absently by Zooey Deschanel, just comes off like someone that just drank a pitcher of Nyquil, and I was reminded of Karen Allen's demented portrayal of Indiana Jones's long lost love, smiling and laughing maniacally at the most dangerous times! There was no real suspense in this movie and the idea of people outrunning the wind is way beyond preposterous. And, as some others have pointed out, the wind would essentially dilute anything airborne and make it LESS potent!!

Mark Wahlberg constantly looked confused, but not by the events surrounding him, but by the script. (How do I act like any of this is believable? He seemed to emote)

Also, Is it believable that being inside a house will stop airborne particles small enough to not be seen by the naked eye?

I liked the first ten minutes or so and had high hopes that the film would take some of those frightening elements and take it a step further, but instead, what we got was one community-theater feeling scene after another and the characters were strangely dispassionate about the whole thing.

All in all, one boring movie. It's pretty hard to defend a film that starts out strong and gets increasingly ridiculous and confusing as it goes along. Don't waste your time, money or brain cells on this half-hearted attempt!!

title: Very Interesting Movie
review: I think this was a very "intelligent" move. It takes a smart person to enjoy this kind of movie. It doesn't come right out and tell you what is going on, you need to figure it out yourself. There was lots of foreshadowing, and hinting around in the movie. It had a very deep concept, "the earth's rinse cycle". When the planet feels threatened, it restores balance. The planet will not sit back and watch us pollute its air and chop down its forests, it will fight back. The characters might have been a little stupid, but the concept of the whole thing was very entertaining. The epidemic started in the northeast, where the industrial revolution started, and started impacting the environment. The ecology had suffered the longest there. Next was Europe. Soon after will be the middle United States. The epidemic would blossom outward, following the path of humanity's conquest of the planet. The safest people on the planet would be the ones in third would nations that have yet to be industrialized, and are still at balance with nature.

title: avoid this film like the plague!!!!....
review:
Dear All reading this - i can now reveal the big spoiler......

The actual reason all the people in this movie felt compelled to commit violent suicide is that they had recently endured a screening of this film!!!!!

Never before have I sat through a movie that actually left me feeling violently angry towards the director for completely wasting my time - and believe me i have seen my fair share of poor movies.

And before you start let me tell you i am a huge Shyamalan fan.

There is not a single redeeming feature in the entire movie, not one. The script is poor beyond words, there is no chemistry between any of the actors, after witnessing awful sights they stand around unaffected and take it in turns to talk!!! its unbelievable how this absolute garbage makes it through all the hours of editing and cutting and pre-screenings etc. and manages to filter down to the poor people that have to watch this! I mean my outrage of how shockingly bad this film is happens to be more emphatic than any reaction of any character in the entire film.

Mark Wahlberg should be ashamed to put his name to this project.

Rant is now over, this is my first review and normally would not be here at half past midnight posting but i feel i owe humanity to be the messenger - take this as a warning.

Peace & Love, Dan

title: Its a cool to watch
review: Well i think the movie is quite good.Manoj has done good work here and was sure he would deliver another breath-taking blockbuster.It is enjoyable and fits nicely...its really happening its really worthy.The dialogue is smart, the camera work is perfect and the information and background setting are divulged to the audience at precisely the right pace and exactly the right moment.The film sees some sort of mysterious ecological event leading to people committing mass suicide, the phenomenon spreading first from large cities then to smaller towns until it is clear a huge chunk of the East Coast is affected. At first, it is assumed to be a terrorist attack but, as more and more people are spontaneously kill themselves, it is clear the cause may be something else entirely...a pretty good film & worth seeing for fans of the genre. 7 out of 10.

title: Jason Vorbreeze
review: The villain in this movie is the wind. The wind chases people. People run away from the wind. As if the wind were a person. This movie is horrendous. M. Night has completely lost touch of reality. His political beliefs are now shaping his once-great writing skills and what we have here is pretentious bile. The acting is dead-pan, as usual in his movies, but the dialog is laughable. This is an example - like Tarantino's "Death Proof" - of a writer/director imitating himself, and the result seeming like self parody. This really does seem more like if Mel Brooks was lampooning M. Night. The best parts of the film are towards the end with a crazy old lady, played by Betty Buckley (basically mimicking Piper Laurie's character in "Carrie", in which Buckley co-starred). If the entire movie centered on the heroes trying to escape her clutches, this would be a fine film. And that's exactly it. M. Night needs to make a haunted house movie, or a slasher flick, or... something simple. He needs to simplify. He's gone wacky. He's getting a bit too original for his own good, and "The Village" and "Lady in the Water" have almost sunk him. But this mess leaves him - and the audience - all wet in the end.

title: In the top ten worst major movies of all time!
review:
First let me say that I watched this movie for three reasons.

1) I like science fiction. 2) Mark Wahlberg , a good actor 3) M. Night. Shymalan the 6th Sense, very good.

That said. The Happening.....wasn't and didn't.

Absolutely Horrible. Awful writing. Terrible directing. And pitiful acting. Wahlberg was disappointing at best! The story line was all over the map, unconnected, leading to a lot of dead ends. Apparently the only plausible thing in the movie is the scientific basis on which the plot is based.

If as he said M. Night had a vision for this movie, he needs to smoke a higher quality weed. Hollywood may have to say goodnight to M. Night.

And Mark. PLEASE! This was as unwatchable as your Planet of the Apes remake. fire your agent.

title: I Dare You To Watch It
review:
A laughable "horror" picture in which plants suddenly decide to give off a gas that makes humans commit suicide. Funniest parts:

  • Cop making small-talk with fleeing motorist before blowing his brains out. ("It's chilly today...")


  • Zooey Deschanel gainfully struggling to keep the Weakest Subplot In Cinematic History breathing- she had desert with another man!!!


  • Marky Mark keepin' it real as a science teacher in Philly, bustin' a move with the chizzle and later losing an argument to a potted plant.


  • Aggressively-hungry teen on porch blown to pieces by a shotgun blast.


  • Agitated autistic-savant "genius" on TV who sums up the movie: "It was an act of nature... that we'll never fully understand!!!"


And there's so much more: the goofy guy who gets mauled by the lions at the zoo, the wooden acting of everyone in the picture, the girl who kills herself at college via cellphone, and John Leguizamo sitting down in the middle of the street to slice his wrists open and bleed to death.

There must have been some of that phantom death-gas loose in my theater because I wanted to do the same thing.

GRADE: D-

title: What happened M Knight?
review: When I saw the previews I was excited about seeing this movie but didn't expect too much judging from the last couple of flops M Knight put out. This movie was beyond disappointing. The actors in my opinion did the best they could with the horrible script given. If I were to pay to see this in the movie theater I would have asked for a refund. If you are a die hared M Knight fan I can understand renting this movie, but if you ask me, I say wait until it hits HBO. M Knight if you are reading this, for the love of all that is holy, please put more thought into your next project. The script was lacking in story and emotion and I think my 5 year old could have figured out what was coming next. This movie buff will never pay money to see another M Knight movie again. I wish I would have been warned about this so hopefully I have helped the next person before they waste their time and money.

title: Maybe the worst attempt at horror ever?
review:
God where do I start? I had heard some good reviews of this but after starting to watch it I was amazed by how bad the acting is just within the first few minutes but it got worse and worse. M. Knight's direction is almost like film school, he had one good movie and has been living off that for years. How he keeps getting money for projects is beyond me.

What bothers me most is his lack of attention to any detail or simple facts. The math teacher says his Mother lives in Philadelphia but they get on a train to Harrisburg PA. which is 2 hrs West of Philly. Even if its assumed they can not get a train to Philly and must go out of their way, why would the train stop in Filbert which is 4 hrs West of and PAST Harrisburg? Then the math teacher seems to get a quick ride to Princeton, NJ but that is a 6 hr drive from Filbert on a good day not to mention the traffic you would have in a disaster. Did he even look at a map?

Notice how incredibly calm everyone is in NYC with an airborne terrorist suicide plague spreading throughout the city, it would be sheer pandemonium. How do you stay ahead of the wind, as if it where a thing you could see and know which direction it's going? Most of this film is so funny that I laughed my ass off. When the girl kills herself on the cell phone, or the private yells about his gun? Pure comic genius. The worst has to be the group all viewing the lions rip off the guys arms in what looks like high def video like they were watching an episode of Jerry Springer. He seems to be trying to scare us but it is so over the top and ham handed it becomes parody. Why is an entire family sitting in a bathtub in Fla. 1500 mils from the problem? M.Kight must always try to get at least one crazy person in his movies that the normal people encounter, why is this woman at the end so insane, is this supposed to scare us?

Man this is one dumb movie.

title: Shyamalan does it again...blows it that is!
review:
I continue to have a morbid curiosity when it comes to Shyamalan films. I find it hard to fathom how a filmmaker that could make such an incredible film like "The Sixth Sense" came proceed to make five terrible films in a row after wards. I didn't think it would be possible to make a more disappointing, pathetic film than "The Village", but he manages to 'surpass' what I thought was already insurmountable incompetence.

There are so many terrible moments in the film, I don't even know where to begin. Walberg talking to the plant, the man feeding his arms to the lion, the 'crazy' lady who lives alone, the shameful failed attempt at melodrama while our two lovers talk to one another through the pipe... These are just some of the really bad moments of the film...the bad ones fill the rest of the time.

WHAT WAS HE THINKING? Who makes a film where you can never see that antagonist? The problem seems to be that, miraculously, Shyamalan's head is still big from his one hit a decade ago. The feedback he gets from the professionals has been tepid at best, yet he chooses not to listen. When the studio questioned the weakness of "Lady in the Water", instead of taking the advice to heart, he proceeded to make a lousy script his way...into a lousy movie. How many failures does it take before you admit you should be listening to others that are better at something than you?

title: Preachy "thriller" fails to thrill
review:
I will admit that I have enjoyed a couple of M. Night Shyamalan films... The Sixth Sense was fantastic - then it all pretty much went downhill from there. Unbreakable... ridiculous; Signs... tolerable, but still not great; The Village... SEVERE disappointment; Lady In The Water... Seriously? Come ON! But compared to The Happening, Lady In The Water should have been an Oscar contender.

Not only were the performances completely lackluster (Mark Wahlberg... whiney... Zooey Deschanel... irritating), but the story line was absolutely absurd & COMPLETELY preachy! Let me get this straight... the TREES are communicating with other vegetation & in order to protect themselves against the beast that is man they start releasing neurotoxins that rids humanity of the will to live??? Wow. The kicker is near the end, after "the event" has ended; some professor is seen on television telling society that: "this is just a warning" & some business about how we're destroying our planet & now Mother Nature won't stand for it anymore. Again - wow. That's not preaching at all - I swear! All this combined with somewhat shocking images of MANY people killing themselves in grotesque fashions (In one scene a man turns on an industrial sized lawn mower, puts it into gear & lays down in front of it.) makes for one HORRID film.

Had I been unfortunate enough to pay to see The Happening in theatres, I would have asked for my money back on the premise that it was 91-minutes of my life I'll never have back again.

title: Better movie than critics and IMDb rating suggest.
review:
This is the first time I have written my thoughts on a movie but felt I needed to give my opinion. I use IMDb ratings and several critics reviews to determine whether or not to waste my money on a theater trip, wait to rent it, or just forget it altogether. I've found that ratings of 6.0 or more seem to be watchable and 90% of movies that fall below that rating are usually a waste of time.

The Happening was, for me, a watchable film and one I will buy on DVD. The pacing was just right as it gave a sense of foreboding and what's gonna happen next. The acting by Mark Wahlberg was decent and a scene with him talking to a plant wasn't ridiculous as more it was a little humor to lighten the mood if only for an instant. I think all the actors did a good job with a good script. There was plenty of startling and eerie images, especially of the old woman walking on the porch. The ending was creepy and left for the viewers imagination.

Overall, I feel this was a good movie and at the very least, a worthwhile rental.

title: Better than Lady in the Water, but gives away twist too early...
review:
M. Night is being lambasted about this film; I won't say this film doesn't have a ton of flaws (believe me, it does), but it's clear to me that he is on a tract to duplicate the successes of Alfred Hitchcock. It is obvious Hitchcock is a huge influence... nay, a source... for much of M. Night's experimental film-making.

Unfortunately, he's turning off a lot of people with this style of film-making.

Let's just get it out of the way now - the idea is unique but the screen writing is atrocious. This film needed a healthy dose of panic. If the film-makers had injected 1/10th of the panic-stricken dialog from the movie 'Cloverfield', this film could easily have been a frightening thriller.

Instead it just plods along delivering cheesy overly-dramatic lines that are seriously out-of-context.

The actors aren't panicked when they should naturally be, and often times it appears they are just standing around waiting for their fate rather than running off in the other direction, away from the terror that is coming after them.

I can see where M. Night was going with this, but I honestly think the studio should have called for a re-write. M. Night is great, but clearly he needed help on the dialog and character actions of this film.

Now let me get to the worst part - M. Night gave away the 'twist' almost 25% into the movie! From any other director I don't mind, but I've come to expect a 'surprise' from M. Night - kind of like, waiting for the jack-in-the-box to spring open, even though you know it's coming. Unfortunately the 'twist' was cited early on, which left me thinking 'ok, now what?' until the credits rolled.

I give M. Night a 5 out of 10, because it seemed like he genuinely tried to do something magical here, but just missed the mark. Next time, Mr. Shamalan, PLEASE accept the help of some gifted WGA member, even if you throw out most of their rewrites.

title: It's not gonna happen
review:
I had my fair share of "trouble" with a Night movie! Happening is not one of them. And it's not because I'm trying to buck the trend (the overall voting here is speaking for itself), but because I really liked the understatement and the underplaying of the movie. It's not about panic, it's about a message, that Night tries to send through. Well the message is very clear and still some won't like what they'll see and won't like the bluntness with which the movie delivers this message!

I liked the acting and I liked the point Night was/is making with this movie. It's a slow building chilling experience (if you let yourself into it), which does not rely on any "twist" ending or anything like that (didn't work for "Village" imo). If you watch the movie, with other expectation than that, you will be disappointed (as many have been).

title: CR*P !!!!!! Nothing More..........
review:
First I have to say that this is the worst movie I've ever seen in my whole life.

Bad Screenplay delivered with bad acting. And the female actress. I don't even know why her character was included in the movie. She looks the same through out the movie (even when people die),she keeps getting calls from a guy when all the phone lines are down but she avoids it so that our HERO guy doesn't suspect. Thats all she does. I read the comments here on IMDb before watching the movie and at least 90% of them said it was bad. So I wasn't having any expectations. But I was STILL Disappointed with the acting. And Guess What? Almost everybody these people(Guy, Girl and the Guy's friends Daughter)knew are DEAD because of the wind but the wind felt sorry for them and spared their life. DING DING DING what rubbish??? This movie is terrible, horrible, bad, and every other word in the dictionary with the same meaning. If you have money and want to waste 109 minutes of your life Please watch this movie.

title: One of the worst movies i've seen in a long time
review:
This film had an interesting plot, humans abuse planet too much, planet fights back by releasing toxins that effect the human nervous system through plants and trees that is carried by the wind, humans inhale toxins begin acting strangely and commit suicide. interesting enough to me plus M. Night Shyamalan and Mark Wahlberg alright so how does it turn out..... Awful.Truth be told there is not one redeeming quality about watching this film. I was literally not entertained once during the 98 min. run time NOT ONCE!!! This was trying to be a serious film, trying to tell us how important it is to save the environment and how we are abusing the planet. I agree that we need to work towards a way to stop polluting the planet to prevent the threat of global warming. But this film has the dumbest characters (weird guy obsessed with hot dogs) oh there's a good idea Shyamalan. Most horrible writing ( Mark and his wife try to run away from wind carrying the toxin ... and get away). The Most terrible acting i've ever seen from Mr. Wahlberg, John Leguizamo and Zooey Deschanel. Just please people don't waste your money on this crap. 1 out of 10 stars

John Leguizamo

title: M. Night, Where did you go wrong?
review:
The Happening centers around.........oh crap I already forgot the characters names. That is how forgettable this movie is. I expected better from M. Night Shamalan (did I spell that right?) who directed The Sixth Sense, Signs, and Unbreakable. One of the main problems with this movie is almost all of the apocalypse movie clichés are followed, which makes for a very boring movie experience, and to make it worse, the movie contained almost to memorable scenes. All of the action in the movie consists of shots of trees and plants an then people killing themselves, and there weren't even any inventive or gory death scenes at all.

Overall this movie is clichéd and slightly boring. I'm not saying it is horrible though, there are many, many worse movies out there. I just would not recommend wasting time and money to see it unless you are extremely bored or happen to catch it on TV.

title: One of the WORST!
review: Let me be the one to conclude this movie with just one simple phrase - THE WORST MOVIE OF THE YEAR! And I mean it - i've watched a lot of garbage this year - I repeat A LOT - but this thing-of-a-movie is by far the most idiotic film ever created from a human being. I even wonder how was it even produced and released to the cinemas so the innocent viewers must PAY MONEY to watch this crap. The bad things in this movie are so many that they're the only thing that's really SCARY and SHOCKING in it. Let's just talk about the little thing the artists liked to call "acting". The "so called" acting in this film is so pathetic that makes the characters look like total morons. Mark Whalberg and Zoey Dechanel are so one-dimensional and dull as the lead actors that after 20 minutes you just didn't care any more about they're characters and whether they'll live or die. It's quite disturbing actually to see well known actors in a mainstream movie of a famous director to act like dumb children in a school play. And what about the story. There is nothing here - NOTHING. No suspense, no horror, no thrills, even no real climax and explanation. Not to mention that the trademark of all M. Night's movies - THE TWIST - is also missing in this one. Not to mention that the event that is HAPPENING in the movie is basically so absurd that's even hilarious. Also - it reminds a lot of a story, written by Steven King, only "The Happening" is much worst. I can't even believe that I've sit trough the whole movie, without killing myself. There is NOTHING that drives the storyline - no real emotions, no real relationships, just plain and artificial reactions between the characters and god-awful stupid dialogs. It's like watching a serious movie which eventually feels like parody and you end up laughing at the whole thing. Absurd and hilarious are quite well said descriptions to the entire script. Further more - the well known cinematography and visual style of the old Shyamalan's films which we all anticipated are just gone. The directing is bad or mediocre at best. There are only a couple of scenes that even reminds us of Shyamalan. I know that the writing AND producing AND directing a movie is a tough job but one director's ego should not be a reason for promising projects to be presented like some Uwe Boll movies. Was that laziness or lack of creativity - you tell me. The only thing good in this movie is the music. It's effective and it really flows with the scenes. James Newton Howard gives us the only thing with which this movie is even watchable - his music score and it's great. But yet again even the good music is degraded by everything else. After all the high hopes, M. Night embarrassed himself utterly with this flick. It should have been a great and chilling thriller but instead it's something I really don't want to talk about any more. The director said that he made it to be a B-movie. Well, I think the B-Movies ARE the future for him, so good luck with THAT.

title: Mr.s Shyamalan should be on retirement...
review:
This movie sucks a lot! Whole idea is OK, but script and plot suffers from idiotic dialogs and poor acting. For example - Wahlberg and Deschanel run through the field and then Mark starts dialog about how he bought a syrup in shop! Geeeez, who wrote that? Also actors (and Zooey) makes some stupid faces all the time wrinkling forehead and gets eyes out of the moon.

Also there are some scenes without sense like nature affecting on one person (but Wahlberg certified that nature attacks groups) and D-movie like ending.

Shyamalan should go on retirement because after Unbreakable (which was solid) gave us some cliché, underperformed dramas...

title: Painful to watch
review:
I have been a huge fan of all of M. Night Shyamalan's movies. So I went into this realizing it would probably not be the typical Hollywood blockbuster, but is so much worse than that.

There is no character development. No plot development. The dialogue is terribly forced and seems very much out of place.

I am sure that fans of this movie will argue that those who don't line just don't understand what Shyamalan was trying to achieve. They will say he was kicking against the Hollywood status quo. Making the viewer have to think and work a little bit (Much like he he did in "Lady in the Water"). I don't mind some work, but the real work was forcing myself not to run screaming out of the theatre.

This movie was quite similar to a Twilight Zone episode. The problem is that instead ob being 20-25 minutes long it was stretched into an excruciating 80 minutes.

Shamylan has encouraged viewers to go into the theatre expecting a fun "B" movie. The Happening definitely had similarities to to a "B" movie, such as: Bad acting, unnecessary dialogue, no real plot, completely anti-climactic and really not making one lick of sense. But Shamylan also seemed to try to hard to make the movie "fun." He threw in smatterings of non-nonsensical/weird dialogue in an attempt to be funny, but it really just made me angry.

Once again, I have enjoyed all of M. Night Shyamalan's previous films, and believe he is a brilliant filmmaker. But The Happening, to put it bluntly, is a worthless piece of crap.

title: Yes, it is terrible
review:
I have a personal rule that i never watch movies that score less than 6 on IMDb. However, I really enjoyed Sixth Sense and the Village and so on reading the reviews - some good, most bad - i decided to believe the 'you must have missed the point' reviews, mainly because i know people who didn't like the village. I was sorely mistake, this movie is a complete **** up - the script/acting/camera work are all bad. It was like watching a film made by high school students on their parents video camera.

I gave it three based on the fact thats its a marginally interesting idea, terribly realised.

title: not surprised...
review:
Okay first off, i can never listen to reviews sure i like reading them and seeing other peoples opinions and what not but i never listen to them because i like to find out for myself. I should of listened to the reviews on this one though, the people weren't lying "The Happening" is horrible absolutely horrible. I've always liked M. Nights movies (the sixth sense, unbreakable, Signs) were all great, the village was eh alright, but after that movie things got bad but for some reason his movies get me curious so it draws me in to see it which is why i saw this movie, now with his first R rated film im even more curious.

Heres what i thought was wrong with this movie...(i wont spoil anything for anyone) the opening sequence was flat, it just STARTS and the acting done by the people who are not "infected" show no emotion of panic or fear. Then there's Mark Wahlberg, i thought he was going to save this film because he is up there as one of my favorite actors and boy was i wrong, sure he plays a teacher in the movie and isn't some tough bad ass like he is in previous films but man oh man does he play the biggest wimp in the world it gotten to the point where i wanted him to get out of the scene, i was embarrassed for him. pretty much in my eyes the acting was just awful, i gave it a 2 out of 10 because there's one scene that kept my attention.

after the movie was done i started thinking, making he wrote this movie as a joke because it was so bad...i mean how can you make a good movie about mass suicide?

title: Three stars for an interesting pitch - forget the movie
review:
The basic idea behind The Happening could have been written down on a single sheet of paper and sold to a producer to turn into a good movie. Unfortunately, it ended up being worked out as a script and filmed by a writer/director who has completely lost his way. Intervention for M. Night Shyamalan, anyone?

The acting is wooden, no exceptions, and reminded me of some of the worst porn movies I have... heard about. Had I not seen Wahlberg and even Leguizamo in much better roles before, I would have written them off as serious actors on the basis of their performances in this film. I can only imagine how bad they must feel about their decision to get involved with this project.

There is no internal logic to any of the actions of the characters. Many scenes are just loose ends without any contribution to the plot development. That includes the few scares, which mainly consist of cheap tricks. Some of the horror effects made me laugh; half way into the movie I began to wonder if the surprise Shyamalan had in store for us this time, was that it was in fact a black comedy. No such luck.

Please, M. Night Shyamalan, stop writing and directing. In stead, sell your pitches to people who know how to write a script, direct actors and basically, make movies.

title: The Happening is so not happening
review: I was very excited to see this movie as it was directed by m.night who is the director of The Sixth sense which is one of best horror movies i have ever seen. So I was so desperate to watch The happening that i watched it on the first show itself(first show of the release date). I felt that the first half was pretty good but then i began to feel that OK first half showed it all now what else can m.night possibly show ahead at such a point. I felt that the concept was good but i guess m.night created a very difficult situation for him self it was very difficult to show any thing ahead after the first half in a story like this and what i thought came to be true there was nothing of it that interested me after the first half.

title: Hopes Dashed for Happening
review: I've always liked M. Night's films - even when they were bad, I've liked them, (e.g. "The Lady In The Water.") So I had hopes for his latest. Unfortunately, I can't be as charitable with "The Happening." The story concept was interesting,almost Michael Crichton in style. But Shamayalan played it more like a 'bad' Stephen King movie. While I had no problems with Mark Wahlburg's or Zooey Deschanel's acting per se, the two lead characters were two of the least interesting I'd ever been forced to watch on the big screen. We're supposed to care about their relationship and their futures together, but because they were shallow and half-developed, moments which were meant to be moving, were mundane. Oddly enough, some of the side characters were far more entertaining, and lasted on-screen for only a short time. The only good thing that I can say about this film is that there is some very well- done, disturbing imagery, which stays with you after the film ends. Sadly, it's the only thing that stays with you.

title: Nothing much happened
review: No spoiler warning needed for this flick - the movie itself has the spoiler about halfway through, after that it's anti-climactic and quite boring. The premise of plants suddenly mutating and gaining abilities to sense nearby people, then release toxins to make them commit suicide, is laughable. Anyone who has had chemical warfare training knows that wind will disperse airborne toxins, but apparently that's when the plants are most aware or something. The characters are in danger, you can tell, not by their reactions (department store mannequins would react more believably) but because the wind blows the trees around and the schmaltzy music gets really loud (which kept me awake at least). And after the holocaust is over, things just go back to normal. Except... OOOOH! It might happen AGAIN!! Somewhere else!!! Scary!!! I get the impression that someone had a basically cool idea, then sat around with a bunch of other people thinking of how to make it work. Then about halfway through the session someone said "The heck with, let's go get a beer and start shooting next week." Whoever you guys are, I want my seven bucks and two hours of my life back. And for those of you rating this movie as a ten... you're saying this turkey is as good as "Casablanca" or "Ben Hur"? C'mon...

title: So disappointed!
review: Do not take your children. There were children in this audience and it was very inappropriate. Again...no kids!! First for the good parts. That's the shorter list. M. Night Shyamalan always knows how to build some tension and he did this on occasion in this film. It was well photographed. Now for the disappointing bits. This is a preachy, extreme environmentalist wacko version of the birds. The premise of the problem that the population faces makes no sense. It's obviously written by someone who has no scientific training. I should have known we were in trouble when Mark Wahlberg's character is teaching a class in the beginning and questioning where all the honey bees have gone. The only plausible answer coming from the class was "global warming". By the way, we live on a farm and the honey bees were prolific this year. The film's bloody bits are disgusting and the scene in the zoo looked like a bad remake of the SNL Dan Akroyd/Julia Childs scene. There was one sickening scene of bizarre suicide after another and it became tedious and finally laughable. Yes, there was laughter in the audience as these grotesque scenes were played out in all their slasher splendor. I even heard a "good grief" and a "when will they die" comment from the audience. The characters are so eccentric, in fact downright insane in some cases, that there is no feeling of empathy. It's rather like the author felt the need to show how bad humans are in general. I was tremendously disappointed to have paid the money and wasted the hours. More than one of the comments have indicated that perhaps the people who do not care for this flick "just don't get it". Yeah, we get it. People bad, plants good. Take off on a B movie. Don't destroy the planet, because that will destroy you. Yeah, we get it. It's still a bad attempt at making that message. It's disgusting, it's sophomoric and lacks any scientific expertise one would expect from a middle schooler.

title: I actually walked out
review: I can't even begin to tell you what a disappointment this latest from M Night was to me. I had started looking forward to it months back when I saw the first trailer, as I have been a follower of his stuff since the Sixth Sense. I actually DID like The Village, and was OK with Lady in the Water- though I have to admit, it seems that each movie was less than the other as they were progressively made. But this- this was a really bad nightmare that I kept expecting to wake up from. In fact, at one point I had even hoped part of the scenario of the movie was that it WAS a bad nightmare- but alas, this nose-dive never pulled back up again. It was as though this was some spoof- not at all like Shyamalan's style to me- no intrigue, no twists or turns, and some of the WORST acting I've ever seen. Course, I felt a few misgivings when I saw the other Wahlberg being the star of this one- but I guess I felt like Shyamalan could work wonders or something. NOT. There were maybe two scenes that actually held any of the trademark Shyamalan humor - and the "suicidal" stuff you see in the trailers that looks like it will be scary, just ends up being as anti-climatic as the rest of the movie. What happened? is all I kept asking. I was ready to walk out within 30 mins or so, but kept hanging on to see if SOMETHING anything would happen to make it get better. It didn't. I just keep thinking- WOW. What a waste from a guy that could bring something like 6th sense and Signs, to get to this. And this my friends, was a joke. Don't waste your money at the movie theater- and really, don't waste your time with the DVD either.

title: No subtlety
review:
Very intense scenes are made gratuitous by a script that treats the moviegoer with condescension.

It's hard to make comments without giving away the story. This is essentially a makeover of a 60's film with none of the scientific sophistication that a modern audience demands in a film. Instead of an intelligent script that might make the point without giving the moviegoer a head injury, they have written a movie that is preachy and illogical.

I'm afraid that Shyamalan tries too hard to be the conscience of the moviegoer instead of a storyteller. The man's films lack any subtlety and this film is the least subtle of them all.

title: The hype more than the happening
review:
(spoiler alert!)M. Night did it again. That is, he bombed again. While the Happening had TONS of hype and seemed like it would have been the thriller of the summer, I left the theater feeling a little cheated. The idea had such potential. A global threat that no one could figure out, but then it made a turn... and it turned a little silly. I mean toxins released by plants?! Well, it's an interesting concept and a great attempt at an environmental movie, but it just didn't "hit the spot".

This was M. Nights first R rated movie and it was only because of the graphic death scenes, which seemed like they were there just so they COULD be there. And for what? The best way to describe my feelings about this film is to imagine you are starving and you are expecting a thanksgiving meal but instead all you get is Split pea soup. Overall, I'd say my rating is to wait for this movie to come out on cable. Marky Mark was the only reason to see the movie.

title: biggest let down of the year
review:
oh man, i can't believe what i just saw. Being a big fan of M. Night, i was super excited to see the happening. i really love the sixth sense, and the village, and really like signs and unbreakable. there's just something those films have that i like, something that gives those films that m. night touch.

i'll never forget the first time i saw his first movie Wide Awake. I was sitting at home flipping through channels and just happened to catch the last half of a movie that i knew nothing about. while i watched it though i kept thinking to myself that it reminded me of other movies. i couldn't quite put my finger on it until the end when everything came together. i told myself that it reminded me of m. night shyamalan, and then as the credits rolled and i saw that i was right i was hooked. i LOVED the fact that he has so many different kinds of movies, but they all still had that same particular m. night style to them.

Sadly, The Happening was missing this quality.

first of all, the acting was terribly unbelievable. No one seemed like they were even afraid. even during the "intense" parts all of the dialouge was just dull conversations.

Terrible storytelling also. how are we supposed to feel for the characters when they are attacked if we don't even get the chance to know them. every 5 minutes a new character was getting introduced only to be killed in the next couple of scenes.

Pointless gore. this could be my least favorite part about the film. one thing i've loved about his other movies was that everything had a point. well in The Happening NOTHING has a point, let alone the violence and gore, which really surprised me coming from a director so adamant on scaring and shocking people without using gore.

M. Night really reached a new low with the Happening.

please, don't go see it.

title: What do you expect when nothing seems to happen in the movie?
review:
I just came back from a screener from this movie. All I can say is that the movie is quite enjoyable but too hard to understand for most people in the audience when what causing the "outbreak" cannot be seen. It's true that some of the scenes in this movie was quite suspenseful and I enjoyed it.

But there's some scene that doesn't quite make sense in the movie. For example, compare the situation when John Leguizamo character got "infected", and Mark Walhberg's toward the end where the toxins supposedly at the peak of its potency. He should have got infected too, but being the main character of the movie I guess that logic is impossible for him to happen. When I came out of the theater and discussed this movie, no matter how I tried to explain the plot and defend the reason things happened in the movie the more I realize that, they were right and I was wrong. The movie sucks.

I really, really hope that this can be as good as Sixth Sense and Unbreakable but for more Lady in the Water is a bit better than this one. At least Happening is better than The Village and The Signs. I think instead of watching it in the theater, rent it. Or ask someone to rent and watch it together with him/her.

title: Shyamalan leads and leaves us on a new path
review:
Alright, I'll say that M. Night Shyamalan is a good filmmaker. He's brilliant with punctuation and tension, and the cinematography is beautiful. In the end he tells very human stories, albeit with bizarre or unusual circumstances.

But The Happening is no new Sixth Sense. He takes a bit of a new route this time with his first R-rated film - but if you're looking to see brutal death and mayhem, there isn't enough of that here to justify a ticket purchase.

It's the smaller moments that count here, and that's where a whole world of emotion is told in just a brief moment (I don't want to give it away, but I'm sure you can spot it when you see the film). But if only the whole sum left us with as much emotion as those little moments, this would've been a far better movie.

title: Worst movie I have ever seen! (contains spoilers)
review:
This has got to be the worst film that I have ever seen! I am a huge fan of all of Night's films... except this one.

For starters, what's up with the terrible acting? Mark Wahlberg has always been one of my favorites and for some reason he has some of the worst acting that I have ever seen. I'd expected the terrible acting from Zooey Deschanel because, well, she isn't the best actress.

Also, why cut out the fight with Mark and Zooey?!?! That makes no sense. If he would have left that fight in the movie, people would understand more what the characters are talking about and the audience could actually feel the characters emotions and they would understand the characters better. Why he cut that sequence out is a mystery to me...

Alright, what really makes this movie worse is that when the 'happening' finally reaches all of them in the old woman's house and Mark, Zooey, and the little girl finally just give up and go outside, the 'happening' magically passed them! Oh, what a huge surprise and twist that is!

You know, for a movie that is called 'The Happening,' there really isn't anything actually happening in the movie.

Oh yeah, and at the end when they find out it's actually the plants that are doing this, it's like "Didn't we already find that out an hour and a half ago?!?!" I mean come on, if you are going to finally tell us what it is, can't you think of something better than something we already knew. Let the audience thinks it's one thing and then at the end make a 180 degrees turn and make it something different. I mean seriously, this movie sucks big time!

title: i don't feel it deserves all its negative criticism (7.5/10)
review: i really don't understand all the negative reviews and criticisms of this film.i thought it was very well done.it's very intense and suspenseful,and and very creepy.it builds up suspense from opening scene,and doesn't really let up.i thought the story was creative,and the reason for the events could be possible,even though it seems far fetched.i did however,think the characters were nothing more than plot devices,and almost caricatures.none of theme were really developed,and there isn't really much in the way of acting going on.but despite that,i liked the film,mainly because of the high suspense factor,which i feel overrides the negative aspects of the film.for me,The Happening is a 7.5/10

title: Outstanding and visionary warning to mankind
review: Personally I found this movie completely riveting. This movie will not appeal to braindead mindwashed morons who get their movie kicks from the endless number of stories about adultery, murder and obscene amounts of money. The plot is very simple and precise. The characters in the movie are sincere and believable. The action and filming techniques provide spectacular viewing. It is a story of true love. Try it.

title: Wait 'til after the credits, I bet the cast and crew pop out and laugh at us!!!
review:
Really? This M Night has got a lot to answer for. At least to me anyway. I have been less than impressed with the man ever since I saw The Sixth Sense (big twist or no, it was still an artless bore) and through the years I have become increasingly aware that he has no place making films....would you want to be the director responsible for The Village?

This, however, had two things going for it; a mysterious, intriguing premise and a terrific trailer. People dying mysteriously left and right? Sure, i'm game for that, let's go out and see it.

From the outset I half-regretted my decision. Half regret because I - along with the rest of the cinema - was laughing my ASS off in addition to the pain.

This is why - despite being a 1/10 - I would recommend it.

It starts off setting the scene of mystery and foreboding; a scene that should create a tense atmosphere which the characters have to deal with. This tension is killed IMMEDIATELY by absolutely godawful acting. When the builder exclaimed his "surprise" at his colleagues falling all around him, I licked my fingers in between fits of uncontrollable laughter, already feeling full after 5 minutes of this ham-fest. In fact hamfest doesn't quite describe this...this turkey.

The pacing is simply awful. We end up right in the the "danger zone" with little chance to connect with the characters beforehand (except the obligatory character building base scene with Marky Mark at the school showing what a funny, likable character he really is; way to use Screen writing 101, M!) Scene selection is all over the place in terms of characterisation; some characters have a few scenes and are then killed off, with little chance to connect with them (although the acting makes them seem less like proper people and more like tools of the script, so there's little connection anyway). Even good ol' Marky Mark busts out a few hams. In fact, it seems as though M Night has an issue with consistency and continuity, be it in pacing or tone; I mean, the characters actually make JOKES?! JOKES when they're in the face of danger?!

So the pacing stinks and the character building is awful. Plot? If that's what you wanna call it. They end up in a house for the last ten minutes after running away from the wind (not making this up) with the secluded Mrs Jones, who remains disconnected from the world thus having no knowledge of the goings on outside. And it is in these final ten, twenty minutes that the true stupidity inherent in the film ramps up; expect more misplaced jokes and awful acting. After experiencing the non-ending and walking out, I felt myself echoing the sentiment of a fellow film-goer a few rows down: "That was the f**kin' most awful sh*t I've ever seen in my life".

It's not like it's a zero trick pony though, I mean M Night has also read the SuspenseWriting101 book as well it seems. The trees swaying in the neurotoxin-infested wind mix well with the music, and there are some cool death scenes, admittedly. So you might say that the (rather humbled, should he read this) director has applied the rudimentary practise of suspense-thriller film-making.

So WHY see this waste of a blockbuster?

This film is, simply put, excellent entertainment. Through it all I kept thinking "This CAN'T be a serious stab at a film, even for M", but I joined the whole cineplex in enjoying the hell out of it. I wasn't bored for a second, nor did I regret spending 6 pound 80 on it. Mrs Jones' antics may be just about the funniest, out-there occurrences i've seen on the big screen in a while, the acting is sometimes absolutely HILARIOUS when it's not (evidently) trying to be funny. It is even more incredible that it manages this feat, despite being directed in such a way that even the biggest metaphor-misser will see that the film is an allegory for environment awareness.

Put simply, please see this film. It will have you rolling in the sticky, sticky aisles, even if you're expecting the director and the cast to pop out at the end and laugh at you for sitting through it.

1/10 for the film, but a 10 for entertainment value.

title: Ignore pseudo-intellectual reviewers
review:
Before I went to this movie I read several of the reviews on here. I found many that completely dismantled the film so I went into it with rather low expectations.

I was pleasantly surprised to see a fresh idea and unique movie. I think that people are not giving this movie a fair shake.

The cast is somewhat awkward together I must admit; Most noticeably Deschanel and Wahlberg. This was apparent to me within the first ten minutes of the movie, however I felt that as it progressed they slowly "worked" for me.

I sadly was the minority opinion among my friends I went to see it with. I kept asking what their problem with The Happening was and it tended to be "it's no Sixth Sense" or "it's no (Shamalayan film here)" That to me, sums up everyone's take on this movie. You can't go into the theater expecting Shamalayan to reproduce the sheer genius that was the Sixth Sense. You're going to see the Happening, not the Sixth Sense 2. Unfortunately it looks like MNS's career began too well for his own good.

Anyways enough of my ramblings. Go see this movie. Bring an open mind. Leave any preconceived notions at home.

Oh and a notice to all you wannabe critics: Quit trying to one-up each other. Paraphrasing each other's work doesn't count as an opinion. Just because you can use a thesaurus it doesn't mean you're worthy of my time or anyone else's

title: Shyamalan's best in a while, but movie-miracles still ain't happening
review:
Please note the reviews also contains slight spoilers for "The Sixth Sense" and "Unbreakable".

Pretty much like the rest of our cinema-loving universe, I anticipated the release of "The Happening" with quite an unhealthy dose of skepticism. I never even bothered to watch "Lady in the Water", but I severely disliked both "Signs" and "The Village" and I even think his supposedly greatest accomplishments "Unbreakable" and "The Sixth Sense" are vastly overrated. Still, the formula of "The Happening" strangely appealed to me and  unlike any of the aforementioned titles  I felt to urge to go and see it on the big screen as soon as it got released. The trailer is downright fantastic and, even though you just know it already features all the film's major highlights, it literally oozes with suspense and morbidity. And also, for me personally, the opening of the film took away a massive load of skepticism and negative premonitions. Shyamalan doesn't dawdle for once and comes straight to the point after the atmospheric and moody opening credits. Strange, inexplicable and unspeakably tragic phenomena overcome the East coast of the United States. Starting within and around large national parks, people suddenly become emotionally and physically paralyzed and subsequently commit suicide as if they're instructed to do so by some sort of higher power. A large posse of petrified people, amongst them a science teacher with his emotionally troubled wife and one of his colleagues' young daughter, attempt to flee towards Philadelphia by train, but the unidentifiable menace spreads out as well. The occurrences are too complex and precise to be terrorist actions and an alien attack is entirely out of the question, so the only remaining explanation would involve a spontaneous revolt of nature. The undeniable strong-point of "The Happening" is that M. Night Shyamalan emphasizes the mystery-aspect a lot less than in any of his previous screenplays. At first there are several wild speculations regarding the origin of the events, but once nature's involvement is established, the focus purely lies on survival of the characters and at least the film doesn't build up towards the infamous  but often disappointing  twist in the end. The concept is pretty good, however the elaboration still too often feels incoherent and unconvincing. "The Happening" contains multiple isolated moments of sheer brilliance and  also unusual in the director's repertoire  pure horror, but as a wholesome it still isn't as powerful as it should be. The sequences in which construction workers throw themselves off rooftops, people stand in line to shoot themselves through the head with the same gun or even lie themselves down in front of a moving lawnmower are highly unsettling pieces of intense horror and probably the most shocking images M. Night Shyamalan will ever capture on film. They're especially disturbing since they're illustrated with a great sense of elegance and style, like the supernatural suicide is some work of art. In between all the menace coming from higher and incontrollable forces, the director also grabs the opportunity to depict ordinary human beings as the ultimate monsters. In their quest for survival, common people become egocentric and dangerous aggressors. It's an ancient and overused theme in Sci-Fi movies, but still very efficient and appropriate. A final and equally typical trademark in Shymalan's films is that the cast of characters doesn't feature any heroic or implausibly witty types. Taking all this and more (good acting, stunning photography, beautiful locations) into account, I'm tempted to describe "The Happening" as a good film and a personal triumph for the writer/director, but there's something that really upsets me. M. Night Shyamalan still is an imitator! Admittedly a very subtle and discrete one, but an imitator nevertheless. The rudimentary concepts for his most acclaimed movies may come across as original and unique, but they're always somewhat borrowed from less conspicuous older films. Genuine horror fanatics will have thought about "Carnival of Souls" and "Dead & Buried" whilst watching "The Sixth Sense"; "Unbreakable" had oddly many ideas in common with two obscure 80's movies called "Sole Survivor" and "The Survivor" and, if you contemplate about it a little, "The Happening" is a subtle re-working of Alfred Hitchcock's "The Birds". If you've seen this classic piece of 60's eco-horror, please take a few moments to think about the similarities.

title: Please Make it Stop!
review: I can only sum up this movie in two words...Incredible Boredom! The acting felt like something out of a really bad school play. As far as special effects are concerned...they did not exist! Normally I would say to someone...this is a film that you should wait until it comes out on video however I would not suggest to anyone to waste that much time on this film! I expected more and got so much less...sorry guys I wish I could give it even 2 stars but please do not waste your money or time on this one...its just not worth it! Mark Walburg simply did not have his heart in it from the get go. I cannot see him playing anything but a short scrappy guy in any film however this time he was cast as a caring sissy science teacher and it simply did not work.

title: For the Intelligent
review:
This film was made, without a doubt, for the scientifically minded. The majority of reviews by people who do not like this film, I would be willing to guess, have an ignorance of science in general.

This film has spectacular cinematography, very good acting, the occasional joke and mildly odd characters; everything you need to make a decent movie. What makes this movie particularly scary, however, is the realistic plot. If you need giant flashy robots destroying the world on screen to make a disaster movie, then maybe your attention span should be examined. This film is made for the intellectuals.

Intellectually, this film is as scary as it gets; of course this exact plot probably wouldn't happen, but it's not a bad guess as a possibility (not a probability) of what could happen. The only thing that bothered me at the end of this film, though, was the lack of explanation as to what caused the disaster in the first place. However, after thinking about it, if the director were to offer an explanation in the film, it would have ruined everything; an explanation would have been too cheesy, fake, and improbable for the situation.

This is genuinely a good movie, but I believe that you need to posses more than a few braincells to enjoy it completely - go watch "War of the Worlds" if you are one with a short attention span.

title: Brilliance!...kind of...
review:
for lack of better words, this movie was amazing. the reason i give it a 7 is because the master of movies (which you know whom I'm talking about) wasn't able to make everybody understand it.

spoiler alert(kind of) the brilliance of this movie was that he did something nobody has ever done before. he made the twist the most open ended as possible. but that was the twist. this movie will have everybody who viewed it arguing wtf? but thats the point, and this movie was the perfect way to do it. movies are made to make you think, change the way you think, or just move you in any which way, but not to just answer every question raised, because then you wouldn't take anything with you afterwards. at least this movie gives you a reason why all the questions aren't answered. watch it, but don't expect the sixth sense, where everything is layed out for you, look deeper...

title: Hilariously Bad , Good For A Laugh
review: I went to this movie trying to keep an open mind. Within two minutes, I was having serious doubts. Within five minutes, I was shaking my head in bemusement. Within ten minutes, I was laughing my ass off. This would have to be one of the most terrible films I have seen in a long time. Where do I start? The plot was absurd in every possible way. The acting was terrible, although many people will be of the opinion that the actors were cast in order to represent "real" people and not act like big blockbuster stars - whatever the reason, the acting was terrible. The casting was plain strange - nobody suited their part, not one person. Surprisingly, Mark Wahlberg - although not really suiting his part - was quite funny, though I'm not entirely sure he was supposed to be. The dialogue was plain strange and quite ridiculous. The supporting characters were just insane. The old woman who is a religious nut absolutely had me in stitches she was so funny. The scenes when they were outrunning the "wind" was just absolutely absurdly ridiculous, there was nothing slightly scary about the grass waving to and fro. It was pathetic. The suicides were poorly done and just stupid. I just can't express how awful this film is. There was nothing remotely scary or thrilling or even interesting about it, the only thing I can say is it is good for a laugh, I barely stopped chuckling at the ridiculousness of it from beginning till end. If it is a thrill and a scare you're after,watch something else. For a highly amusing comedy, watch this - it won't disappoint.

title: Abysmal failure!
review:
At the time I write this review "The Happening" has an average score of 6.2, how that is possible is beyond me! I have seen a few of M. Night Shyamalan's movies, I really liked "Sixth Sense" and thought "Unbreakable" was pretty good, but I have to say that "The Happening" is the worst film I have seen in a long time!

The story is paper thin and the basic premise of the film is absolutely ludicrous. Apparently Mr. Shyamalan thinks it is perfectly reasonable to expect several different species of plants to develop some sort of hivemind and "decide" to start producing and releasing completely identical neurotoxins simultaneously! And not only that, the plants can also sense the presence of humans and only release the toxin if they deem the number of humans to be high enough! Not to mention that it seems the trees are in control of the wind!

But besides the silly premise, is the movie any good? Well, sadly the answer is NO! The script is not good, on several occasions the lines feel stilted and unnatural, making it very hard for the actors to do a good job. It is very odd that Mr. Shyamalan wrote it with Mark Wahlberg in mind, since he feels miscast as "Elliot." Wahlberg has delivered very good performances earlier, but here it falls flat. I'm not happy about the casting of Zooey Deschanel either. To me, she always comes off as rather odd, which doesn't really work in this movie, in my opinion.

There are only feeble attempts at character building, which leaves the audience uncaring about the fate of the two main protagonists and the overly sappy ending is downright silly.

It is supposed to be a thriller, but I never felt any suspense and the only slightly scary thing in the film is the cranky old lady. Not a good thing, when the main story is about something that has the potential to wipe out the human race!

Some of the reviewers who have given "The Happening" a good review have more or less implied that if you don't like it, it's probably because you are not the kind of person who appreciate "thoughtful" films. I find this rather insulting! There is nothing thoughtful about this film. It is, IMO, a poor attempt at playing into the whole "doomsday" perspective that the media likes to portray regarding global warming and "eco-disaters." It would seem that Mr. Shyamalan started out on top of his game and has gone downhill ever since.

Easily the worst film I have seen in 2008.

title: Do not waste your money on seeing this film.
review:
I went to see this film with a friend last night as there was nothing much on and it looked fairly promising. The cinema was packed, so it was clear that everyone had been lured in by the same false promise (or the complete lack of good films on).

I chose not to tick the 'contains spoiler' box as despite what the title would lead you to believe, nothing very much happens in this film.

It starts with some poor quality footage of a park with two girls sitting on a bench, discussing something as irrelevant and banal as the rest of the film. Forgive me for saying that the combination of the horrifically painful acting, and the director's choice of a cheap, tacky close-up shot of one of the girls' face with wide, 'startled', blue eyes, wasn't going to win any awards.

I wish I could say that the film got better, but it really didn't. The bright blue-eyed girl from the beginning was replaced with another, who sadly prevailed on screen for the duration of the film. I didn't think that it was conceivably possible for anyone to act this poorly, let alone act this poorly and then be cast for a main part in a film, but I was proved wrong by this little gem.

I must credit 'The Happening' with something though; it's the only film I've ever seen that manages to achieve the complete set of terrible directing, horrible acting, poor script, ridiculous plot-line, bad camera-work and bad production. In one scene in a country house, the microphone makes a guest appearance at the top of the screen. It was probably the best actor in the film.

In spite of this, I must say that I did find many parts of the film unintentionally amusing, including the particularly endearing scene when a construction worker falls off the scaffold and his co-worker takes about five seconds to produce an unconvincing reaction. For anyone who still has an ounce of faith in cinematography, horror and, quite frankly, humankind, I advise you strongly to heed this warning: Do not see this film. Ever.

title: worst movie ever made!
review: Say what you want, but the movie was horrible. Never during the movie did i even think it was good. M. Night Shyamalan has been making horrible movies and yet the public still goes to see them. After the sixth sense he has made nothing but garbage. This movie was so far of the wall. Honestly plant releasing chemicals to kill people how retarded can you get. The most entertaining part of the movie was the previews before the zoo keeper and the lions and the lawnmower scene. As soon as the movie ended the whole theater i was in booed. So to those who say this is a bad review because i don't understand movies. you can think what you want I am a avid movie goer i like all types of movies but this movie was by far the WORST MOVIE I HAVE EVER SEEN!

title: I see calculus... And I want a hot dog...
review:
Ill start with the negatives and get to the positives.

So, I just got back from the theater, and I gotta say that I was hoping for a bit more from this film. Mark Wahlberg's performance was better than I expected. Most of the time he sold his character pretty well, it was fairly believable that he could be a teacher. Zooey Deschanel though... There were many times when her speech was very stilted, she sounded over-rehearsed and unrealistic.

She also looked cross-eyed a few times... Seriously.

There were 2 kids in the movie who just seemed kinda out of place. Their bit in the movie had no real effect on the storyline one way or another. The only conclusion that I can come to is that that they might have been there to show how desperate and violent humans can get when put in an extraordinary situation such as this.

Now the good...

If you are a fan of violent death scenes, you should appreciate a few of the ones here. The zoo-keeper, the policeman, and the car crash victims were my personal favorites. Most of the scenes though were a bit tame. But the ones that were nasty and gory made up for the ones that weren't.

This movie had a few scares in it, though not enough to be a truly scary movie. Unless you are freaked out by the thought of plants being able to make you kill yourself, don't expect to be too frightened by this movie.

All in all, it was decent. Ill buy it when it comes out on DVD, but its not good enough to warrant a second theater screening.

7/10

title: An Honest and Calculated Review
review:
I am just now sitting down after returning from the 7:45 showing of The Happening at our local theater and after being asked twice what I thought about it, my immediate answer was: I...just don't know yet. I've had the drive home alone to better gather my two cents, so here goes.

The movie as a whole...I don't feel got the experience and vision across that Night wanted us to have.

One reason for this includes the fact that I feel some of the side actors were trying to lather up their acting chops to match that of the main characters--thus, the chemistry between the two groups was just blatantly off and the non-A listers just looked like a bunch of overactors.

Then there's the spoken script. Characters in movies are all given silly lines from time to time and they just have to make it work, but in this film the lack of chemistry mentioned above often failed to resolve this and sometimes even normal lines seemed really strange when paired with the overactors.

You might be wondering: any positives to mention?

Well, I suppose. I think Mark W did a better job than most people here are giving him credit for. I'm not saying he's phenomenal in it, but there were a few moments where I do feel I was seeing a different side of him and where his natural standoffishness was working for the character. He and Zooey have decent chemistry, though I felt her acting was inconsistent at times. John Legiuzamo was decent; he can pull of being a father figure. The film score by James Newton Howard is nice when he's not trying to scare you, and when appropriate I felt it brought real emotion to the story and scenes where it was needed.

In short, I am giving it an overall 5. I began with a 7 because I could see the kind of movie Night wanted to have which could have been great, but a 5 is representative of the product. Not horrible (i.e., not deserving of the 1's and 2's others have been putting on here..hello, we're putting this in the same league as Showgirls, The Neverending Story III, etc? I think not), but not his best film by far. I'm a huge fan and believe in him, but this was the first film where I didn't leave feeling thoughtful, inspired or "changed" for a moment. I just left uncertain of what to think of it all.

It's not a film I will ever watch again, so perhaps the best course of action to take for the curious viewer would be to either wait until a friend rents it or wait a week until it is free to download off of the internet.

title: Ignore these horrible reviews from those who lack imagination
review:
This movie had everything.

To think I nearly passed up the chance to watch this movie as it rated a low 5 on this web site. This site has decent guidelines 70% of the time of course it takes a certain type of person to appreciate this movie for what it is and its brilliant.

Peoples opinions on this movie do not seem to apply to the same movie I saw. I think Mark pegged his character.The movie started off good and kept me at the edge of my seat with a plot that could not be denied of is originality. This movie is worth watching and I am glad I caught it in the big screen despite the fact that so many of you lack the capacity for abstract thought. Enjoy!

title: A Powerful and Moving tale about the End of the World
review:
This movie has been getting a lot of bad reviews that it doesn't deserve. Myself, I'm a fan of all M.Night's movies and The Happening is no exception. The premise of the movie is a about a sudden ecological event that becomes a threat to all humanity causing people to brutally kill themselves. The movie introduces us to high school science teacher Elliot Moore (Mark Wahlberg) and his less than faithful wife Alma (Zooey Deschanel) trying to escape from Phildelphia before the the event "happens" there too. Math teacher and friend of Elliot, Julian (John Lequizamo) and his daughter Jess (Ashlyn Sanchez) tag along. The thing I liked most about this movie is how Shyamalan shows how people would really react to the end of the world, not by running around screaming but sitting idly by,confused and filled with quiet fear.

In summary the people who didn't like this movie obviously didn't see the how deep it's meaning goes. If your looking for a cheap horror movie,this movie isn't for you, but if you you are looking for a deep, moving, and powerful psychological thriller than you should see this movie. Also if you aren't convinced after my review take a look at Roger Ebert's review, he should be able to convince you otherwise.

title: Rubbish
review: Yet another poor film by M. Night Shyamalan. It was terrible from start to finish a total waste of money. The plot was dreadful the acting was poor a complete waste of time and money in my opinion. I know you guys in America will love it though as with most of his films, I think with that sort of money a 9 year old could come up with better idea's for movies. M.
