Night Shyamalan must be on some sort of drugs as he keeps coming up with these ridiculous films. Plants that kill people what will be next? I preferred day of the triffids to this garbage; Come on seriously how you guys ranked it so high is beyond me. Worst film of the year so far for me.

title: A Good Film
review:
I was kind of glad The Incredible Hulk was opening because I figured most people would see that because of the PG-13 rating. I was impressed with M. Night Shyamalan's first R- rated film. If you enjoyed The Village and Signs you will definitely like The Happening. I liked it better than The Village and would rank it right below Signs.

The pace of the movie is usual for Shyamalan's films. The actor's I thought did and excellent job. I liked Zooey Deschanel, she brought a lot of humor to the film. Mark Wahlberg as a Science teacher actually worked for me. I got used to seeing him as a cop, but thought he was believable in this role.

Shyamalan is always thinking on another level than most film directors and writers and he remain's in my opinion one of the best story tellers ever in film making history. When you are watching this movie you'll find yourself thinking of things you've never imagined. The R-rating is necessary so keep that in mind if you're bringing any children. Their was several younger kids watching the movie in the row right behind me and they seemed to be enjoying it.

I've enjoyed all of M. Night Shyamalan's films and I must say he is still at the top of his game. I went and saw this movie with my girlfriend the first day it opened. She doesn't like scary movies and this one is NOT scary. Shyamalan does have his usual suspense filled scenes and my girlfriend seemed to enjoy those. She's only seen the Sixth Sense so she wasn't really familiar with his other work. Needless to say we both really enjoyed this movie. All in all if you liked his previous work, GO SEE THIS MOVIE!!!

title: Weak acting, shallow characters & simple plot - go and watch it!
review: I saw this movie yesterday, at its opening day in Santiago de Chile, apparently before its release in the US! It is not a great movie, the acting is weak. Mark Wahlberg's casting seems the worst error, even though the plot doesn't leave much room for character development and the movie as a whole seems to have been shot in a rush (it was actually shot in quite a short period of time). Yet, is has Shyamalan's signature all along. It is scary, with no digital monsters, buckets of blood, sinister killers or psychos hiding in the dark... despite a simple plot, shallow characters and weak acting, the wind blowing through grass and trees may prove enough to make you shiver. This kind of achievement is reserved for just a few directors, Shyamalan being one of this few. While we are still waiting for his 2nd masterpiece, this point makes this film worth a trip to the theater.

title: I wasn't scared
review: I found the movie boring, predictable and frankly not very scary (even if the premise of the story is terrifying). At the end of the day we are supposed to be scared by a virus but it doesn't really sneak up on anyone and in minutes the victims are dead. Even then the virus just disappears (just in the nick of time for main characters) and everyone lives happily every after (except in France). No one even had to figure out how to outsmart the virus. The characters just run long enough and hide well enough and by luck they survive! I am massively disappointed and didn't like the "global warming" message in the movie. What a waste of a good idea and waste of some good talents.

title: I wanted to kill myself after enduring this movie
review: In the first 2 minutes of the movie I was like wow this is going to be good but then DOWNHILL just DREADFUL the rest of the movie HAPPENED. Absolutely the worst film I've probably ever seen all the way around story, directing & especially acting. I really don't have much more to say but this movie was so stupid, absurd & the acting was so cheesy I actually was laughing at scenes that were supposed to be serious. OH MY GOD at one point Marky starts talking to a plant I mean bad it was ridiculous. I don't know why I have to write 10 lines to review a movie on this site?? I could have summed up this stinker in 2 lines yet I'm forced to write a short story about a movie u shouldn't see unless u go in wanting to watch a corny dopey crap-per for cackles.

title: The Happening
review: The first time I saw this movie it freaked me out, it was like whoa! I thought this was the most amazing movie ever. The happening had so much suspense, it always had me wondering what was going to happened next. Mark Wahlberg played his character very well, with his witty sense. However I didn't like his wife she always had a sense that she was hiding this guy from her husband. Overall the characters brother was very weird. I always wondered why in the world would you let your daughter go with the uncle if u were going to end up dying regardless. The mother of young jess was no where to be found I thought she died in the movie. After seeing this movie a couple of times I began to like it movie, it made me sad because all these people were killing them self. These people jumped off buildings shot themselves, and just died by something strange. I still like this movie a lot it was the best suspense movie ever!

title: Ummmm... what just happened?
review: Blimey words can not describe how truly bad The Happening is I'm still in a state of shock. The acting was terrible and I wasn't sure whether it was actually meant to be a comedy as I found myself laughing quite a lot. The two main characters are normally very good actors so I can only assume that they got five minutes into acting in this film and thought 'this is rubbish I can't be bothered to act anymore'. It's almost worth watching just so you can say "Yes I agree with everyone it really is that crap!" It's a shame because if you watch the trailer for this film you think oooo... that looks good, so I would suggest you just watch the trailer as it contains the only good parts of the film.

title: "You like hot dogs?....Don't you?"
review:
Yes....the summary title is actually a line from this absolutely dread attempt at an apocalyptic thriller by a writer/director who should have quit while he was ahead (after Unbreakable). I caught this movie on HBO and while watching I had to see what the IMDb community thought. Usually I place my barometer for trash movies at about a 5.0 (of the realistic 9.1- .2) scale as "watchable". Occasionally I'll indulge in a trashy Showtime movie (not the dirty ones I mean ones life "Traffic Jam" and Texas Chain Saw the Lost Years. This movie delivers that quality, with a Hollywood budget. The first review I read gave this one 3 stars.....thats generous. The acting is almost as atrocious as some of the lines these robots are forced to deliver. Poor John Leguizamo.....I guess now i know why you don't see him getting work anymore, but man I feel for the guy. Anytime Mark Wahlberg out performs you on screen, you should question your craft. This movie does raise some questions in my mind...they are as follows.

1. Is Shamylans a worse director or writer? Compelling arguments can be mad for both side, but in the end I have to give it to the writing side. Past of the overuse of close ups he'll deliver a shot that isn't utterly painful at times. But the script....oh the script........ 2. Will one of his movies ultimately be so bad that the scenario proposed in the film comes to fruition? Simply put, I'd believe that more than any of the premises of the last three movies by this hack. 3. Why did Mark Wahlberg seem like the appropriate cast for this or any role?

He'll always be a one hit wonder.

title: Why did Ebert like this as much as he did?
review: "The Happening" is a sad and pathetic film. Throughout the movie, I was thinking, "Does MKS really think the world and 'nature" are like this? Where did he go to school? Does he ever read actual, real books about science, physics, and subjects other than film?" Of course, it was easy for me to think these thoughts because the acting is totally and uniformly awful. There are NO good acting roles in this film and every single actor just tanks it. Wahlberg is terrible in a Snidely Whiplash fake way in the first scenes and just goes downhill. I've never understood Deschanel's appeal and she makes Wahlberg look like Gielgud. My only hope is that MKS really does understand how stupid the whole story is and was trying to create a grand metaphor for, for...something else, I guess. Can't imagine what. Don't waste your time on this, even if you just want to see how bad it is.

title: What Happened?
review:
Confession: I am an M. Night Shyamalan fan. I own The Sixth Sense, Signs, The Village, and Unbreakable and eagerly show them as masterings of writing and direction. I am also a Mark Wahlberg fan to a point. His character in The Departed could not have been better served by any other actor and his turn as an aging athlete in Invincible was both heartfelt and inspired.

Admission: I went in to this movie expecting it to be Mr. Shyamalan's return to greatness following the professional hiccup that was Lady In The Water. It was going to be yet another display of perfect storytelling, carried by a very capable lead actor, that I could add to my collection of Great Modern Movies. I had nothing but hope.

Admonishment: Stay clear of this movie. Don't even watch it as a rainy Sunday afternoon option to cure boredom. The direction is somewhat sound and the pacing is slightly above average, but what's going on IN each scene is absolutely negligible . Outside of one scene where a distraught construction worker watches his coworkers plunge to their deaths, there's not one redeemable moment in this movie. The acting level of every minor character is that of a high school educational movie troupe, the revelations of what is HAPPENING are spoon-fed and forced, and after 15 minutes I felt like I was stuck watching JUST ANOTHER DISASTER MOVIE. Worse, I didn't care to see what became of any of the cookie-cutter major characters: the loving wife, the honest friend, the goofy-science guy with the answers... they could have bit it in the first third of the movie and maybe, at best, I'd have woken up. Sure, John Leguiziamo is good and Zooey Deschanel is admirable in their respective roles, but when you don't care about whether they live or die you've gotta think there's a problem somewhere in the script. And as for Mark Wahlberg? Miscast. Seriously miscast. He spends his entire time here trying too hard to be the nice guy you just know he's not. The trivia page for this movie says that M. Night wrote the lead role specifically with Marky-Mark in mind. I don't know what he was thinking and I fear that his instincts may just be THAT FAR OFF. And that's a shame, because when his instincts were on we got Incredible Cinema. Now we get a dumb 1970's B Horror movie that I only finished because I hoped that somewhere, somehow, some SIGNS or SIXTH SENSE magic would show up. Here's a spoiler: it never does. Somebody get M. Night into therapy now (or at least a UCLA film class for a semester or three)to work out his issues and get his edge back because The Happening is the new Webster's Dictionary example of a LETDOWN and the second bomb in a row for a guy capable of SO much better.

title: Contrived and pretentious
review:
Like most of Shymalan's films, The Happening is pretentious. Don't get me wrong, there's a few stunning sequences (esp. an early one featuring some unexpected falling objects). But the deliberately tantalizing hints scattered throughout the movie, once again--much like in The Village, frustratingly proved to be just a tease and ultimately lead to nowhere. The whole setup and intentional atmosphere in the early part of the movie promised far more than was eventually delivered.

The Happening is not a very bad movie, and it has the potential to be much better. But that would require more honesty from Shymalan. Shymalan is a master creator of suspense. But except in The Sixth Sense and maybe Unbreakable and Signs, he failed to bring satisfactory resolution to the suspense he crafted. Consequently, by the time one leaves the theater, his later movies (The Happening in particular) feel empty, silly, contrived and forgettable.

It is most unfortunate that Shymalan's later movies increasingly bear the hallmark of a director/writer who has got famous and admired too early too fast. Fame and acclaims could lead one to all so easily be convinced that he's cleverer than the rest, and it showed in Shymalan's movies. He might indeed be a very gifted movie maker, but his strong self-assurance has got in his way of making truly good movies--movies with realistic emotional resonance, rather than inward looks of what is in Shymalan's own mind. Shymalan is overdue for a bit more self-confrontation. Until he confesses to himself that he's actually not as clever/intelligent as he believes he is, he cannot be as clever/intelligent as he has the potential to be.

title: Does Not Happen
review:
An invisible force is causing a breakdown of human behavior in the NE United States. People become disoriented and die. What is going on?

Remember the old expression, "there's something in the wind"? Well, someone who is not too creative decided to make a movie out of it. As a short story it would have been fine, read and forgotten, but now we have to contend with a truly boring movie with a Class A star (Wahlberg) to boot. Mark, what were you thinking? Go back to police dramas.

Ah, but there is an explanation and it is simply that a force of nature is causing all this and no one can figure out why. Normally, I wouldn't give the answer away, but no one should have to sit through this Snoozer with halting dialogue and absolutely no suspense. Ah, suspense could have made this worthwhile. Can't believe I just said that.

It's just not that the main story is unclear, it is also that the characters don't seem to know their lines and they seem not to even know their relationship with each other and we, in the audience, don't know either. Can't even come close.

Already, I have taken up too much of your time with this NON-HAPPENING event. Yes, there is something in the wind: a bad movie.

Violence: Yes. Sex: No. Nudity: No. Language: No.

title: A disappointment, despite having potential
review:
I liked the sixth sense. In fact, with that movie, Shyamalan created a whole new style of storytelling. However, after that I watched Signs, The Village & Lady In The Water, I noticed the the pattern of steady deterioration in his work.

At least the rest of them had good performances by the actors in the lead roles. Mark Wahlberg frankly surprised me by how bad his acting was - I think he only did a few minutes of decent acting in the beginning. But then, he probably stood out because he had the most screen time; others were equally terrible, if not worse. In this case, it seems as if it's the director's fault. I also wonder if the mistake was greater in casting. Surely when you do so many close ups of the lead, you'd want an actor who is better at facial expressions. I respect Mark Wahlberg as an actor, but this movie really did make it seem that he'd only be good for the more physical actor playing a bad-ass.

Onto the plot, I thought the main concept of the movie was pretty interesting, it wasn't something totally useless like Epic Movie, but something one could ponder about. But the execution was rather poor. For example, at the end when a scientist loudly claims on TV that this was nature acting back, it seemed too overtly out there & sounded comical. I'd rather go with the government idea, because that idea was portrayed a bit more subtly.

The opening scene turned out to be pretty good, and for a moment, I found myself thinking "Yes, Shyamalan has returned!" But while the movie continued, the story didn't unravel any further. Halfway through the movie, we are told that plants are behind this pandemic, and that was the only explanation we ever got. I was naturally disappointed, not to see 'The Shyamalan Twist'at the end(although the scene at the end where Elliot & Alma walk towards each other in the fields & remain unaffected may have been intended as the twist, but I failed to see it).

Nonetheless, there have been good movies where we never really get a full explanation of the plot, like the low-budget Canadian movie Cube. But they had more interesting characters. As for the characters in this movie, most of them seemed unrealistic. For example, the little feud between Elliot & Alma - were they not overreacting to Alma having dessert with Joey when supposedly working late? Or about the part about Elliot joking about a pharmacist? Another thing, the characters' reactions to the deaths surrounding seemed odd. Yes, Alma & Jess stated early on that they don't like to express themselves, but surely a bizarre pandemic could trigger a frenzy of emotions within them.

By the time we reached the freaky old woman, I hoped maybe there would be something to the movie. But sadly, all that freaky old woman was was a freaky old woman.

title: typical.
review:
I fall for a lot of bad movies, but his movie was just awful.

It redeemed itself 3 times; the gun idea, the hanging from trees shot, and the idea of the lawnmower.

The acting was atrocious. The main guy, does a decent job, but the lead female role is so badly acted, i kept on laughing at her blasé approach, which was entirely unrealistic.

The script and the visual idea was sometimes painful, and they seemed to try to create lackluster suspense with the script and to create boring takes on interesting suicides.

The idea was pretty good; an "agent" which makes you kill yourself. however, we never get a good enough idea about what this waste-of-my-life was all about.

bottom line; interesting concept, terrible result.

title: How to Kill yourself
review:
The first scene itself was hilarious. A women pulls out a sharp object out of her hair and drives it into her throat.

The next Killings: A cop pulls out his gun and shoots himself. The dropped gun is then utilized by other gone bonkers so orderly by picking it up and shooting themselves.

Mark W. will surely wish this bad as it can get in his acting career. His acting was opposite of the Oscar winning "Departed". And yes if it was meant to be funny, it was - Mark talking to the Plastic Plant.

I wanted this movie to revive M. Night S. post The lady in the water. He instead has slumped to a new low. It wasn't at all frightening, even whinny tiny bit. My film making/studying brother says its the Hollywood Producer pressure. He is the most recognized globally known Indian Director, and that burdens him with high expectations.

Bring back the Sixth Sense M. Night. I /We believe in your immense talents.

title: Hmmm... plot not working for me
review: I watched this film not too long ago... And wow.. just wow.. This is maybe one of the worst movies I have seen in quite a long time... The worst part of it was possibly the acting. While I actually think mark Wahlberg usually does an okay job... my god he didn't do it this time, and neither do any of the other actors. The best acting was probably by the construction worker early in the movie. other than that, the actual plot is just silly, and it seems like Mr Night knows just how unbelievable it is and tries to make it more believable by making people mention things about plants and the human energy time after time... It simply seems misplaced a lot of the time. The final moral about trying to be more careful about the way we treat our planet is all good and well.. but is kind of old and really doesn't save this movie. The one good point it did have was that it is rather scary and suspenseful I was certainly kept on the edge of my seat until the end.. so it does deserve a rating of 3 for that.. but other than that.. it's bad, simply put. sorry. But don't watch it, even for a laugh.

title: Missed opportunity!
review:
Where to begin with this sorry saga! The Happening is without doubt a missed opportunity snatched from the jaws of victory by our good friend Mark Wahlberg. Wahlberg who, when given excellent direction and material can turn in a mediocre performance at best, finds that given no direction and bad material, well; I'm afraid you only get what you deserve.

Acting lesson 101:- An actor should be that good that you don't notice them acting! Wahlberg is so wooden I half expected to see a carpenter use him as an instrument to bludgeon one of the victims with.

The story in the Happening is a good premise badly realised. The film lacked a cohesive direction which left you without any empathy for the main characters or what was happening to them. There are many good scenes in this film, what is lacking is a strong enough thread by our main characters to mesh everything together.

There are some quite shocking scenes of construction workers jumping off high rise buildings that left me puzzled, would airborne spores really have reached that altitude in sufficient quantity when there didn't seem to be very much vegetation in the surrounding area?

In previous films by Shyamalan you had big name actors like Bruce Willis, Mel Gibson & Samuel L Jackson. The only link I can see here is Joaquin Phoenix who had been in the film "We Own The Night" which also starred Wahlberg. Perhaps Phoenix tipped Shyamalan that Wahlberg was good!

When all is said and done about this film, it is the actor who should be able to carry a film, be the star attraction,the film merely being a vehicle, you only have to see this from the likes of Will Smith who has had a couple of turkeys, yet is forgiven by his box office returns. Wahlberg is not in a position to carry the lead in a movie, he should stick to being a co-star in films with actors with more charisma like "The Departed" We can only hope that Wahlberg is not given the opportunity to ruin yet another film.

title: Two hours of my life I will never have back...
review:
There are so many rotten and useless aspects of this movie, I don't know where to begin. The pedestrian acting responding to the hollow direction? I've heard the director said he intended to create a B movie. Well, this is not how it was billed. When exactly did he decide this? Isn't that convenient once your movie is decidedly a totally campy piece of trash? We were sold his first R rated flick- promising a comeback that never came back. That there is still money backing Shayamalan or that we are still a hopeful public isn't up for debate in my mind.

So many ridiculous moments come to mind, but if there is one that stands out in my mind: the impossible and utterly laughable segment in which the person's arm is ripped off in a lion's den after the repeated coaxing on the part of the person. After tapping one lion's nose, "hey, look here." he turns to the other, in case he missed that, and had the remaining one promptly ripped off! I'm sorry, that is that height of hilarity.

The best part? That this was communicated via video through someone's Iphone, as simply as "hey, look at what my sister sent me." Okay, first off, why was the sister not jamming her Iphone into her eye socket upon seeing this? And second, the Iphone is incapable of recording video(in the real world). What a cheap and shameless marketing ploy.

title: I just can't give it a grade...there must be something we're all missing...is this the twist??
review:
I won't do it. When you get to the end of this review there will not be a grade out of ten because I just can't do it. I want to slap a poor score on it and then the next minute I'm crying out to M. Night Shyamalan (who never answers back) that there has to be a secret to this film as to why it was PURPOSELY made so poorly. The man is not new to film making and I have loved every single one of his movies and the thing is they have all been downright brilliant. Brilliantly written, perfectly cast, wonderfully acted and beautifully directed. I will also say to all those people out there who crap of Lady In The Water...I adored Lady In The Water, pure and utter brilliance and beauty and probably my favorite of his films. The Village I could live without, it wasn't quite as intelligent as his other entries and then there is this which doesn't even register on the scale of intelligence. It's ludicrous!! There is virtually no story, not one that makes sense, the acting is horrid on the part of every single actor especially the lead cast. There is no beginning and end really, no twist, no cares, you just never wanna see it again. I'll get to my rant in a moment.

I'm going by face value and although I used to not be able to stand Mark Wahlberg but lately he had grown on me with some impressive performances. In this film he is absolutely putrid. One of the worst performances I have ever seen and I am telling you that 100% he is doing it on purpose. He is purposely acting bad. First of all his character acts like a child...and this is done on purpose I am sure of it I just don't know why. Other reviewers have noticed this as well. His scared puppy dog look about being left behind on the train, and his tone and his facial expressions...he's acting like a 10 year old boy but WHY?!?! Almost as bad is the performance by Zooey Deschanel. She acts like a child as well and that can't be just a coincidence?!?! She has these enormous eyes that are constantly zoomed in on as she just plain acts BAD!! The two of them together make a deplorable twosome with some sort of back story about them and their wedding that we are never privy too. John Leguizamo CAN act. I've seen it...and this is not it. He's acting almost as poorly as Wahlberg and has that child like quality about him too. There is some bad blood between his character and Deschanel's character but we don't know why and don't care really. The supporting cast aren't really terrible, they just aren't in it much and we don't care because the lead cast is so awful.

Is M. Night Shyamalan trying to create a movie that is so bad it will become a cult classic twenty years from now? Is that his twist? Will he pop out twenty years from now when the Golden edition Red Ray disk version is released and say HA I PLANNED YOU ALL TO LIKE IT IN TWENTY YEARS!! Is there some hidden mystery to the lead cast acting like children? Is it some message about purity and environmental ruin? There has to be something...someone please save the reputation of M. Night Shyamalan for me because this film single handedly ruined him as one of my favorite directors and yet I hold hope that there is something more, something fiendishly clever about the movie. I kept wondering if the twist would be that all these people were filming a bad B Movie like Godzilla or Valley of The Dolls or something but no it appears that it just might be that bad. But to hold out hope I will not rate this movie for the first time in 700 reviews!! I only encourage film buffs to watch this and try to find for yourself the reason why it is terrible but do not go see this expecting to be entertained because it is ridiculous!! A summer bomb by any stretch of imagination!!

title: Huge disappointment
review:
Mass suicide, chaos, panic and disorder. It all starts suddenly and people rush to find an explanation. But first and foremost they try to find a safe place, attempting to flee from something that seems to be spreading faster than the plague. Seen from the trailers this seemed interesting enough.

The films start isn't entirely bad either, except for a frequently appearing boom mike and acting that is a lot poorer than expected from its cast. But it starts to get bland and boring very quickly and at that point the acting and the boom mike get to be a source of irritation. And as the film runs towards its end it is clear that it doesn't get any better. No, instead it gets worse - it finishes itself off with a true cliché ending that manages to change the feeling of slight irritation into massive irritation.

So, in short... Poorly written, poorly played, poorly edited and badly ended. Complete and utter waste of celluloid.

3 out of 10 missed chances.

title: In my opinion..
review:
I watched this movie after being excited for it since I saw the first trailer. Unfortunately, it was completely terrible! When I say terrible I am over stating how I feel, but rather summing up my overall view of the movie.

The acting was terrible. In fact, I believe it was one of the worst acted films I have ever seen while under a dramatic/suspense category. Mark Walberg is usually good, but it was like watching him in The Big Hit. He talks like a puss and is put out as the strong willed protagonist. He didn't feel strong, smart, or interesting.

Supporting actors were about just as bad.

And I never felt as if the people in the movie were ever truly scared or troubled about what was happening.

NOW THE STORY.......

The story was very good at first......but it seems to me that M. Night came up with the idea and didn't know how to completely unroll it into a movie. It felt very draggy and repetitive. As if they looped the same scene throughout the entire middle then ended it......terribly.

OVERALL.....

This movie does not come with my recommendation, and you can say he just doesn't like M. Night, but really this movie was just not done well, but could have been.

It was like watching a baby chick hatch, cracking little pieces of the shell, but then die before getting out.

OOOOH, Almost, but not quite....

title: Sucks, simple and plain.
review: Despite the poor reviews, I was still interested in seeing this movie, as I am also a big fan of M.N.S.'s movies. I loved the Sixth Sense, Unbreakable and Signs. "The Village" wasn't good, and "The Lady In the Water" was awful. "The Happening" is really really really really bad. It's another MNS movie with an intriguing premise that fails to deliver big time! I'm giving it 2 out of 10 on merit of premise and the first 20 minutes of the movie, but as the film goes on it just gets worst and worst. Script/story, dialogue, acting and ultimately direction are all culprits in this incredibly bad movie. Unless you're seeing it for free, seriously, don't spend any of your money to see this film. No, seriously, don't even spend $3.99 to rent it, or you'll regret it.

title: Skip it
review: The screenplay was laughably bad, the entire movie was predictable and the acting was atrocious. I respect Mark Wahlberg, because I love Entourage, but he should stay behind the camera. His performance was nothing less than embarrassing; he was the star and gave arguably the worst performance (which is impressive, considering there was nary a good performance in the movie). John Leguizamo stood out among all the actors, but his performance was still very lukewarm for what he is capable of. The special effects (of people dying)were neat and marginally scary, but only because of the loud thuds. Mostly I was cringing because this movie was so poorly put together. M. Night Shyamalan just put the final nail in his Hollywood coffin....or at least I hope he did. I can't take another one.

title: A disappointing film
review:
If you go to watch the film with low expectations then you will probably enjoy this film, however, after seeing the trailers for this film I was expecting something good. I was disappointed. They had a great storyline and plot however the actors didn't quite fit the part and I was often left cringing at some of the acting.

With a great beginning the film seemed to loose it halfway through and it was padded out with low-budget scenes. It was almost as if the writers had forgot themselves what he film was about as they produced mismatched theories which didn't quite fit.

Overall it was a watchable film but not something I will be rushing out to buy on DVD.

title: Nothing really "happens" in that movie
review:
Alright.I just watched the movie and this was....bad. Ironically after finishing the movie I realized that I had been expecting all along something to 'happen' . But the happening didn't bring much excitement.

What I am disappointed with, is the potential of the idea brought in the story..pretty original, but not well explored.

The development was too linear, if not constant, and the viewer gets rapidly bored since nothing is really happening.

We are introduced to some kind of natural disaster, which never receives any explanation. Now, I understand that bringing the cause of the disaster is not itself a factor defining a good movie, yet you need to keep the viewer interested by another mean, but the deception here relies on the fact that there is nothing else in the movie, there are no ornaments accompanying the story. The viewer is just witnessing human reactions.

Now the problem is that it's not based on a thriller, nor on a science aspect, so one can obviously deduce that the main work should be concentrated on the actors and there emotions, but unfortunately this side was also a failure.

To resume : Good potential, great originality, but not well explored, boring dialogs, story is too linear and actors don't seem to be much involved in the disaster...

enough said..

title: oh man... terrible movie.
review:
Nothing happened in this movie at all. This movie was totally boring. See, i'm so used to seeing his movie drag out to the end of the movie, and end it with some sort of great twist. But nothing ever happens in this movie. Its just a long drawn out event that lasted way longer then it should of. Not suspenseful, not scary, people ends up dieing in the movie, but at the end, it never explains why, and its open to guesses.

People are complaining about the acting, there's nothing wrong with the acting. Its just that this movie is so boring that a lot more focus is put on the acting. The dialog for the actors are short. I actually didn't mind the acting by the main characters.

I wouldn't recommend this movie to people. Lady in the water was better than this movie.

title: Bad wind!
review:
"im going to ask for my money back" thats what i and everyone else was left saying leaving the cinema.

the trailer looked terrifying and urged me to get my money out of my credit crunched pocket only to be let down after about 30mins. the best part being bob the builder and his mates falling off the wobbly scaffolding.

An awful performance by everyone. the whole cast were out-acted by the wind and plants! a film trying to make the wind and plants scary? what was M.Night Shalalamamama thinking? save yourself the journey to the cinema and wait for the DVD. i recommend watching it in your green house for added effect!

title: Like many others I vote "not happening" for The Happening.
review:
I'll try to sum this up quickly. M. Night Shyamalan has a lot of good will in my book as "Unbreakable," "Signs" and "The Sixth Sense" are some of the most entertaining and nerve-wracking movies made in the last 10 years. For those three great films alone I'll go see M. Night's future films hoping for anything even close to those highly entertaining films.

The Happening isn't all bad. It is however, about 60% bad. And when it's bad, on occasion, it's downright awful. I was going with it for about the first 30 minutes. The first 30 minutes seemed like a collaboration piece between M. Night and John Carpenter. Again it worked for a while, sort of.

As the non-story "builds" the directing and acting both seem to get sloppier. Scenes become unintentionally funny and I for one found myself groaning out loud and talking back to the screen. I haven't done this so often since Nicolas Cage in "The Wicker Man." I'm convinced The Happening will be studied in future film classes as an example of when things go horribly wrong. It's worth seeing, but don't expect to see a good movie.

title: Really really disappointing..
review:
It is a well known fact that Manoj Night Shyamalan is a prodigy when it comes to making our hair stand on ends, and make you cringe in your seat with fear. It is also a well known fact that he might be losing his touch a little bit. Although his scripts are among the most original to come out of Hollywood, since Signs, his films have failed to capture the attention of audiences. With all due respect to Shyamalan, I have loved all his movies immensely except Lady in The Water, The Happening shows signs of lack of care in making the movie. Something that one would never associate with him.

Shyamalan is famous for the tension he creates on the screen. The scary and awe-inspiring moments which he is able to create on celluloid is nothing short of pure genius. Read : The scene with the boy with half a head from The Sixth Sense, the green man running across the screen in a flash from Signs, and the sight of a police jeep driving up in the middle of what seemingly is nowhere from The Village. M. Night Shyamalan is truly brilliant when it comes to things like that.

Like all the above mentioned, The Happening too has a fair share of such sequences. Namely, people falling off a rooftop (the poster above), a man walking straight into a lion pen - swarming with lions, and another man laying himself down in front of a giant grass-cutter. The loudness of the sounds which accompany these are shocking, not to mention spot-on! From shots of the wind ruffling through giant oaks and tall grasses, to shots of utter silence, visually The Happening is stunning. But that is about it.

The storyline is merely a different take on what one calls, in layman's terms, global warming. The biological accuracy of the plot is unknown to me. The consequences however, are, simply put, freaky! It is some sort of toxin or whatever you would like to call it, that makes human being suicidal. It looks mostly like a zombie movie. Though, films like 28 Days Later and I am Legend tackled the situation differently. The acting is way below par. Mark Wahlberg is not suited to play a science teacher. Zooey Deschanel, blue-eyed wonder, (Shayamalan has one of these individual's in most of his films) is flat. No expression, no nothing. The little girl, Ashlyn Sanchez is also flat (Why not Dakota Fanning? - though she wouldn't have much to do). There is no character development at all. The timing for most things is wrong. You never really feel for the characters. Just the sheer apocalyptic nature of the plot is enough to dismiss everything else about the film. It just seems a bit too over the top.

There are also too many misleading plot twists. The hippy family, and old Mrs. Jones (plain insane I tell you. I felt like smashing her head with a shovel). The two kids which accompany the main cast midway through the film - What were they even there for? All over, just the background score and the visual look and feel of the movie are commendable. Shayamalan still stands out in that field. But, be serious. The Happening is nowhere close to a good movie. It's just all wrong. Why would anyone crack a romantic joke when they have better things to worry about? Concentrate on staying alive - that helps! Don't waste your time on this. Catch a few of the scenes I mentioned above, on YouTube, stay home and watch a rerun of The Sixth Sense, Signs, or whatever.

3/10 overall. Give us something better, M. Night. We know you can!

title: Annoying technicallity
review:
I'll not go into storyline discussions, there are currently over 300 comments already. Either you like it as a B-movie, were characters are in-perfect beings in suspense running from the unknown, untouchable and invisible, or you think the suspense mechanism used is ridicule and unbelievable.

My critiques is a technical one. Ever seen Out of Africa, where in one of the scenes you can see a black object hovering in the top middle of the picture? An incompetent sound recorded whos single job is to hold the microphone on a stick couldn't keep it up and the microphone hovered in view. That was 1985 and just once. "The happening" is 2008 and the the microphone dips into the picture 15-20 times through out the whole movie. I just hate it when a movie is trying to draw you into the story-line, trying to get you to the edge of your seat... and you see a technical error that reinforces the 'oh-yeah just some actors in front of a camera repeating their script-lines' feeling.

Seriously, did Mr. Shyamalan even looked at the movie after shooting the last scene? The microphone is so often in view that he could just as easily cropped the top 10 pixels of the whole movie.

Send back to originator and put some more effort in it next time.

title: so bad, in any respect
review:
this movie is so bad, I can't imagine why other critics used so many words to describe and criticize it. The acting is bad, , the background of the characters is unclear (so is the conflict between the couple). There is some resemblance to War of worlds, but this story is so poor, and...stupid , that any comparison will be an insult. There is one similarity to the recently made version, with Tom Cruize; the little girl portrayed in both films is hysterical, and is an irritation to the audience ear.The elderly lady , who owns the house , tops everything else in this movie by adding a grotesque figure to this basically impossible plot.

Do not go to see it, it is a waste of your money, or even worse; of your time.

title: Disappointing
review:
I include "Sixth Sense" and "Unbreakable" at the top of my personal mood-piece masterpiece list. Shyamalan has shown an uncanny ability in the past to conjure up tension and dread almost out of nothingness on the screen. That takes talent.

However, with this movie, it seems that he has become overconfident, overusing some of his old tricks to the point of gimmickry. The overuse of staccatos and things jumping out of the corner of the screen show that he was really reaching for the cheap scares, perhaps to hide a weak script. And that's were the problem lies: A weak script. Unlike his previous films, which were patient, well modulated, detailed, and flowing, this movie seems to just clunk along without creating any tension, character empathy, or dread. It doesn't do a very good job at making us care for the characters. The story feels hackish because the dialog is hackish.

I don't know the man, obviously, but judging by his latest work, he's become overconfident. Overconfidence breeds complacency. His complacency is evident everywhere, especially in the halfhearted script. I hope Shyamalan takes some time to prepare his next script.

I get the feeling he probably needs to get his ego in check as well.

title: I want my money back!!!
review: I do not have enough time in my life to fully bash M. Night Night Shamalalalala. He sucks! He really sucks!!! I am so angry at myself for giving this D rated producer another chance. I even subjected my son to this awful movie. I like Marky Mark. Not a good roll for him. Nor for Zooey. I like her too. I also like John L. I hate it for them that they were and for evermore linked to this highly marketed FLOP. This movie was so bad I would have rather watched The Village for a second time. My only hope is that some way some how this will get to M. Night Night Shamalalalala, and he will send me my money back not only for this movie but for every movie he has mad. I could have used that money for gas. What is he trying to do, be such a liberal that he can join Al "The Snore" Gore and get a Nobel Peace prize. Please help me. Mr. Nobel created dynamite. Where is the peace in that. Maybe it should be called the Nobel Piece prize. Let me finish with this last statement.I will never ever go and see anything that M. Night Night Shamalalalala is involved with. And I do mean PERIOD. The End.

title: Dire!
review:
I am a casual fan of 50's b-movie thriller and horror films and have seen a few real stinkers in my time, but also some true works of genius. A film can be bad and awkward and messy and still achieve greatness, the Happening did not.

Lord knows what they spent the $50,0000,000 budget on - there were virtually no effects, a short filming schedule, outside naturalistic location shoots, minimal extras and only a few big stunt shots. The actors (whilst good actors in my opinion) are hardly high-salaried Hollywood a-listers so I doubt it went on them.

The acting was bad. Stilted, awkward and in places downright amateurish. At points you could almost see the actors trying to be bad it was so bad. This style of acted bad acting just didn't work and it made the film feel really childish, rather than b-grade. I had images of little kids playing in the yard putting on a play or something, not b-movie! There was nothing amazing in the cinematography; the camera work did nothing to build a sense of tension nor intrigue for me, it was just really flat and uninteresting. In particular there was one shot with very little movement where the boom mic came down into the frame - really inexcusable and if it was done on purpose to make it look b-grade then they should have backed this up with other such touches.

The story you could scribble down on a post-it note. If this had been a 30 minute short film or something it may well have just about clawed enough substance together to be interesting but the film just went on and on and on and was punctuated by some truly awful and clanging expositions from characters throughout.

Basically this film could have been done really well. The concept is interesting but M Night it seems is not skilled enough to make a contemporary b-movie. As such the elements which attempted to make it so were heavy handed, misplaced and jarring throughout. If you want to see a fantastic b-movie then I suggest that you look to Grindhouse's Planet Terror and Deathproof - two genius contemporary homages to the genre.

Save your money, there's better stuff out right now.

title: wait for DVD, a few good moments, but not worth a trip to the cinema
review: i cannot understand the people who have voted 7-10 points for this... a really terrible script, some truly wooden acting from Zooey Deschannel, and even Wahlberg struggles with the material. As for the story ? an interesting premise, but no real commitment. The characters that are meant to be introducing some form of explanation are portrayed as such loons that you don't take the seriously - so how are we meant to take any of it seriously? Save yourself the trouble; watch 'The Birds' instead, it's basically the same story - couple in peril (cause unknown), driving around, trying to get away from the danger, but with a sappy kid thrown in for good measure. I've always been a big fan of the way The Birds ends, but with the happening i was just glad it was over.------------it does have an excellent score however, very creepy.----and ther are a few good scenes, i suppose...

title: Good Idea, Everything else just...kind of bad
review: I was waiting this movie since a saw the trailer, really waiting for it. The Friday the 13th of June was the premiere. The idea and plot the movie is really good, a new idea, but the acting is weird, the people is not so stupid to see that a virus or something is in the air and get our of their cars to breed fresh air. Well not everybody can do that, some thinks. This director is responsible for The Sixth Sense, and Signs, and The Village, and I enjoy those, and are really precious horror and sci fi films but "The Happening" is not going to be in my collection of GOOD HORROR AND SCI FI MOVIES. Anyway, Good idea, bad movie, not worse than others, but just bad.

title: Shyamalan Has Seem to Done it Again!
review:
Let's be honest here; Shyamalan hasn't really done anything spectacular since The Sixth Sense. I actually went into this movie having no prior knowledge of it besides my friend telling me it looked good. I was surprised when I saw that Shyamalan had written, produced, and directed this new feature film. I was also surprised by the fact in the first few minutes a woman stabbed herself in the neck. Yeah.

The first fifteen minutes or so were pretty decent. Entertaining for the most part, but after that, it was pretty downhill from there. I am a big fan of Mark Wahlberg, but through the entire 91 minutes of this film, he didn't seem quite to click with his character. All of the characters seemed quite out of place for one reason or another, and I think that can be blamed on the writing.

First of all, why did there have to be "another man?" Honestly, that was just unnecessary turmoil between the two main characters. Or perhaps it was just a plot to get Shyamalan a part without being too obvious. I absolutely HATED the parenting aspects in this movie. Okay, so there are people all over New York City killing themselves, a supposed terroristic attack, and Jess's mom decides that is the perfect time to leave her family and go get her a doll house?! And then Julian leaves his only daughter to find his wife, thinking, oh!, maybe she might still be alive. No. Why would you do that?! That just frustrated me to no end.

What also frustrated me was the lack of closure and answers to the never ending questions being asked. The movie just kind of ended. Kind of... The question I kept asking myself, my friend, and the movie screen (if it was supposedly the plants) is, "why now? Why not 20 years ago, or a decade from now?" They seemed to try to explain that in the news sequence, but even the person being interviewed had no idea. Of all of the Shyamalan movies I have seen, there has always been a plot twist, which has made most of his movies the only thing that makes them watchable.

The only thing that made The Happening watchable was the amazing direction. There is no doubt that Shyamalan is a fantastic director, but it seems like he has lost his knack for writing.

title: An attack on the senses!
review:
I've got to say this is quite possibly the worst film I've ever seen... and I've seen some awful films :) The acting was appalling; Wahlberg's performance has somehow lowered his career to an unbelievable level of torment and the dreadful attempt rest of the supporting cast was nothing more than an assault on the senses, in fact Deschanel's dramatic moments had me laughing out loud in the cinema, the casting director should be shot. The cinematography was dreadfully cheap and arduous to watch while the drawn out and characterless storyline lacked direction and conclusion. As far as Shyamalan's direction is concerned, I've seen stronger purpose and vision in school nativities.

In summary the film seems to be Shyamalan's momentary comment on mans effect on the planet strung into a miss-conjoined series of random events and slapped onto film, truly offensive to anyone with any sense of taste or fracture of intelligence.

You have to watch it to believe how bad it is!

title: "You just don't get it"
review:
I think the majority of the people that are rating this movie any better then a 5 think they are at some deeper level of understanding. I understand the movie fine, the plot, although possible, isn't feasible. The actors are all trying their best but the screen play and the lines they are forced to say sound that way. Nothing is realistic in portrayal of the expected emotions. The first half of the movie is playing on a dead suspense note because you and the actors (probably shamalan too) are trying to figure out what the hell they are gonna do with this movie. Then, just like it probably happened in the writing process, an answer just comes out of left field. We are expected to believe that what Wahlberg's character says is the truth, how he knew what was going on is beyond me. I must say though, the last third of this movie is entertaining. Once Shamalan gives up trying to keep up the poor suspense, there are some really interesting ideas to be played out in the world they have created for the viewer. Sadly, shamalan tests out two simple ideas of "what would probably happen".

(SPOILER FURTHER - STOP READING TO STAY SURPRISED)

The ending was incredibly cliché. I guess not having happy endings isn't the new hot thing, it is back to typically happy endings. (^^ SPOILER ^^)

I would wait for the DVD, or download it for free on the internet.

title: SPOILERs - for a bad movie....
review:
Save your money and your time.

I am a faithful fan of M. Night Shyamalan. When everyone trashed any of his other movies, I defended them. His movies have always told such different stories; and he tells them and films them well. So, where did he go wrong here? Oh yes, he went terribly wrong.

***Spoiler to follow*** It seems he paid millions of dollars to tell his viewers that the abuse that the earth is experiencing from human existence is making her angry and she's not going to take it any longer. And apparently, you don't want to see her angry.

****And more spoilers**** For me to really enjoy a film, the characters have to be believable and act the way real people would act in certain situations. I'm talking about the porch scene. This scene had more holes in it than the police put in Bonnie and Clyde. If a little hole in a car will let in enough air to affect a carload of people, how did these people have only shutters on their windows keeping out the "whatever"? People are jumpy in times of violence. Why did the kid keep pounding on the door? Why did Mark Wahlburg not grab the kid away? Better yet -- if a one person in a group of people standing on porch gets blasted with a shotgun, the whole group will generally freak and hit the ground or run. They will not hang around like a bunch of dorks waiting to be picked off like quail.

***Yet more whiny spoilers*** Okay, now my last rant... Why was the old lady crazy? He made such a point of her madness, but no hint or explanation. Why put it in the movie if you're not going to exploit her insanity? And that thing in the bed, it reminded me of Norman's mother. Was there a dead child under that mask? Don't put something in a movie that's so distracting but adds nothing to the movie. My point, I was distracted about the whys and what fors of the old lady that it detracted from the rest of the movie.

***Summary without any spoilers what-so-ever*** You've been warned. Don't believe the good reviews, listen to me. Wait for the DVD if you feel you really have to watch it, because it's not a big screen movie anyway. And if you've read the other reviews that trash the acting, they weren't wrong. :-\

title: Big disappointment.
review:
I think when the Director said to go in to enjoy a fun B movie, what he was really saying was, look, I know this film is awful. The acting is terrible and I'm sorry to say that because I like Mark Whalberg & John Leguizamo (although the latter probably gave the best bit of acting in the movie, though that's not saying too much).

As a big fan of The Sixth Sense, Unbreakable & Signs, it's hard to believe this piece of tripe is from the same director. I don't understand how some of these takes made it to the final cut of the movie. I reckon M Knight may have actually suffered the Happening while in front of the camera, making him disorientated to good acting. Yes, that's it, it's got to be. I I could go on and on but I won't. Absolutely awful, the end.

title: If only the script could have reflected Shyamalan's great ideas and imagination
review:
M. Night Shyamalan has a habit of making movies that look and sound genuinely interesting. The man clearly has an immense imagination, and it shows in the content he produces. But after the disappointment of The Village and the absolutely terrible Lady in the Water, I think I was one of the few that still held out hope for The Happening.

For good reason too.

As the title and promos suggest, The Happening revolves around an "event" that is making people in certain states in the US commit suicide. Originally pegged as the work of biological terrorists, everyone in the top most Eastern states attempts to flee, but the threat continues to wreck havoc on the populous. The film focuses on the plight of Elliot (Mark Wahlberg) and Alma (Zooey Deschanel) Moore, who are attempting to get out of Philadelphia with the daughter, Jess (Ashlyn Sanchez), of one of their friends.

Intriguingly, Shyamalan starts the film right off with the event beginning to take place in New York City, and barely breaks pace to breathe from there. Much like Cloverfield, this is a movie about running and survival. We are barely introduced to Elliot and Alma before they find out about what is going on, and attempt to leave Philadelphia. He leaves very little time to get to know anyone the two encounter (much less the pair themselves), and spend more time on how they are avoiding what looks like an inevitable death. And in this respect (minus some really bogged down exposition near the final third of the film), Shyamalan manages to recreate the breakneck thriller style we knew him for back when he was first starting out (so basically everything pre-Village).

He is also very effect in his use of violence. It is never too gruesome, but it is fairly graphic nonetheless. The film was advertised heavily as his first attempt at an R-rating, and he uses this minor hindrance to his advantage. But instead of being in-your-face about the violence, he builds up to it, hitting us with graphic images for only a few minor seconds (as opposed to the near pornographic depictions in "thrillers" like Saw IV and Hostel). He teases and shows only what he needs to, and then throws up the rest quickly in the cases that need it. And when he is not being ridiculous with his death sequences, it looks like he is making a genuine attempt at scaring the audience.

But unfortunately for Shyamalan, this is not the movie that will deliver him out of the rut he is in. If anything, he just made the hole a touch bigger.

For one thing, the storyline becomes ludicrously bad after the devastating effects begin to become apparent. It just seems like he cooked up the idea for the story, wrote an amazing opening, and then had no idea what to do afterwards. Everything that comes after the initial set-up either feels half baked, or feels haphazardly thrown together at the last minute. There is little commitment to these scenes, and there is even less in the cohesiveness of the story. The film is not long at all (and practically flies through its running time), but it feels like a lot of loose ideas Shyamalan had super-glued together in his script, than it does something he actually spent real time working on. I admire and like the reasoning behind the attacks, but Shyamalan only has the idea on display here, not the real workings of it.

Laughably bad death scenes aside, Shyamalan also needs to work on his dialogue. The Happening is nowhere near as dialogue heavy as any of his other scripts, and as a result, leaves a lot of room for error. I know that Wahlberg is a decent actor capable of greatness. But here, his character is worse than one-dimensional. Yes, we have the pathos for his character built up in nearly every scene, but his dialogue does not sound like that of any human being I have ever met in my life. If I am being faced with a life-altering decision, I doubt I would ever just say "Oh no", and not really mean it. If the audience is laughing at what your characters are saying, instead of being terrified of what may or may not be coming for them, something is most definitely wrong.

We know, at the very least, that Shyamalan can write decent dialogue. The man was not nominated for a writing Oscar simply based off the crazy ending people still talk about. So what happened here? Did he really set out to write the most wooden dialogue of the year? Did the studio really push him into the project based solely off the main idea that is expressed with the first ten minutes? Valid questions yes, but ones that will never be answered by the man himself.

Acting wise, the movie is nearly unwatchable. Wahlberg and Deschanel are the essence of mismatched pair, and not once is their relationship believable. I realize that some of their subplot involves the troubles they are having in their marriage, but it does not explain the fact that they never show any real desire for having liked each other in the first place. Sadly, Deschanel fairs even worse than Wahlberg's cardboard acting. I really liked some of her previous work, but here she looks confused for the majority of the film, and completely out of it for the rest.

The supporting cast is not much better. Sanchez does not even bother making an attempt at trying to look desperate, John Leguizamo gets next to no time to develop anything, and Betty Buckley's character is just too quirky for words.

The Happening has some great ideas, but no foundations to do anything with them. Shyamalan has the ability to make something of his movies, why not use it instead of giving us this half-baked garbage?

3.5/10.

title: Certainly not what I expected
review:
A deadly killer rises up out of nowhere, indiscriminately taking victims, shattering families and lives, and crippling the northeastern United States in a matter of hours. It has the power to cause even the most strong-willed of people to fall under its power, rendering lethal wounds unto themselves, decimating the population. New York, the city that never sleeps, falls silent. All that is heard is the sound of the rustling wind. It's an interesting premise, one that fits M. Night Shyamalan's thriller genre: take an everyday occurrence, something we take for granted, and make it the most terrifying thing imaginable. Make it a story of survival, of beating the odds, of the everyday man in a battle against nature itself. A story of human love triumphing over human nature, and of the will to live triumphing over the will to destroy life.

If only that had been the case.

Rather than taking that interesting premise and developing it into realizing its potential, Shyamalan's latest piece is instead a horror of poor writing, poor acting, and poor execution. Not even a promising cast, led by the usually watchable Mark Wahlberg, could save this train wreck of a film. Instead, the viewer is subjected to 91 minutes of watching Wahlberg and company wander aimlessly with looks of chronic constipation, sometimes running from their unseen enemy, sometimes hiding like small children playing a game of hide and seek. Just as laughably, too.

Wahlberg's character, Elliott, is a high-school science teacher who always sounds like he's talking to hyperactive five-year-olds. He is married to Alma, played by the normally enchanting Zooey Deschanel, but who in this film appears to be awakening from a drug-induced coma. Perpetually wide-eyed, you have to wonder if she really comprehends any of what's going on or if she's just following a game of cat-and-mouse. For two award-winning actors, these performances were very sub-par, quite on the same level as Hayden Christensen and Natalie Portman in the recent Star Wars movies, if not lower.

Elliott and Alma are joined by Elliott's best friend Julian (John Leguizamo) and his young daughter Jess as they try to escape the affected areas of attack. Julian eventually leaves them to find his wife, leaving Jess, who has the role of the eerily quiet, affected child in this volume of Shyamalan's work. (Reference: Haley Joel Osment in The Sixth Sense, and Abigail Breslin in Signs for comparisons.) They run through the countryside, trying to escape the wind, and although they're caught in it, they emerge unharmed.

That's another big issue I have with the film: believability. A deadly neurotoxin travels through the air, yet somehow Elliot and his crew, though being caught in it, are never affected. The neurotoxin is apparently unable to travel through cracks or holes, as evidenced by the numerous door slams and window locks in the movie. So many times, while watching this movie, I was reminded of the fright films that used to be shown in schools in the 1950s and 1960s, during the Cold War, which led hundreds of thousands of children to believe that hiding under a desk would protect you from a nuclear bomb. Were a neurotoxin to truly be released into the air, such as sarin or mustard gas, no amount of door slamming or towel-stuffing would be able to save you; even a fraction of a percentage of the toxin could travel through, and that would be enough to kill. That is a fact. What's sad is that this reality was shoved aside, asking the viewer to ignore all logic in favor of the story.

There is just so much wrong with this movie it's almost embarrassing. From the bad script, to the horrid acting, to the sluggish pace of the action, this certainly has to be Shyamalan's most forgettable film. Let's hope he's able to pick up the pieces from this disaster and make a comeback in his next movie.

title: Another poor showing
review:
OK, so M. Night Shymalan is back with his follow up to the truly god-awful 'Lady In The Water' which is something of an achievement in itself as I'm surprised anyone would give him a penny after that effort, but they did so here we are.

The premise of the film is based around a sudden biological attack in eastern America which causes its infected to commit mass acts of suicide. Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel are the couple on the run from the ever widening affected area. An interesting idea, you would assume, especially given the fancy trailer which has been doing the rounds for the last month or so.

However, there is a problem with The Happening. It is terrible in many ways, and by terrible i mean truly terrible. The first problem I had was the acting, particularly Wahlberg, who it seems was challenging himself to use only one vocal tone throughout the film, which as soon as he opened his mouth in his opening scene sounded absolutely ridiculous.

My second issue with the film was that it was like being locked in a room and coughed on repeatedly by a Greenpeace activist. Shymalan uses the entire film to get across an idea that he is teaching all of us uneducated people the error of our ways, well I'm sorry but the man is simply making himself look like a fool.

Thirdly the film was just plain ridiculous throughout, I mean for example, for anyone who has seen or plans to see this film, when you leave the cinema, please ask yourself: Who was controlling the wind? And one final thought, in the trailer there is a sequence in central park where a woman is looking around her as the woman next to her and all of the people in the park around her become infected with the 'virus' I ask you all, how is it that she does not get 'infected' at the same time? It just WOULDN'T HAPPEN.

So in conclusion 'The Happening' is an interesting concept which has been terribly hampered by a poor script, terrible acting and poor execution.

Rob Yeomans

title: I'm 26 And this is why I didn't like it
review:
I'm not entirely sure what age has to do with it? Is it an over-a-certain-age sort of film? It's a fifteen over here mate! In a Nut shell I think the whole Idea of the film was good, but they shouldn't have put the best part of the film on the adverts (which by the way seems to be the down fall of a lot of movies these days). It was too long winded and yet not really that long at all ... it goes to show something when you're sat watching a film for an hour and a half (or whatever it was) and you feel like you've been in there forever! Also, I thought that in most films you were supposed to feel a 'connection' of sorts with the characters ... not at all! There seemed to be no chemistry what so ever with the main characters and I believe the director tried far too hard to over use the 'shock tactics'. I was really looking forward to this film and was sorely disappointed! I honestly went to watch it thinking it would be great, I'm actually a fan of MNS!

WHAT'S HAPPENING???

title: There's Something Happening Here
review:
The Happening (2008) ***

I should admit that I have a predilection for disaster flicks. My fascination with natural (or something like it)disasters on celluloid has lead me to give generally favorable reviews to otherwise not very strong films. I debated myself whether to go with a 2.5 star review or the positive 3 stars. I at first chose 2 1/2. I slept on it, and decided that I was interested enough in The Happening to kick it up half a star. This review is one of guilty pleasure, and may be against my critical judgment.

This movie is preposterous, hammy, cheesy, corny and silly. Despite that, its execution is clever, and its premise is terrifying and, to me, extremely intriguing.

An unknown natural disaster is affecting the North Eastern United States, beginning in New York City and spreading throughout the region. Eliott (Mark Whalberg) is a high school science teacher, who lectures his students on the disappearance of bees all over the country. He's soon after pulled out of his class room and informed that there is some kind of "event" happening. This event causes people to become disorientated, attacks their motor skills as they stand still or walk backwards, then triggers them to kill themselves. Suicides come en masse and no one is safe - other than animals. Eliott, his wife Alma (Deschanel), his friend Julien (Leguizamo) and his daughter hop a train to Pennsylvania in hopes that this "event" wont' be happening there. Of course it moves there, and they're train is stopped in the middle of nowhere after it loses contact with everyone. Stranded, they attempt to flee west, where the event is not happening. Julien, frantic over his wife who is in Princeton, heads off to find her, leaving his daughter with Eliott and Alma, who are struggling to keep their marriage afloat.

The origins of the "event" are not really in the end officially determined - its proposed that the plants have released toxins as a self-defense mechanism; others propose its an army experiment gone awry, to which the government refuses to comment upon. The plant theory is the most precedent among the group. This of course equals trouble since they're stuck in the middle of nowhere surrounded by forestation.

The Happening goes to some pretty extreme, and pretty silly lengths to get its message across. Some of the suicides are so over the top they're comical - I'm still unsure if Shyamalan was in on this little joke or not. There are other moments which seem to be added for nothing more than shock value. The movie is rated R, and it earns it with a number of moments.

Shyamalan certainly has a strong talent for direction and photography - the film shows that definitely - but he is deeply lacking in the writing department. Tracing back his films, there has always been a weakness in his writing - dialogue is often contrived and expositional when its unnecessary, dating from the Sixth Sense to Signs (both films which I like very much). Poor writing hurts The Happening, and there a few cringe worth moments of foolishness. There are scenes where it sounds as if voices were dubbed in later to explain what we just saw in case we didn't pick up on it ourselves. There is a scene near the end that offers this method of clarification, where the problem isn't actually that it was explained through dialogue (it probably needed it) but the manner it was done. A shot cuts to outside of a house, and Eliott's voice cues to sum up what just happened in one exposition heavy sentence, end scene. I'm not suggesting that I necessarily have a better way to clear this up, but its done so poorly that I simply must be possible. What comes after that is also extremely clichéd and entirely tacked on for no reason other than sentimental posturing. This of course is the fault of the writing. Oh, and also get ready for people to say the word "happening" or some variation thereof at every chance.

Nevertheless, Shyamalan's directing chops are still sharp, and there are some very effective moments throughout the film. The manner of how people are affected is not only interesting, but awesomely eery and creepy. There is something about seeing a entire park of people stop dead in their tracks and become disorientated that his a nerve. There are moments in the film where when these people stand still that it almost seems to take on the creepiness of a similar scene in a far different film. Alain Resnais's Last Year at Marienbad has a famous scene in which two people talk on balcony overlooking a garden at a hotel. The people in the garden stand entirely still as they cast shadows but plants and other fixtures cast none. I suspect that if you know this shot, it will make the scenes in The Happening that much creepier. The pacing of the movie (which has a fairly short run time) has been attacked as "too slow" and "nothing happens." I actually thought the pacing of the film was one of its strongest assets. It takes its time, and I enjoy that in a film.

From what I've said here I'm really not justifying giving this a positive review, however its the premise of the film, which I think is so deeply interesting and truly scary, that keeps this afloat, but may also damn it at the same time. I will say it here and now that I am disappointed, and frankly if it came out tomorrow that The Happening was being remade, I would jump to see it get a do-over. Either way, I was still entertained by this one.

title: Booooooooooooo
review:
Wow. That is all I can say. Immediately following the end of the movie, I gave a different one word reaction.

I loved 6th Sense. I loved Signs. Unbreakable and The Village were kind of cool with a certain amount of creep factor and some decent acting. But this stinker is possibly the worst piece of garbage to ever come out of a major studio.

Do you hear that? I think it sounds like the end of Marky Mark's career. I am a huge Mark Wahlberg fan, but he seemed to be stuck in some feminine, bad-acting mode that should have him in Days of Our Lives, not on the big screen.

The acting was terrible. The script was terrible. The character development was forced and contrived. The only scary part was a crazy old woman that they sort of just stuck in the film near the end as they probably realized just how boring of a movie they were making.

I mourn the death of Marky Mark's acting career. He coulda been a contenda.

And as for M. Night Shyamalan, his movies seem to be getting worse instead of better.

I WANT MY MONEY BACK!

title: Please wait until DVD is out to watch...
review:
Truly the worst of Shy's films, it hurt me to watch. I was perhaps expecting the best thing since sliced bread and therefore had further to fall... but why do i still feel like i'm falling?? The acting was souless, unbelievable, and unfortunately was always going to fail with poor direction, editing and script.

Please don't waste your time and money in the cinema, the film probably had it's merits but i was bored after 30 mins, nothing of any relevance happened after the first 15 mins... watch that much and it's intriguing, watch more and wait for something to happen, and wait, and wait, and wait... and then get scared once... hmmm...

Perhaps too simple? I'd like to see a directors cut produced that maybe adds something to it, in it's current form it doesn't feel finished and feels like the director got bored after 30 mins and decided to try a different film!

title: Not even an interesting failure
review: Once upon a time, I was a fan of 'The Sixth sense'. I loved the tone, the pace and the craftsmanship. I saw some of these elements in the others movies that 'Night' made, but I feel the urge to file most of his work under 'humbug'. I'm don't want to bash his films, if I give a filmmaker two hours of my time I want his films to be good. The 'Lady in the water' was a failure, but at least a stylish failure:he tried to do something different and had to pay a price for the risk. I respect that effort. 'The Happening' travels a very familiar road: it's another disaster movies. After 'Cloverfield', 'The Mist' or maybe even 'War of the worlds' comes another tale of people who try to avoid a haunting fate. This time, sadly to say, it's emotionally flat, mannered, empty and not even stylish. Not subtle in any way. The acting style wasn't working. I love Zooey, but here it seemed as if she's been eating mushrooms all the time. Wahlberg can be sharp, like in 'The Departed', but his line-reading seems uninspired, flat. The stilted acting style feels too cerebral. The way people react to all the horrible events the witness doesn't feel real, there's a lack of internal logic. There are some scary moments, but when it starts raining construction workers the whole cinema was shaking with laughter. The idea is GOOD but the overacting is horrendous. And then that final scene.... an attempt to a 'twist ending'? I was angry with this lazy film. I don't know if I even by another ticket for a film by M. Night Charlatan.

title: a very B-rate film
review: I was shocked at how poorly made this film was. There are high school kids who, given the same amount of money, would have made a better film. The idea behind the film is plausible. I was intrigued by it. But 'The Happening' totally fails to live up to its promise. The acting is bad. The special effects are horrible. And when it tries to be 'Hitchcock', it's laughable. This is a movie you can sit through. It didn't make me walk away. But there are parts of this movie that seem like a spoof of thrillers... only they're not meant to be spoofs. For example, there is a scene where supposed home video of a bloody scene. It's a joke. You look at it and go, 'they've got to be kidding'. And when a car rams into a tree, a dummy goes flying out the front window about 50 feet, and it looks totally fake. All you can do is laugh, and say 'how could a movie have gone so wrong?'

title: What "Happened" to Shyamalan?
review:
The only thing I wondered after watching The Happening was what "happened" to M. Night Shyamalan. I'll come right out and say it: this movie was bad. It wasn't scary, suspenseful, thought-provoking, or anything else that it tried to be.

The most frustrating thing about the movie is M. Night Shyamalan, because the biggest fault in the movie was poor direction. He's already proved to the world that he can be an awesome director. It's not like the potential is there--it's already been proved! It is baffling, then, to see how this movie can be made by the very person who brought the Sixth Sense. Yes, I know, people claim that you can't compare this movie to his previous works. Yes, I can. That movie was really good. This movie was really bad.

Let's start with the acting. It wasn't there. The entire movie, I felt an emotional disconnect because I did not feel that the characters were actual people. They were just people staring off in the distance, delivering poorly written lines, not even showing a shred of panic, nervousness, or even more than a slight concern that people all around them are killing themselves! Mark Wahlberg is not the greatest actor, but he's not a bad actor. Obviously, he's not (insert Academy Award winning actor's name here) and he can't be compared to said person. I'm glad that he's moved on from his rap career as Marky Mark, but films like this aren't helping his future. His acting was corrugated cardboard. I felt like I was watching early William Shatner. The supporting cast was equally unconvincing. Dang it, show some emotion, the world is ending! The only good acting was found in John Leguizamo, and *SPOILER* he croaked 20 minutes into the movie!
