The script was bogus. The dialog was unconvincing. People don't talk like that. The first few lines in the movie made me groan for being cheese whiz, but I dismissed it, only to be bombarded by more and more. It was just simply unbelievable.

The plot was flimsy. After the first scene in the movie, I was able to guess how the rest of the movie was going to unfold. Unfortunately, I was correct and had to spend the next two hours watching it unravel. *SPOILER*

As soon as they zoomed in on the trees in Central Park, I thought to myself, "Hmm, I bet this has something to do with the trees. Don't tell me Shyamalan's jumping on the bandwagon and preaching to us about how we need to be more eco-friendly..." What do you know! It turns out to be killer trees! Welp, I know this isn't politically correct, but why not just torch them to the ground? OR, why not just go to a place where there AREN'T trees, like the desert!? Drive to Arizona or New Mexico! The whole sub-plot with the protagonist's marriage problems is fluff. It's added to add depth to their characters, but it doesn't pull it off. There's no chemistry between Wahlberg and Deschanel.

Walking out of the movie theater, my sick and twisted mind thought, "Well, if the movie succeeded in one thing, it made me relate to the characters. Except with them, it was the TREES that made them want to kill themselves...I'm just left with an awful movie."

Shyamalan, there's still a little shred of hope that your next movie will be your redemption! You can do it! Just don't look for me in the movie theater--I'm still out of pocket from the money I wasted on this flop.

title: An M. Night Shyamalan Apologist No More
review:
I have been an M. Night Shyamalan apologist for a while now. Everyone loved "The Sixth Sense." Most people loved "Unbreakable." Then it starts to slip. I loved "Signs" and really loved "The Village" (that one's theme of "the good old days" hit close to home for me), but some didn't. I didn't like "Lady and in the Water," but my wife did. I figured it just wasn't my cup of tea (the whole fairy tale thing), and I thought Night had too big a part (he's not a terribly good actor). But it had a good concept and some quality actors and some very good performances so there was some forgiveness from me. With this movie, I am no longer coming to his defense. OK. I know he doesn't need me to, but I'm looking for much better from him next time out.

I was a little generous and gave this title a 5 out of 10 because the first half of the movie was actually pretty good! The first 30-45 minutes were tense and kept me on edge as any good suspense movie should. It built in some questions as to what was causing the "happening," and caused me to jump in my seat a few times. There were some okay performances from Wahlberg and Deschanel and a couple of great performances from Leguizamo and Buckley (she reminded me of Kathy Bates in Misery a little with her out-of-touch intensity). I was also very impressed by the performance from Jeremy Strong as Private Auster, and Spencer Breslin caused a disagreement between myself and my wife--it was hard to recognize him since he grew up some and did not overact as usual! But the second half of the movie just fizzled. There were very few tense moments since we knew what was coming every time the wind blew and someone stared into space and took 2 steps backwards. And the explanation for the cause came too early in the film so the questioning pretty much ended. There was no real climax in the story. Two people standing in a wind-blown field is not very exciting (and their romance was even more boring). It would have been acceptable for the pre-attack warning to be wind-blown grass for a low budget, independent film, but Night used ILM for his special effects. ILM!! And wind blowing through the trees was the best they could do? Then in the end it was just a long, "green" environmentalist guilt trip. Now, maybe my right-leaning political viewpoint taints my feelings a little, but who wants to sit in a movie theater and be guilt-ed by a suspenseful thriller--especially when there was very little suspense or thrill? (By the way, it takes a lot of electrical energy, fuel, and petroleum-based film to make a movie, but that's an entry for a different type of website.) And the worst thing? I sometimes use my watch to time the actual running time (without credits) of a film. It felt like hours and it was only 86 minutes! Unbelievable from Night--I'm usually riveted throughout any of his movies.

Night, you're my boy, but you really missed bad with this one!

title: Scary Movie 5: The Happening - Funniest Yet!
review:
M. Night Shymalan has made the funniest entry in the Scary Movie series by keeping the visual gags to a minimum and ramping up the situational and verbal comedy aspects that the past four have left out. Scary Movie 5: The Happening has everything a great parody movie needs a wonderful opening scene that sets us up for what will surely be the funniest 90 minutes of Summer '08. The reaction shots from the cast rival Jason Bateman and Micahel Cera's best work on "Arrested Development." The whole production looks stunning and Night's eye for composition are still some of his strongest points, but it's the way he handles his actors that really caught me. In a bit of inspired comedic casting Mark Wahlberg is our hero through this canon of classic Hitchcock motifs and like Charlie Sheen before him, Wahlberg turns in some of his best work since Boogie Nights. You can see and hear the joy in the actor's voice as he spits out comedy gold at every turn. The "You should care more about science" exchange may go down as one of the great moments in comedy history right next to 'Who's on first?' and the drop off scene in "The Big Lebowski." The death scenes are some of the best in the series even topping the stabbing of Carmen Electra's implants. The 'follow the gun scene' has some great moments from the extra blood spurting that is obviously a nod to "Ichii the Killer" and "Kill Bill" even the sound effect is different for each successive shot from the same gun, possibly an 'in' joke referencing the grindhouse horror of old. Making the villain 'wind' is Mr. Night Shymalan's finest bit of writing since Sam Jackson's reveal as the mastermind in 'Unbreakable.' I had thought Night had run out of ideas after his last two efforts but in the comedy/ satire genre Shymalan has found his true calling and one can only hope he chooses to continue on this path. I loved Scary Movie 5: The Happening and would recommend it to anyone looking to laugh and cry tears of joy as you watch a cinematic masterpiece that I will be proud to place on my DVD shelf. Thank you Mr. Night Shymalan you have returned with great success, let's hope you return for 6.

Scary Movie 5: The Happening receives: 94% out of 100

title: More like The Crappening
review:
The previews, rated R hype and actor appearances on talk shows really made me want to see this film, I was actually excited.

I couldn't have been more disappointed. The acting was terrible by absolutely everyone involved in the film (big or small roles); Mark simply cannot play a good guy in this context. I love Zooey, but she was on something in this film - like she was doing interpretive improv in the theme of a space cadet. Maggie Gyllenhaal or Kate Beckinsale would have been a far better choice for Alma and any actor in the world would have been better than Leguizamo.

The premise and resulting story could have been so great for this, as unusual as it was. The scene when they are trying to outrun the wind actually had several of us in the theater laughing out loud. They abandoned the crazy, nursery, hippie guy too early, he should have been more involved in the plot. Also, at no time did anyone suggest heading for a "concrete jungle" which I believe would be paramount to this plot. The film was shot at in the farmlands to a miserable degree and should have included some alternate shots or even side-stories in the city areas. Mark pointing out the fact that the two major outbreaks started in parks hurt to watch, as if anyone at that point hadn't figured the entire movie out.

Ultimately, the supposedly R-rated scenes are OK to watch and would be worth it to see when it comes out on video - don't waste your time seeing it in the theater.

title: Pointless
review:
This movie was terrible

First of all, there was absolutely no introduction, and within the first 5 minutes or so you have already seen the whole trailer. I don't have much to say about it. What there was for a plot line was not very good. It seemed almost like a rip off of 28 days later, only they are not even conclusive about what is killing the people. Then the end once again, shows the even happening somewhere else, leaving the movie producers free to make another crappy movie. The only enjoyment that came from this movie, was making fun of it. Thats about it. It seems like the movie producers were thinking they hadn't made a movie in awhile, so lets make one real quick and get it out there.

title: Trash.
review:
This movie isn't worth the admission fee to see in Theatres. It's poorly directed, poorly written, and the acting is very wooden and unbelievably fake.

Potential Spoiler Alert Beyond This Point:

A brief look at the feeling of this movie is that it attempts to establish a serious and frightening mindset right from the start, but will randomly throw in light-hearted situational comedy involving Mark Wahlberg and Zooey, or some random characters they meet. The movie does not really take any direction, there is no goal met by any characters in this movie, and besides a lack of climax - the movie also ends abruptly. I will not go into details about this movie beyond this, other then to say that I hope you have a good imagination and love nature; It may be the only two reasons you could like this movie. And Mark Wahlberg's acting certainly didn't help the movie save any face.

A 4/10 at best.

title: Disappointing
review:
First, I want to make my history with M. Night and his films very clear: The Sixth Sense: 9/10 (fantastic film, Shyamalan's best in my opinion) Unbreakable: 8.5/10 (great performances by Bruce Willis and Samuel Jackson, another Shyamalan hit) Signs: 7.5/10 (intense film, thriller throughout, strong suspense towards the end, but lacked some creative elements) The Village: 7/10 (mediocre at best, not very thrilling, suspense is slow moving and doesn't culminate well) Lady In The Water: 5/10 (just a poor film, I enjoy Shyamalan and his work so I gave him a lot of slack on this movie, but it was a pure disappointment and wasn't even entertaining to watch)

Now, let's move on to the reason I am here: The Happening (4/10). Clearly, Shyamalan's biggest disappointment thus far in his career. It was simply a bad movie. Some of the most entertaining (mostly because they were laughable) parts were people committing suicide in the most gruesome yet comedic ways. I won't go into detail to avoid spoilers, but some parts in the movie were so pathetically done and so unrealistic that it shed a shameful light on the entire film. I made the mistake of coming into this movie with high expectations, because the movie had a good premise, and I thought it was M. Night's time to shine again, after his stumbles with Lady in the Water and The Village. Also, I expected a performance out of Mark Wahlberg that I didn't exactly get. Some of the dialogue that his character was forced to say took him out of his element and made him look childish while acting. Mark is a great actor so it was a let down to see him be involved with such an awful film. His performance was the best that he could have done, given the feeble script and odd nature of his character. All in all, the film was casted well but not performed well, and the premise for the movie had some potential but wasn't executed. A huge disappointment from Shyamalan. Hopefully my ratings of his movies won't climb slowly downhill as they are appearing to now.

I will warn you once, don't see this film, and if you do treat it as a comedy.

title: Smart Idea.......... Terrible Delivery
review:
I was hoping for a good movie. I was hoping for a good movie from M. Night Shyamalan, who I know is capable of a great movie, but in whom I have been disappointed with lately. I loved "The Sixth Sense", and thought "Signs" was pretty good. As of right now, I am not sure if "The Happening" or "Lady In The Water" is my least favorite. And unlike his other movies, M. Night Shyamalan doesn't have a role in "The Happening", which makes me wonder if even he was disappointed with this movie.

The idea was good and original, and I honestly feel like it could have been a great movie. There are many things that this film presents to the viewer to make them think, and in the end form their own opinion. Ideas that are indeed scary, and not that far fetched. Things that are hard to imagine, but not really that unrealistic..... which makes the "Ideas" in the movie truly scary!!! However, in my opinion, the movie didn't capitalize on its own ideas. And the movie didn't even come close to capturing the tension and terror that would go along with its own idea/ story.

(Start Spoilers) Basically after years of abusing our planet with pollution, etc, ... nature takes the offense. Basically the movie talks about how plants can produce toxins to defend against threats. Plants finally determine that humans are the environments biggest threat and starts to produce a toxin that targets the humans. The story goes on to explain that humans have a genetic chemical/ programing that makes us want to live and survive. However the toxins that the plants are producing, alter that "programming", so instead of wanting to live..... we are programed to want to die. So once exposed to the toxins, we become confused and end with us committing suicide. (End Spoilers)

Like I said, really creative (but not unrealistic) idea. Something that would be devastating and truly scary!!!

But unfortunately, other than the basic idea, this movie has nothing. It is not scary. It seemed undeveloped. The movie seemed very stretched out, for the content that was made for it. (In current form, would have made a better 1hour episode for Twilight Zone or something like that.) The acting was horrible. I get that they were trying to be "real people" in a "real situation" and not actors in a movie. But even cutting some slack for that reason, I didn't buy them in their roles.

Sorry, I wanted to love this. But in all honesty, this movie was painful for me to sit through.

title: Horrible. To Easy for M. Night Shyamalan!
review:
It had some good points, but out of it all it was a waste of 3 bucks. >.<

It wasn't as developed as we've been expecting from M. Night Shyamalan All this talk about it being his first rated R film was a bunch of . It certainly didn't deserve an R rating.

It was just a little too plain, I mean the hints in the movie as to what was causing the problems were just a little too profound I mean come on! It was mainly just a movie for people who don't really want to have to think or have any sort of emotional attachment to any of the characters except Jess, and that relationship is barely there at all.

My recommendation if you want to see a scary movie go see the strangers, or something like that because this wasn't any where near up to par.

title: Intriguing plot, abysmal execution.
review:
OK, I was more excited for this movie than I have been for any movie in a long time. I was practically jumping with joy going to the theatre. I love most of M. Night's work ... 6th, Village, etc.

This movie did not live up to my expectations. I'm the kind of guy that can forgive a lot as long as the plot is fairly decent and the acting good.

The Happening has some decent acting, but it seemed like the lead actors were sleepwalking through their parts.

Gore for gore's sake (no I'm not talking Al Gore, BTW), does not impress me. How many different and creative ways can we kill ourselves? That's the most imbecilic part of the movie.

And the plot? The concept is intriguing but the execution was dreadful.

This movie was preachy throughout and attempted to make philosophical points rather than just an interesting movie that we all would enjoy.

I'm looking forward to M. Knight's next movie (whatever it may be) because I know there is more greatness to be shared. This one, unfortunately, earns a solid 2.5 thumbs down.

title: absolutely horrendous
review:
Allow me to provide some background information on my relationship with the films of M. Night Shyamalan: I adored "The Sixth Sense" and still think of it as one of the best films of 1999 and one of the best supernatural thrillers in ages. "Unbreakable" was a fascinating take on the superhero genre. I loved parts of "Signs" to bits and consider the sequence in the basement towards the end of the film one of the finest examples of suspenseful build-up in recent film history. I even liked "The Village" and could easily dismiss "Lady in the Water" as a mere misfire. I was greatly anticipating "The Happening", especially as it seemed to be echoing one of my favorite guilty pleasures- the paranoid 70's sci-fi thriller.

Let's get one thing out of the way- "The Happening" is unbelievably, impossibly, ridiculously, hilariously, inconceivably bad. Normally I would refuse to rate any film that had any good scenes or that was well-directed less than four out of ten, but "The Happening" has to have one of the worst scripts among recent big-budget Hollywood films. It's absolutely shocking how retarded the logic behind this is and how poor so much of the dialogue is. This script began as "The Green Effect", a tremendously poor (trust me, I read parts of it) script by Shyamalan that was soundly rejected and eventually reworked into "The Happening". Having seen the critical reaction to "The Happening" prior to going into the film I found myself pleasantly surprised by basically the first thirty, forty minutes of the film. It was nothing special but it had something going for it, Shyamalan's direction was top-notch, and Wahlberg was playing the sort of goofy science teacher I'd loved (and loved to hate on occasion) in high school.

Then the descent began. The bulk of this film is some of the most hilariously awful crap produced by a talented filmmaker since Schaffner's "Sphinx". Shyamalan, who was using close-ups and steadicam shots to frankly brilliant effect early on, begins to use the same shots to comical effect. There is one painfully, painfully long close-up of Mark Wahlberg pleading for time to think and then calling for his group to 'keep ahead of the wind' that is up there with Nicolas Cage in "The Wicker Man" in terms of hilariously awful acting. That scene may very well be the turning point in the film, with Wahlberg's acting becoming more ridiculous by the second, culminating in a performance that essentially wipes from memory all his tremendous recent achievements as an actor. I don't blame Wahlberg for this, I blame Shyamalan. Wahlberg claims Shyamalan tried to force him into real paranoia so his performance would work better. What happens here (no pun intended) is that Wahlberg ends up looking amazingly uncomfortable for the last hour of this thing and struggles to deliver any reasonable line deliveries.

Okay, I do have to credit Zooey Deschanel for making this movie watchable. Besides being amazingly, ridiculously gorgeous she is a fine actress and creates a sympathetic character (and a fairly well-drawn one at that- one of the few pros in Shyamalan's script). There's also the score: oh my it's gorgeous. Seriously, ignore this film and just buy the score CD by James Newton Howard- it's brilliant.

"The Happening" starts out well but ends up being an absolute embarrassment. I was prepared for a mediocre offering- perhaps a misguided effort such as "Lady in the Water". I was not expecting a disaster on the level of "The Happening". Its last forty minutes and especially its last ten minutes or so are among the worst I have seen in a long time.

Have you ever wondered if it was possible for a film to go from enjoyable to absolutely horrendous in the space of ten or fifteen minutes? "The Happening" is proof that it can, pardon the (intentional) pun, happen. Evren Buyruk from USA

title: If you like Mark Wahlberg, then don't see this terrible film!!
review:
Marky Mark, please choose your movies better next time. This film was absolutely terrible, not scary at all, and it made me think question my obsession with Mark Wahlberg. And besides Mark's bad acting, all the other actors were just as bad. The dialogue was ridiculous. There was only one actor who really stuck out in my mind and that was the ginger kid, but he died half way through and by then everyone in the theater just wanted the movie to end.

I like Signs and some other films by M. Night Shamamalan, but this has got to be by far his worst film to date.

People didn't kill themselves because of the plants, it was because they watched this movie.

If I could rate it a 0 out of 10, then I would have. It was that bad.

title: What Did I Just See?
review: Excuse me? Was that movie a thriller, comedy, horror, action etc? I'd have to say comedy because this movie had me laughing all the way through. The acting was inexplicably horrible, the writing was sub par and the sentimental moments between the main characters were ridiculous and unnecessary. Mark Wahlberg's performance was so bad that I thought he was doing it on purpose and the woman playing alongside him was probably even worse. I remember near the end all you could hear were people snickering at out of place lines and poor delivery when the director was obviously going for something more serious. The only reason I gave this movie 3 stars is the story. It was a solid conflict and it kept your attention throughout. Yet the ending was pathetic and predictable and left the viewer waiting for more. This movie wasn't scary, thrilling, or action packed. It was mainly comedic but I'm pretty sure that's not what the director was going for.

title: I liked it. Historical value.
review:
I should disclaim my opinion of this film by first saying that I have been characterized as a "movie whore," but I liked it. I am a big fan of Mark Walberg, although I'm not sure I spelled his name right, and I think he did a great job in the film. There was one scene in the film where I screamed so loud I scared myself a second time. I'm such a pussy.

I did not like the hysteria that reared its head in the film (briefly) about nuclear power, as I happen to think that it is the cleanest answer to all of our energy problems.

Twenty years from now, when people look at the environmental hysteria of our day, I think this film will be seen as a perfect example of it.

Still I liked it.

title: This was horrible
review:
It really was. I was so excited to see it. The previews looked great and I was hoping it was going to be good. But..it wasn't. As much as I love Mark, he was awful in this. The acting and dialogue were horrible. The love between Mark and his wife at the end was corny and cheezy. I thought the whole movie was predictable. The only good thing about the movie, were how the people killed themselves. That's it, and there were only a few scenes lasting a few seconds. Then you had the very last scene which suggested a possible sequel. I won't watch it. I'm sure most people wont watch it if they do come out with a second one. I'm done with M. night shyamalan.

Don't watch it. Not even on DVD. Love you Mark, I'll still watch your movies, but this was just bad.

title: unclear what's happening in this movie
review: Elliot Moore is an innovative Philadelphia science teacher whose marriage is on the rocks. That's the least of his worries however when a mysterious endemic strikes the northeast region of the United States, causing erratic behavior, violence, and even death among the general population. Along with a group of survivors, it's a race against time to try and make it to safety before their fates are quickly sealed. M. Night Shyamalan's latest showing is interesting, startling, unusual, but also frustratingly uneven; from one point of view it's a supernatural tale of human survival, from another it's a domestic exploration of love and reconciliation, and from yet another it's a deliberately distant, ambiguous story thread designed to pull viewers along before they realize there's really no point. A miscast Wahlberg tries gallantly to pull it off with a straight face, while some of his co-stars seem to be reading off of cue cards. At times serious, at times unintentionally silly (?) it plays mostly as a mixed bag. "Different" would probably be the most accurate description. **

title: Not great, but has some good moments
review:
From what I understand, M. Night Shyamalan is a huge Hitchcock fan. What struck me right away about "The Happening" is how much it reminds me of Hitchcock's "The Birds." The theme of people caught up in the mayhem when nature inexplicably runs amok is common to both films. Modern man wants to think we are always in control and are pretty darn smart. So when suddenly faced with a deadly situation that seems to originate with nature, strong feelings of despair and impotence surface. The realization that we simply can't win a fight with mother nature quickly sinks in and we are left feeling very small. Conveying this sense of despair is what "The Happening" attempts.

While "The Happening" is not a great film like "The Birds," there are many similarities. I wonder how a film like "The Birds" would be reviewed today. Plodding? Lacking action? I agree with Roger Ebert's review. This film is not a blockbuster action flick, and anyone who can't sit still for five minutes without a car chase or explosion, will probably be bored. But if you appreciate a film that doesn't rely on special effects to move the plot along, this film is worth a look.

I do agree with some of the negative reviews pointing out the weakness of some of the dialog in the film. (I especially did not care for the man who owned the plant nursery, who first guessed that plants might be behind the problems. His character really made no sense and was almost cartoonish.) I also agree that the message behind the film could be a bit more subtle, although I was not that put off by it. But the reviewers who are taking issue with the plot may be missing the point. How many films of this genre have a plot that really stands up to scientific scrutiny? The fun of these films is in the suspense and if throwing logic out the window for 91 minutes helps the fun, then I'm all for it.

This is not a great film, but if you are a M. Night Shyamalan fan, I think it is a step back toward his earlier promise and is worth seeing. You might want to wait to see it on DVD. I don't think it will lose much on the small screen.

title: The Happening is good but do not have your expectations sky high when you go for watching this movie.
review:
I watched the movie "The Happening" today. The plot seemed really interesting - Nature deciding to take revenge on Human Race for all exploitations that has been subjected on them by Humans. Its high time for humans to learn to preserve and respect the nature. The movie was OK but Mr Shyamalan could have sent across a really strong message if the open ended questions were answered and not left for user interpretations. However I really liked Mark's acting skills. The pace of the movie was OK.

I will recommend you to watch this movie but do not have your expectations sky high.

title: M. Night once again does his best to not dole out cookie cutter films...
review:
Love him or hate him, his movies have a unique signature upon them that definitely separate him from the dozens of movies release each month from Hollywood. As a matter of fact, Hollywood apparently has run out of ideas remakes upon remakes, and now worse with movies like The Departed, Strangers, The Ring, and Bangkok Dangerous they're down to ripping off European/Asian movie directors for their ideas.

This time M. Night strikes back with notable differences from all his other movies. First of, M. Night usually forgoes direct violence and gore and replaces it Hitchcock styled atmosphere/sound over gore. Looks like studios are tired of this and forced his hand. Interestingly enough, even with the added gore and violence, there was still a great deal of that "atmosphere" utilized to heighten everyone's awareness. A good deal of work was put in the sound fx to also put some flavor into several key moments.

Like all M. Night's movies, there are SERIOUS flaws in The Happening. Bad acting across 4-5 scenes you simply cannot deny, just really dry delivered lines. A surprising number of no name actors is probably the reason for this, which leads to the music of the film. I haven't seen music this bad in a film this decade. It sure seems as if studios are cutting M. Night at the knees financially. Lastly, this blame will fall solely on the director, the pacing was a tad uneven, abrupt in some places that failed to achieve the desired effect I would say.

Despite it's flaws, the plot and premise is quite interesting, even if it's a bit far-fetched. Once again I found myself smiling throughout the movie and enjoy this movie as if it were one of those old 50s B&W goofy horrors about a giant brain eating up half the planet. Shyamalan doesn't explain the plot in total detail, leaves you with several clues as to what triggered the main events and how the main characters dealt with those events. If you like weird sci-fi with dashes of brilliant horror footage, this is your movie. If you like M. Night movies not because they're full of action and violence, but because they're interesting and different.. you'll love The Happening. However if you have ADD, adrenaline junkie, or hyper-critical in your films.. you'll hate this film steer away.

title: It's better to think of this as a comedy, you'll have a better time.
review: Making the plants and trees the antagonists, hmmm. At least its original thought. But thats its only redeeming quality. Once it was revealed that it was the plants that is causing the panic it became a comedy for me and I had a pretty good time laughing at all the ridiculous attempts at creating fear. Its especially funny when Mark starts talking to the ficus tree like its going to suddenly jump at him! The isolated old woman actually did a good job at being creepy and made me jump. Oh, and no ending. It weirdly just stops. Three stars because of the score, it's the best part of the film.

title: Cheese and Crackers!
review: Mediocre Acting and a Questionable Plot make this a 'meh' sort of movie. I enjoyed some of the suicide scenes as they were disturbing and unusual. But as for the overall review, I think this could have been much better.

title: Horrible, UNbelievably horrible and so stupid!
review: I cannot even believe how stupid this movie is! Creepy and worthless! Basically just a bunch of people killing themselves in different ways!

title: my notes
review: Watched it when it first came out and it was one of the worst movies i've ever seen (1 viewing)

title: I'm speechless...
review:
What a dud! But I'm used to it coming from that director. I should've read the start credits more carefully. The story is interesting, but just like other people said. The execution is awful. And M. Knight Whatever, is mostly to blame for it. He just can't showcase his script and actors. The directing is appalling. I stopped counting the number of times I giggled or laughed hysterically at all the unintentionally funny moments in the movie. Betty Buckley's guest starring being the part where I completely lost it. The rest is just as embarrassing, but that was it for me. There is some good gore (?), but I would've rather have had a more compelling directing/acting, with actors that don't quote stupid lines, with eyes like a dead fish (Zooey, this is for you). Mark Wahlberg was the weakest lead ever. And the rest of the cast was either underused or badly used.
With a mystery that is literally going nowhere. The movie ends just as awkwardly as it went on for an hour or so. And the end credits start rolling.

title: Another great film
review:
I love M. Night Shyamalan. He's a brilliant writer/director and I've been so impressed with his unique ideas or twists on previously attempted genres. This movie, however, I didn't really enjoy. Though, it is not for the same reasons as most other reviewers have stated.

The movie delivered no one-liners, no stand up acting from any particular actor/actress, and no real climax. Those are the good things. It felt real. The characters reacted in a very human way, no heroes, the lines didn't feel scripted. It felt as though the person sitting next to me would react the same way. Amazingly realistic. Almost too realistic. But, MNS has always been one to push the boundaries.

What I did not like was MNS's finding his way into the box of the environmentalist. Because of the huge "green" push and global warming phenomenon, we've seen a large rush of that in Hollywood. I thought MNS was better than that. Though the thoughts are underlying and he does a fantastic job of presenting the issue in a different light, we still see the "humans as pests" ideas and the overpopulation theories at work. I don't like the boxed up Shyamalan. Nothing against environmentalist but we've heard and seen enough of it. Keep it out of my thrillers.

The best part of the whole movie and probably the biggest reason to see it is the score. Brilliant. Simply stunning. The music made the movie. Had the score not been as wonderful, the movie would not be worth seeing.

Overall 7/10 in my book.

title: What is happening?
review: Saw this film a few years ago. I just now saw it again. I thought seeing it again should change my score. All it did was remind me of Bird Box. About an invisiable entity that makes people crazy and then kill themselves. I rated the recent Sandra Bullock thriller higher than this version of the film. Although the two films are not related the premise is the same and seeing The Happening again, did not make me change my mind. Sorry!

title: Really?!
review: If horrific acting and a very predictable plot (and lines) is your thing then this is the movie for you. If I could give it a negative star rating I would.

title: One of the most hilariously unintentionally bad movies i have seen!
review:
This movie is hilarious. It is actually so bad, its good. The acting is absolutely dreadful! Especially from Zooey Deschanel! M. Night Shaymalan Has an extremely varied career as a director!

He has made two amazing movies (the sixth sense, and signs), as well as three OK movies (split, the village, and the visit), and three absolutely horrible movies (the happening, the last airbender, and after earth). I think this is very disappointing, since we saw in his early career that he really can make amazing movies with signs and the sixth sense, then he come with movies like the last airbender which is widely regarded as one of the worst movies of all time!

Lets go back to this movie! This movie has so many extremely stupid and dull moments that makes me laugh so hard! One example is when some of the survivors find bodies hanging while driving on a road, and after we see this, a girl in the car screams and freaks out so hard! Even though she obviously wouldve seen this before we saw the bodies hanging!

Just watch it! its actually so bad its worth watching. You will laugh so hard!!

title: Worst movie. Hiper-generic
review:
Horrible. Sincerely, a film completely without link, without a palpable and continuous history. It's just an extremely generic eschatological movie with the same US story being attacked by something hyper-evil, and the heartthrob hero being completely immune and smarter than everyone else.

title: Seriously?
review: Quite possibly the worst movie ever made. If I were a judge, instead of sending people to jail I'd make them watch this movie. I'd only make them way h it once though. Once is plenty. What starts out as impossibly horrible dissolves into, get this, something even MORE horrible. Sort your sock drawer, get a bad sunburn, clean up after the dog.....do anything but watch this....thing. You'll thank me later.

title: A terrible film from Shyamalan
review:
M. Night Shyamalan takes on the fear of terrorism, environmentalism, and the apocalypse in his worst film. The Happening begins with people randomly killing themselves for seemingly no reason in also sorts of elaborate ways from stabbing themselves in the throat and throwing themselves off buildings to shooting themselves in the head and hanging themselves. The suicides grow progressively more outrageous reducing the horror of the mysterious affliction. It is revealed early on that the attack is airborne and centered in the Northeast.

Science teacher Elliot Moore (Mark Wahlberg) decides to evacuate Philadelphia by train with his wife Alma (Zoey Deschanel) after being invited by math teacher Julian (John Leguizamo). They hear more disturbing new and witness more disturbing deaths as they lose contact with major population centers. The evacuation transpires without much fear being generated. In a reversal from the most nonviolent previous film, The Happening goes out of its way to display grotesque deaths.

Check out more of this review and others at swilliky.com

title: M.Night Shyamalan does it again (and not well)
review: What is this, a plague causing people to kill themselves you've got to be having a laugh. This film had more clichÃ©s than I could count, poor acting, even worse cinematography and was virtually pointless to make. Shyamalan has made one good film in his sorry career and is now deepening his own grave (which almost reached Australia by the time he made the last airbender). So what was good well the main thing that stood out was I wasn't bored during it however that may have been because I was to busy scrutinizing it my main problem was the story, it was unrealistic perhaps if Shyamalan had come up with a better disease this might have been better.

title: Purty Good
review: First of all, some reviewers need to learn what rating a movie 1-3 means. A rating like that pretty much means the movie is so bad that you would have to be tied down to keep watching it. Reviewers definitely are being over dramatic when rating this movie a 1-3. Personally I think it at least deserves a 5 even if you hated it. Some might say it has somewhat of an awkward script,so what. People are awkward. Doesn't that make the movie a little more realistic. We want perfect actors with perfect scripts and a perfect story. Some of us need to lower our expectations a little. It's an OK movie. It's worth the watch.

title: Uhh...
review: When the lead actor from your movie openly talks about how bad it is, you know you did something wrong. The trailer actually made this movie look good. People just suddenly killing themselves, I have to admit I was curious and really looking forward to this movie. So apparently if you give off bad vibes, the plants will emit this gas in the air that causes you to kill yourself. THE PLANTS!! It is kind of new and different, I like that but this movie does nothing for me. In fact, the actors in this movie seem just as bored as the audience is. I'm just waiting for M. Night to redeem himself with a great movie because I know he can.

title: Really really really bad.
review:
The happening.... Complete misnomer.

This film could have been really great, but instead was nothing but incredibly boring. The initial idea that a viral/airborne disease/virus or whatever causing people to commit suicide could be very good, a change from the usual zombie rubbish that is everywhere, but clearly no thought was put into this film, everything about it is boring and amateur. The cast members have no spark between them, quite frankly I believe they knew this film was as much a load of s**t as the audience did. I spent the majority of the film not really knowing what was going on, then when it was finally explained that it was actually the plants causing the mass suicide was pathetic! I still can't understand what the director was thinking actually making this film....

Very very disappointing,

title: Oh dear!
review: Sometimes whilst watching a movie there is a specific line or scene where it all falls apart. In this case it when camera tracks in on Walbergs face as he says "oh no" and the characters then outrun the wind. This way midway through the movie and up until this point i was actually enjoying it a little. There are so many problems with this movie, a complete lack of tension, dismal performances from Wahlberg and Deschanel. at no point did i ever care about any of the characters. Terribly unfunny attempts at humor and unintentionally hilarious scenes that are meant to be horrific or disturbing such as old woman smashing her head through window. And what was that house where everything was plastic? seemed like a plot device solely to have Wahlberg talk to a plastic tree. The positives of the movie are James Newton Howard's score and little else. Shymalan needs a strong producer to tell him not all his ideas are worth filming. A disappointment.

title: The title refers to M.Night Shyamalan's failing career.
review: There was a time where a great filmmaker by the name of M.Night Shyamalan was creating films such as "The Sixth Sense" and "Signs." I wonder why this once gifted brilliant artist turned to making awful apocalyptic films that made good actors give horrible performances. "The Happening" can be thought of as more than just the title of a bad movie, but what is happening to the talent of Mr. Shyamalan. "The happening" is also about a disease or natural defect in which people space out and kill themselves. It's occurring in Central Park, where high school science teacher Elliot Moore (Mark Wahlberg) and his wife Alma (Zoey Deschanel) must fight to survive and escape from the terror. The whole idea of a disorder in which you go crazy and kill yourself is something hat SNL would do a spoof on as one of their prime skits. To make a serious drama about it, and have leading actors try and deliver strong performances turns it into something pretty silly. Mark Wahlberg gives his worst job of acting, and is even a better wrapper than an actor here. He talks so stupidly, and it is hard to take him seriously in such a crazy subject matter. Deschanel out acts him. She's god awful as well. The directing by Shyamalan is over dramatic and tries to be suspenseful when really there's nothing to shock you. His writing is worse. The characters he writes are used as a way to make the story feel as if it is effective, but really we have seen similar stories in films way less audacious and pointless. I miss the old days when M.Night Shyamalan was behind the camera and writing mind adventures instead of laughable disaster movies with no suspense and terrible directing.

title: Good concept but disappoints
review:
The Happening seemed to have potential from its concept and the idea but the overall execution and writing of the film collapses. A main reason why the film is harshly criticized is because of the acting from the leads Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel. They seemed miscast and it was hard to take Wahlberg serious as a Science teacher and the chemistry between them two seemed almost fake (at least in the first 45 mins).

The film starts off promising, drags around in the middle then picks up and becomes a more thriller suspense in the last 30 minutes. From around the part when they meet the older lady Ms Jones, I feel as if the films picks up and start becoming a little more interested. Still crazy in concept but it was more enjoyable from this point on. From there, we see her helping them in her house, feeding them and of course acting suspicious towards them. Once her characters exits out, we then see Wahlberg and Deschanel try and survive in her house then they eventually end of leaving. We last see them curled up in the outhouse, then it cuts a blank screen and a tagline shows "three months later", and everything seems fine and normal. Fee like this ending was a copout and Shyamalan could have thought of a better ending. As a rewatch 05/04/20' The Happening remains an overall disappointment in concept film. It has some moments of entertainment as already highlighted but a majority of the film is quite boring and plain. There isn't much of a climax.

title: Good concept really doesn't take this movie anywhere!!
review:
This movie is based on the idea that nature retaliates back! It does, but then nothing happens in the movie. Few death sequences, filled between a broken relationship between Walberg and Zooey.

The start is promising and as you try and search for a climax, its just poof! And at the end of the movie, you are left with nothing. I don't know if someone takes Walberg seriously, but he was a personal favorite. Just that he doesn't have the mantle to take this movie forward. Weak screenplay, loose dialogues!

At the end its just a sci-fi which doesn't thrill you all that well!Better try and see the first part and make a counter factual ending for the movie on your own than watching the entire movie!

title: Seriously M. Night? Seriously?!
review:
Shymalaladingdong gave us this thing I can't call cinema (it's a disgrace to movies everywhere!)in 2008. It really says something when I am still ranting about it. Three Whole years later. So here it goes.

As soon as I saw the previews for this movie I was ready to see it. M.Night is good at comebacks, Know what I mean? Sixth Sense was awesome, Signs was terrible, The Village was incredible. We all saw how bad Lady in the Water flopped, so I was thinking it was just a pattern and this was going to be the movie of the year. I don't think I have ever been more wrong in my entire life.

The Movie starts off with Zooey Deschanel and her rather unattractive face staring at the camera. She is talking to her boyfriend of all things, which makes perfect sense until you realize that she is married. To Marky Mark. Yeah... So anyway, she and her oblivious hubby find out that all these plants are giving off a compound that makes random people suicidal. Which means that they spend about two thirds of the movie running away from the wind while infected people jump into lion pens and run over each other with lawn mowers.

Why? Did somebody read this and think that this was going to make ANY money? "Hey honey, we are starting an M. Night movie at work." "Oh great honey! What's it about?" " Oh just a bunch of meatheads shooting little kids and driving jeeps into trees." Honestly, was M. Night kidding us? I was waiting for Aston Kutcher to jump out and go, "You just got Punk'd!" This is not a movie. This is a lame piece of crap with a girl who insists on spelling her name with two o's. Why? Can't she just spell it Zoey like everyone else? I'm going to go eat some olives. Athena2264 OUT.

title: "...All is left for us to do is to learn fast how not to sink so rapidly..."
review:
Shyamalan is well-hated for this one because he doesn't seem to care about his audience's state of mind. He started, he showed, he gave them some new dramatic scenes, he hinted at what might have been, and before it was adequately explained, he left suddenly. He had no intention to prepare them and he would not come to an aid when they were lost. I don't believe this is vanity. He merely wants to leave the audience totally unprepared in order to feel the powerlessness. To understand this film, one must choose the right frame of mind. I am touched by the storytelling being deliciously atmospheric and surrounding. Nature can act up and takes back whatever we think are ours at anytime. It doesn't need to reason. All is left for us to do is to learn fast how not to sink so rapidly. I don't even care about the possibility of the plot. Shyamalan asks us to close our eyes and to feel the feeling. He accomplished, and that is good enough for me. It doesn't make him god-like and superior than the audience, which is, I believe, where much of these hateful sentiments must have come from.

Cinematography of this film is top-notched. The frequent use of wind is effective. Almost all spoken lines are written to be an undertone of the atmosphere. The ending of this sort of film is always problematic. You start with nature, and it is hard to end it in a man-made way or an alienated conclusion like the likes of "Knowing", of which some extra terrestrials are responsible for everything. I think Shyamalan delivers what he has intended. Only a large number of people out there are not particularly fond of the delivery itself. This is the price he pays for trying to be different from his past works. I believe this film will redeem itself and finds its place. No need to like it now. Some minds must first grow.

The near-ending scene at the bus stop adds to the completion. It is so ordinary and calm, and it is priceless when compared to deaths and the state of uncertainty before that. I think the film reminds us to love what it is now, and to appreciate every moment. A critic wrote that "The Happening" is actually not happening. Precisely. This is not a film to be intellectually fulfilled, but to feel.

title: not much happening
review: Saw this three years ago in Glasgow, Scotland on it's release. I'm still laughing. Sorry this movie is so bad it's good. I need to go, I'm going to wet myself with the giggles thinking about this movie..oh god, please make the laughter stop.....oh man. I think i've got it under control. right let me try this again.....Mark Whalberg, in a defining role. Not! After such great characters in the likes of Boogie Nights,The Departed and the Fighter he must now wish he had managed to body swerve this one...........excuse me a moment...ahem...I need a medic, Anyone, help! Someone please, my stomach is aching, I'm doubled over. When I hear the wind rustling through the trees I just fall over in kinks of glorious loud laughter......watch this you have to.

title: The Happening...not so happening
review:
To say that I like M. Knight Shyamalan movies is an understatement if ever there was one. I have loved every one of this man's films from The Sixth Sense on--he made two movies prior, but I haven't seen either yet. Unbreakable is one of my favorite movies of all time and Signs is one of my most often viewed; I've lost count of how many times I've seen it.

So it would be safe to assume that I was going to give The Happening a look-see. I've been waiting for it for a few months now. My hopes had risen quite high as they tend to do and I didn't try to rein them in because Shyamalan hasn't let me down yet. There is a first time for everything.

This movie has an interesting premise. Something is causing people to do themselves bodily harm in localized areas of the Northeast. The ways in which these people harmed them selves were bizarre, gruesome, disturbing, and tended to result in their deaths. The opening scene was an attention grabber but from the moment the two girls on the park bench started talking I started thinking, "I wish they had gotten better actors." I didn't stop thinking that for the duration of the movie.

After you get past the over-the-top shocks and the intriguing set up, there really isn't much to the movie. It is all plot, no story, no character--though there are several feeble attempts at developing a couple of them--no emotion. Nothing but watching people die in creative ways, and some of the suicide just seem out of place or to run too long. This movie couldn't even make mass suicide disturbing, only curious.

Shyamalan has, prior to this movie, been more of the Hitchcock school of film making. That is what you don't see is scarier than what you do...for the most part. But in this movie he chooses to show almost everything. It was an interesting change in the beginning, but became an odd choice later for me. Why bludgeon us over the head with a series of suicides when the scene with periodic gun fire in the distance gets the point across so much better. The most suspenseful scene in the movie is when a woman affected by "The Happening" circles her house out of view of the camera stalking Mark Walberg's character, who waits in fear inside. The camera simply pans a wall tracking her progress behind it, but it was a great moment. It makes the death scenes just seem to be indulgences, schlock, cheap thrills.

Another problem I have with this movie is the "Happening" itself. I actually like the idea of it, people inexplicably begin killing themselves en masse. The key word being "inexplicably." When you are told in the movie halfway through why what is happening is happening, and are told by a crazy man with an affinity for hotdogs, and the explanation is a lame as it is, then it kind of loses something. Mystery is good. But again Shyamalan decided to hide nothing. Let's talk about the acting some more. It was...off, let's say. I like Mark Walberg. I really like John Leguizamo. I don't have a problem with Zooey Deschanel. But no one ever clicked. Half the time it didn't even seem like the characters were responding to each other. It was just odd to watch. This movie was just odd.

Now, I do have a theory on why this movie turned out the way it did, and I may be grasping at straws to salvage it in someway for myself because I did wanted it to be good. It came across as very cheesy almost jokey, but there weren't very many jokes in it. The few that there very good, like anything the two boys that showed up later in the movie did or said. There were also odd plot contrivances abound. There was the cooky old man that figured out why what was happening was happening. There was the cooky old lady cloistered away from society that offered help, but at a price--she had the greatest line of the film by the way: "I see you eying my lemon drink." There was the fragile couple growing strong through the tragedy.

Then you have the general light tone of the film and the beware-or-this-could-happen-to-you message and the happy, but not so happy, ending. All this lead me to my first theory. And that is that Shyamalan was paying homage to the '50s sci-fi B-movie, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, The Incredible Shrinking Man, The Blob, Them and others come to mind. I don't know what Shyamalan was thinking when he made this, but The Happening had that hokey feel to it and the plot followed the lines drawn by movies that came before it. I don't know.

My second theory is that this was just a bad movie.

I did not like this movie. I do not recommend that anyone see it, unless they are just going to go see some innovative death scenes. I won't say that there are no redeeming aspect to the film. It still looks like a Shyamalan movie. The cinematography is beautiful and the shot selection is nice. There are a few very suspenseful scenes and the show moves along at a good clip. I just wish that the show was worth watching. It is not.

title: Night's Disaster
review:
I am a movie fan, and one fan of Night. I was totally biased towards his themes and ability of in direction, etc, after watching The Sixth Sense, Signs and to an extent with Unbreakable. I was excited when I got this DVD expecting same standards.

This is a total disaster for Night.

I read all the reviews, but just hoped that there will be something I would be able to like. None. Looks like the entire crew here were totally misguided. Even the actors couldn't save this movie. Script is bad, direction is worse. Things happen exactly when I was expecting them to happen, in exactly the same way. After the first few minutes, there is no suspense, forget story line.

Why should such a movie be released in first place. Money and lot of time including Night's could have been saved. Disaster.

title: Are you kidding me??
review: I don't get it. All the suspense, everybody going crazy, killing themselves. And the whole time it's plants. Plants. Try to take it seriously, I dare you. They can't move on their own but they have some sort of crazy ability to make us kill ourselves. Mark Wahlberg can't act but he does pull off a couple funny moments. This movie had zero action, and no threat of a bad guy or anything. Wherever you go, the wind can get you and you'll die. But in the end, Marky and his girl both go out into it, and magically nothing happens. Whoa, didn't see that one coming. Stupid movie, don't know why it was MNSs first R rated film. Don't bother with it.

title: So very close to a return to form for Shyamalan
review:
I had such a good vibe going during this film. I couldn't work out why all the hate toward it. M. Night Shyamalan appeared to be back to his best so I began trying to work out which brilliant ending he was going to lay on us this time. There seemed to be little hints here and there that I figured would leave me saying after wards, "ofcourse, why didn't I see that coming?" Instead I was left feeling absolutely robbed at the brain power I had spent on this movie.

Shyamalan was back near his best in terms of building quiet suspense, even though we aren't entirely sure of what the disturbing occurrence we are in for is, which makes it all the better. The premise he's developed makes it easy for him to throw horrific images at us, but he does it with his own sense of style and creativity none the less. He's certainly nowhere near top form but it's definitely a step up from the awful Lady in the Water.

One of the reasons this movie fails in a lot of peoples eyes is that it lends itself to being over-analyzed. We know what Shyamalan is capable of in comparison to what he's providing us with lately and so we naturally see little faults in all aspects of the film much more clearly. A lot of the dialog is awkward and unnatural and some of the character decisions are questionable at best. The ending however must go down as the big one when we consider this is the man's specialty. The Sixth Sense, The Village and my personal favorite Unbreakable all had endings that left us both shook up and satisfied for days, even weeks. The Happening doesn't even come close to having either effect on us.

Not one to be proud of on Shyamalan's part and he's been let know this by his many razzie nominations. But it's not all bad and it's certainly not unwatchable. The man does have other traits beside delivering us with an incredible ending, despite what a few may think.

title: I never thought Id say this...
review:
I hated Signs. I thought the Village was completely predictable, however having not bought into any the hype or seeing much of the trailer when it was first released, I gave this a go. It cost me £15 for three ex-rental titles at Blockbuster, and this was one of them.

Forgetting for a minute the performance of Zooey Deschanel, which was wooden to the point of making her character appear mentally unhinged and the subplot of the relationship issues which was so flippantly tackled was completely irrelevant. This aside, I enjoyed the movie and an interesting take on a semi-eco message, for £6 a great value piece of entertainment!

Goblin - www.openbytes.wordpress.com

title: Uh...not really impressed...
review: I have been a fan of Night for a really long time, and I have to say I think he could have done better. First, he needed to stick to PG-13 rated movies, I think he got a little carried away with the R. Some of those suicide scenes made me queasy...also, at the end of all his movies he leaves your mind working after it is over. At the end of The Village, you have to decide for yourself if Luscious is saved. In Lady in the Water, you have to decide if Story really did impact all the people she met. However in this movie-what do we have to think about? Is the story going to repeat itself in France? Duh! I unfortunately wasn't blown away like I have been by all his other movies.

title: Good Story boring characters
review:
I think this movie has its place among those which have to be seen but surely can be forgotten very fast.

The story is very similar to "Der Schwarm" a novel written by the German author Frank Schaetzing; veryvery recommended to read; in 2002 or something around.

Creatures of the sea become dangerous and produce toxics which seem to be able to kill all mankind. But then the planctonic algae decide within their metamorphic mind to let the humans live. It was just a warning to mankind not to destroy the nature especially the marine environment.

I think shyalaman stole the storyline, or maybe he bought it, and then transferred it upon the earth and into terrestral liveforms. Marc Whalberg and this woman with the big blue eyes, really acted as bad as Tom Hanks and the french actress in sacrileg.

So just seven points for this movie.

title: Pretty good although very flawed movie.
review:
In a seemingly normal morning in New York City. Some people are experiencing some things like lost of memory, incoherent speaking, some do harm themselves, some turn killing people and others killed themselves. A science biology teacher (Mark Wahlberg), his wife (Zooey Deschanel), their friend (John Leguizamo) and their friend's daughter (Ashlyn Sanchez) find themselves on the run away from their city of Phildelphia. Thinking that they will be safe in the country but it turns much more worst, because of the unexplained phenomenon has something to do with mother nature.

Written and Directed by M. Night Shaylaman (The Sixth Sense, Unbreakable, The Village) made an intriguing horror film, which the director nearly pulls off making a hard R-Rated flick. There's some memorable violent sequences but maybe not enough of it. Walhberg is good in the role and the supporting cast are fine. The movie starts out great and it's impressive for awhile. Effective first half soon loses its edge and never quite recover but at least, it's an improvement over the director's previous feature ¨Lady in the Water¨.

DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (1.85:1) transfer and an good Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. DVD includes Deleted Scenes with introduction by the director, featurettes and an gag reel. ¨The Happening¨ isn't quite the feature, i was expecting but it's somewhat close. It's the kind of movie that starts with a bang but ends in a whimper. Although despite all the flaws, it's still worth a look. Alan Ruck and Brian O'Halloran appears in cameos. (*** 1/2 out of *****).

title: There is something more in this...
review: The Happening is a good movie! And not as bad as many people says. Not perfect, not super but still good. Better than the water girl. Much better. Shymalan's big problem is here, that he can't give us new story anymore. The plot is the same since Signs. This is the biggest problem with this movie. The actors are good for me. Maybe the acting is a little bit strange, not usually... but still works. Especially Mark Wahlberg was fine. I think the script was mot enough. The story was good, but the script I think is too small. There are some really scary scenes, and the cinematography works perfect. The score is good. James Newton Howard feels again what Shyamalan wants to say. So, with a better script and a longer movie and more time to finished completely the Happening could be a perfect work. But now it is a money pit. A little bit shame for Shymalan. I think he must think about these before his next idea! But I still believe him!

title: I can't believe people actually watch movies to fill holes in their lives. Then of course you'll be disappointed.
review:
I'm reading IMDb reviews and I can't believe people actually watch movies to fill holes in their lives. Then of course you'll be disappointed. And they criticize the idea of the movie, saying it was hard to believe or not intelligence-provoking enough. Dumb f..s, do you actually watch a movie hoping that the script resembles in veracity an Engineering University lecture or hoping that it brings you the answer to the question 'how did the Universe set off'.. I for myself, just enjoy the imagery and leave veracity to engineers.

The Happening was 3 out of 10, and that for the suicide scenes. But still, PLEASE, PEOPLE, why is the idea STUPID ? Plants reacting to pollution and letting out self-defence toxic compounds doesn't sound crazier than any other Science-Fiction film plot. Please give this a break and concentrate your critique on script or acting.

title: A terrible written empty and dull thriller
review:
I stopped expecting the next Sixth Sense a long time ago. The Happening is a dull and empty thriller. M Night Shymalan tries to get cheap shocks by showing graphic and violent suicides. Terrible Acting, No tension and no suspense makes this movie a miss.

Following the masterpiece that was The Sixth Sense M Night Shymalan made the good Unbreakable. In 2002 he made Signs. Signs had the thrills and the scares but was missing something. In 2004 we were sent to the Village where there were also scares and a great story. All were good movies until the Lady in the Water. I was overcome with Confusion and a headache. Now in the Happening there were no scares and no thrills. M Night Shymalan really seems to be loosing it.

The Happening is not worth seeing. I certainly hope that M Night Shymalan starts making good movies again. I will be seeing The Last Airbender and if it is as bad as this then i am gonna give up on Shymalan. I give The Happening.....

3/10

title: Don't Waste Your Time
review:
Absolutely Terrible! OK, i had pretty high hopes for this movie after the 6th Sense, but this movie had me disappointed after the first 2 minutes and only got worse.

The acting isn't great but the story is worse, the problems that our stars are meant to over come are Ridiculous and the whole premise of the movie is absurd, only to be outdone by the solutions that would seem absurd to a 5 year old.

The story does not evolve at all and the characters are intended to be mysterious but instead come across as ignorant morons which takes away from the whole mystery or apparent lack of throughout the movie. The story does not change at all from moment one and the characters do not evolve at all, and show no connection to each other or the plot.

In summary, don't waste your time, the way you feel after 2 minutes (Cheated) is the way you feel at the end. Terrible excuse for a movie.

title: This is Shyamalan
review: All the discussion about the movies of Shyamalan can be endless. People who ever watched any of his movies will be divided in half. First half will say 'bullshit', another half will watch it with their jaw fallen. This is Shyamalan. You either love his movies, either you hate them. If you love them, you will love this movie, if not, you shouldn't even try to. Once again he did a great job make you feel everything going on on the screen and not feel safe. And the movie really makes you think about everything, even your own life. Another great job by M. Night, definitely worth watching for any Shyamalan appreciator, another movie which seems to be similar to other his movies, while being something totally different.

title: Why Shyamalan's "The Happening" is happening....
review: For those of you that love the "fear" aspect in films as opposed to the "horror" aspect, this is a film for you. Widely advertised as the first R-rated film from director M.Night Shyamalan, "The Happening" is more for those of you that prefer your movie not spoon-fed to you and like to think. M.Night does not waste any time on getting the movie going, as the violence starts within the first two minutes of the film. From there, it is a roller-coaster ride that takes us throughout the eastern part of the United States of America. This area is infected with this unseen affliction and it is graphic as people are killing themselves in pretty creative ways....I will stop there to not give anything away. For those of you looking for a slasher-type blood and guts horror-fest, you will hate it. For those thinkers that love a motive behind the violence and want to see actual "fear", it will give you fear. The difference between "fear" and "horror" is evident here. This is not a "horror movie". It is a movie that will scare the pants off of you.....The scariest movie that I have seen in the last 20 years is "The Sixth Sense"---this is a movie that I would not want to watch alone. Would you call "The Sixth Sense" horror??? i wouldn't... "The Happening" just joined that club. The message in the film will come to you after you see it and think about it. Fear and Scares, with a lack of the word "horror" do work once again in Shyamalan's blender....he simply has fear with no horror---which works!!!! This one is scary because it is REAL!!!! enjoy...

title: The Horrible
review:
This is a movie about nothing. There's no monsters, villains, fiends, suspense, atmosphere, acting or script. How a movie like this could cost $80 million, released by a major studio and given the green light by a supposedly tough team of producers and executives is a true mystery.

The first five minutes are compelling. Something is forcing thousands of NYC residents to kill themselves. Switch now to Mark Wahlberg who portrays a befuddled science teacher and he tells his class about the mystery of why bees are vanishing. Could this have something to do with the unknown power that's causing mass suicide.

Then we see Mark, his wife and friends fleeing the city on a train that suddenly stops because the engineer has killed himself. Then we see endless shots of plants and trees blowing in the wind. Is it the wind or the plants that's causing people to kill themselves? at one point, as a few survivors race away from the oncoming wind, Mark faces the camera and shouts: "Wait a minute! I'm trying to figure out what's happening?" The few people in my theater all cracked up. He voiced our confusion perfectly.

And then, we next see Mark and company happily back in NYC. Traffic flows, people shop and stroll along the sidewalks. But wait! What happened to all those dead corpses? Is the invisible killer gone? What was it?

This movie is a landmark in inept film-making and should have been shown on the Sci-Fi Channel--home to the cheesiest made-for-TV flicks to be found in the world.

title: Yuk
review:
I have stopped watching this film, to come create an account, and tell anyone else who is reading reviews before seeing this movie, DON'T.

I keep shaking my head because my brain doesn't understand what I am seeing. These are actors that I have seen in other movies...acting. What went wrong here? M Night, go back to doing whatever it was you were doing before the 6th sense, and I don't mean movies, I mean the other job you had to be doing.

Screenplay - terrible, nobody talks like this, people don't behave like this, I kept thinking it was because they had already been affected by the event. "look heres a car" "Shes going to the town of Princeton" "Hot dogs get a bad wrap" "You've got binoculars in the back, from when you were spying on our neighbors" soooooo many more.

Acting - more terrible, if the lines you are reading on the page don't look right, tell someone, and they can do a re-write or something.

Special effects, not bad, rent the DVD, and fast forward to the kill yourself scenes, and then take it back to the store.

title: Completely Disappointed - An Insult to Intelligence
review:
This is the first time I'm ever giving a 1 out of 10. I think :p I see other people's comments regarding this movie and it is pretty much spot on. There are a few people defending this movie but they fail to defend it well. They speak of "The message" behind this movie. What message? Are you kidding me? Save the world? Give me a break. Global Warming is a joke. The earth is cooling and the ice caps are getting larger and thicker. Look it up. Don't be subjected to the Hitler Clause: If it's said enough times then people will believe it.

It is a no-brainer that fun, stupid and silly movies sell. They bring about laughter and that is the BEST emotion. Films like Zohan make it big because people LOVE to laugh. I recently watched Harold and Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay and I absolutely adored it. It was stupid, silly but GREAT fun. The Happening however, is absurd. It's stupid and silly in a completely different way: It insulted me. It insulted my intelligence.

You see The Sixth Sense, which is by far one of my favorite movies of all time, was made by a man who created not only a work of art, but a puzzle piece of which the viewer needed to pay full attention to or he or she would be lost and would not get the point of the movie. After coming out of that movie, I heard so many people saying "I don't get it". I didn't get THAT. NOW I do. Let's face it, most people do not have the kind of intelligence quotient required for the kind of movies that Shyamalan is capable of. IT SEEMS that either he's lost his edge or he's changed his ways and DUMBED his movies down in an attempt to appeal to "the masses". If that is the case, it sure did not work.

The story line is awful. The idea of what "happens" in this movie is ridiculous and even if he was attempting a "message" within this movie, it fails miserably. EVERYBODY knows....what we do to OUR environments. We are all WELL aware however, we are not children and we shouldn't have to be subjected to be subjected to being assumed that we all are . If I sum this movie up it would be this: "The trees and grass will kill us because we're killing them".

That sounds like something a child would say. Is it an impossible situation? No. It IS plausible however improbable. Plant life does not adapt en-mass to kill. It adapts to survive. They become resilient to anything that is thrown at them. The Chernobyl incident is a prime example. 20 Years after that accident, life is sprawling there. Trees and other plant life have taken over and have begun to break down all that man has built there. Even more surprisingly, animal life has INCREASED since that accident. The Plant kingdom does not NEED To (lol) kill all humans and even that is severely flawed. Any biologist would tell you that the premise of this movie is beyond silly.

I grant that this is a fictional tale however, fiction should at least be entertaining. I was completely bored with this movie and it was quite predictable.

Please go back to making intelligent movies, mister Shymalan and if not, at least start making FUNNY dumb movies. I'm sure you could do very, very well making a movie along the likes of "Scary Movie". Who knows, you might be the master at it.

title: If you still want to see it...don't waste money on a movie ticket...rent it
review:
I have been working in the movie business for a few years. No I am not expert but I have developed a somewhat versatile opinion. I am usually very good. I give movies a chance to prove me wrong, but this one wasted my money.

I made it through 25 minutes of what I would say is the worst impersonation of acting I've ever witnessed. Everyone was in a different movie. I kept waiting for the underlying plot to come through...maybe they were robots. But alas...it was just the lack of chemistry and effort on the actors parts.

The story line fell short. There was no buildup or anticipation, just a whole lot of confusion. I can't tell you how it ended...I couldn't make it that long.

If you still want to see this movie...don't waste the 11 bucks for a theater ticket...rent it for 4.

title: Be careful - the plants are out to get you.
review:
Man has become a threat to nature and therefore it is time for payback. Plants have developed some kind of very sophisticated chemistry and it is being released in order to get rid of mankind. The chemistry works instantaneous and makes the affected very suicidal; There are some very spectacular and gruesome suicides in the movie.

Mark Wahlberg together with his girlfriend tries to escape from an infected area and we follow them from Philadelphia to a remote place in the countryside where they at last overcomes the obstacles they have in their relationship because they face death and this makes them realize how strong their feelings are towards each other.

The idea itself, that nature by some unknown defense mechanism is able to annihilate enemies is to me in a sense perfectly comprehensible. But not in the way that is suggested in the movie. Man is a threat because of various kind of pollution and plants would need the ability to "reason" to infer that this is caused by man and this is of course a ridiculous thought. Man itself, the individual, is not a threat and nature has no way of "knowing" where for example pollution or co2 comes from.

A ridiculous movie with a very tiresome epilogue.

Regards Simon

Ps. When you read reviews that gives max score check to see if the user has made more than one review. If not consider the possibility of a lobbyist. If you agree consider putting this post scriptum at the bottom at your own reviews.

title: What Happened?
review: I am not a big fan of M Night S. , but I did not expect this film to be something of this sort. From the trailer we are confronted with people who meet a tragic ending but it leaves us guessing with why? Watching this film, I still felt that MNS failed to mention the answer as to why it was considered the Happening. I can come up with a few reasons, but I cannot be quite sure and thats what troubles me about this film. I solidify this film as a two, because MNS did attempt to keep this film true to its genres as all his other ones. Some scenes were graphic and actually disturbing that I notice the audience did look away at times. I think he had the right idea, but was deficient in his execution. Watching it, I did not have high hopes for it so I might not recommend it, but if your an MNS fan, than I think this film might suit you more.

title: Fine fantasy...
review: The impression I got sitting through THE HAPPENING was akin to the feeling one gets sitting through a good fantasy novel (of the T.M. Wright variety, say, or Stephen King at his very best). The cinematic craftsmanship speaks for itself: it's superb, on all fronts. Like LADY IN THE WATER, THE HAPPENING was (for me) a fully realized fantasy- like a dream, functioning, at times, on an almost subliminal level. It would be interesting, indeed, to see what Shyamalan could do with one of the hundreds of novels or short stories written by the likes of Richard Matheson (I AM LEGEND) or Charles L. Grant (HOUR OF THE OXRUN DEAD) or Charles Beaumont (THE HOWLING MAN) or Harlan Ellison (FLOP SWEAT) or Shirley Jackson (THE SUNDIAL) or H.P. Lovecraft (THE COLOUR OUT OF SPACE) or Robert E. Howard (PIGEONS FROM HELL) or Edgar Alan Poe (THE OBLONG BOX) or Henry Kuttner (THE GRAVEYARD RATS) or... You get my drift. (THE MIST, by Stephen King, was turned into a decent movie, by the way.)

title: Hilareous...
review:
When I saw the film in the theater. The first thing I wanted to know after watching it was: what would people write about this? Is this some kind of joke? I didn't watch any interviews of M. Night Shyamalan or read any reviews before. I only heard the plot of the movie from someone: It's about the plants and trees which produce a poisonous chemical so that the people kill themselves. In a nutshell.
