First off, the acting. I couldn't even believe it. The worse acting I've ever seen. It was indeed as if it was intentionally but it was annoying. It was like a theater performance where you have to overreact. God...so horrible. It was probably the most horrifying part of the movie.

The story itself seemed pretty cool to me, but everything was just too much. The long close up shots. The horrible clichés in the movie..and so on.

And even if HE DID wanted to make a bad movie...it didn't work. People wanted a nice scary movie to watch and it would have been if it wasn't for the 'inside joke'. I loved the parts where the people all fell from the construction site building (although ...they looked like dolls - on purpose?) I don't want to HAVE TO see interviews before I watch a movie. I don't want to read about inside stuff before I watch it so that it will explain it. Same with art. I want to have my own interpretation on it/ So yeah, it was horrifying, but in a bad bad bad way (I only liked Sixth sense, unbreakable and a little signs)

title: What a barker - woof, woof!
review:
When it comes to movies, you can feed me just about anything and I'll eat it up. I'm hardly ever critical of movies I've seen.

But this movie??

Ya know, we should be conserving the Earth's resources and the total waste of cellulose to make this waste-of-time movie . . . well, maybe the director should be made to reimburse the Earth in some way - perhaps sentenced to planting trees or seeding fields of waving grasses. Oh, wait - that (according to this movie) would be dangerous to humans!

There's little that I can add to the plethora of comments about this dog. But I did wonder about the people that have written positive reviews - what must theirs lives be like? Wouldn't ya love to follow them around for about a day in order to see what makes them tick? I'll bet it's educational. And fun.

I only wish I'd read the reviews before seeing this. . . this. . . thing. I can be thankful about the fact that someone else paid for the admission - and the popcorn was good.

title: Not a convincing turn from Wahlberg or Shyamalan
review: THE HAPPENING is the latest mystery-thriller from pop-director M. Night Shyamalan, this time Mark Wahlberg takes the lead and mixes up a cocktail of nonsense. The traces of nerve and anxiousness feels way gone as Shyamalan builds this drama around the terror of the unknown, and were THE VILLAGE and even SIGNS made small but effective bursts of thrills, THE HAPPENING wants to full-on shock in the opening scene and instead of slowly revealing the mystery throughout, it takes us away from the original drama and steers away from excitement. It may have seemed as a good idea at the time, taking Wahlberg and co. into the county and small-town scenario, but the movie looses all of its drama and ends up feeling like a true lackluster. And the whole deal doesn't feel believable, at all - and then I'm not talking about the shocking terror upon us, but the brother relationship between Wahlberg and Leguizamo doesn't fit, and Zooey Deschanel's part is a sad turn. THE HAPPENING is M. Night Shyamalan's most accessible movie yet, but his most disappointing as both a writer and director.

title: Not to bad!
review:
I think a lot of people are giving this movie a bad reputation because they expect so much from M. Night. The Sixth Sense is a movie that comes around once. You can't expect M. Night to make tons of movies as good as The Sixth Sense.

First, he's not trying to scare you, he's trying to give you a good story. The Happening is not only original, but it is also a well thought out story. There's never been a movie about a toxin causing people to kill themselves. At first the plants may seem to be a stupid "villian" in the story, but facts are given to make it seem more reasonable.

The acting was a hot topic in this particular movie. Mark Wahlberg had questionable acting, but Ms. Deschanel is definitely a good actress. I think the acting in this movie is more natural. It's more real life and not "drama, drama, drama" as you see in other movies. You would think of it as real acting!

title: Just Expect The Unexpected
review:
I just finished watching this movie and I have very mixed feelings about it, which is not unusual when one comes in direct contact with M. Night Shyamalan's vivid and ever so subtly terrifying imagination. For it is exactly the unusually subtle nature of the fear he invokes that makes his works so remarkable.

If you are looking for blood, gore and spilled guts, do not watch "The Happening". This movie's strength is in exploring the kind of horror most of us can relate to: treating our direct environment (let that be people or any other living organisms) with neglect and then facing the unpleasant consequences. We get a sense of havoc, but the story revolves on the fragile state of the human psyche in terms of dealing with a sudden shock.

I suppose I liked "The Happening" more than I disliked it. It is so refreshing to see something unexpected in a genre that lately has presented such monotone plots. It also allowed me to reflect on the possibility of an impending doomsday with a little more objectivity.

As for what I personally did not enjoy so much was that the movie seems to progress at a slow, comfortable pace - up until about the last ten minutes, during which events sped up so rapidly that I was scared to blink in case I might miss something. I am not so content with the ending, which keeps me from highly praising this movie.

This is one of those love-it-or-hate-it flicks. I happen to love it more than I hate it.

title: Good movie. people went in with a bitter taste
review:
Lets face it, M.Nights last few movies weren't up to par with that ones that launched his career as a horror/thriller director. The Happening wasn't as good as his first few movies, but it definitely wasn't as bad as lady in the water or the village. This movie provides a sense of fear from start to finish, as the action starts right at the first scene and doesn't stop. The plot was good, they could have taken it in a whole different direction and if planned out more this movie could have been a lot better. The acting performances were good as well, especially Mark Wahlberg. I don't know what people are saying, that he cant be a "nice guy" in movies. It's true and it does seem like hes hiding his anger in this performance but thats what makes it good, he finds a way to be overly calm when everybody in the world is dying.

Good movie, not M.Nights best, but not his worst either. 7/10

title: Such great potential, such a weak story
review:
and um...

well... where to start? many people are considering this as M Night Shama-lama-ding-dong's worst movie yet... i'll stick up for the failing director and say that this was Definitely better than Lafy in the Water.

over all, i personally enjoyed watching this movie. the concept was very interesting. its an idea that i myself wouldn't mind writing a script for and possibly making a new movie on. its an idea that has extreme potential, potential for infinite possibilities for an audience to see in a movie. but possibilities that M Night refused to give us... and it just leaves the viewer asking themself, "Why not?" many people say this movie is simply full of terrible acting. i disagree. i wont deny that i spotted several parts throughout the film where the acting was weak.. but i believe that M Night was trying to achieve the reality of how ordinary people would act in a situation such as 'the happening'. but in my opinion, i think some of the acting was certainly in need of better directing.

and i couldn't help myself... i had to laugh when they ran from the villain of the movie... the wind, HAHAHA!!! but there's one fatal error that M Night made in this movie. its too simple. although hes known for being a simplistic director, shamalan went way overboard with the idea of trying to create a movie as simply as possible. in return, he ended up creating a movie where nothing actually... 'happend' (no pun intended). it seemed too simple.. so simple, that it looked like the entire film was pulled off with less than a million dollar budget! and with most of the budget going to the two big name stars of the flick; Mark Walberg and John Leguizamo and M Night's first R rated film????? ARE YOU KIDDING ME???? that was PG-13 all the way! unless if the version i saw was edited, (which i saw via internet sources from japan) but this movie was just... OK. i give props for an interesting idea to mass human suicide, but the movie loses points for such a WEAK story.

with all due respect, M Night Shamalan needs to stop writing movies. not directing, but writing. hes an incredible director, and comes up with amazing ideas to films, but he should make like steven Spielberg and hire somebody to wirte his scripts for him.

The Happening (where nothing happened) 5.9 out of 10 stars

title: why is everybody down-rating this film?!?
review:
What is the problem with the film-watching people of today?!? I read things like uninspired, waste of time, 'Shyamalan's worst film yet', and none of these things are true! If anything, it was one of his best! Original, chill-worthy, and why is it a cliché? what exactly is it that makes this film a cliché? Do you people even know what the word cliché means for Christ's sake?!? 'A phrase or idea that is overused to the point where it becomes boring and dull', can anybody else think of a film where it uses the same conventions as The Happening with as much depth and fact. I cant!

All people want to watch these days are CGI and Special effects, and pay no attention to detail and hidden meanings to things. You don't want to use your minds anymore, you just want to watch with your gobs wide open stuffing in popcorn and going away talking nonsense about what you 'thought' the movie was about! You are the same people who watched Pulp Fiction, and said aww what a great action movie, did you see the bit where that guys head exploded! You didn't even notice the whole point of the film, it wasn't about the killings and the violence! Try watching it again, but watch more bloody carefully!

In closing, for those of you with an open mind, a good understanding of films, and don't have a grudge on Shyalaman, I say definitely go to watch it!

title: Don't Believe the (adverse) hype
review:
The critical kicking that this picture received upon release was such that I almost gave it a "swerve". I am glad that I didn't.If you want the bad news read pretty much every other review,if you want the good news read on.

The premise of this film, a natural "event" that causes humans to kill themselves is compelling and intriguing.A 91 minute running time makes for a pacey, if inevitably compressed storyline, which hooks the viewer from start to finish.The combination of an "unseen killer", the natural "Rush and rustle of leaves and branches" and the human carnage that results is genuinely spooky.

Lead actor Mark Wahlberg guides us perfectly competently through the story with Betty Buckley playing a genuinely disturbing cameo as hermit Mrs Jones.The plot does require "suspension of disbelief" in several respects, but hey this is a story not a history.

Not a classic, but a good yarn nonetheless let down by an absurd, frustrating, corny, commercial "ending" which had me howling in disapproval.

title: Wasn't ALL that bad...
review: My opinion of this film... isn't bad... but, isn't great either. Like many before me have said, it lacks..."Umphf" but that said, i still enjoyed it. It had scene's where it made me cringe, ( man with the lawnmower, whole street and one pistol etc.. ) It made me feel sympathetic ( Bloke goes to find his wife ) Yet, again... it comes up, " umphf " is definitely what it lacked, and NO, it certainly wasn't the acting, Mark Whalberg gave his usual performance, that tbh, was no better then most films he has done, so criticising him on this film is to criticise him on every film he has done, since the acting was pretty much the same, if anyone was too blame i would say it was the girl-friend, she lacked any sort of emotion and tbh, was boring to watch and listen too. Script i believe is the biggest killer here, could of been produced in a much more " reach out and grab you " way, but just.... didn't. It's a good film to watch tbh, but not something i will go out and buy as soon as it hits the shelves, but i did enjoy it, and would certainly recommend everyone to at least " Try " it, rather than listening to most people's narrow views, since most are expecting a revolution with every title released, and these days, those are few and far between. Anyway good luck with the movie, hope you enjoy it!

title: I'd give it 8.5 if I could
review:
I love M. Night Shamylan's films, so perhaps I'm a bit biased. This one was definitely very well done, despite what many many others are saying about it.

The acting was good, the subject was chilling, and its ability to draw the audience in shouldn't be ignored. Some have said "why should we care about these people? I'm not invested in their plight" (paraphrased). Why should you care? It could very well have been you, your family, your friends, who were affected by this "Happening".

The only flaw, and the reason I can't give this 9 or 10, is the ending. The scene with the couple at the end, followed by the TV report, could have been cut. In fact, it should have been. The report should have simply said that the event was over in the Northeast, and left it. The final scene should be included though. Why all this? "The Birds". That's why. The end of "The Happening" left you with a small sense of relief, but the end of "The Birds" leaves you wondering what the heck is going on. Hitchcock intentionally refrained from explaining why the birds were attacking the world (and never defined the scope, which I liked as well...it could have just been California or it could have been the whole Western Hemisphere...or more), which made the end more chilling and horrifying than could have been achieved with a "proper" ending. "The Happening" should have ended the same way. We find out it's over in the Northeast, that nothing's gone on for a while, that there's theories going around including conspiracy and terrorism, the newsman says "everyone would believe you if it had only happened *somewhere else*", and then.....boom

title: Leaves a mark.
review:
This movie has made quite an impression on me - although I might think twice about watching it again.

I've seen films of the apocalyptic nature before; nothing has hounded me more than this happening did. The night I watched it, I went to sleep with the suicide scenes still running in my head...girl piercing her own neck with a hair accessory, construction workers' calmly stepping off of the edge of a building, bodies hanging from trees in a quiet neighborhood (gets my vote for Most Chilling), John Smith getting himself mowed. I don't think most of those acts can even be conceived by the normal suicidal person. I wonder how the infants killed themselves.

It was around 4:30am when I woke up and couldn't go back to bed. So Mark Wahlberg, Alma, and the little girl didn't get infected because they shut themselves inside a room, blocking anything that the wind can pass through; that college kid calling mom's cellphone didn't lose human logic before she opened the window. For people inside buildings, I'm assuming that the way the ventilation for air conditioned facilities' work let the toxins in. Oh, think of the materials one can use in the corporate world! The mere idea makes me shudder.

The fact that it has hounded me longer than your typical The-End-of-the-World-is-Just-Around-the-Corner movie and forced my mind to explore places I would rather not go to tell me that there's something about The Happening that was actually done right - if not masterfully so.

title: Though it's not Shyamalan's best, It is still a good movie
review:
OK, the Sixth Sense, Signs, and the village are all great movies. This movie is still a good movie, just not as good as his other's.

First lets get the reasons why this movie isn't perfect out of the way. First of all the acting wasn't the strongest it could have been. There was a bit of goofy dialog here and there but it wasn't terrible. The whole back story between the main characters was kind of useless. Also there were a couple very gory things that happened (only once or twice) kind of ruining the moment of being scared. OK, got the bad stuff out of the way, lets move on.

What made the movie good was the fact that no one knew what was happening, and know one knew were it was. Many scenes were creative and done well to make it scarier.You could tell by the expression on some of the peoples faces that something is going completely wrong. All of this made the movie very frightening. There were also some good humor here and there to keep the movie flowing.

Overall I believe, though it's not Syamalan's best movie, I would still recommend to people who want to be scared.

title: The Happening Makes Us Think It Will Might Happen....
review:
Everyone likes to call themselves a 'fan of M. Night Shyamalan'. I, admittedly also call myself such. I am finding reviews about this movie to be rather jilted and what I have come to expect. Most people walk into a movie expecting the plot, scenario, imagery, effects, etc, to all be spoon-fed to us by the makers of the film.

M. Night Shyamalan is one of a dying breed to tell his audience's - think about what your are hearing and seeing.

Despite what seems to be a weak plot, and lack of panic and chaos due to a seemingly horrible world-wide event only adds to the irony of the film and the message that is being sent. The fact that the plot is simplistic / lack of panic and chaos points to the current human condition - we are so numb to everything around us that even if something shocking or horrific occurs, natural or man-made, we glue ourselves to our cameras or TV's for a short period of time, and then we are completely desensitized to it.

Shyamalan has succeeded greatly in showing us his view of how people have been conditioned in today's world, how we have ignored the fundamental harmonies we used to have between ourselves and our fragile world, and the possibilities of what might occur and how a desensitized human population might react to an unexpected and unfathomable event.

Think about what you are seeing and hearing - EXPERIENCE the movie instead of watching at face value. The Happening will prove to be a frightening and a mentally terrorizing experience for you!

title: Missing the point.
review:
I think many reviewers are missing the point, or at least the significance of this film. "The Happening" is not about the earth taking revenge on humanity, just like "Signs" was not about an alien attack. Simply put, "The Happening" is about suicide, the suicide of Western civilization. Demographically western Europe, by way of birth rates, is disappearing. The U.S is just at maintenance levels. The elites have lost the basic instinct of self-preservation. Just note the reluctance of many to fight a war that threatens everything we hold dear. The elites (a strong concentration in the affected area) have strangely substituted the fight to end global warming for the fight against global Islamic terrorists. They don't want children, they want to enjoy the present without the encumbrance of children. These are all aspects of societal suicide. The killer is our own selfish hedonism and blindness to the real enemy coming back to blow us away.

Night is a subtle artist and the heavy handed premise of earth's revenge on the mean humans, obvious from the first third of the film is simply the story for his real point, societal self-destruction. Assuming the film's premise that plants are way smart, why would they want to kill us? Especially plants and trees that live in a park. Aren't they pampered, protected and cared for continually? The environmentalists are the ones trying to reduce the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere, that's what the trees breath! Maybe that's why they want to kill only in the predominately liberal Northeast. There is irony here, please appreciate it.

"Signs" was not about an alien invasion but about God being in control even when we can't understand everything He's doing. This is not about attack of the killer tomatoes but the strange suicide of the West.

title: M. Night Shyamalan's redeemed himself with a fresh new take on filmaking
review:
After lady in the water making you not care about his characters and the village with too much of a twist but still scaring you. M. Night Shyamalan has redeemed himself with a real look into the human psyche, instead of actors pretending.

The airborne pathogen inducing people to lose their sense of self preservation and consequently kill themselves, while it is invisible and not a huge beautiful special effect monster, it is still one of the scariest things that could be possibly put into a movie and seem realistic. After all, the whole "scary murderer, ghost, vampire" Thing has ceased to scare people.

I greatly admire this leap of faith that Shyamalan risked in order to create this film. That risk was simply a new approach to directing actors.

Actors nowadays are judged by their ability to display emotion, instead of the realism of their performances, this film however puts people in a very real threat situation and they react... well, like people, not actors. If you haven't seen the film yet, go into it thinking how would you react in certain situations, such as when Elliot, Alma and Jess meet the crazy old hermit and she accuses Elliot of attempting to steal her things He responds exactly like any person would.

Defensive, confused and abashed. While at the moment of the scene being played off it seems a little corny, in retrospect I was struck by the pure genius of such a reaction.

Though the movie lacked special effects, it was not lacking in fear and rather realistic gore which, at times (if you aren't too big on gore like I am) is a bit too much, someone turning on a lawn mower and having it run over them, or jumping into a lion exhibit at the zoo in order to kill oneself is not exactly something I needed to see, but it instilled fear, which i'm sure was the intension.

Overall, it was fabulous, if you aren't big on horror movies, this is the most clever and terrifying film without being corny and full of unreal occurrences. I loved being scared, and actually left the theater to blowing around tree's and strange mist (Mist doesn't happen in New Mexico) and i was actually afraid of the toxin for a split second.

title: creepy and engrossing
review: M. Night Shyamalan's is back with this disaster movie that is very creepy from the very first moment. It kicks off on a normal day, with people doing normal things until something terrible happens. Special effects are really strong, many scenes incredibly disturbing (the one in the zoo for instance), and the horror of the situation is captured and showed everywhere.Highly original, apart from the embarrassing family drama, shows a faceless and nameless threat driven by the wind, that is effective 100%. It's a thought-provoking work (as usual for this director), that shakes the audience and is well acted as well. A great movie with a concept not that original (nature rebelling) but told in an original way.

title: Stop analyzing the movie, it was great!
review: This movie was hardly horrible. Was it an Oscar winner, no. But I enjoyed it very much. For those of you saying it was unrealistic, what are you talking about? Some of the best movies of all time, Oscar nominated, classics are the most unrealistic. The Birds, Jaws, Jurassic Park, Independence Day....the list goes on....lighten up and stop analyzing everything. This means you bytesmythe43. Really, writing a list of why the plants couldn't be responsible? Are you serious? The whole idea, I thought was very cool and original. The idea that something is driving people to suicide, was awesome. That concept was great. The actual acts of suicide were so creative and I (a horror movie fan)loved the way they happened. Yes maybe the actual reason was a little silly, but I don't think they would have went the terrorist route, then someone would be complaining about that. If you like weird, odd, chaotic, the unexplained....then you will like this movie. Stop thinking too much!

title: Open your eyes people
review:
I don't find anything in the movie that bad, as some of the critics or the audience has blabbered out. M Night Shyamlan is one of the sensible directors in this era. His ideas, stories, concept really amazes you. I am not being biased at all. I too dint like the Lady In Water. But "The Happening" dint deserved to be treated like this.

And why the hell one has to compare to the previous movies. Sixth sense is no doubt a masterpiece, and no other movie will be like that. And his movies do have the element of reality, like how would one react in those paranormal situations. This movie is more on the line of SIGNS. This movie is way better and has a different concept when compared to other D-day, End of the world Kind of movie where there will be zombie all over hungry for blood. And this is the movie where nature prevails at the end.And I think even some of the critics and people are hungry for same kind of movies.

I won't say its THE BEST movie.But its worth a watch

title: Great storytelling
review: This is a great movie. At Disneyland, they used to have a ticket book where you'd have A through E tickets. Whereas an E ticket ride might be Space Mountain, a C ticket attraction might be Mr. Toad's Wild Ride. So...just because Mr. Toad's Wild Ride isn't an E ticket doesn't mean that it isn't well done nor enjoyable. I think this film is an extremely well done C ticket. Why does every film have to be a masterpiece? Why can't a film be like a fun, read-on-the-beach mystery? M. Night is still a master of unfolding a story. Maybe it's a matter of taste, but I find his style engaging. If you liked the "hand held cam" shot in Signs, there are similar, creepy moments in this movie to enjoy.

title: What's happening? A decent alternative to the summer blockbuster, that's what happening.
review:
M. Night Shyamalan has had a rocky track record as of late. While The Sixth Sense was a huge hit both financially and critically, his films have slowly been declining in critical praise and box office performance ever since, which was apparent from Lady in the Water, which didn't manage to break even during it's run and was generally viewed as one of 2006's worst films. The Happening is his first new project since his last disaster and it's been billed as Shyamalan's first R-rated movie. Despite the heavier rating, The Happening is similar in style, theme and content to Shyamalan's other films, although it's a bounce back in the right direction after a few mishaps.

The Happening chronicles an epidemic that sweeps the North-East coast of America. At first thought to be the result of a terrorist attack, large groups of people begin to become disoriented, lose their speech and commit mass suicide at random. The events occur sporadically, first in Central Park, then throughout New York City and eventually spreading throughout the whole North-East coast. Elliot Moore, a New York high school teacher, desperately tries to seek safety with his wife, Alma, and his best friend's daughter, Jess, as people begin inflicting death upon themselves all around them.

While the film was billed as a visceral, gory R-rated horror, that couldn't be further from the truth. The Happening is more of a drama that focuses on a horrific event, rather than a straight-up horror movie. This will be familiar for fans of Shyamalan who have likely grown accustomed to his slow-moving, atmospheric films that focus much more on character than they do on generating scares. This isn't to say that the film is without its freaky moments. Some of the mass suicides, particularly one where construction workers begin plunging to their deaths, are incredibly eerie and unsettling. The idea of people turning on themselves is creepy in itself, as one can really only rely on themselves in life. By having people randomly commit suicide, Shyamalan taps into the fear of people turning on themselves and he's got the visual style to create some very chilling imagery revolving around the suicides. His use of long wide shots allows the audience to focus on what's happening, as opposed to using jumpy, sporadic cuts that end up detracting from the content (like most horror/action directors use these days). Shyamalan's already proved himself to be a master of suspense with The Sixth Sense, and there are a few shocking moments throughout the film which had me jumping out of my seat that hark back to his horror debut.

The downside seems to be that in an attempt to get an R-rating, Shyamalan has thrown in numerous useless instances of gore. I'll admit I'm a huge fan of gore and violence, but it really feels out of place in a film like this. A scene in which lions bite a man's arm off or a scene where a man is torn apart by a lawnmower seems unnecessary and at odds with the rest of the film. Obviously it was a marketing strategy, but it detracts from the movie as a whole.

Another weak point of Shyamalan's is his script, particularly the dialog. While he's a great director, especially at building up suspense, and he's skilled enough when working with the plot, storyline and the twists he has become famous for, his dialog is really weak. Often the stuff they say is rather ridiculous and unrealistic (a young soldier says "Cheese and crackers" as opposed to a more common expletive) and it ends up evoking laughter in the audience. The attempts at comedy are also fairly poor, with characters randomly talking about "hot dogs" and other things of the sort. Shyamalan's strong suit isn't comedy and while humor could be a nice contrast in a dour movie like this, it doesn't work here.

The acting is also fairly bad, which is a surprise considering the cast. Mark Walberg and John Leguizamo have proved themselves to be good actors, but here they are pretty terrible, and most of the blame can be pinned on Shyamalan. They are both notorious for playing tough guys and here they're miscast, both portraying soft-spoken teachers. The issues with the dialog don't help them much either, and they're always overacting, in an attempt to appear more "nerdy" or things of similar nature. Zooey Deschanel is entirely wrong for her role, as Wahlberg's wife, and even the character is developed poorly. She talks like a character out of "Juno" (with the quips on the phone about Joey being a stalker) and she seems to quirky and unnatural for a movie like this, which stays fairly grounded in reality, at least for a horror. It's obvious that despite Shyamalan's directorial finesse behind the camera, he's not nearly as gifted when working with actors.

The Happening isn't nearly as good as some of Shyamalan's other efforts, nor is it nearly as bad as some. It's a decently good eco-thriller that manages to conjure up some good scares, with a message beneath them all. It's not the best horror film, but it's one of the more original ones to come out recently. It definitely doesn't deserve the critical drubbing it has gotten, but then again, the same critics smashing this film are praising mindless drivel like The Incredible Hulk, so it's to be expected that a more thoughtful film would be trashed. If you're tired of seeing the standard cookie-cutter summer blockbusters, do yourself a favor and give The Happening a shot.

title: Pretty good, but not the best it could have been
review: I would give it a 6 and 1/2, but I just gave it a seven. the reason I think I enjoyed this more than most people is because, I'm a fan of Mark Walhburg!I respect and love him and his work! I agree with a lot people when they talk about him getting into the role of Elliot.Mark's used to doing characters that are tough, this character's more laid back, gentle, and an all around sweet, appreciative, smart guy. So Mark really needed to try and practice hard to nail this role, So it's kinda hard to look at him differently, But all in all, he pulled it off, Not extremely good, but good, I could tell the hard work, and even though his characters are tough, they have a heart and caring side to them, which made it believable for playing " Eliiot". All of the people that go to this movie expect being scared, But if you know "M. Night", you know his movies like "Signs", weren't that scary, he goes for a more supernatural, kinda mystery thriller, not scary movie.I liked it, because I'm a fan of supernatural movies, whether scary of not. But that's for people like me, who love movies to death, where they look and see they idea's and get into the art and appreciation of the characters, there backgrounds, and can see where they're'e going. I could connect with them,especially Mark's. I'm also a sucker for romance though into this kinda movie, so I loved how in they end, the couple loved each other so much, they realized, how much they needed each other, and sacrificed themselves to be with each other.so for you movie buffs, who just like supernatural , and mystery, go see this movie.Expect to be creeped out, but not scared.

title: Something for the Summer....all that is required is a little imagination
review: I don't understand why this film is getting such a bad rep...oh yes, hang on, i do, it's because you have to be able to relate to movies to get it. I don't think that people got the fact that this is a 'End of mankind' movie with a little twist...we see everything from a very human perspective. There's no explosions, meteorites or high paced action, just well built tension and such an amazingly well told story. MNS knows the perfect pace and the perfect way to tell a story. So many people are expecting some sort of 'Twist', that they forget how to empathise with the characters and try to imagine what they would do if this really happened. i hear a lot of ranting about the dialogue, but i really found no problem with it, sure its a little ON THE NOSE, but people don't really speak in quotable lines of dialogue, i can't think of one real quotable line that anyone in real life has ever said. Im not complaining about most dialogue, I'm just saying that people should be more open to something a little bit different, and you are not one to be complaining if you rated D-WARS as a 8 out of 10 movie(yeah, I'm talking about you). If you want something a little bit different this summer, go and see the Happening.

title: Either outsmart the inexplicable or die. That's OK - in a movie.
review:
In "The Happening", we see an intense effort either to survive by outsmarting the inexplicable or to face the end with dignity. I found it appealing.

I liked Mark Wahlberg's science teacher and how he handled his class. The trick he played on one student might get him into trouble in today's hypersensitive world, but such theatrics must be tempting to many teachers. If everyone could teach like that, our test scores would be great.

I liked the struggle for an explanation. Not that I agreed with the movie's take on evolution, but when you are in a desperate run for your life from such an unknowable threat, you might improvise a bit. Wahlberg's character, the TV talking heads, and John Leguizamo's math teacher were all out of their depth, and they were all probably wrong about what was happening. But at least their theories fit the facts before them. The "force of nature", whatever it was, clearly affected smaller groups as time went on, and realizing that fact saved at least some of the characters.

I liked how Zooey Deschanel conveyed terror without surrender at least until there seemed to be good reason for surrender without terror. From the promotional clips, I was afraid that she was stuck with one of those old female characters whose only role was to just stand there. I was prepared to hate that, because her characters are usually strong people who can deal with life and convey their turmoil without the standard kicking and screaming.

However, her character did deal with life and taught us something valuable. The first shot of her face, a quietly expressive one, shows understanding of the scale of the danger if not the cause. Eventually, as a painful ending becomes likely, she shows how you can face this as long as you fulfill your responsibilities  in her case to atone for her contemplated transgression and also to the young girl in her care.

I was actually disappointed that the ending was so bland. There was no good reason for the movie to stick with the explanation as understood by the characters, who were making the best of very limited information. The danger they perceived could probably be overcome medically, and the movie needed to end by finding some new level of revolt by nature. Now I am stuck with trying to create my own ending, but maybe that is part of the fun.

title: This isn't what you'd expect from the trailer.
review:
I would like to start of by saying that this movie didn't live up to the expectations that I had for it from the buildup the last few months of waiting. I WAS looking for an all-out thriller that would scare the crap out of me throughout the entire movie. I left the theater having been entertained, but confused about how I felt.

I thought about it for a while and decided that it just wasn't what I was expecting. This doesn't mean I didn't like it, doesn't mean it was better than what I was hoping for, just different. I think I want to blame this on the trailers being developed for movies these days. Lately it seems too much is being done with trailers. Anyone else agree? "Twists" are given away in thrillers, all the funny parts are shown for comedies, and sometimes movies are advertised as something they just aren't.

Shortly after leaving the theater I decided that this movie is more like a parody than a thriller. The performances were obviously cheesy. They were great, in quite a not-so-subtle way. The thing that further impresses me is that the scary parts were truly intense and the funny parts were honestly funny. Everyone else in my packed theater seemed to think things were funny as well, as I heard them laugh. I suppose they think that the performances and humor were accidental and this is maybe a reason for their hatred of this movie. I also think it is because of the let downs everyone had for the buildup of the trailer.

If you go to this movie expecting an all-out thriller, you probably will be upset. If you go expecting an M. Night Shamyalan "Sixth Sense" you're going to for sure be let down. Go to have fun. Go to be scared. Go to watch a parody of disaster movies. You'll have a good time.

title: Jump on bandwagon bus M. Night.
review:
Here is the thing, and I think most of us agree... his best work, is The Sixth Sense... it's been down hill from there. As far as film is concerned. Personally my favorite M. Night movie was Unbreakable, just because I thought it was such a fresh look at superhuman abilities, tying it to comics. I could have taken or left The Village and I wasn't a fan of Lady in the Water. (Signs was good, but that was a love or hate movie I thought.) ---- Now, "The Happening" and it's funny, because 60 mins into this movie I said what the hell is "Happening." This is M. Night's lousy attempt to get on the Inconvienent Truth bus.

I love M. Night as a writer, but this is not a fresh idea. There was no twist. He actually made Mark Wahlberg look like a worse actor than he already is. This was junk. I knew the angle 15 minutes into this movie. Global Warming... wow... that's original. Other than the suicide scenes this was a whining rant, much like the guy on TV at the end of the film. Then cut to the "Happening" in Europe. Wow? really? let's confirm the guy on "CNN like news channel." Crap. This movie was crap. I don't mind Global Warming movies, if they are well thought out and have something behind them, but this had nothing... a moth story, and a fossil fuel story. Yaye.

The only two things I liked in this movie were the fact that it was short, and the fact that it was so bad that hopefully M. Night will sit down and rethink his line of writing, or quit doing it all together.

title: Stop Hating
review: I agree, when i saw this film the theatre was very full and people seemed to be right into the movie. Even the odd screams now and then. I can see how some people may not like the acting, some of the minor characters could have done better. This film gives an unsettling feel. l But over all i think this film is a true one for anyone who loves post apocalyptic movies. M Night should have stayed true to his twists. But i think the twist was more in the middle. When we realize that it was plants. I still love the plot and the idea of the film. M Night is staying as one of my top writers/directors. He'll come back with something.

title: The real twist is that you want to kill yourself after watching it.
review:
I have seen a lot of bad movies... But honestly, when I see actors like Wahlberg and Deschanel in a movie written and directed by someone who is supposed to be extremely talented (like M. Night, key words supposed to be) I expect something better than Pluto Nash. This film didn't deliver.

I came to the theater with very low expectations after his last two films. I am not an M. Night fan boy, but I have enjoyed a couple of his movies. Not having either a love or hate for him, I would've been satisfied with just a mediocre suspense flick, but this film fell so far from even mediocrity I honestly can't figure out how it ever got produced and released. M. Night was harping about how this movie was "absolutely terrifying," before its release, yet there was not one scene in the entire movie that was even a little bit scary or suspenseful. A little too big a fan of himself perhaps, but that's another matter completely.

Several times we saw the boom mics fall down into the camera view, and the "special effects" were so bad that everyone in the theater laughed at most of the scenes, even some of the more key ones that should've been dramatic. The acting was the most horrible thing I've seen in a big budget movie, and I say that with absolutely no exaggeration. M. Nights direction and writing were laughable. I don't know what else to say about it. After watching this movie I felt robbed. I want my $15 back for those tickets.

The most frustrating thing is that the movie is so bad that I know it must sound like this review is exaggerated, but it honestly is not and it's difficult to get that through when a movie is this bad. The acting is the worst I've ever seen. The plot development is terrible. The pacing is terrible. The writing is terrible. The direction is terrible. From the opening scene, I should've known right then to turn and run, but this is one of those movies you just keep thinking "it has to get better, right?" But it never does.

I think the real twist in this movie (other than the total cop out, afterthought, ridiculous ending) is that after watching it, you actually want to kill yourself.

After this, I can honestly say I will never pay to see another M. Night movie, and I hope that many people agree with me so that we never have another "The Happening" from this narcissistic no talent writer/director.

title: The worst crap ever!
review:
This "movie" sucks big-time. The manuscript is horrible, the acting is the worst i have seen yet, and the same goes for the photography, directing and cutting.

I am sorry that there is no possible way to vote "zero", because this movie doesn't even deserve to be rated "one". I will have difficulties taking M. Night Shyamalan seriously from now on.

Present me with a cheap home video cam, 4 randomly picked hobos that will work for a bottle of whisky, 14 days to write, direct, and film, and whatever i'll come up with, will beat this so-called "movie". I am not only very disappointed. I am shocked!

title: There is a 17% chance you might find this movie good...
review:
...and about a 99% chance that you will hear this title when it comes to awarding the Golden Raspberry award, while an equal chance you won't hear it once during the Oscar telecast! To summarize this film as best I can, the environment strikes a blow towards the extermination of the human race. The trees, long suffering at the hands of humans, begin to seep toxins (and obviously, a breeze...how that happens I'm not sure!!!) which cause a reaction in humans.

What kind of reaction? Well, it prompts a zombie like state in which the human victims seem unable to prevent themselves from killing themselves, however they do have the foresight and planning to plan out ways to kill themselves.

And kill themselves they do: whether its jamming a hair pin into their throats, walking the plank on a construction sight, steering a riding lawn mower and then proceeding to lay under it, or feeding limbs to lions, the level of uncomfortable ways to die seem to be ratcheted up over and over again! There's nothing really unique in the idea of nature vs humanity, however the common sense in this film is lacking, and it is that which becomes incredibly annoying! For instance Julian (John Leguizamo) pulls a number seemingly out of his head to express the chances that Trenton, NJ, where his wife was headed, is safe from the toxins. Of course, the minute he separates from Elliot (Mark Wahlberg), we know its only a matter of time before he bites the big one! Another problem is that the film seems to turn upon itself in its own contradictions. For instance, this toxin which is theorized produced by the trees, grass and bushes creates a sudden sense of disorientation which prevents the infected from speaking or remembering what they were doing just before- however in the zombie like state, it doesn't prevent them from devising rather complex methods of ending their lives. So in essence, its not hallucinations that the toxin prompts, but rather it is mind control! Does that really make sense? I know that Hollywood is sounding the alarms about the planet in part because there doesn't seem to be the political will to tackle the problem, however enough is enough.

As a side note, if you have lost someone to suicide, or are susceptible to suicidal ideation's/planning, or if you are horrified by the thought of suicide, this film really isn't for you. Having lost a family member to suicide, I found watching it problematic!

title: A good movie, but not Shyamalan's best
review:
After being extremely let down by Shyamalan's last film, "Lady in the Water", I did not know if this movie would be worth seeing. Since I enjoyed "Signs" and "The Sixth Sense" so much I gave it a chance. I was pleased with this decision.

The happening has been advertised as Shyamalan's first R rated movie. I believe this is due to the pure shock factor this movie has. Through out most of the movie my jaw was dropping to the floor, not because of gore, but because of shock. This movie shows excellent portrayal of what real people would do in this situation. Despite the criticism, Mark Wahlburg has a pretty good performance as Elliot Moore, the science teacher. His part could have been written better, but he does a nice job of acting it out.

The reason this movie is not excellent? The plot. This movie does not have a clever way to put things together like in Shyamalan's other films. The climax in this film hardily exists. This movie has an OK idea but Syamalan did not do anything to make it more interesting. However this does not ruin the movie. The violent deaths and shocking scenes keep this movie alive. 6 out of 10.

title: Dumbest Movie Ever?
review:
The good news is that this movie is short.

Of course, this makes you wonder what they left out. Were there scenes even more inane than the ones in the movie?

You've probably already seen the "spoiler" that the plant kingdom apparently gets ticked off at human beings for global warming or nuclear power or too many people choosing plastic instead of paper. So, the trees, shrubbery, etc. begin to emit a neuro-toxin that causes people to become dopey and then kill themselves.

Sad to say, but the most "entertaining" part of the movie is the variety of creative methods used to commit suicide. Sure, there are several pedestrian self-inflicted gunshot wounds to the head, but at least some people have enough imagination to hurl themselves off a construction site, climb trees so they can hang themselves over a country road, play Roy vs. Montecore at the Philadelphia Zoo, run a Jeep into a tree (did the driver think to disable the airbag before hitting the gas?), test the safety features of a commercial lawn mower (I see a lawsuit coming), and face-plant into a glass window.

You also have to hand it to the plant kingdom: they may be green and immobile, but the trees sure know how to rub it. They could have just produced a toxin that would kill us; but, noooooo, they have to emit something to make us want to kill ourselves. Now that's sending a message.

Technically, the movie is fine. The problem is that Shyamalan had an interesting idea and then decided to try to stretch it into a movie. It would have been great as a 20 minute student film, but no more.

Any claim this guy may have had to being the next Hitchcock (or even the next John Carpenter) is gone with the wind.

title: Try and Catch the Wind
review:
Greetings again from the darkness. Even in his less successful films, writer/director M Night Shyamalan usually delivers a thought-provoking, unique looking final product. This one, while not one of his better efforts, is no exception.

Roger Ebert fell in love with the insight shown by the characters in the midst of a wake-up call from nature. I say it is a terrific premise, and one most of us have at least thought about, yet it falls way short of showing us the insight of people into their own lives. Granted the dialog is limited, but most of these people just seemed dazed and confused.

None of the sub-plots are well developed and we are left to do most of the thinking and consideration ourselves. The talented director really just throws the idea out there. Actually, very little happens other than a few people are frozen in time until they walk backwards and harm themselves. The film does come alive briefly during the segments with Ft Worth's own Betty Buckley as Mrs. Jones, one of the most bizarre senior citizens whom could ever hope to encounter.

With all the missed opportunities and "inside jokes" like the nursery owner (Frank Collison) proclaiming his love of hot dogs, this one borders on boring rather than melancholy. Sadly Zooey Deschanel and Mark Wahlberg show little in their roles and John Leguizamo's sniveling role is an embarrassment for all men and his judgment is certainly outside the realm of reasonable. Don't miss Spencer Breslin's (Abigail's brother) brief, but fun role.

All said, this would have made a better Twilight Zone or Outer Limits episode since Night refused to work too hard on this one.

title: you never know....
review:
While there was some cheesy acting, disturbing death scenes, mass paranoia and hysteria, these things make up the components of a cult classic. I wouldn't be surprised if, like many of Shyalaman's features, turns into a midnight movie. Think about it. Besides what I've already mentioned, there's a doe eyed heroine played by Zooey Deschanel who stumbles around from scene to scene. Now recall all the old paranoia horrors and you'll find every nuance of The Happening as cheesy but equally frightening as any other cult classic. No matter which way you look at it, The Happening raises many questions about humanity environmentally and internally. People were afraid of Russian terrorists and aliens in the fifties and we're afraid of virtually the same things, this just happens to be a modern retelling.

Additionally, I have to give a shout out to the person who wrote the review titled "the not so happening". The fact that this person thinks that "Failure to Launch" is a good movie completely discredits his/her entire elementary reasoning in their review. Enough said.

title: don't mistake comically things for bad acting
review: When I saw revives for 'The Happing' I was a little upset. I kept thinking, "was it really not that good?" But of course I went to go see it anyways. People were going in to the movie theater expecting a hardcore scary movie, so they came out thinking this movie had really poor acting, and a dumb storyline. My personal opinion is that the movie was more comically than people realized; they mistook funny moments for bad acting. And when you think about it most of Shyamalan's movies have a comically aspect to them. So if you're going to see this movie go with an open mind; just don't walk in thinking this is going to be the scariest movie ever, or you'll end up disappointed.

title: i "happened" to enjoy it (snicker)
review:
after the disappointing and obnoxious egotism of lady in the water made a mediocre m night shyamalan movie seem amazing by comparison, but for some reason i really did enjoy the happening more than the village and lady.

from the opening credits i knew i was not about to be disappointed, while most people create credits with a black screen and long shot of a city shyamalan gives an eerie pattern of slow moving clouds and a discordant progressive overture, i mostly skip credits on DVD but i will watch this odd arrangement again and again.

the rest of the movie holds up in a similar way, unexpected and(usually) pleasurably so. the deaths are a new type of horror for shyamalan not startle or jump out at you but more of disturbance and unsettling presences, the cinematography and imagery hold up beautifully, the screenplay, not always so. after the old English dialog the village and the awkwardness of lady in the water i forgot how skilled m night is at writing dial and crafting realistic characters and sometimes he seems to forget himself. the couples feuding over having a dinner date with a friend(played by m night shyamalan) is borderline absurd and definitely laughable, and an extended conversation with an older couple is an attempt to be funny but is an obvious blunder as comedy and a lazy and awkward way to advance the plot.

overall this is a good transitional movie of m night movie away from misguided experimentation and back towards hard hitting urban horror, come with an open mind and you will enjoy.

title: A painful experience....
review:
This truly seems like the work of a very inexperience director and of a really low budget movie. If you can, try to spend those $8 to buy a ticket for some other movie. Trust me, I wish I could get back those two hours of my life back. There was part of the film that was just painful to watch. Given that there were 1 or 2 moments that were pretty horrifying but overall the movie was just pointless. The story was pretty good but might have needed few more editing.

What's the deal with making the movie funny? I know humor in needed every now and then but think about if the director is trying to shoot a serious scene but trying to make it funny at the same time is just simply bad directing. I still can't believe that the same guy made Sixth sense and Sign.

title: The Happening Night!
review:
Saw this movie yesterday... on Friday the 13th...last show which started at 2230 hrs. I was expecting a real thriller and rater R horror flick, Night didn't disappoint this time. I was very upset after watching Lady In the water... couldn't believe it was from Night. Mark Wahlberg stole the entire show. Brilliant job.. although this role was totally different from what he play in The Departed.. nonetheless, it was perfect. what i liked in this movie, is that it was very much different from a typical Night genre movie. the happening of events could be very much real. in a nutshell, it was a very good concept. i would give it a 7/10 the best part: James Newton's music & of course, Mark W. the worst & wasted part: Zoey

Go, watch it once...

title: A good old scare.
review: I can see why people didn't like this film, i genuinely can. The story line never really extends beyond what is presented to us in the first scene. And at times the acting leaves a lot to be desired. But then I, and others who I saw it with, were genuinely scared by the mindless suicide witnessed throughout, and the aftermath of it all. The scene of the hangings springs instantly to mind. And the truly terrifying performance by Betty Buckley. As a horror film, and as a person who enjoys the scare factor of a horror film, I can say this film does not put the genre in a bad light, nor has M. Night. Shyalanan let himself down. The film offered a good blend of horror and sci-fi, and at times, despite cheesy, a comedy edge to it. I feel that if the protagonists had shown a greater bond with each other, and formed emotional attachments with the audience, i would have been more gripped and involved with the film. As it was i felt detached and a mere onlooker. Considering this film left a lot of loose ends untied, and sorry attempts to explain it with a shockingly over the top news report, I thoroughly enjoyed it.

title: Horrible acting, Horrible plot.
review:
I was really hyped up about this movie when I first started seeing the trailers. So I gathered some friends and went out to watch, even though I read that this movie wasn't very promising. I think I should have followed that advice, obviously.

There's not much to say. The acting is horrible. Even Marky Mark was barely mediocre. There's no chemistry between him and his horrible acting "wife". The dialogue is childish and predictable. One of the final scenes where he's talking to his wife across the field was the breaking point for me. I decided to walk out of this horrible movie.

I cannot say this enough, the acting is just utterly horrible. And the lines are so stupid. "Close the windows and door", "why is there something wrong". Well duh, you know there is, why ask??? This kinda thing really gets on my nerves.

There are a few funny scenes though. I don't think they were meant to be funny, but I found them quit humorous. I think these comic relief scenes were the best parts of the movie.

Anyways, if you want to waste some money, and a little of time, since the movie is short, go right for it. But I would wait for it to come on TBS...

title: Unintentionally hilarious
review:
Here I thought M. Night Shyamalan had finally made a movie I would like. The movie even started out very well, setting up a mysterious and interesting premise. But once they start tossing theories around, and acting on those ideas, the film becomes an unintentional comedy. Outrun the wind! Nature only hates us in groups larger than five!

The few moments of intended comedy are the least funny moments in the film, completely out of place and forced. Pointless subplots and relationship issues don't help the matter any. In the end, it's just a boring mess. As one critic stated, "The Happening is a movie to walk out of, sleep through, or - best of all - not to bother with"

Shyamalan's films have gotten progressively worse with each new one, and this is easily one of his worst, but I don't think I can call it worse than his Lady in the Water.

title: Cheese & Crackers
review: Im telling you I've supported & love the Nights work right up till this point.However if the man has any sense he will just disappear for a long time after this.Sad to say thats not going to happen cause hey did anyone else catch the shameless promotion of his next project towards the end of The Happening?!?!?The R rating is a gimmick folks I knew this when I saw the posters with the highlighted R. I knew it when the TV ads had nothing under the rating ie Violence Language etc. I thought maybe it was just the studio but alas I was dead wrong. You want to know what The Happening is about? Nothing.Nothing but a big middle finger to all the people who have supported him post Sixth Sense. I cant say anymore really im too disappointed. Welcome to the fold Manoj Nelliyattu Shyamalan.

title: Show Girls 2...?
review: OK, first of I am going to say that I have been satisfied with some of Shyamalan's previous movies, like The Sixth Sense and to some extend Signs. That said I cannot say that I found The Happening remotely satisfying... and I normally love these kind of movies were you are supposed to get the feeling that something huge and extraordinary is going on, whether it will be aliens, natural disasters or a strange virus. To get to the point... the acting in this movie is the worst I have seen since... well since I saw Show Girls. It was that bad. At times I was wondering if this was some kind of a new public joke, to see how long people were going to watch such bad acting. The plot seemed random at best and the dialog is... well it is.... my god it is bad. This is what you would expect from a school play (a really bad school that is). The movie constantly got you thinking things like, "what the hell was that all about", "what? WHAAAT?", "no your kidding me right?" and "please don't let it be the plants". I just got home from the cinema and to be honest with you, once again, I am shocked to see the score on IMDb. Over 6... who gives this movie over 6 in score. I will give this movie 3 stars (and then I am being generous). 1 for the first 5 minutes of the movie which was actually kind of good, 1 for at least trying to make a new sci-fi movie, since I strongly believe that we don't get enough of those, and at last but not least, 1 for making me laugh my ass off at certain scenes which was so weird, so misplaced and so poorly acted out that I was almost peeing myself. If you thought this movie was, well lets say average, then I can strongly recommend Show Girls. It has got a lot of the same qualities. Enjoy.

title: The opening scene and (some of) the performances were about it...
review:
What starts out strong sometimes burns out fast, and The Happening, a "psychological thriller" based on an unknown phenomenon leaving mass suicide in its wake, is no exception, as it fails to live up to the hype, or even it's writer/director's past achievements.

Certainly not M. Night Shyamalan's best, this film left me feeling cheated, and like I had been condescendingly preached to. It falls prey to many of the trendy plot vehicles utilized in a slew of modern thrillers - as my brother said while we were watching it, "terrorists are the new asteroids." I've seen worse movies to be sure, but this was extremely disappointing based on Shyamalan's previous body of work. Not to rehash what I'm certain a lot of other reviews say, but of course Sixth Sense and Unbreakable were awesome. I even liked the Village quite a bit. But everyone runs out of steam sometime and it seems Shyamalan has reached a point where the initial "surprise" we expect has evaporated, and we're left running on empty.

What starts as a great premise, one which hearkens back to the best of Hitchcock and The Twilight Zone, comes up short here in a thin, weak script, and a tragic loss of pace which turns what could be a genuinely spooky thriller into little more than a dark comedy. I'm sure my opinion is a little slanted, as I tend to laugh at a lot of horror movies, but there are some genuine laugh-out-loud moments here which are severely misplaced, to the point that they draw laughs away from the intentional jokes inserted in an unnecessary attempt to lighten the mood.

The performances were decent, with Ashlyn Sanchez (as the little girl, Jess) giving the best performance, par for the course now in Shyamalan's films. I disagree with some of what I've read in that I feel Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel gave decent performances. John Leguizamo was excellent as always, but the script left all three of these fine actors chewing scenery, as we are left to build tension ourselves in a failed attempt to create environmental and circumstantial dread.

Add to that a number of plot devices we can assume were introduced to build character involvement, none of which are followed through effectively, if at all, and the audience simply doesn't care about these people, preventing any horror or tension from building.

SPOILER: As can be expected, Shyamalan seems ready to depart from his "spooky buildup, then a mind-bending twist" formula, but this one, which simply ends right when one expects it may finally be getting good, could use a little twist, or at least a squeeze of lime. There is simply no flavor here, and the pacing initially whets your appetite for a main course that simply isn't coming.

My other, personal diatribe involved here is not so much against this film, but more so against the MPAA and the movie ratings industry itself. Believe you me, I LOVE the GORIEST, and MOST OFFENSIVE movies around, and am not easily, if at all, shocked. That said however, the whole "M. Night Shyamalan's first R rated film" angle that is being beaten to death in the marketing campaign for this film is a load of hooey. I have seen WAY gorier and more offensive stuff in PG-13 films, and if this is the same R rating as we get for both Pretty Woman AND the Saw franchise, then god help any confused parents trying to decide whether this is acceptable fare for their children. Take my word for it, it IS... unless you count those kids being bored to death. (Watch "This Film is Not Yet Rated" for a great explanation of the bizarre MPAA ratings system.)

Overall, I'll suggest that you wait for the DVD on this one, or even better, torrent a cam version. Even with that crappy quality, you won't miss anything.

title: Move along. There's nothing happening here.
review:
I tend to take everything that I read on the Internet with a grain of salt, but given the steady stream of rumblings from the Internet crowd pronouncing that The Happening was pretty bad, I felt that I needed to take a look for myself. Now normally I wouldn't give the Average Joe's opinion much weight, but the fact that The Happening had slipped to the Movie of the Week at my local cinema in the space of seven days, it gave some credence to what I had been hearing - The Happening just wasn't happening.

For once, I'm in complete agreement with the Average Joe.

I'm not going to reveal too much of the plot, just on the off chance that you might actually want to see The Happening, but like most of Shyamalan's films, the less you know about it going in the better. Okay, so here's the basic setup: The Happening revolves around a family on the run from a largely unexplained natural disaster with the potential to cripple the continental United States  possibly even the entire world. The story opens in New York City, where we are soon alerted to the fact that an inordinate number of citizens appear to be topping themselves in bizarre and gruesome fashions. In typical Yank overreaction, fueled by media hype, the nation suspects that they are in the midst of an advanced biological terrorist attack from enemy, or enemies unknown.

In all honesty, the premise for The Happening sounded reasonably interesting  akin to the sort of inventive horror fare that you might expect to see coming out Japan or Korea. Despite the fact that the theatrical trailers hinted at this film being another one of those 'end of the world' blockbusters that crop-up around this time every year, much to Shyamalan's credit, the film doesn't rely on clichéd explosions and ridiculous action setpieces to entertain. Instead, the meat of the film revolves around the random collection of characters and their relationships as they try and escape the chaos enveloping them. The protagonists (for a lack of a better word) will certainly act as a catalyst for some amusing/interesting debates once the credits roll. Come to think of it, this sounds like familiar territory. It's been well publicized that the director is a devotee of Alfred Hitchcock  hmm, I can't help but think that The Happening may be Shyamalan's homage to Hitchcock's The Birds obviously minus the titular birds, oh, and the fact that The Happening was bloody terrible.

As mentioned previously, The Happening doesn't need to rely on expensive CGI effects or massive explosions to tell the story  it's all about the characters and their journey. Now just about anyone with an IQ above twenty should be able to appreciate a character-driven story, but what happens when your characters are idiotic and unlikable? What happens when the very actors portraying those characters put in a performance that would rival a plank of wood or, dare I say, maybe even Keanu Reeve's on his best day?

I don't know if Shyamalan was specifically going for a C-Grade horror movie feel, but from the woeful banter between two characters on a park bench in the opening scene, to the foreboding few last seconds of celluloid, I almost thought that I was watching some well-financed film student's end-of-term project that had found its way onto the big screen. Think Italian Spiderman with a multi-million dollar budget.

The acting was absolutely woeful  preschool pageant woeful. I haven't cringed that much during a film since Ed Norton stomped some black kids teeth into the gutter in American History X, nor have I been that embarrassed for another human being since Richard Simmons appeared on Whose Line Is It Anyway. The whole cast sucked. Period. While I'm not going to single-out anyone for a special mention, I was expecting a lot more from a line-up that contained the likes of Mark Wahlberg and John Leguizamo. I almost had the feeling that they were having a laugh was this for real? Did they skim over the script, find out who/what the protagonists were and collectively decided to ham it up purely in protest? If you want ham, have Bruce Campbell on speed dial.

If the poor acting didn't kill all immersion in the story, the characters sure will. It's hard enough trying to emotionally invest in the well-being of a bunch of clowns who can barely deliver their lines in any sort of credible fashion, but multiply that by a hundred when those characters are also complete morons. Their motivations. The idiotic crap that came out of these characters mouths. I'm going to lay the blame squarely at the feet of Shyamlan and his screenplay. Case in point, take the hippie plant nursery owner espousing the virtues of the humble American hotdog like the director was getting a kickback from the National Hotdog Foundation... oh, or what about the lone soldier doing his best Gomer Pyle impression. Christ, even Pyle wouldn't have been caught dead uttering the phrase "cheese and crackers" when the world is going to Hell in a handbasket.

After twenty minutes in, I couldn't give a toss as to whether these characters lived forever or died that very instant.

I've decided to keep this review relatively short and sweet - I was going to go on an atypical rant about how M. Night Shyamalan is the most overrated director working in Hollywood today, how his work is little more than a film student homage to Alfred Hitchcock films, and how he struck it lucky with The Sixth Sense but meh, slamming Shyamlan is almost a national sport these days. After watching The Happening, I really can't be bothered wasting any more time on this guy  the proof is in the pudding.
