title: Gr8 Movie
review: Master piece by Indian maker...... some says pathetic but same movie made by Spielberg than it is recognized as futuristic movie... ..therefore i strongly says i gr8 movie ................ ....10/10 no problem at all giving full numbers it totally deserves it !!!!! GOOD Work Shyamalan !!!! sorry i forgot to say hats off to him for making such a masterpiece and also recommend him please make such type of movie for bollywood.. his work is very much appreciated in India and many Indian stars work in it.... He hasn't made 10 movies yet and 3 of them are already on the IMDb top 250. Overall The happening is the kind of movie that will make the audience cheer in the end instead of throwing fruit & vegetables on the screen.

title: Say Good Night to M.Night - SPOILERS
review:
I have given M.Night movies their last chance.

In 1999 I was blown away by a film written and directed by a local unknown writer/director. The Sixth Sense was nothing like I had seen before. It was one of the few films I had seen where I had NO CLUE what was going to happen. It was well written, directed and acted. I looked forward to M. Night Shyamalan's next film.

Next came Unbreakable. It was not really my "kind" of film, but enjoyable. I was still a fan. His next film, Signs, was filmed in my neighborhood and I watched Mel Gibson rehearse, and followed Joaquin Phoenix down the street in the Philly burbs. I found Signs to be suspenseful and, again, well directed and acted. The Village may not have been a 10, but the cast was fantastic and the twist worth the price of admission, in my opinion. I was still a fan.

Then came Lady In the Water. I am still trying to figure that one out. At least people talked about it. And Paul Giamatti was in it. Not much else I can say. My faith in M. Night was really fading...but I was still willing to give him the benefit of the doubt. I mean, he DID write and direct The Sixth Sense! NO MORE. M. Night, you have lost my paid admission. Perhaps you have lost your place in Hollywood, too. The Happening was the worst movie I have seen in...well, ever. The writing was watered down, the characters were one dimensional and the actors brought nothing to the role (wasn't Mark Wahlberg nominated for an Oscar once???). He and Zooey D. seemed embarrassed to be in the film. There was no suspense after the first 10 minutes. The shock and awe was there (a man gets run over by a lawn tractor and blood spurts from a head wound like a cheap horror flick) but no substance. This film had the look and feel of a student film.

SPOILERS: After approximately 10 minutes of setting up what could have been an interesting film about human nature being "controlled" by some toxic substance of earth, ended up being 80 minutes of people running away from the wind. Literally. I did not buy this premise one bit and the only possibility of a unique view (the lonely women who couldn't grow plants played by Betty Buckley) ended up being squashed when she, in turn, is killed by the plants in the wind. Oh, then all of a sudden when the two main characters venture out into the "wind", the toxins stop. How convenient! Oh and make sure that you end this story with the ever cliché pregnancy. I couldn't have guessed that one. the theater emptied with SILENCE. There was nothing to talk about.

This film felt like a student's attempt to force feed you the director's view on global warming and that if we keep abusing Mother Nature, it will lash back like in some science fiction film. I have given M. Night Shyamalan his last chance to "wow" me with his talent. Fool me one, shame on you; Fool me twice, shame on me. It is over.

title: What a crap!!!!!
review: I have just wasted one and a half on this boring movie, what's a crap. The title of the movie is "Happenning", but, believe me, nothing is happening! I agree with the previous reviews, this director is constantly deteriorating in movies he has been directing and this movie just touched the bottom. The idea of the movie just sucks. The leading actress is a disaster! And her acting was bad enough to incorporate nicely into this bad movie. I don't mention Mark Walberg, who participated in writing the screenplay and is playing the main character. If you don't want to waste a time, stay away and go see other movie, because any movie you will choose will be better.

title: This movie is funnier than You Don't Mess with the Zohan.
review:
This movie was hilarious. The trailer made it seem sort of scary, but I had no idea it was a comedy. Mark-E Mark was such a funny science teacher! He was good at talking about science, but I liked him better in New Kids on the Block! It made sense how the math teacher used math a lot! I liked that.

I laughed when Mark-E Mark's wife didn't really care about other people and was just acting so silly. She didn't make any sense at all! It was hilarious.

It was silly how they ran away from wind like that! It was also pretty comical when things that were obvious to the viewer went completely ignored by people in the movie.

I didn't like when the people hurt themselves! It almost made me not want to watch the movie. I think that movies can be funny without the use of violence! People getting their arms ripped off by lions is NOT FUNNY, even when it's fake!

All and all, I thought this movie was pretty good. It sure was funny! Parts of it were sort of boring, and I didn't really understand why other people in the theater weren't laughing? Maybe they just didn't get it!

As soon as the credits for this movie started, my 56 year old father stood up and said, "That was s***," and walked out.

He's so silly!

title: well made and definitely a must see.
review:
I watched the movie VERY late because of all the criticism the movie got. But in the end i decided to watch it because Mark Wahlberg's movies are usually good/entertaining.

It was honestly very good; the characters were realistic, as were the scenes in the movie - huge sense of realism, and people should have been able to relate to it..However, people are looking for something more dramatic and more climatic, like the end of the world or something, which this movie doesn't deliver.

The acting wasn't meant to be flawless, it was meant to portray human nature and the actors and the director achieved this.

All in all, it's a movie that makes you think and please don't mock the script, it was honestly very well made and its a very thoughtful movie.

The only other movie i saw from Mr. Shymalan was the sixth sense, which was years ago, and i liked his directing style. His movies are different, because they're not over the top - The idea behind this movie might be hard to digest, but do watch it, and think about the message that the movie is trying to relay across...

title: I have to disagree with most here.
review:
This movie was the best Shyamalan movie since The Sixth Sense. Most people don't realize that his writing style for this is less focused on the fear factor of a pandemic, and more on characters that are scared, but are mostly trying for a way to improve their situation and out-think the danger.

The dialogue in this movie was incredible, especially for Wahlberg, who usually just comes off as corny, actually had many lines that fit his persona, and fit his character.

The casting was great, the directing was great, the action was great, even the ending wasn't bad.

I think M. Night Shyamalan has finally matured as a writer.

title: Another underrated film by MNS
review:
To all: The Happening was a good film. There,I said it. Some people disagree, but their reasons for finding the movie bad or tasteless bothers me (but doesn't surprises me). I remember people giving The Village bad reviews initially because not everyone understood the film for what it was right away. Looking back on it now, I think most people will agree that Village was a great film. I think Happening is receiving the same initial bad rap that Village got, but in time most MNS fans, and others who watched the film will conclude that Happening was a good film.

I feel people are misunderstanding Happening. Two main complaints regard the acting, and the plot/script/story. As I was reading the reviews I began to think that I had misunderstood the acting. For a second I too started to think that the acting was bad. But thankfully I read someone's comments regarding the acting and dialogue:

"If the dialog seems simplistic, well, look a bit deeper and realize exactly what 'regular folk' might say or do if the events of this Happening actually were occurring... this is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends... not with the bang of snappy repartee or quotable sound-bytes, but with the whimper of incredulity and dread.

Complaining about the acting or dialog in The Happening is like complaining about the 'jumpy camera work' in Cloverfield."

Just like in all MNS movies, I felt that the acting was on point in Happening. The acting is not only a statement on how people "might" behave during such a catastrophe, but a statement on how people do behave even when there is so much to lose. Consider this: right now I'm writing this review, and shortly, you'll be reading it as if there's nothing better to do in the world. And at the same time of my writing, and your reading, the USA is fighting in a war! Yet here we both are, concerning ourselves with issues ridiculously less important as if nothing were happening at all.

The beauty of Happening (much like Village) is that it leaves most of it's audience thinking "This is ridiculous/lame, because it could never happen." Unfortunately, Happening/Village weren't portraying events that "could" happen, but events that have and are happening. People leave the theatre bickering about how preposterous the plot/story was, but in actuality the only thing preposterous is that the film was a clear portrayal of our world today and no one realized it.

But anyway, I won't keep going on and on. I just hope no one gets dissuaded from watching the film, and that those who gave it negative feedback rethink their opinions.

title: Excellent blend of intelligence and imagination
review:
I know a lot of people don't seem to understand M Night Shyamalan. I really enjoy his films and with the exception of 'Signs', I have always found so much to think about and talk about after. This is no exception and I was pleasantly surprised after having read the reviews.

If you liked the mellow side of Sixth Sense, and the un-Hollywood drama of Lady in the Water, then I think you will enjoy this film. I know that it has been said that the characters react in very odd ways  but I would say that this was a lot more true to life. There is a real Hitchcock feel to the whole thing. If he was making films now, this is what I think he would be doing.

I've never seen Mark Wahlberg in a bad film, and this is no exception. From the way he deals with his students at the beginning, to the way his character adapts to the tale as it unfolds  it's all excellent stuff. The reaction of other characters - from their voyeuristic fascination, to their complete non-reaction, was refreshingly realistic.

I haven't enjoyed a film this much since Lord of the Rings. It's not an action movie, - it is more intelligent than that.

title: A Movie ahead of it's time
review:
Before watching this movie don't go on the internet and read reviews about it at all. Because if you do it this way, you will not be truly open minded to what the movie is trying accomplish. And before watching this movie really ask yourself how you feel about the state of the world today, considering all the talks of it ending in 2012.

I thought Mark Walberg and Zooey Deschanel did a great job with the movie. The problem that I had with M.Night's previous work "Lady in the Water" was simply, the characters didn't act normal, and they all seemed to strive to be too peculiar due to the fact that this was an M.Night movie. I saw this to be the problem in the first 10 minutes of the "Happening", but it was quickly rescued starting with the believable acting role of John Leguizamo. In the end it was additionally all brought together by the very complicated relationship of Walberg and Deschanel(Which was great!) The reason I say this movie was ahead of it's time is because it directly deals with scaring one not by folkloric trickery, CGI, or funny shaped monsters, or super sudden and expected killing patterns, but by the scientific possibility of something that could totally happen to our planet.

Of course majority of the thrill seeking youth won't be excited after having seen this one, as it doesn't have to do with a Big Bad Wolf, along with three little Piggys, or some super predictable eerie killing creature that can't be stopped until the end. Even adults who don't broaden their minds will have a hard time grasping hold of this film. People always want the norm, and things to happen in the natural order of the standard desire. After watching this movie I know that the fact that M.Night can scare me by the howl of the wind, and the crinkle of leaves and plants is a true art form in itself.

title: Shyamalan as a Thinker / Filmmaker in today's Cinema
review:
M. Night Shyamaln's best film yet! Do not fall in the trap of what the critics say. Remember Vertigo by Alfred Hitchcock which was not well received by the critics at the time it was released. Now it is #9 on the AFI's 100 greatest films. M. Night Shyamalan and Darren Aronofsky are two great filmmakers of their generation.

Terrorism is not just a social happening; it is environmental. Terrorism is not something from outside. It is something from inside. It is our intention which makes the environment murderous. The environment responds to what is "happening" within us. And the environment includes humans, animals, plants, and the air we breathe. It is everything.

Our actions might have an appearance of benevolence, but our intentions are the source of real benevolence OR malevolence. Offering food and shelter to someone when we just do it because we have to is NOT benevolence, as was the case with Betty Buckley's character. The movie is full of different characters with different intentions. The John Leguizamo's character with gossipy and envious bent, the soldier's supposedly protective-and-serve attitude with his obsession toward his gun, two young boys with prying arrogance and a sense of entitlement.

When you truly want to live for someone else, to serve someone else, to love someone else, then you will survive. That is the intention which is fundamentally woven into the fabric of this planet and the universe. The rest leads to destruction, sooner or later as the movie tries to point out. So does the theory of Punctuated Equilibrium stating that how we adapt to our environment decides our fate as a species. Our individual fates are bound with our identity as a species.

title: It Was Good
review: In my opinion, i thought that the movie was really good, weird and different. It has a different concept from other scary movies and even though there was no reason cause of the events causing the people to harm themselves, the script was excellent. Although The Sixth Sense And Signs were box offices hits, i believe that this one will be a hit also.It's Shyamalan's first rated R movie and i believe that for his first one, it's very good. It's much better than Lady In The Water. Mark Walberg, & John Leguizamo did an excellent job in this film, so did M. Night Shyamalan.I recommend to everyone to go out and see the movie.

title: The Happening isn't what people seem it to be.
review: I took a day off and actually watched this movie. I analyzed it as I watched, but The Happening actually surprised me more than I expected. I anticipated a HORRIBLE film, but it wasn't half bad. The plot line was excellent. Mark Wahlberg could have done a better job, really. But I guess we are SO used to him being such a bad-ass that him being a serious character was, well, kind of disappointing. I work at a theater and everyone who has come in has asked me if that movie is good. All I can say is "If you ignore the ending, it is." The ending isn't a BAD ending, but it isn't an ending that we get from Night. There is no plot twist. It's what we see is what we get. I actually enjoyed that..for once. I also liked that the fact that this could possibly happen. Plants do react to human stimulus, and if a plant feels threatened, it produces what it needs to in order to get rid of what is attacking the plant. So, from a perspective of a theater worker and a movie lover, I'd pay 8.50 to see this movie. I'd pay 19.99 to get it on DVD. It's not what people expect, and that's what makes it actually appealing.

title: Masterpiece of Humility and Altruism over Arrogance and Selfishness
review: Another masterpiece from the maddeningly misunderstood and much maligned auteur M. Night Shyamalan. Beware: spoiler alert!! The Happening is a first-rate, suspenseful, Hitchcockian morality play chronicling the struggle between rational man and an unknowable world. Humanity consists of selfish arrogance (or selfish insanity) and unselfish humility. When confronted with the unknowable, only the latter endure. Along with the main characters--a married couple and a child--we watch helplessly as the selfish and self-assured attempt to explain, flee, or conquer The Happening only to meet their own grizzly demises as comeuppance for their nasty, selfish, and brutal lives. Survivalists, jingoists, and proselytizers, among many others, reap what they sow while the humble, kind, and unassuming lead characters continually exhibit the behavior that insulates them from The Happening. Our heroes are forced to care for a child, nearly left behind at a small-town diner, and almost blown away by shotgun blasts. But they persevere and even thrive while others do not for one reason and one reason only: they do not presume to have all the answers and are always considerate and selfless - even in the middle of a crisis. Shyamalan's lesson is that we should live our lives with humility and altruism despite being surrounded by a sea of presumption, pomposity, materialism and egotism. Of course Hollywood has no idea how to market Shyamalan's films and this time they're banking on the willingness of 15-year-old mall rats desperate to part with their summer movie dollars on any horror flick that comes their way. Of course this picture, like all of Shyamalan's work, belongs in front of an educated film audience willing to challenge themselves and dig beneath the surface for enlightenment through art. Sadly, nearly everyone--critics and audiences alike--failed to "get" this film just as they failed to get each of his masterpieces that came before. But that shouldnâ't surprise Shyamalan as nearly everyone succumbs to the happening too.

title: A MUST SEE FOR ALL GENERATIONS (or maybe not so for the really young kids for some violent images though)
review:
Come to think of it, I have watched all M. Night's movies whether they were on theaters or after they were released on DVDs. It seems as though the director comes back on top every other films. First it was the sheer genius work of Sixth sense, and then the downer..., the "unbreakable" (what the heck was that, really!?). After that it was the good old, "Village," (I truly loved it). Then it was that intellectually insulting (as far as the ethnicity studies & anthropological aspects go) "lady in the water." And now this time, M. Night comes back with his game on a full throttle. Two very enthusiastic thumbs up for the HAPPENING.

It's a story about " the attack of the mother nature." Although it was a bit hard to read between the lines and some sequences time to time, the message the movie conveys just overwhelms you and makes you think about Human vs Nature relationship again and again.

Some reviewers argued that the acting was just so unnatural and unrealistic. But one must keep in mind that that was done all purposefully to give a unique look/feel to the movie. In its simplest term, acting wasn't the most important part of the film. Some people also criticized that script was just too poorly written. I say those who say so are not much of readers. The script was near perfectly knitted together and riddled with clues and signs so cleverly that makes an educated reader go, "wow." Let's face it though, yeah.... not so much Drama-Drama. But why? Because the movie really isn't about it, either.

We humans arrogantly think that we "own" the nature that surrounds us. And that's a flat out ignorance and gravely destructive misunderstanding. We humans are mere part of the nature that allows us humans to be who we are. The mother nature owns our destiny no matter how hard we try to overcome all the natural disasters that occur every year around the glob. No more unrestricted drillings of oil on land and ocean and exploitation of forestation by cutting down trees. And to top it all off, the issue of over-population is going out of control and makes the provisional conditions of food supplies all around the world worse and worse each year.

M. Night goes to the extreme and tells us a story of what if the mother nature says she's had enough and decides to preserve herself by getting rid of those who threaten her own existence here on earth. And that threat turns out to be us, Humans. This is s a powerful message and one should not ignore it as just a thing in a summer blockbuster movie.

I say the movie is for all generations because it is perhaps the biggest issue that we all face and everyone should take part in learning about it. I kinna regret that M. Night chose to go rated-R for this project for I would have hesitated to take my own children (if I had children that is) to go see it all together because of its graphic death scenes (This is why 1 minus 10 stars.) But I guess that was also well intended and absolutely needed in the directors mind.

In the movie, only adults die of this "neuto toxin" released by plants. And we see two kids die only in the hands of adults who shoot them with rifles to save their own fannies. Perhaps, this is why M. Night only wanted adults to come see his movies. To make us think about our actions and responsibilities we have for our children.

title: Loved it!
review:
I loved it!

Another horror (or was it sci-fi?) movie for adults, or at least for people of all ages who have more than two brain cells to rub together. We're beginning to see more of those and thank Yog-Sothoth for that! I was beginning to fear the genre (not gen-dre by the way, just genre ending with an almost silent "e") had died and gone to teeny bopper cat-jumps-on-the-table-and-that's-supposed-to-be-a-very-scary-moment hell.

Shyamalan claims he just wanted to make a B flick. Well, folks, he missed his mark once again. I say he perpetrated a damn good, atmospheric film. He's got a knack for setting up nearly silent, eerie screen moments that really put you on the edge of your seat. In his way, he's got as much timing and pacing as Stephen King does. The actors do a very good job (I can't believe Wahlberg used to be a pop idol: he's actually become a pretty decent actor), there's some very interesting camera work, and I felt I was told a captivating story.

Is it flawless? Nope, but it's really, really well done nevertheless. It kept me there and involved 'till the end. It was worth my bucks, my time, and writing about it.

Is the ending bad? Nein, mein Liebling. The ending could have been more flamboyant (I'm thinking, say, of the hand that emerges from the grave at the end of Carrie) but I think that anything else would have been cliché. I liked the ending just the way it was. The story's mainly a snapshot in the life of the main characters and life, from what I know, usually just ends without fanfare, explanations or big revelations. So it's a perfectly "legal" ending to a good movie.

The last two characters we see in the movie are, if I'm not mistaken, a gay couple or at least gay friends. I really like the way they're portrayed: very naturally as just two human beings walking and chatting in the park on a nice summer day. This, in its own small subtle way is a masterstroke. To a person like me who is sick to death of hearing and reading about gay this and gay that all the time (I mean : who cares?), it was very refreshing.

I'm really curious to see what Shyamalan's going to come up with next.

Now, if he could just learn to spell his name right...

Kirktoons

title: Beautiful, suspenseful, and thought-provoking
review:
After his last film, Lady in the Water (which was garbage), I wasn't really expecting much. Especially since I've heard so many horrible reviews of The Happening. Well, I'm hear to report that I was very pleasantly surprised. I found it to be an excellent, and sometimes brilliant film by Shyamalan. On a basic level, the cinematography was incredible, as well as the music by James Newton Howard. I'll try and explain why I liked this film without using too many spoilers.

I thought the film was shot beautifully, and the acting by Mark Wahlburg and Zooey Deschanell was particularly touching. Interestingly, many people I've talked to have said the acting was really bad, and the script was atrocious. I found that the acting and dialogue was done in a certain way to set a certain tone. True, the lines were not "Juno-witty," but they were definitely realistic to how people would talk in such a situation. Very simple statements. They didn't have to say too much, because Shyamalan's visuals told most of the story. With that said, I thought the acting was really good.

SO people everywhere on the East coast start acting weird and then kill themselves and the quickest way possible. An act of terrorism? That is what they think, but it turns out that (spoiler alert) it's really plants. OK, that isn't really a spoiler, it's pretty obvious. Let me explain further. Plants are proved to adapt and evolve over time to create defenses against harmful things in the environment. This film takes that a step further, explaining that humans have become that harmful thing, and when humans are around plants have adapted to release a neurotoxin that causes the human to commit suicide.

I thought this was a very interesting concept, and could have been elaborated on further, but hey it isn't the plants' story! It a story of love between a husband and wife, and what they choose to do when threatened with the certainty of death. In addition to this, the film has a very obvious message. Without being too political, the film makes a strong argument that we have now become a threat to our planet, and presents a very realistic way that nature, or God, could solve this threat. This film was very thought provoking, at least for me, and I found myself thinking quite a bit about the deeper messages.

The film was very suspenseful, and had a lot of very disturbing imagery that will stick with you for a while. Being Shyamalan's first R-rated films, expect some graphically depicted suicides. Rather than delivering a flat-out suspense thriller, it becomes much more as the film also serves as a social commentary and message movie. I think a lot of people just wanted a no-brainer thriller with a twist ending.

There are a couple points of controversy I want to address. It seems the vast majority of people hate this film for a couple reasons. For one, it doesn't have a twist ending. All of Shyamalan's films up until this point have had a twist ending. This one doesn't. Kinda. I'll explain in a second. Until this point Shyamalan has tried successfully to surprise the audience with each film. I think here, it is definitely a surprise that there is no twist. The twist is that what you see is what you get. Also, I think a lot of people just don't get the film. They think it has this corny ending after a silly plot about plants killing people.

If you truly understand the ending, I think you will get a lot more out of the film. (SPOILERS HERE) Throughout the film Mark Wahlburg's character refers to the mood ring he wears, and how the different colors it turns represents different human emotions. Also, during the scene in the greenhouse, a character mentions that with a certain technology, plants give off a certain "color" based on the environment they are in and how they are treated. It sounds kind of silly, but it actually is true and real technology. In the film, plants and humans alike both give off "energy" that can be sensed by the other. That is where the ending comes in. Even though the harmful toxin is in the air (the old lady died, remember), the two lead characters are able to survive when they go outside to find each other. It is suggested that the love the feel for each other is so strong, that the energy they give off is not seen as harmful by the plants, and therefore they live. It's also seen when the girl is on the swing. On the other hand. The old lady is giving off such a negative energy that she is killed. This will make more sense when you see the film. (END OF SPOILERS)

In conclusion, I really loved this film. I thought it was beautiful, suspenseful, and thought provoking. If you like M. Night's other films, and go in with an open mind, then I think you will really enjoy this film as well.

title: Why is it so hard for Americans to find a good movie these days?
review:
Because we're looking in all the wrong places.

Don't get me wrong, Shyamalans new flick is not perfect in any sense of the word. The dialogue is chunky and awkward, the acting follows accordingly into sometimes seemingly mild absurdity. The R rating is completely wasted, especially since it was hyped by the media. And worst of all, Walberg is miscast in his role as the leading protagonist.

But the message and theme remains and it is clear as a bright blue morning.

To say that this movie is a walking "green" advertisement would be to oversimplify. This movie is about the power of fear, the complexity of human relationships which are at the same time beautifully simple in moments of extreme duress, and most of all, a nod towards the overall discourse of our modern world towards trying to find "simple" answers in regards to unexplainable phenomena. For those critics that slam this movie because it leaves us with a hanging string would be to prove Shyamalans very point: that as a society, we have become unfamiliar and yes, uncomfortable with whatever does not hand us answers in percentage, mathematical, or clear cut formulas. This movie is not supposed to provide any clear formulaic answers, merely present us with an exaggerated situation and then allow us to come to our own epiphany.

How do I know this to be true? For the reviewers that have actually seen this movie, then you know that there were those moments of complete quiet on screen. Where only the wind breathed life and the grass swayed ominously and Walberg and Deschanel ceased their constant running and looked fearfully out into the open green fields. What were they looking for...what were they running from? They didn't know, not for sure...only that something was after them, something they could not stop, something that they could not see, touch, taste, or hear. Only something that they could feel. If not clear enough, these intense moments of human frailty are then reiterated in the form of a child running limply beside Deschanel's character. In those moments, Shyamalan's brilliance takes center stage, allowing us as viewers to pause and consider and finally realize, along with Walberg and Deschanel, that the glory of being human is our ability to choose love over fear, that within our most frail moments we have only two things: our fellow humans and the beauty of the physical world that surrounds us. Everything else fades into obscurity. This was meant to be the only answer and ironically, within our modern age, it was the one answer that most viewers could not seem to grasp.

title: Interesting...
review:
I saw this movie yesterday and I have to say that this was a good movie by M. Night Shyamalan. It's not his best but definitely not horrible or bad like "The Village". Instead of focusing on science-fiction and fantasy that he has done in the past, his eyes are on Mother Nature.

The film opens with Mark Wahlberg's character Elliot Moore instructing a class about the honey bees' populations that are dramatically decreasing across the world. I've never heard of such a case, but after doing a little inquiring and research, I learned that this is known as CCD or Colony Collapse Disorder. It is unknown why this is happening. If the bees go instinct, it could very well cause the extinction of the human race.

The film's plot brings in the question: What if plants and nature can turn against us by our abuse and hate? As an airborne toxin sweeps through the Manhattan, making people kill themselves, Elliot Moore, his wife (Zooey Deschanel), his friend Julian (John Leguizamo), and his daughter Jess (Ashlyn Sanchez) are forced to flee Philadelphia and travel cross country to avoid the toxin.

"The Happening" is a very interesting movie that captures suspense, mystery, drama, and character development that is well in Shyamalan's capability. He once again proves to be one of Hollywood's most daring and unusual directors. The score by James Newton Howard is haunting and the work of the cinematographer helps plaster the landscapes that bring the winds of destruction.

Sure, "The Happening" may seem unrealistic like many Shyamalan movies are, but is it? Could nature turn against us? I'm probably one of the few who appreciate this movie, but again, it is not Shyamalan's best work partly because of the R rating. It was rather shocking to watch the explicit scenes of violent suicides and murders that made me jump and at time gasp. To me, it did not seem like Shyamalan's style since all his other movies are PG-13 or lower. The other thing I did not like about this movie was its pace. The film seemed to go by too quickly. There is some character development but not enough to make it moving like "Signs" or "Lady in the Water". I was also hoping for Shyamalan to make his appearance in the film like he does in his other ones, but he doesn't. 7/10 -Give it a chance; it's better than what most critics say.

title: Good Horror, Not The Greatest Shyamalan(but NOT that bad)
review:
M. Night Shyamalan, tries to make a summer horror movie, with no pretensions. The problem lies that pretensions are what make some artist's good, it's their ambition(insane, and annoying at times though it may be), that makes them so vital. "Lady In ...(read more)The Water" was ridiculous but it was interesting, it's arguable, it has ideas greater than itself. "The Happening" is an example of what you see is what you get. There is no twist here, just survival and some thin guess work for a plot, some very intense sequences, and an ending which has some subtle hints at environmental crisis and the woes of global self-destruction.

People continuously go see Nights movies expecting "revelations", when at best he's made some clever twists and subversion's of standard speculative fiction conventions; ghosts, superheros, aliens, fairy tales, utopias and monster myths, etc. He stands out as much as he does because he makes interesting genre films in places other's wont tread, or tread poorly. At a time when all movies are either franchise attempts or remakes or both, it's nice to see someone(anyone), at least try and think of something new.

It just feels like people expect Night to be Hitchcock, when really he's somewhere between him and Larry Cohen.

So what's left is a good pop corn horror film, with some original images, good music, a few awkward bits in the dialog, but over all decent writing with some light comedic touches(very needed), for effect. I think as a director overall he's grown, while as a story teller, he may be running on steam. Even though it's not as thought provoking as his other films, it's got all the suspense and dramatic tension, audiences have been waiting for since "Signs". So a little disappointing, but overall still worth checking out.

(Spoiler Following): There's a lot places the plot could have actually gone, there are theories that the evolution of flowers helped wipe out the dinosaurs, which I was just sure this movie would mention, but it Dian't...or maybe something more with communication between human and plants(hinted, joked at, but never done). The movie makes it clear that "man" is the problem, like the ending of "Planet Of The Apes", one can imagine M. Night Shyamalan somewhere on a beach banging his fists into the sand shouting "You blew it up you maniacs" at the statue of Liberty, however in 2008, pointing out that man is self destructive an enemy of the environment of the planet, is like shooting fish in a barrel. Every movie from Godzilla to Frankenstien tries to point out how were messing up the natural balance, only Night doesn't seem to see any possible end in sight, just the beginnings of crests on a terrible wave of future problems(which is fair, and if nothing else honest), and so it seems the optimist of "Lady In The Water" and "Signs" where we had hope and each other to believe in, has finally given in to modern pessimism (remember all those cars driving away from the dinner)...were all f*&ked, we are a disease...but at least we got movies.

title: Good Movie - Bad Reviewers
review: It makes me crazy when I read reviews and the people writing them criticize a film and don't even have their facts straight. How can you understand a complex movie like The Happening when you didn't get that Alma and Elliot were "married," not dating as a previous critic stated. I think the actions of people in a crisis is explored in such a subtle way that I wish I had a pause button to think and talk about it more. The only thing I wanted more was back story to the main characters. I wanted to be more invested in their survival not frustrated in trying to understand why a father would abandon his child to look for his wife that he was not even sure where she was. I do have questions, but think that M. Knight has delivered another complex thoughtful film here.

title: A Fine SciFi Movie
review:
Having read all the bad reviews I just had to see this movie for myself. After viewing it, I can't understand why so many people are bashing this movie. In fact, those giving this movie a bad review are probably among the same egg-head crowd that gave good reviews to real stinkers like "No Country for Old Men" or the real snooze-fest "There will be Blood."

First of all, it's true that there were some unbelievable parts/premises in this movie, but that's why it's called "Science Fiction", emphasis on the word fiction. For the SciFi genre the acting was fine and realistic, as were the events and circumstances. The movie flowed in a fine coherent manner, and while not a spectacular flick, I would say it falls somewhere in the middle of the road. At the very least, it's certainly entertaining and makes you think. Lastly, the movie was just what I thought it would be from my impression by the coming attractions.

I can only surmise that those that didn't like this movie were expecting something spectacular from MKS. However, I never really thought MKS was such a great writer/director in the first place. So I've taken this movie at face value as another SciFi flick. If you're expecting "The Sixth Sense" then don't see this movie, because you'll be disappointed. However, if your expecting a decent horror flick (or don't even know who MKS is) then you'll probably like this movie.

title: Half Happening
review:
Something the supposed contemporary auteur, M. Night Shyamalan, has never been quite good at is getting directly to the point. He usually likes to keep us guessing the whole way through and by the time the expected twist tries to catch us off guard, we are either completely floored or entirely annoyed. In his latest offering, THE HAPPENING, he finally learns how to get straight to the punch but that, as it turns out, is just as problematic as keeping us in suspense. Shyamalan seems as if he has been somewhat humbled by his recent difficulties finding an audience but from the moment his name appears ominously in the credits as the man who does everything (writing, producing and directing), his presence looms over the premise with an air of obnoxious knowing.

THE HAPPENING first hits Central Park and we are given no time to breathe before the scenario turns apocalyptic. People stop in their tracks, repeat random phrases and find interesting or perhaps just easily accessible manners in which to kill themselves. No one knows what's happening, except for Shyamalan, who appears to be reveling in the delirium from the rustling trees above. The affliction spreads and the mystery is at first certainly engrossing. Whatever intensity the scenario creates though is unnervingly undone by the cast's delightfully laughable attempt at keeping it classical. Mark Wahlberg as enthusiastic hopeful, Elliot Moore, leads his wife and best friend (Zooey Deschanel and John Leguizamo) toward safety, despite having no idea where that is. His naïve optimism is cute when it should be compelling but he can hardly be blamed for what is clearly Shyamalan's overall approach.

The classical style and contemporary reality ultimately clash and it becomes clear that Shyamalan's biggest obstacle is Shyamalan himself. His bigger ideas are solid but muddled by the little ideas he throws in to keep things interesting. Naturally, the tragic events are initially assessed to be terrorist attacks. Shyamalan paints America as a panic stricken populace that know who to blame when they cannot explain what is happening. They don't even question the possibility of it being a more organic threat until too much damage has been done. This is in itself heavy enough to sustain intrigue while making smooth criticism of the American government as shepherd and its people as sheep, but when you meet the people he is criticizing, they are so futile, prattling on when they should be in crisis mode, you wish they would just breathe in the bloody toxins already and die. The promise of a more satisfying film always seems just out of reach and a little help behind the scenes, primarily in the writing department, would help Shyamalan find the focus he so desperately needs.

THE HAPPENING is passably suspenseful, occasionally intriguing but mostly ineffective. It feels contrived, as though Shyamalan were trying too hard to win back our graces, doing so in such a false fashion. Perched comfortably at his pulpit, he preaches about protecting the environment but without ever communicating any actual passion for it. Consequently, the pet cause feels more functional than it does pertinent. And all the while, you can feel him looking down at you, disappointed that we don't get his genius when what he really should be doing is looking inward to see that perhaps he is just not communicating as clearly as he could. Then he might be able to see that we want to love him; he's just making it too hard to do so.

title: Do not listen to the naysayers; this film is actually quite good
review:
I am not sure what people expect when they go to see an M. Night Shyamalan film. Do they expect to see a "twist" ending? Academy award winning acting? Stellar writing? If so, they you will be disappointed with The Happening. However, if you want to see a somewhat original, mildly shocking, and entertaining film, this is a good movie to see.

The Happening is not a frightening film, where you will jump out of your seat or scream with fear. However, there are scenes that you will not expect that will shock you a bit. The dialogue is sometimes a little corny, but it at times is very funny. Some people may think the premise is "laughable", but there have been many, many more far fetched movies made recently that do not get this type of criticism.

People love to criticize M. Night's films because they hate him. They do not bother to watch the movie with an open mind to see the cleverness of the writing, the message within, the subtle humor, or the human struggles that are always present in his films. Many of his critics do not bother to see the movie for what it is. They instead say "it's not The Sixth Sense, so therefore it sucks". On one Message Board thread, people are criticizing his writing because Mark Walberg's character says "with whom?" (which is correct) rather than the more common "with who?". They criticize the writer because he portrays a teacher that uses proper English! That is a great example of him receiving undeserved criticism. They are not interested in giving you an honest critique of the movie; they are interested only in bashing Night every chance they can. I wonder how they would have criticized Night for butchering the English language if Elliot said "with who?" instead?

Well, I think there is a lot to this movie, and I would encourage you to go see it. But go with an open mind, the the attitude that "I am going to be entertained by this", and you will not be disappointed.

Some of the scenes may disturb you. There is not a lot of blood and gore (as in the Saw movies), although there is more than any of his previous movies (including The Sixth Sense). You see a lot of people die, so if that bothers you this movie may not agree with you. The ending is very subtle, and there is no twist so do not look for one. I don't necessarily agree with Night's message in this film, but it did not ruin the film for me. This is a drama that is wrapped around a couple having marital difficulties in the midst of a terrible "event" that has befallen the northeastern United States, and it shows how they survive through this crisis (similar to Signs). No aliens this time, however.

I saw the movie twice. The first time I took my wife, and the second time I took my oldest daughter and her fiancé. I appreciated the movie more after seeing it a second time. That has happened to me previously with some of Night's films, specifically with Signs and The Village. I missed things the first time but seeing it again helped me to appreciate the movie all the more.

Go with an open mind and enjoy the film. At times you will gasp, laugh, cry, and be sitting at the edge of your seat. Both times I saw it the audiences appeared to be satisfied with the film. I know I was.

title: Loved it --- but I think you have to be a thinker.....
review: and not expect to be spoon-fed or expect a super-hero movie. Maybe the expectations for M.N.S were too high. Cut him some slack. It was a good movie with a great message. It requires some thought people. And if you actually can do that,you'll get it and realize what it is about and how subtle and powerful the movie and messages are. And how good the actors portray the knowledge of what they assume is the end of the world and their own mortality. No super-Herod. No super-honeybees. No riots in the streets or panic. Just the quiet knowledge that nothing was coming to save them this time. People that hated it expected that and should go see one of the super hero movies where the lines are black and white and can keep hoping for a savior at the end. This is not a black and white or good and evil movie. It is a shades of gray movie. There is no clear-cut right and wrong side. And I can understand the plants and trees getting their hate on. Watch them dump toxins in the river and then say you can't eat the fish from that river or burn down thousands of acres of rain forest a day. It doesn't take much thought to get into his head and think - why wouldn't the plant's, who all life depends on, say enough is enough. It's a fine plot for a thriller. It's a heck of lot better than 99% of the slash crap out and what does that say about the state of mankind and your movie dollar? So those of you that hate it and rated it a 1 star, it makes me wonder what you found so outrageous or horrible about it. No need to answer, I just find it amazing that you didn't like it. Especially those of you that got Signs and unbreakable. Those of you that didn't, it doesn't surprise me that you didn't get this one either. Anyway. It's a good movie and well worth seeing.

title: The Happening
review:
The New R rated film by M. Night Shyamalan, The Happening staring Mark Wahlberg, Zooey Deschanel, and John Leguizamo. The movie is about a Pheliadelphia high school teacher and his loved ones who flee a mysterious phenomenon that's causing pepole to kill themselves.

I have Liked M. Night since the Sixth Sense all the way through Lady In The Water (yes i liked The Village and Lady In The Water) but this time he hands in a confused movie. The movie starts out really good and then by the middle where walhberg and his family are trying to find a place to hide it starts unravaling. The acting was good, I liked Mark Walhberg, lots of pepole though he was miscast. Zooey Deschanel, who I really like, was the one that felt out of place. I liked her, but not as good as I had hoped I would. John Leguizamo was also good. The movie isn't scary or suspenseful, its also not a horror movie, it's more of a drama in my opinion. They are trying to promote this movie as "His first R Rated movie". Big deal there was hardly any blood or language to earn its R Rating.

Don't get me wrong I liked this movie, but after a while it started to lose me, the ending needed something... Its hard to review this movie without giving anything away (which its not that big a spoiler). Overall I liked the movie, but M. night needes to really sit down, take a year or two off and make an amazing movie again!! P.S. The movie Dose Not have a twist in the end!!

title: "Thinner Than a Pringle Chip And Infinitely Less Organized Than A Canful" or "When Good Houseplants Go Very, Very Bad"
review:
I have to type fast because this morning I cast a mocking glance upon one of my houseplants and with the noontime wind beginning to gather momentum on the crests of nearby hills, I naturally have oodles of utterly vague and impulsive illogical "plans" to head for, um, the hills to escape its plantarly wrath; little time to compose a coherent summary of this "work". Kind of like its director when same was scrawled onto the back of a Starbucks napkin from whence it, on the merits of its obvious brilliance (cough) rocketed directly to production.

For cult-viewers who may have tired of rewatching _Striptease_ every Friday night for the last 12 years, here you have it! Talentless body-doubles for Demi Moore and Rumer Willis, amazingly enough at low-budget prices! During the interminable shot of Zooey Deschanel doing a series of, was it about 800?, eyeball widenings, a small part of me wondered if this was to be a comedy, and I patiently waited for Leslie Nielsen to emerge with a Roundup mister from behind, say, Betty Buckley playing a wrinkled old hippie with daisies in her hair.

Alas, it was not to be.

Neither were *any* of my lowest expectations. Amongst its many failures as a movie worth $20 and 2 hours of my valuable time, let's examine its complete and utter incompetence in the realm of character development. Had Mark Wahlberg even *cared* that Zooey Deschanel was having an affair (or if she even *were* having one!), perhaps we might have been impressed with their later reconciliation. Nope.

Holes in the plot? Two words: "Alpine Lace Cheese".

One example from the many dozens I'm sure I could cite would be why new-mom and new-dad let little Rumer wander around in the ex-Betty Buckley's house - o - anachronistic - horrors knowing that her recently and extensively mutilated body lay just around the corner nestled comfortably on the residual shards of broken glass in one of those charming cottage-y windows.

Even so, couldn't they have at least gone with the so-clichéd traumatized - youngster - remains - mute - and - later - launches - sequel - esquire - subplot? Might I add that it would have been the work-of-a-moment to give Buckley's character a quaint love of plants (so we could feel indignant when they later carved her into little pieces), but no.

Speaking of Ms. Buckley, what in the sex-bot-heck was that frigging doll doing on her bed anyway? Come to think of it, I don't want to know.

Meanwhile, my message to MNS: that "Make An R Movie With Absolutely No R-Rated Shots" free-ware you downloaded that promised to auto-gen screenplays with all kinds of quirky don't-go-anywhere mini-plots and bare-bones dialogue was a PRANK, a prank, I tell you. We're talking about a hideous agoraphobic and osteoporosis-riddled joke.

You've been had, latte-boy. Kinda like everyone who watched the promising previews of this move, then wasted an evening's entertainment on the swill you somehow, criminally, felt was worthy of full-scale release.

At least we're extracting our money's worth in the pruning of it. As topiary, I estimate there's just about enough here for a Happy-Meal-sized Loch Ness creature, possibly minus the head and neck. Well, maybe the torso, but for sure the tail. We could do the tail.

title: Where's Captain Planet when you need him? Lazy bum!
review:
So what can we expect from Night's first R-rated outing? Meh, really not that much. Just like his past couple, Night's films are really beginning to be pretty damn weak. And with his latest flick, The Happening, which sounds like a Bentley Little book (only if), you're given the same Night treatment. A movie that works and doesn't work all at the same damn time.

In The Happening you got people killing themselves due to a supposed neuro-toxin that the plants are dishing out. Why? Because we're not treating Mother Earth so nice. Well, that's one theory. The idea is kinda cool, revenge of Mother Nature. But when you can predict what's going on, by the oh-so obvious direction (cue mysterious music with gloomy shot of swaying trees) the movie immediately becomes an adventure flick instead of some sort of mystery. So, about 20 minutes in, I get the jist and the only thing I slightly care about is how they're gonna stay alive. The way the movie played out was okay enough, I guess, but the writing and acting by all involved, minus Leguizamo and the slack-jawed dude from O'Brother, were laughable and completely overly dramatic. Marky Mark....why is he so damn breathy in all his friggin flicks? If his character isn't abrasive, forget it. The writing, God the writing. I don't know what's going on here, but if anyone truly thinks this is professional stuff, go to the zoo and jump in the lion cage. And what a stupid scene that was......was that guy made of jello? Arms do not pop off that easily. Ugh....

The Happening's good aspects is the production value. It's a great looking and sounding film. But the story, writing, acting, and even direction is all average to weak. With barely anything interesting or shocking happening after the first 20 minutes, the movie just pulls you along for an average, uneventful feeling ride. Go see it if you're a M.Night Fanboy or you're easily impressed.

title: What Happened???
review:
First off, I had to come back and change my rating from a two to a one to offset all the 9 and 10 star reviews. Right now the IMDb rating is 6.3 and I'm pretty sure that as more people actually see the film, this will drop significantly. It would appear that there is currently a flood of people calling this a great film which is like calling a pile of my dog's waste products an artistic masterpiece. Now on to the review:

I was really excited about going to see this film on opening night. I like Mark Wahlberg, Zooey Deschanel and John Leguizamo and even like most of M. Night Shyamalan's films. The previews looked pretty good and there were some good reviews.

My God, what happened? The acting from the beginning felt very "B Movie", and upon reading other reviews it appears Shyamalan has said this is intended as a B Movie but that is certainly not how it has been marketed. The opening "horrific" scenes were pretty much covered in the previews. Actually, most of the stuff that should have been frightening was covered in the previews, albeit briefly.

I agree with others here that Wahlberg was grossly miscast. Zooey Deschanel was charmingly funny in some parts and in my opinion gave the only real relief from an otherwise total flop.

-------SPOILERS BELOW--------------------------

Now for the plot. The plants are fighting back. Yep. Not only that, they are coordinating attacks on specific groups of people. Large groups at first, then they start picking off the smaller groups with amazing accuracy. You know an attack is coming when the plants manipulate the wind to blow their toxins into the crowds. You see an attack coming as the heavier wind is blowing like a sheet across fields, etc. Yes, really. Not only that, they attack a group in a field but leave another group in a different part of the same field unscathed. I know Wahlberg says something about having to be close to the source or the toxins will dissipate but then how do you explain the construction workers on top of the fairly tall building getting hit so effectively? Makes no sense.

Now I'm all for suspending belief and enjoying a movie for what it is but when a movie is trying to push a message (like this one definitely is) of what COULD happen, I would like at least something to make sense. Very little makes sense with this film and as others have stated, the acting is sub-par and overdone, the screenplay is weak at best and I felt there was little entertainment value at all. I found myself looking at my watch trying to gauge how much longer this would last within the first thirty minutes. I left the theater feeling I've just wasted $20+ and an hour and a half of my life.

If you want to see a truly scary movie about the consequences of what we're doing to our planet, go rent "An Inconvenient Truth". It's more frightening and will be a much better use of your time.

review: The Happening was a very weird and suspenseful movie. It had a very weird vibe to it the whole movie through. It kept you on the edge of your seat for the most part. Half of the story was the love story between Mark Whalberg and his wife Zoey Deshanel. They pretty much were always fighting and couldn't get along. Some scenes were not meant to be funny and just made you laugh at times. It wasn't intentionally meant to be funny and it kind of was. For the most part though this movie will have you saying wow and think to yourself what if this was really happening. The same stuff was just pretty much happening over and over again. Their wasn't as much happening as you would think from the trailer though. Their weren't a whole lot of scenes that make you jump. The messages were very good and I think were a main part of this movie. The acting wasn't amazing but not bad it was pretty god. Mark Whalberg has played better roles but did a good job. Go see it if you want a movie that will have you saying wow after it.

title: The Happening...(contains spoilers)
review:
The Happening includes the following: -Cliche 'suspense movie' opening credits to include a score completely written in a minor key.

-Poor Casting - Even worse script writing (Kinda of like the Sci-Fi channel's original series Tin Man but with less purpose) -No underlying plot -No climax -No introduction or ending -Lack of character development -Over use of global environmentally friendly 'we're the bane of the earth' dogma -(Spoiler alert) Plants making people kill themselves via airborne toxins and wind? Overall M. Night's "The Happening" was exactly that is just happened, it was no more than a poorly written, predictably cliché suspense movie with no actual suspense.

Rating: Adequate at best.

title: Horrible film
review: This is a terrible film. Mark Wahlberg acts like he is latently gay throughout the movie and Zooey Deschanel is wooden and frequently just looks like she does not really know how to act at all. The movie is basically a propaganda piece from the Club of Rome/ New World Order movement to convince human beings that they are a cancer on the planet and that the world would be better off without us. According to Shaymalan, some things are 'acts of nature that we will never fully understand'. If scientists in the past has had this philosophy we would never had understood anything about our planet.....it is intellectually and scientifically lazy.

title: Why oh why oh why?
review:
Why is M. Night Shyamalan still allowed to make movies? Does he think The Happening is worthy, creditable, notable, doable, seeable? I sat down really wanting to finally see a movie that had at least a scintilla of worth. Plot? What plot? Suspense? What suspense? Character development? Don't make me laugh. Dialogue? Script? Anything? No, no and no. Even the film score was yawningly predictable.

This film is so awful, I cannot find a place to start, so I won't. I wish film studios would exercise a bit more caution when allowing this kind of thing to happen. We have lapsed into such mediocrity in so many areas of the American culture... and this is an example of why.

M. Night Shyamalan, really now. These things are getting worse and worse. Please try and do something at least slightly dramatic, suspenseful, interesting. The Happening cannot get much lower than awful.

title: most people don't have a clue or just plain ignorant...
review:
i feel like the world is deteriorating and people are becoming much more simple minded these days rather than the opposite of becoming more intelligent and aware of the BIG picture of our world today. this is true. today's society has become worst than ever. people don't care about anything or anybody anymore. all they think about now is what's good for themselves. we're more divided than ever, distancing ourselves from one another and this is not only happening here in the US. it's everywhere. now think about this for a minute: do we always have to rely on some kind of disasters either natural or man-made (e.g. terrorists, etc.) to bring us closer together? think about it!

after you think about that question then you have to be in the right mind to go and see this movie. this is not about any airborne epidemic, natural disasters, missing honey bees, plant's natural defense against people, etc. think deeper when you see this movie. there is a meaning or message to this movie. i think M. Night Shyamalan has delivered the message quite good but not perfect; as people these days are so simple minded and ignorant that you just have to spell everything out for them like a 2 year old. i was very disappointed about the bad reviews that this movie has received and more upsetting that people are talking and laughing throughout the whole movie when i went to see it. sure it has a bit of a horror kick and surprising jolt out-of-your-seat moment as my girlfriend got surprised a couple of times, even some funny scenes.

so i'm not going to spoil the movie for anyone nor ruin it. but as you watch the movie, think about these things...location where these events are happening, time when these events occur (there's a reason M. Night Shyamalan noted the time and location throughout the movie), people's reaction to these events, how they react to such event, how they feel about these occurrences, how they deal with these events, take a closer look at the scenes toward the end because there's a meaning to them...it's almost subliminal. so think a moment after you see this movie...think about humans, people, us, and our connection, our instinct, our reaction, our perception, our way of thinking, and so on...

it's not a sci-fi horror movie or stupid meaningless movie. this is M. Night Shyamalan's style of telling a story and sure it's not as obvious and direct when he communicates his message like his other movies but it delivers. i'm not defending him as the best writer/director or anything of sorts because not all of his movies are great. but he does have a stylistic way of communicating his messages to his audience.

title: Its supposed to be a B-movie people
review:
the dialog and the acting is bad because thats what M. Night had in mind, he wanted it to be a big budget Rodger corman like movie.

"One of the things that I said to everybody--the cast and crew--I said, 'This is a B movie,'" Shyamalan said in a press conference in New York on June 9. "Let's get ourselves straight here. This is just a great B movie. We're making the best B movie we can here. That's our job. We're making a B movie. If the themes of the movie have something that stick with you, great. Great. But we're not going to put that in front of the movie. We're going to have a lot of fun. It's a paranoia movie. We just need to pound away. That's our job.' I was really clear about that."

the problem with the film audience is they no longer understand subtly, they have to be told that they are watching a comedy or else they don't get it.

title: Kept me interested, and that's all that matters
review:
My review of this movie would simply be: Pretty good, not bad. People seem to be bashing it left and right, but I guarantee you those same people were interested in it from start to finish.

Here are my favorite things about it... 1. It takes a taboo issue of suicide and makes it involuntary, which is totally disturbing. Put yourself in the movie, no matter how strong a person you are, you too would be committing suicide just like everyone else. Shymalan is great at making you think about how you would handle the situation he presents.

2. People keep saying the acting was terrible all around. That's just not true. There were 3 great characters, all portrayed perfectly by Jeremy Strong, Betty Buckley, and Frank Collison.

3. The movie was not too long. In fact, it was the perfect length for the story. I never got bored.

Problems with this movie... 1. Mark Wahlberg should always be a bad guy.

2. Some of the suicide scenes were just grueling, in particular, the later ones, which just seemed like audience punishment. By the end of it, I couldn't even think of a method that we didn't see, or wasn't mentioned.

The movie definitely gave me bad dreams, which is part of the masochism of seeing scary/suspenseful movies, so all around I'd say good job, but there's no way I'll be re-watching this one. 7/10.

review: O.k the performances are not that great, although Betty Buckley as Mrs.Jones gives a great 10 min performance ,the fact that others were being infected and mark wahlberg his wife and the child survived seems a bit odd too and the twist in the end if there is one is very difficult too understand , o.k i agree with those who criticise director M.NIGHT SHYAMALAN for these facts because even the script have it's holes too and from a director of his calibre people pretend something better but there are many good points and i don't understand why the IMDb users are giving him all this bad reviews because no one can deny these positive points in the movie :No1 the movie is rarely boring and it's gripping from the first scene till the end only in some scenes in the middle of the film tend to lose it's grip.No2 i've seen comments here about the last 40 minutes of the movie that are horrible, o.k the first part is a bit better but the best and the surely most terrifiying parts of the movie are the scenes which involves the creepy and scary character of Mrs.Jones that made me stay gripped to my seat in the theatre.No3 i think the reason that this movie is critically bashed because it is directed by M.NIGHT SHYAMALAN and people had expected more .
