My hands have been full these past few years defending M. Night Shyamalan. 'The Village' was a beautifully haunting stroke of genius and a personal favorite of mine. 'Lady in the Water', while certainly outlandish and a tad self-indulgent, was an enchanting fairy tale with a worthy message. While both of these films have been the target of an absurd amount of lashing, Shyamalan was made Hollywood's go-to whipping boy.

And here we arrive at 'The Happening'. Shyamalan's first R-rated venture. An eco-thriller which poses the question, what if Earth were to one day simply purge itself of mankind? It's a terrific set-up, thought-provoking in typical Shyamalan fashion. But unfortunately, I won't be taking up the task anytime soon to defend 'The Happening' as I have with his previous efforts. I didn't hate it, and I don't think it's quite as bad as some have claimed, but I simply cannot defend it.

'The Happening' would have made a great short story. The makings are there, the potential is great. But a good story does not always a good movie make. A promising and disturbing start ultimately gives way to something much less suspenseful as Shyamalan's script begins to tread water. For perhaps the first time in his career, 'The Happening' becomes a shoddy piece of work from the man who once brought us 'The Sixth Sense'. A few memorable scenes stuck in a poorly constructed picture. The film simply gravitates without much direction or insight.

Shyamalan, who has been able to draw some fantastic performances from actors in the past, instead seems to bring out the worst of this cast. Mark Wahlberg, whose career has been on the upswing since his Oscar nominated performance in 'The Departed', is at times painful to watch here. Awkward close-ups mixed in with awkward dialogue. He seems lost and confused, probably trying to remember what possessed him to take on this role. The rest of the cast, which includes John Leguizamo and a zoned out Zooey Deschanel, just doesn't have anything to work with. They're all wandering around aimlessly waiting for Shyamalan to explain himself.

If you've seen the trailers, you've seen 'The Happening'. In between frightening scenes of deranged suicide, there's not much to pass the time or make a movie with for that matter. This is Shyamalan at his dullest, his weakest effort to date and a sore disappointment. There's a great environmental message here worth listening to, but it deserves a much better movie. Something compelling, something worth seeing. 'The Happening' had potential, but Shyamalan ultimately leaves it to suffer.

More reviews at rottentomatoes.com/vine/journal_view.php?journalid=219276&view=public

title: swing and a miss
review: Once again M. Night Shyamalan dose not disappoint with his disappointing movies. i recently had the unfortunate pleasure of sitting through MR Shyamalan's latest dumpster baby of a movie the Happening. Well folks like the village and unbreakable his steady decline in the quality of films has not broke. heres whats going on...a mysterious thing is happening people are killing themselves because of it Marky Mark (an otherwise decent actor who phones it in big time) and that girl who was in Almost Famous for a few seconds are on the run from the "happening" they of course figure it out and live while everyone else dies. no big surprise there. but in the midst of what should be world wide chaos due to this unknown event people are relatively calm and almost seem bored. the script would be better suited to line a parrots cage with, the usual twist and turns in one of this guys films are not predictable because they are absent. the film sluggishly mopes about without ever invoking fear or dread; something you might expect from a film about unexplained mass suicides. the characters are transparent and dull and most of the conversation is useless. for a few minutes this guy talks about hot dogs..."do you like hot dogs? hot dogs are underrated. got the mustered" what is that all about. turns out hot dogs would have been an even better villain killing people left and right then what the true "horror" was. as for him trying to shock people with his first R rated film...well have you seen the commercials then you've seen the scary parts already don't worry seeing them out of context is better then having to sit through this junk feast. in short save your money. i have the uneasy notion that this film will have the same effect on its viewers that it dose on the people in it offing themselves. Oh and a quick note to MNS thanks for begin a huge tool and trying to capitalize on peoples fears by having people in NYC jumping form buildings to that horrific sound. if your form NY you know what i mean, this guy shamelessly slapped that scene on screen to invoke fear and to say look how i reached people. well MR Shyamalan i too want to reach people namely you and kick you in the nuts. go see a constipated dog trying to squeeze one out it will be more suspenseful i give you my word.

title: Well...
review: I'm from Philadelphia (actually, about 5 minutes away from the director's home.... and am a huge fan and also thrilled that Philadelphia has a man of this talent and caliber. So, I'm not all that unbiased. I'll only say that I thought the movie began brilliantly and petered out after the first 30 minutes (more or less what most are saying). But, what most disturbed me was that at least twice, recording microphones momentarily popped into the top of the scene...Now, how in the heck could that have happened in a film directed by someone of his caliber? Reminded me of those awful westerns in the 60's where, from time to time you'd see the plume of a jet overhead. Geez-Louise Knight... get it together!

title: It's actually the best M. Night Shyamalan's movie so far
review:
It's actually one M. Night Shyamalan's movie that has a relevant meaning. Unlike many of those who hated this movie, I'm actually not Mr Night's fan. I mildly enjoyed 6th sense but generally found all of his other movies pretentious and heavy handed, except this one. This is his only movie so far that doesn't have a twist ending, which is a good thing! This time, Mr. Night doesn't mind showing you the blood and gore, which really took me by surprise. The visual horror is a double edged sword. It can be funny to watch, which may take away some seriousness of the subject. It also takes away the subtlety. Once you see it happening in front of your eyes, you are somewhat desensitized.

Though there are no plot twist, I am still quite intrigued and involved through the whole time. I'm literally glued to the screen, anticipating and guessing what will happen next. The pacing is effective and dialogue are simple and down to earth. It makes you feel those characters are more real. Regardless if the characters are likable or not, you still care what's happening on the screen and how the story unfold.

Some people complain that the characters have no depth. Here's the thing about the movies that are depicting catastrophic event: because of the time span are usually limited to few hours or a few days in these type of movies, there's very little room for character development. Therefore, the director would usually tell a bigger story through the characters, not so much about the characters. I really don't care that much about any one individual in the story about extinction of human race. I'm more concerned about how story unfolds through character's eyes.

Some people also attempt to analyze and criticize the science behind the story. Well, here's what I'm going to say to that: unless you are a real biologist, don't bother trying to criticize the plot because you only come off sounding really stupid and ignorant. Nobody can yet explain some of the plant behaviors and we are only finding out more and more unexplainable things about plants recently.

It is definitely quite different from all of his previous movies, yet, you feel the similar tension build up. There are some flaws here and there, but generally speaking, it is a very entertaining experience without the pressure of pulling off some unbelievable plot twist. Therefore, I enjoyed it much much more than his other movies.

Another thing I really liked about this movie is that you can find humor in the most unexpected situation. The over the top gore and hysteria at certain moments really comes off rather comical. I'm not sure if they are intended or not, but they let you peer inside human psyche in a very bizarre way. I won't give out too much details in case you haven't seen the movie.

All in all, it's surprisingly good, engaging and entertaining. The character may not have witty dialogs or use fancy word play, but who really give a fly pig about fancy word play? If you want unrealistically pretentious fancy word play, go watch a sitcom, in which every single word uttered is carefully crafted to make you go: yeah, that's really smart and funny and inventive. People in real life don't talk like that.

title: great movie
review: The happening is a great movie. It's about something that effects humans in a way that makes them start killing themselves. First, people become confused. Then they kill themselves. It is revealed after some suicides that plants have released some sort of toxin into the air that reverses the survival instinct in humans, and therefore they want to kill themselves. The plants do this because of the bad effects people are having on the environment. The suicide parts are scary. Examples are a woman sitting on a bench next to another woman in New York City. This is the first suicide. The woman who kills herself tells the other woman she doesn't know where she is or something. The woman sitting next to her thinks she's joking and says something in response. The other woman then pulls something out of her hair and stabs herself in the neck with it. Other suicides include a man getting into a lion's pen at a zoo and a lion bites or tears his arms off. The movie is very scary and creepy and the plant's toxin thing is a very interesting idea. It's not as good as the sixth sense. It's way better than signs and way way better than lady in the water. Lady in the water is awful and signs is fairly bad. M. Night Shyamalan really came back good with this one.

title: Worse than you can possibly imagine...
review:
Okay, so it's not Shyamalan's worst film but it comes pretty close. Mark Wahlberg is very talented but he looks confused most of the time. The plot is about some sort of wind that makes people do crazy things. On certain sources, this was labeled as a horror. While the trailers appear that way, there is nothing scary about it at all. I never felt frightened or at the edge of my seat, it's wind and plants for heaven's sake!

The first five minutes had serious potential but then it went completely downhill. I could not take any of the dialogue seriously. There's nothing wrong with campy horror movies but there's no satire or humor for it to be considered that. It just gets ridiculous with a moronic anti-climatic ending that I won't give away because it's not worth explaining. Avoid this movie, I want my time and brain cells back.

title: The Best Waste Of Time award
review:
This movie, if you would like to call it that, is nothing more than an embarrassment to anyone with the slightest of intelligence. It's quite horrific and painful to endure something so pretentious, yet the story still thumbs it's nose at you, asking you silently, "Are you still here, watching me sucka?" This piece rates up there with a Uwe Boll film.

It should have won an Academy Award for The Best Waste Of Time. In fact, I can't wait to buy the Blu-ray edition so I can waste more time listening to M. Night on the bonus features talk about how good he is and that his idol is Alfred Hitchcock. Also, he does a cameo for every single one of his films in his Honor. How unoriginal is that???? More like blatant plagiarism, I would concur.

One has to wonder how M. Night ever became a director. Further investigation on Wikipedia, reveals an affluent upbringing and 8mm camera, a most unusual combination for a pretentious young spoiled Indian kid. I tend to give directors a chance and watch some of their other "work". Oddly, I could not but help notice his films share a similar vein amongst themselves. It almost seems he uses a cookie cutter template for his script and drops in fresh character names for his next movie. Nothing like beating an already dead Harp Seal, right?

We see the same mundane story unfold in front of us for each of his new releases, yet he manages to ensnare some big name celebrities to draw us in like a moth to a candle. Is there not any more pre-screening allowed? Oh, and isn't life grand when you have a lot of money but no imagination?

title: Not as bad as you would think.
review: I think people have just gotten used to hating on M Night. It seem like every time he is about to put out a movie, everyone just goes off about how bad it will be. This is a movie that truly explains that they are all wrong. I rented this movie on iTunes only knowing that it is about plants that are attacking people. I first though that it was going to be some kind of over the top completely fake story. I was wrong. Every moment was enjoyable to me and I could not stop watching it. This is a film that makes me wonder how people hate movies like this. It seems like the only movies these days have super special effects and famous people. Nobody is enjoying a story anymore. Hopefully this will curve and people will like stories again. Maybe then M. Night will shine, but for now he will not be getting the best of reviews from the world.

title: The first and last scenes
review:
Anyone notice at the beginning of the movie, the event started happening with the TWO women sitting together? Then, when the event started again at the end of the movie, it was TWO men walking together? Both times, one of the people were talking and started acting weird. I found it weird how the event seemed to start with a couple of the same sex. Was there a significance or is this just a coincidence?

Anyways, I thought it was an interesting movie. I have only seen a few other movies by M. Night and one can certainly tell this is one of his. It's twisted and thought provoking. There was no cameo appearance though, was there? That's kind of M. Night's signature to his movies. So that is surprising.

title: People just hate M. Night
review:
This movie is fun, decent, schlock. That's it. M. Night has even admitted it in interviews. It isn't something his ego churned out to save humanity. It's just a fun thrill ride, with an environmental message so ham-handedly forced in I honestly believe it to be an intentional parody.

If anyone else had made this movie it would have been lucky to gross half as much, but would have been praised as an awesome splatter film. Instead, because of M. Night, lots of people paid to see it, and then complain about it. I seem to be the only one who believes that he can bounce back if he swallows his ego.

One thing that can't be denied about this movie, though, is that while you may not like his screen writing, he knows how to direct a scene.

title: The Happening
review:
OK. The Happening. I have four words: it's not that bad. People complained that the story doens't make any sense, that the acting was terrible (John Leguizamo sucked, though), and so on and so forth. Seriously, though. The Happening, sure, wasn't the best movie, but it wasn't the worst movie. It had violence (thank God of that), Mark Walberg did better than most people think, and the story was fine (except the part about what was killing the people). The music was phenomenal. James Newton Howard is a genius.

Now, on to the bad things. God, John Leguizamo was a horrible actor in this film. He doens't do well in too serious movies. There was almost no definite moral to the film. It was like all other horror films: it kills people off.

So, I end my review with the percent of this film, and thats a 5/10.

title: Mother of God, what kind of terrorists are these?
review:
It will happen one day.

Despite everything or anything that we may do, there will come a time when we are no longer walking upon the Earth.

The simple fact is that most species that have live on the Earth are extinct. We will have our turn.

I do not think that the trees and grass will finally get fed up with us and eliminate us as a threat. But, M. Night Shyamalan postulates that as a possibility. His subtle, slow film that allows one to think about what we have done, what we are doing, and what the possible consequences are will not be a big hit with the viewers that are looking for transformers or zombies, or ass-kicking action, but it is a message that deserves to be heeded.

Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel were perfect for this film.

title: Nice idea, but as for the realisation....
review:
A staggeringly bad delivery of a really interesting premise. When you find yourself praying for the main characters to die horribly, and soon, you know the film makers have got it badly wrong. Compare this to the less conceptually interesting but brilliantly made Cloverfield, taking one recent apocalyptic instance, and I'm wondering if my vote of 2 was 2 too many....

The list of cinematic crimes committed here is too lengthy to bother with. Those which, however, particularly offended me include the wildly inaccurate depictions of the effects of gun shots on the human skull and of a long pin in the jugular (no budget for fake blood?), the comedy car-meets-tree scene and the painfully sentimental and cosy 'return to normality'.

This is just a terrible film. Now imagine this directed by Romero or any other stalwart of the End-of-the-World genre and the pictures in your head will be far superior to this pasty and dreary exercise in banality.

title: Feel good hit of the summer
review:
I can't even lie to you. This is truly an awful movie. I mean, Mark Wahlberg legitimately runs away from the WIND! The acting is terrible, the premise is stupid, and well, sorry, but bad direction.

However, I cant hate the movie.

Too much made me laugh. Like The scene where the two kids get killed by the shotguns. Markie Mark is hilarious, and did anyone else realize that the fat white kid was in the Santa Clause 2? Watch this movie with your friends, but don't expect to be scared. If you go in expecting to laugh, you will. oh, and watch the deleted and extended scenes, especially the one with the kid at the violin recital.

title: A Flop
review:
Shylamalan has had his successes, The Sixth Sense, Unbreakable and Signs. However, in recent times he has failed to deliver. The Happening unfortunately continues in the same disappointing vein.

The Happening follows the flight of a husband and wife, and a child from a chemical induced matter, which is driving people to suicide. It is a chilling prospect but in retrospect Shylamalan has tied his own hands. It is a concept which is difficult to actualize without an emotional core, and far-more difficult to conclude.

The film is a mighty flop, apart from fleeting moments of tension, and a good performance from Mark Whalberg in a role in which he is ill-suited to, it is awful. The Happening has no emotional engagement it is a mere film of flight, running away from a threat and nothing of substance in-between. Zooey Deschanel, although very photogenic, only manages to produce one emotive display throughout which involved her beautiful eyes, we needed more

I respect Shalayman's message, bringing forth an issue which is a the forefront of many minds today, respecting the environment and not over industrializing the planet but it doesn't work. Maybe the issue is not dealt with enough or strongly enough but it is a rather flimsy deliverance.

title: A mysterious element is causing people to commit suicide.
review: Is it me, or is each subsequent Shyamalan movie getting worse and worse? Where to begin. Well, the premise of the story is okay, but it's been done. Try watching the original, Day of the Triffids. Not the remake ("Hollywood", stop remaking classics!). Second, the script. The dialogue was stilted and made no sense most of the time. Here we are with the "plant guy" who all at once tells us it's the plants. Okay, he knows botany, but how does he know what's going on when the only news that has been given out is that the country is under attack from terrorists? Oh, I know. Watch out for that daisy, there's a hidden toxin under those petals. And the acting. Even more stilted than the dialogue. And those facial expressions. What was this, acting class 090? And as previously noted, every single actor in this movie, okay the main actors, were not right for the part. Even Buckley, who is a fantastic actress, could not save her character's role. It made no sense. Shoot, the entire movie was a waste of time. Or as my hubby likes to say, There's 90 minutes I'll never get back. Mr. Shyamalan, your talent seems to have been blown away in the proverbial breeze.

title: The Happening
review:
Like M. Night's popular Sixth Sense with Bruce Willis and Signs with Mel Gibson, I assumed that The Happening would be a movie that was difficult to discuss without giving away an important revelation that gives meaning to the story and people's bizarre behavior. In the case of the two former movies, we saw that the thoughts of the protagonist(s) were all a big, beautiful, though troubling, metaphor for the reality of things. I enjoyed Sixth Sense and Signs for that reason. The viewer stumbles along saying, "Okay, that seems a little puzzling there, but this is science fiction, so I'll suspend disbelief." Until in the final few scenes the author gives you the final piece of the puzzle, and it's "Aha!"

So I'm watching The Happening with all due diligence, as bizarre stuff just cascades seemingly out of control, and the lead charactersthe Moores (Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel) seem to be the protagonists hereact rationally one minute then inexplicably the next. Until finally the movie ends, and I'm still waiting for the Big Metaphor that strings it all together... and waiting, and waiting.

...

For my complete review of this movie and for other movie and book reviews, please visit my site TheCoffeeCoaster.com.

Brian Wright Copyright 2008

title: expected more....
review: "the happening " is a not bad kind of movie... but one watches this movie after watching sixth sense and signs i'm sure he wont be satisfied.. Actually i expected lot, lot, lot, lot more from M. Night Shyamalan.. But i wont say tat i was worst ... it was good.. but notgood enough... then i think budget is the main problem for this film...and also the cast... Mark Wahlberg is apt in character like marineofficer.. or a cop something like that... but when it comes to sentiments and drama type acting.. he is OK... and what i have quote when i talk about the minus of film is the heroine...Zooey Deschanel.. she always stars like she lost something... and coming to the plus.. james newton is as usual gr8 in his scoring.. and the girl who has done the character "jess" was pretty good... then tat guy who plays the roll as jess's father has also done his job.. camera angles in certain scenes remind you that you are watching a M. Night Shyamalan movie... overall the movie was not excellent but worth watching...

title: Why do we still watch his crap
review: Why does his movies still have any regard. Total tripe. I can't believe I watched this--and if it wasn't on blu-ray I probably wouldn't have given it a chance. That's the last M. Night Shamalamadingdong movie I'll ever see. They're all predictable or completely stupid or both. Don't give me some racist bullsheeite either--I really tried my best but after 6 movies of total junk, I'm done. Rave about him all you want I think the movie industry will see him go by the wayside. I guess I have to give another three line of vitriol--easy enough--this guy is a pampered mama's boy from what I have seen in the behind the scenes documentaries. That should just about do it--I won't waste any more time on this hack.

title: Misanthropic Tree Huggers Manifesto
review:
I will never view another film by Shyamalan again. Wanting my money and time back has got to be the worst feeling after watching a film.

William Arnold of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer had a blurp on the DVD jacket saying it was "Daring, Refreshing, and Scary." It's cast includes Wahlberg and Leguisamo, so I assumed it couldn't be horrible.

I will never again make the mistake of renting a film before checking out the reviews by others first. Granted there are always a few cretins that will hate a great film or vice versa, but for the most part those that take the time to comment are usually somewhere in the mid range of the bell curve.

This film really offers a psychological insight into the nature of those that view man as a plague upon Gaia. The real joke is just how awful and polluted countries are that don't embrace free markets and science.

I bet Gore was pleasuring himself while watching this movie. I'm sure he'll be less than pleased at the coming tide of calls for him to return his Nobel prize as we enter another Maunder Minimum of Solar inactivity.

title: After two steps back M. Night takes one step forward
review:
Movie: The Happening 8 out of 10 stars Directed by: M. Night Shamyalon Stars: Mark Whalberg Rated: R for Some Mild Cursing, disturbing images, some graphic scenes of suicide and sucide.

After his smash hit The 6th Sense in 1999,Night has never lived up to it. Sure Unbrakeable and Signs where good. (I for one enjoyed them both and thought that Unbrakeable was very underrated.) But after those 2 Night has been O.K. at best. The Village was not a good movie at all. And Wail I thought that Lady in the Water was a good movie it still was not a step in the right direction of once again being a great director.

The Happining however changed that, wail not perfect, or even as good as Signs he shows that he still has what it takes be a great director. The writing is good as is the acting. The story has a thought provoking theme and is well told and developed. But what is pherheps best about the movie is also what the worst part is and that is that you the viewer are left to decide what really (pun intended) happens. Mark W. Is excllent. And Zooey is HOT!!!

So all in all not perfect but a good movie. Hopfully Night builds upon this and can once again return to top form.

title: Great really cool premise and violence! WORST. ACTING. EVER!
review:
This movie was very interesting. However, it would have worked much better as the written word rather than a film. This is because the acting is horrible! Marky Mark is AWFUL! And his love interest is MUCH WORSE!! She is so annoying and horrible, and the dialogue written by M. Night Shamalayadingdong is so contrived and insipid it will literally bring bile rising to the back of your throat. I really really, really REALLY wished Zooey Deschanel killed herself in this movie.

That is what ruined this movie. However this is a really great movie otherwise. Its very well done in its ideas, very well done. I was really impressed with the handeling of the premise, how creepy it was. The scenes were people killed themselves was excellently horrific, very well done. Instead of over the top violence or something, it was silent austere suicide. Creeped me the hell out. And the very end is not a happy ending. Thank god, because the denouement when ***SPOILER*** marky mark's wife gets pregnant made me want to puke, and if you think about it made no sense.

title: The Happening fails to impress
review: The Happening should be re-named "The Not-Happening". I thought I'd give this a chance,having seen the trailer, which I did find interesting. The thing is, The Happening started out fast-ish,then amidst that action,there was some kind of annoying sub-plot(a bit like the kind of thing you might see in Friends)where Elliot's (Wahlberg) wife admits to having an affair, hiding mobile phone calls and the like. Its almost laughable that something like this should be in the script when the characters lives are in stake. There would be no room to even develop that sub-plot anyway. There's hardly any atmospheric music (I mean,Dark Knight had me on the edge of my seat,because of the music, and its by the same guy in The Happening, isn't it?) For me, it just went off the boil after the first 5 minutes. The main thing that keeps a movie rolling for me is music. If it isn't there, it will fail. Within The Happening is an interesting story that could have worked if the pace was a lot speedier. And the dialogue? Nah. Must...try....harder!!

title: Poor
review:
It's at times like this I'd wish I were more eloquent. I've just sat through this tripe and my only response is to consider slapping myself in the face. The reason I don't is that I may one day perhaps bump into the writer and slap him instead, and so I'm holding it in reserve for that.

Wahlberg, a (generally) superb actor - what are you doing here? The participants in this flick are prone to an almost trance-like state, and I can only guess you took your cue from that for the whole film. You're too decent an actor to be appearing in this - next time, when you're picking a role, go by the script, not by the director's name.

I can only guess what the directors directions were - "err, just walk around a bit and say the words written on the script... and... action ! Yeah, I know it looks poor on paper, but The Sixth Sense was good. Remember? Remember The Sixth Sense? Forget about Signs, that was a mistake... This is me being good again..." This is crap of the highest order. Generally, I like my eco-proselytizing a little less "on-the-nose". The way the "be kind to the planet" message is delivered would make even the staunchest Greenpeace-supporter puke.

All those involved (and yes, Shymalan, you especially) should be thoroughly ashamed of themselves. To those that bankrolled this POS, take a good hard look at the reviews either here or on metacritic before you give "golden boy" Shymalan his next paycheck.

Come in Mr Night, your time is up.

title: what???
review:
so let's get on with it right away.

"what???" was what i said when the film stopped with that "28 Days Later" ending. so what was that killing all those people? was it the "wrath of nature" or maybe that devilish witch-acting mrs.Jones or more prolly the two knitting grannies with gas-masks on? but, thinking of it, it was just an overrated writer/director that did all that. following the same patterns when writing and directing a plot is what he's been always doin with the exception of this very film which did not have any ... and to get through it there are 'good' and 'bad' ways for killing people in a movie and i'm more than sure that this one was one of the worse ever ...end of story

neeeeexxxtttttt!!!!

title: Not happening
review: This movie is such a disappointment. There are only a few moments where you get scared, and the rest of the time you're bored. Even the suicides become boring and impersonal (only the first one is in close-up and shocking.) Most of the suicides are from a distance, or you only see their feet as they pick up a gun and shoot themselves. We don't really get to know the characters, so consequently it doesn't really matter when they die. The big reveal comes too early in the story and the ending is a big let down. All it seems to be is an exploration of how many ways you can kill yourself. I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone.

title: Only Hollywood ;)
review:
Man I was looking forward to this movie so incredible much! I thought: M.Night as the director and freaking Mark "Marky Mark" Wahlberg in the lead role, I mean - I'ts a given combination! BUT unfortunately this movie took me by storm the first 9 maybe 10 minutes, and there after it really stunk! Totally predictable, very bad acting (even from Mark Wahlberg), a lot of clichés and the worst part was the whole story. Okay, I really do admit the plot to be original but I've seen M.Night Shyamalan write ten times better ones! One other, very disturbing thing was that almost every "mature" character was using words like "chill" and other words from the streets... WHY? It isn't realistic, God damn it! Basically NOTHING in this movie is realistic and not even the movie itself was filmed particularly good. No great looking angels, no cool special effects (except for the wind flying through some grass, which even I can do in my films) and I can go on like this for days, giving this movie constructive criticism but if I go over to some positive criticism I'll give M.Night some credit for making an original idea, thinking about the world's environment AND making this movie pretty descent after all, with only $60,000,000 (normally today a movie costs about $100,000,000).

M.Night Shyamalan. If you read this (most likely not, but anyway): Keep the good work up and try shooting in some exclusive and fresh angles! One thing I would have done with the ending is when Elliot Moore walks over to Alma Moore, at the end, I would have rewind the movie back to its very beginning and then I would have fade in the words "IT'S HAPPENING" and then I would have fade out and fade in to "THE HAPPENING" - THE END =)

title: Hmmm. . .what to think?
review: Well, I think M night is a genius; I always have. However, this movie has me a little moved. I mean, I think the fact that wherever they went they were in danger gave the movie a good sense of fear, but there was way too much graphic violence. I'm not a fan of modern day "horror" movies that show people getting killed in the worst way. It doesn't interest me, but what I have always liked about M's movies is that they were original and some were a little frightening at points. In the end, his movies tended to make sense and I always liked how the little bits and pieces of clues throughout the movie came together in the end. . .This one was not like that. I did get a sense of fear, but I was more disgusted than anything. I did like how the movie wasn't just the same old pattern, but it just lacked that M night"ness." There were a few "clues" planted in the movie, but for the most part the answers were given away and in the end I just kind of felt let down. I mean, he didn't even give a cameo:( I don't, however, think that M should stop writing. I love his movies and I'm sure his next one will be better. We aren't all going to make a number one single you know? I'm sure Hitchcock made a couple of flops in his day. . .

title: Somewhat Entertaining
review: The happening wasn't a bad movie, it just wasn't all that good. The movie starts out with so much promise, as the opening scene is probably one of the best I have ever seen. It really draws you in and makes you want to see more. The problem is there really is no more. The acting in this movie is great. John Leguizamo plays a short, but good part in the movie. Mark Wahlberg again shows he can sell any role he plays. The storyline as a whole was a pretty good concept, but as M Knight always does, he never really gives closer, and I think thats why I rated this movie only a 4. I don't like when I finish watching a movie I have no idea what happened. For me I thought it was just OK. I don't think I would recommend this movie but I wouldn't try to talk someone out of it who said they were going to watch it.

title: Stay away from this !
review: This is one of the most boring movies that this summer has produced; it is clear now that Mr Shyamalan's magic touch is no more and another proof that banking only on one talent - in this case supernatural thriller , unknown and terrifying around us , with as little visualization of this evil , unknown and in all of us as possible , cannot work forever; the movie is also a painful slap on the face of Mr Walberg ,as no one in this film in fact knows what he /she is doing .An interesting basic idea ,but horribly presented , plants as evil force and bunch of people running somewhere , and dropping dead , and that's that !

title: Slapstick
review:
Alright, first I really need to say that when I first read the plot line of this movie, me and my boyfriend both thought of a rip-off of Suicide Club, an Asian production. Thank god it wasn't, or maybe it should have been and maybe it would have been a better movie if it in fact was a rip-off. But no, Shyamalan took a perfectly interesting storyline and made a slapstick movie out of it. Where you think the movie could be okay, especially if you know Mark Wahlberg is starring in it, you should better keep your money in your pocket and really don't go see it in cinema's. This is one movie which I'd like to see copied, so that the director knows it isn't worth buying it.

The Happening tells the story of a weird phenomenon which causes people to commit suicide. Of course people all over America are fleeing and it isn't before long that Mark Wahlberg discovers it might have to do something with the plants. Together with his wife and the daughter of his best friend, he's trying to survive in a world that's gone crazy. Well, that's it for the story. Could be pretty interesting, no? Well, that's what I thought, but Wahlberg is being a stupid comedian, who isn't funny when he has a funny line, but who is funny all the more in the rest of the movie, which causes the movie to be a bad comedy at all the wrong and mismented times. The acting is really really REALLY bad and should be nominated for a stupid Razzie-award, or whatever it is called. It looks cheap and the only person I really believed in this mis-production, was the woman who heard her daughter commit suicide over the phone. And if it wasn't her, then it was her dog.

DON'T GO WATCH IT! IT SUCKS!

title: Another pathetic film in fact one of the worst I have ever seen
review:
I have just seen one of the worst films ever made..."The Happening" in which nothing is happening which makes "The Happening" nothing.

One of my favorite actors Mark Wahlberg obviously did the film for the money as he spurts out his share of ridiculous gibberish dialogue. He is the only name actor in this ridiculous film about a huge toxic breaking wind. The film defies all scientific and medical plausibility about how toxic contagious spread. Also the idea that a virus or "bug" could suddenly make you violently and actively suicidal is so crazy it's make you laugh. Especially the scene in which a man suicides by letting his industrial lawn mower ride over him and another scene about an elderly women who kills herself by headbutting windows and walls. Those scenes left the audience in screaming fits of laughter.

The film reached a new cinematic low when Wahlberg's character communicates from a room in house to an "OutShed" some thirty metres away through a pipe in the wall. Even a twelve year old could figure out that you don't get high fidelity sound through old water pipes over a long distance that must also have perpendicular bends.

I also noticed M. Night Shyamalan carefully places Indian nationals in almost every scene and they surely must be family and friends.

Shyamalan uses his usually cliché suspense and intrigue techniques combined with scenes of graphic blood and gore to the standard measure.

The scenes of people monitoring the magnitude of the suicidal virus on the TV news in public cliché is about as cliché as you can get. I think that most people need a leader to unleash that side of them that can see the the absolutely ridiculous side to things they see otherwise they sink into this quiet reverence and dismay at the graphically violent scenes.

This film had no scientific plausibility and the way Wahlberg delivered his lines made me certain he was offered a great deal of money for the role. He is a really great actor why he stooped to this ridiculous crap alludes me.

The act of suicide is a combination of complicated deep-seated depression combined with the long standing premeditated sense of purpose or some really passionate psychologically motivated processes. The act itself has never been associated with organically or other forms of toxicity and even if when a physiological imbalance or causality could be diagnosed the onset of the act of suicide would and could not be that sudden.

I mean if the mental faculties were available to determine which process would result in death then surely other faculties would be operative.

Which ever way you look at it the process was ridiculous. Also why in America? why not in some extremely populated region like India where the Director M. Night Shyamalan comes from. I guess in India the only way to suicide would be drowning in the open sewer puddles which would also look pretty funny. Imagine 1600 million people in such a highly populated place with negligible means of suicide people would be head butting each other for months.

Another really stupid film by this way too over-rated Film director M. Night Shyamalan. He should stick to Bollywood films that have Indian nationals dancing around "Maypoles" as they celebrate the grant of their Australian permanent residence or the birth of their eight child here. Shyamalan must be a hot favorite for the Rasberry award this year. Minus ten stars and its good night M. Night Shyamalan never again!

title: Too Much or Too Little... I Can't Decide
review: I suppose this movie is likable. It works. It succeeds at telling a story, and is a nice return for Shamyalan. But... Is it just me, or is both too much and too little shown? I wonder: Do we really need to see all of the violence that there is in the film, if it's only backed up by an unsatisfying, relatively non-violent ending? I also wonder: Can the sentimentality of the film be backed up without more characterization of Elliott and Alma and the situation of their relationship? Let's start with the "too much" idea first. Why do we need to see Central Park being affected by whatever it is, whatever you want to call it? Why do we need to see workers jumping off of a building? Would it not be more frightening to simply hear about the events through radio broadcasts? The uncertainty would definitely scare me more than seeing what is actually happening. Granted, the "seeing" part of things is wonderfully mastered. It just doesn't invoke terror as simply hearing about the events might. To move on with the "too little" idea... Wahlberg and Deschanel are both talented, but are not given enough to really work with. The opening scenes make Deschanel like she does not have the slightest idea what she is doing on film. She simply stares at her phone. This induces more laughs than curiosity. Alma's relationship with Elliott just exists. When Leguizamo's character tells Elliott that he saw Alma crying on their wedding day, it does not offer any real insight. Seeing Alma and Elliott interact makes me think of them being more like strangers than being husband and wife. More interaction between them, aside from the obvious dialogue, would help to bring credibility to the unjustified ending. As for other complaints... The supporting cast of characters is predictably killed off, although the violence hardly ever becomes too graphic. One of the biggest complaints I can register against the movie is the whole reason for the events. Plants? The film would have been better off without any explanation whatsoever. That, as well, would have added to the horror. Still, I did more or less like the movie. It did what it came to do, and did it well enough to be more than simply passable, but not well enough to be admirable. There just should have been more or less than there was.

title: Horrible disappointment
review:
There is no tension at all during this morning. I attended at 935p movie with about 30 people and besides a few jumps from the audience it seemed like everyone was bored.

After the first disease scenes there is no suspense since we know the outcome for everyone infected. The method utilized may change but we know exactly what's going to happen and that ruins the suspense of each of these infection scenes.

PHL 30th Street Station - if NYC had been contaminated with some sort of infection I believe every east coast city would be clearing out. 30th Street Station seemed like a normal afternoon.

During an emergency I would imagine television/radio/Internet ratings are enormous. In this movie they turn off the radio. Huh? I actually started surfing the Internet towards the end of the movie hopeful that it would end soon.

I enjoyed Signs and was hoping for a movie similar to Signs but this movie was a big disappointment.

The title says it all: Not Happening. The entire theme of the movie. Nothing much happens.

title: Awful...
review: I have always tried to give M. night a lot of credit, but this movie was awful. The acting was dry and very unenthusiastic. I gave up trying to like this movie when the army officer was suddenly worried by saying "Cheese and Crackers." Even when someone would be dying no one would seem to be surprised. In the very first scene when the woman stabs herself with her own hairpin the woman sitting next to her just has a blank look on her face. Although I will give props to Shymalan for the humor in the movie. Such as when he starts talking to the plastic tree I found that scene to be pretty funny. I've always liked M. Night and always defended him but after watching this movie...he made that impossible.

title: This is a Serious Casualty
review:
The first film that I watched from M. Night Shymalan was the terrific Signs. However, since then he has been getting worse and worse. The Happening may be even worse than the disastrous Lady in the Water. It starts off brilliantly, but soon dissolves into a lazily written, poorly constructed and unintentionally funny failure.

A large-scale disaster is occurring. Nobody knows what is causing it, but anyone who is caught up in the deadly incidents is driven to suicide. With news of the epidemic heading towards Philadephia, school teacher Elliot (Mark Wahlberg) and his wife Alma (Zooey Deschanel), along with his friend Julian (John Leguizamo) and Julian's daughter (Ashlyn Sanchez), attempt to flee. However, the supposed attacks are spreading quickly, and no one knows when the epidemic will strike next...

Shymalan kicks off the proceedings with pizazz in an intense opening which is both chilling and disturbing. However, he starts to lose his bearings in the second half. The film is also too short to be effective, shooting past details as if it can't be bothered to realise their full potential. If this is Shymalan's attempt at a comeback, I think that it's time for him to call it a day. His heart doesn't seem to be in it, and his direction is too pretentious and ultimately inept. I think that I'm just about finished with Shymalan myself.

Shymalan also pens the script, which contains some awful dialogue. One man says, in reference to the supposed attacks, that "there appears to be an event happening." What event? Is the circus coming to town? There is also one horrendously cheesy moment in which Wahlberg's character attempts to communicate with a plant. The script is one of the films biggest weaknesses. Some of the communication between the characters is just downright outrageous.

For me, the acting is a mixed bag. In my opinion, Mark Wahlberg and John Leguizamo deliver the strongest performances, crafting characters who I came to care about and who I could invest in. Wahlberg's solid performance may in fact be the best thing about the movie, whereas Leguizamo's final scene is especially affecting. However, Zooey Deschanel made me feel more uneasy in some scenes then all of the suicidal maniacs put together. At times, she seems so lifeless, so strange that I tended to stop thinking of her as a normal person. Meanwhile, young Ashlyn Sanchez fails to convince in her key scenes as the daughter of Leguizamo's character.

There is another flaw. Whilst Shymalan knows how to start a premise, he doesn't necessarily know how to end one. This is especially obvious in The Happening, where there isn't any real ending or closure to the story. But to be honest, I was glad that the film didn't go on any longer.

The musical score is effective, if nothing exceptional. It creates a strange and intense mood, and does what it needs to do in the long run. Technically, the film is adequate. There are some moments where the technical crew are superb, such as in one scene where two cocky boys upset one crazy survivor. My biggest disappointment is that the brilliance on display in this scene and a few others doesn't last for long.

Overall, The Happening is a bundle of missed opportunities. Whilst it has serious promise in its premise, it is let down by bad execution, some lacklustre writing and truly shy film-making. This film isn't anywhere near the visceral thrills of films such as 28 Days Later. In fact, there isn't really that much blood to speak of. So far, The Happening is the worst casualty of summer 2008, smacking the final nail in Shymalan's coffin with a resounding crack.

title: Just OK
review:
Mr Shymalan, where have you gone?

Let's be perfectly clear, this is no 6th Sense, or even Signs. It's better than Lady In The Water, but thats not hard to do. That said, it's still a decent flick. Keeps your attention, some imaginative scenes, and storytelling. The idea was good, but the execution and development were bland by Shymalan's own standards.

This is not Marky Mark's finest hour, matter of fact, none of these actors put in a very memorable performance. The dialogue was very much lacking. The characters were simple and straight forward, most came and went without any development. None very believable, especially Private Auster and the Mrs. Jones. Not so much because they were poor actors, just poor characters. A bumbling idiot as an Army guy and a paranoid reclusive old woman with a nasty attitude, but a sense of hospitality for no apparent reason? Sorry, just not quite believable to me.

I thought the camera work was very good, lots of sweeping scenes and great odd-angle shots. Colorful at times, dark and eerie at times. Well done.

******MINOR SPOILER COMMENT*******

As far as the story. Do we really need yet another avenue for left-wing environmentalist propaganda? Global Warming? Gov't conspiracy? C'mon M Night, you used to be way beyond this sort of thing. I still love the work but it's really a disappointment to see another director fall into the "we are __________(fill in the blank.. Americans, Humans, polluters, etc.), and therefore we are evil and should be punished" mold that envelopes and dominates Hollywood. M.N.S. used to be a breathe of fresh air, now he seems to have discarded his individualism to become just another stiff towing the radical left message that owns Hollywood.

title: Umm....
review:
...I just don't know. That's probably the best way to describe my, and quite likely everyone else's, reaction when this movie's credits started to roll.

The movie starts out with a lot of promise. New York's Central park suddenly grinds to a halt and its once bustling inhabitants start walking backwards, talking in gibberish and eventually committing suicide. We then flash over to a construction site where workers begin throwing themselves from their gerters to the ground below in front of the teary eyes of their friends. The incidents are assumed initially to be the result of some sort of bio-chemical terrorist attack and New York is eventually evacuated. Neighboring Philadelphia soon follows suit and this is where we are introduced to our main characters, played my Mark Wahlberg, Zooey Deschanel, John Leguizamo and his on screen daughter. They, along with thousands of others start their trek away from whatever the hell is going on.

If this ever actually happened we'd all be quaking in our boots, combine that with the strong opening and you are easily strapped in and genuinely curious to see what happens next. The problem is the movie runs along at a relatively slow pace, which you will probably gladly sit through in anticipation for the pay off at the end...unfortunately, there really is no pay off to look forward to. The cause of the Happening is presented early on as a theory and doesn't take long before it's presented as likely fact by our protagonist. The ora of mystery that falls over the first 30 minutes of the movie is more or less destroyed by this epiphany and there's little more to keep you guessing. By now you care enough about the characters to root for them and keep you invested, but by the end I still felt cheated out of something, I just didn't know what. M. Night Shyamalan's made a career out of surprise twist endings that turn your entire perception of the preceding film on its head. If ever there was flick made for that it's The Happening, but he decides not to cash in and instead turns it into what feels like a 90 min PSA for global warming.

As far as acting John Leguizamo is the stand out while Wahlberg is good but not great as he often is. I like Zooey Deschanel but she's wooden and unlikable for the lion's share of the movie, which isn't at all her fault given the dialog and scripted personality she's handed. You do get a sense of her improv prowess though, during two scenes of solitude, while she waits and fidgets impatiently.

M. Night Shyamalan is without question a talented director, however. As week as his story is, it is also well shot and paced. There is some very clever camera work that actually manages to be scary in of itself. Creepy almost in its simplicity. I don't think he's earned the rank of today's Hitchcock like some have bestowed upon him, though. Talented, yes, Hitchcock, no. Some of Alfred's stuff is better than others, but I've never seen a Hitchcock film I didn't like.

Like I've said or at least implied the movie's entertaining enough to keep you from looking at your watch, but by the end of it you can't quite understand why. Maybe it will appreciate in time and fewer expectations. I will gladly give it a second chance.

But a warning to gore fans. The movie's promotions like to highlight the R rating this receives but given the lack of graphic violence, course language or even suggestive humor I don't think Shyamalan was going for the R rating so much as it was just given to him.

title: Bad acting, choppy writing
review: Everyone in this movie except for Mark Wahlberg could have been recast, with positive results, and no one would have noticed. Leguizamo is wasted as some geek math teacher with no common sense. Everyone in the movie seems to have inappropriate emotional responses to things not yet in evidence. Some of the time the characters' facial expressions do not in any way match what they are talking about; they talk about very tense, upsetting things with no expression. The leaps of logic that people make are in no way logical, and Elliott's hissy fit screaming "give me a minute! give me a minute! give me a minute!" does not fit with his character, and really, it isn't as if people are harassing him for a decision. There was no chemistry whatsoever between Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel, strangers on a bus could have been more connected than this "husband and wife", even with the purported marital problems that seem to have been exaggerated. The way Elliott talks about Alma to Julian as they exit the school, it seems as if the marriage is hanging by a thread and he almost seems to be setting Julian up to be prepared for Alma to be an angry, distant, mentally unstable twit. Julian for his part treats his child as if she were about to go postal, which she never does either, and at times his character seems forced, as if only thrown in to have another "star" name in the credits.

title: I wanted to like it. I really did.
review: I even gave 3 stars because the main idea was intriguing. I liked Shyamalan's other movies, even The Village, and I like that he's a man of color in a predominately white industry. I wanted to show my support by going and watching this film. But it sucks. After the first 20 or so minutes, I realized that nothing new was going to happen. Whalberg figures out the plot half-way through the movie, and for the rest we're just watching him and Zooey D. run around in fields, interact with a crazy lady, and then figure out they're OK at the end. As a friend of mine said after we left the theater, Shyamalan had one great idea and made a movie out of it. But one great idea doesn't make a movie. I sincerely believe if he would have built on it and created some sub-plots that it could have been a good movie. But he didn't and man oh man was it boring.

title: Truly Dreadful!
review:
I was slightly reserved about going to see this film after watching other examples of M. Nights work. The Village and Lady In The Water were both simply awful.

However, I was hoping that this latest outing would bring back the greatness of Sixth Sense and Unbreakable. Unsurprisingly, it was not to be.

Unfortunately, all I was given was a poorly directed mess of a movie with 2D characters I couldn't care less about. The problem that is blighting many recent horror films.

The acting was absolutely atrocious, no emotion, no feeling, nothing. Wahlbergs performance was at best, terrible. Zooey Deschanel was laughable in her cringingly lacklustre role. The best way to describe all of the performances in this film is by calling them wooden. No-one stood out and even characters with precious little screen time acted like they couldn't be bothered.

The dialogue was simply inexplicable, some of the lines spoken in the film were jaw-droppingly abysmal and it wasn't scary, not one scene of this mess was in the least bit horrifying. Though the UK version being cut probably didn't help matters.

The premise of the story was brilliant and could've been done successfully, but this is a complete sham of a movie and I wish I had thought with my head instead of my heart.

Terrifyingly awful.

title: Ha Ha Happening. 'Oh, tell it again Joe. It makes me laugh so.'
review:
I am going to give this film a 2 out of 10. Not because I like it in any way, shape or form, but because I'm nice. Now i have given this 2 stars, I can no offend this terrible idea that should have been covered with a lampshade. Seriously it is just stupid. He made one good film with a big twist which was almost 10 years ago. Anything else? it is nothing like Hitchcock in terms of suspense. It had a bad soundtrack all the way through it, which was meant to supply some tension into our brains. Hitchcock for one didn't show off his camera equipment in at least 4 scenes. Even if he did I would have let him off for doing so as his films were good and they probably spent less time in the editing room as they barley had one years and years ago. On a further note, did anyone think this resembled two days before the day after tomorrow. (South Park episode, season 9) That i love because it is not making it dramatic.

Not a bad movie overall. No. Wait. It is.

title: Good premise, but very poor follow through
review:
All of Shylaman's older works were his best, but with this film, he brings us a poorly drawn story with some very bad dialoque and acting. I loved the premise, but the movie itself doesn't deliver.

THe story starts off in Central Park, where we find the average people doing their average routine. Than there's the ominous wind blowing through the trees, and suddenly people freeze in time it seems and suddenly start to do uncharacteristic things like walking backwards, talking as if disoriented and then, well you will know if you see the movie. Other events start happening as well. One of the more important scenes happens at a construction sight, but I will offer no spoilers here.

Cut to a teacher (Mark Wahlberg) talking about the disappearance of Honey Bees with his class where he is soon interrupted by the vice principal, who leads him from the class to the auditorium where all other teachers have gathered and are discussing what has happened. Of course school is dismissed, and Elliot Moore (Wahlberg) is soon leaving town with his wife Alma (Zooey Deschanel) his friend Julian (John Leguizamo) and Julian's daughter Jess (Ashlyn Sanchez) to escape what is happening. They are soon confronted with the fact that whatever is happening is now spreading from bigger cities into the smaller towns and on. WHat happens along the way? I will say no more. I will say though that you do learn what is causing the problem. At least Shylaman doesn't leave us hanging.

I loved the idea. THe plot is preachy but I think it could've worked much better if Shylaman had let someone else write the story. Like I said above the dialogue in this movie is really bad, and the actors seem embarrassed or just not sure what to do. THe Happening suffers from some of the same things that hurt The VIllage a couple years ago. Shylaman is good with building suspense and making things ominous and spooky as he always has been. I also loved the score to the movie, but none of these things can save this movie from being anything but below average. Sorry, but this movie cannot be recommended.

title: Time to water my plants
review: First off i need to say that the acting was the wost I've seen in a long time. All the actors seemed to be forcing there lines and over doing it. The acting was so bad that it was distracting me from the movie itself. I do need to give credit to the crazy old lady though. She was the only person i thought did a good job. She was the main reason i got a little freaked out. The fist part of the movie was pretty good but after that it went all downhill. I think that the plot itself was o.k. and if more time was spent writing the script and shooting it then it could be a good movie. Nothing really changes through out the movie besides 'holy crap more wind RUN!'. They never really go into anyones personal story stopping me from caring if anyone died. I also think that some of the ways people were killing them self's was a little cheesy and i found myself laughing with the rest of the crowd at many parts. I was also sad to see that the was no good twist. I was really looking forward to it but it was reveled half-way through and all i could think was "thats it? the plants want revenge? really?" Overall i think if it was written better and had MUCH better acting then this could have been a good movie but I'm sad to say i think this was a total waste of time. Although I think I'm going to starting watering my grass a lot more....even if its raining.

title: disappointing movie
review: well i had scene the trailer a couple of times and was really excited about watching this movie, however since it's beginning till it's end it was a downhill road. first of all while i always found Mark walhberg to be an OK actor (not excellent but not bad) he was terrible at this movie i mean come on i know you want to seem as a "normal" nice teacher but even nice teacher lose it you are running in the middle of a field with everybody killing themselves around you and you don't even hug your wife. everybody is killing themselves you don't know what to do or where to go and here you are giving a smiley face it's unbelievable even the kids in the movie were acting better. Following that while i always found disaster movies and books my favorite science fiction section this movie failed in all sense. while i appreciate that for one time the movie hero doesn't save the world. However the plot is completely incoherent a small example for not telling the whole movie is when John Leguizamo is in the car searching for his wife then he finds everybody dead while logically you turn around he just keeps moving. these small plot loops who could be easily fixed if you proofread the script . finally the direction and the used clichés are just terrible. while you might be tempted to watch stay away from this movie!!

title: A response to the movie: Brief, thought provoking, and reasonable
review:
Movie had low production quality, less than mediocre acting, and an unreasonable and overly dramatic message, unless M had a message that transcended the apparent message in his movie: This country is in large part driven unfortunately by fear. Fear is the feeling that inevitably permeates throughout society. Having said that, the biological "attacks" didn't originate until a woman screamed. At the beginning and the end. Why did the woman scream, was it because of the fatal chemical excretions of the plant-life or was it for something else unrelated, but the ever-present fear that resulted from that scream was the catalyst for the spread of the fatal chemicals. Then the fear spread throughout the northeast and was attached to those that were scared, regardless of the size of groups. Whalberg and Deschannel near the end were unharmed because they were experiencing at that moment "Love" as opposed to "Fear." The end with the scientist developing a theory of this biological toxin being a response to the environmental and progressive fiendishness of human civilization seemed to be direct and obvious in its message. Yet could that message in itself be drawing on the "Fear" that has driven society for so long? I doubt M has the cleverness or even the time to indulge in such possibilities or complexities in writing this movie. It's making good money, so mission accomplished I guess.

The Movie itself had, like I said, low production quality and less-than-mediocre acting regardless.

4.5/10

title: Too bad
review:
I, like most comments I'd read before this went into "The Happening" as a fan of M. Night Shyamalan's work. Granted, it's pretty obvious his career has been on a steady decline since he blew everyone away with 99's "Sixth Sense", but still somehow his films always have that sense of tension and startling discomfort that very few directors are able to consistently maintain. These techniques (along with obviously one of the great plot twists in recent history) made him such a smash success with Sixth Sense, and also made films like "Unbreakable" and "Signs" oddly enjoyable and totally suspenseful. Even the disappointing "Village" maintained many of these same characteristics making it at least enjoyable until the lame twist of that movie. At first I was hoping to leave "Lady in the Water" totally out of the equation, chalking it up to M. Night trying (and failing) something new, breaking out of his own box he'd created, something that eventually had to be done, at least giving that weird and hardly enjoyable movie a point.

Now, onto "The Happening". The trailer was promising, and that eerie feeling of paranoia and helplessness that made "Signs" so intriguing was back. So I went in with high hopes, especially since I'm also a fan of Wahlberg (who seemed to have improve with every performance leading up to this) and the always good Zooey Deschanel as seemingly capable leads. Everything was going well, until the movie started.

The opening sequence was possibly the highlight of the movie, which is pretty annoying considering none of the film's antagonists are even introduced at this point. Already though the screenplay is evidently forced and for lack of a better word, lame. Laughs were heard all throughout the theater at just the basic dialogue of the movie, whether it be someone who's supposed to be terrified replying "cheese and crackers" or Wahlberg reacting with a 'shocked' "Oh no!" after several people are attacked by this 'happening'.

The actual plot of the movie isn't bad (SPOILERS AHEAD) but it essentially turns from a super-natural horror mystery into a unnecessarily boring and flat chase movie which finds a goofy, bumbling, uncomfortable looking Mark Wahlberg and a detached Zooey Deschanel who seemed like her only true work on this movie was letting M. Night film her (admittingly amazing) eyes in super close ups for half the movie, basically running from maybe-abandoned house to maybe-abandoned house from the big bad toxins in the air. This could have been pulled off much better with characters who we cared about, or at least characters who would react like a real person would in this type of thing. Instead of the total paranoia, shock, and disbelief that made a movie like Cloverfield so popular, we're given ridiculous small talk about how cool hot dogs are. I wish I was kidding.

John Leguizamo's character is totally useless in the movie, and Wahlberg and Deschanel's relationship is so obviously forced that you're almost rooting for one of them to kill themselves then end up together. In fact, the happy ending that at least these two get ends up being cheesy and stupid. Not to mention the huge amount of emphasis put on something so insignificant as a mood ring gets.

You'd think with all of these detractors, at least the gruesome suicide scenes would make this a cool, eerie movie. But no, unfortunately some of these scenes induced as many laughs in the audience as the terrible dialogue did. Aside from the opening sequence (which even itself had terrible dialogue and awful characters you were just couldn't help rooting against) I remember only being creeped out at one of the scenes, the haunting mass hanging scene. Others were just seemed totally forced and well, dumb. Whether it was some idiot turning on this big lawnmower and casually laying down in front of it or some crazy old lady (who sadly may have been the scariest thing in the movie...not a compliment) smashing her face through a window?, the scenes seemed like something a 15 year old might think up, not the guy who made us all squirm in "The Sixth Sense".

With all that, I gave the movie a 4. Admittingly, it may be just me remembering M. Night's previous films and giving him bonus points for those. Or maybe I sort of welcomed the whole 'plants' plot and just wished for more (aka a lot more) out of it. Either way I (along with the rest of the audience) walked out extremely disappointed, laughing more times then I screamed, only remembering the movie for Zooey Deschanel's eyes.

title: Good premise squandered.
review: Horribly acted, horribly and obviously foreshadowed from the get-go with cringe-inducing classroom scene and a spoon fed sappy moral that would inspire Al Gore to strangle a spotted owl with his own hands.If you liked the movie, fine, but the people who think the movie was "subtle" and those who hated it didn't "get" it, your arrogance is unbelievable. There was nothing "subtle" about the movie. The moral was spoon fed to us from the first scene with Wahlberg's discussion about the bees. "Sometimes we just don't know why nature does things". (Even more proof that it WAS plants). Scene after scene had cringe-worthy moments and dialog. "I don't feel comfortable expressing my emotions" was said twice--TWICE so we really get it and hope that she will learn to express her emotions (and be ready for the reward of motherhood) by the end of the movie. But DOES she? You'll have to see the movie to find out. "If you take my daughter's hand, you better mean it," cut to slow-motion close up of Zooey taking the girl's hand. The "crazy" plant man talks to the plants and waxes on about hotdogs. But how do we KNOW he's crazy? Zooey helpfully points at him, then points at her temple, twirls her finger, and mouths the word "crazy". Yes, just like your four year old nephew would. And finally, "what was the color of love"? "I can't remember." Are you EFFING kidding me? That's just straight-up insulting. I heard Al Gore watched this movie and promptly went out and strangled a spotted owl with his bare hands Mark Wahlberg was visibly uncomfortable throughout the entire ordeal, as if he hated the movie as much as everyone in the theatre did. The film reached its low point when our heroes encounter a crazy man who talks to plants. How do we know he's crazy? Well, because Zooey Deschanel looks at him and then points at her temple and twirls her finger around, giving us the universal third-graders sign for "crazy". Yes, she actually does that, just in case M Night's ACTUAL DIALOGUE didn't make that clear. All in all, a stunning failure even by the standards of a man who continues to make nothing but stunning failures.

title: A lot of promise that unfortunately failed at the final hurdle
review:
After seeing the trailers and watching cast interviews etc , I was eagerly anticipating this movie , not only was I a reasonable fan of MNS's movie's but it came across as engaging and interesting and just my kind of movie. Midway through the movie and I wasn't disappointed , fast paced , unnerving scenes and thoroughly gripping and was excitedly waiting for the story to pan out. Unfortunately the whole movie faltered and didn't live up to the early promise, the content was just missing IMO , it felt like it just ran out of steam.

There were unnecessary scenes on one hand,what was the point in the whole crazy lady and her old school creepy"baby"doll side story?? totally out of place and before anyone says about her comments about the world not caring for her etc etc I got that but the rest was redundant. On the other hand the movie ended so quickly and with such an anticlimax I was left , or so I felt, a little bit cheated especially since the very final scenes just lacked originality and just lacked the response I assumed it was going for .

I think my whole problem about the film was I was expecting something special from such a great writer/director but ultimately I set my standards too high and this time he just didn't hit the mark.

title: If at second and third and fourth you fail: fail, fail, again.
review:
The premise of the movie is well worth pursuing: "It's not nice to fool with with mother nature!" Unfortunately M. Night Shyamalan is not up to it.

Something is affecting the human race, or at least in the North East section, and it makes them kill themselves. We get to see gore and shock and awe (MNS has decided to get with our need for explicit violence), and for a while it looks like a WMD attack. Then it becomes something more difficult to grasp: it's nature, and she's p.o'd at us for global warming.

Mark Wahlberg plays a nerdy school teacher, and it's difficult to watch him struggle to get into the skin of the character. As an actor he's best at showing us pent up anger, frustrated rage, and sociopathy. As a dweeb he just seems lost. In fact all the characters in this soap opera seem lost. I get why the Director wants to show "average people," but "boring" people? He's married to a borderline, who's self involved and immature, and his friend (John Leguizamo) decides to let him know this at the outset of the movie. Why? Who knows! The end of the world seems a little more pressing than marital dynamics.

Everybody heads to the countryside, because someone deems it's safer, and yet nature seems to track them down and get them in bunches. Naturally we end up with just Mark, his wife and Leguizamo's daughter, holed up in an old lady recluses home. MNS decides to unleash Betty Buckley as a Norma Bates clone on the trio, but luckily she's felled by the suicide spores and has the funniest suicide scene in recent memory.

This is not a horror movie, but it is pretty horrible to watch MNS descend once again into adolescent movie making. He's absorbed Hitchcock and King and resurrected himself as Wes Craven with a bigger budget.

Shyamalan has had his shot at this subject matter and now hopefully someone with a better gift for making it look realistic and worth watching will get a chance.

title: The Happening is a satire...
review:
I first hated the film, but after thinking about it, I really do think Shyamalan meant for the film to criticize environmentalists. I believe, in other words, that "The Happening" actually spoofs, satirizes, or criticizes environmentalists who assert that our actions hurt nature and therefore we concomitantly hurt ourselves. Some reasons appear below, although more evidence would likely appear after I -- or someone who wants to email me -- more circumspectly examines the film: 1. Shyamalan created an absurd premise: Most environmentalists have stated that humans' wasteful lifestyles threaten natural life (plants, trees, water, among other elements); consequently, then, through hurting nature, they claim we hurt ourselves. Perhaps Shyamalan literalizes this idea since "The Happening" centers on plants, trees, and grass, thatbecause people threaten themrelease toxins which first confuse people, then paralyze them, and then convince them to kill themselves. In one absurd scene, for instance, a police officer stands in the street, wind blows such deadly chemicals over him, he freezes, then grabs his gun and shoots himself directly between the eyes. After he falls, a nearby, infected pedestrian finds the officer's gun and also shoots himself; a businesswoman then sees this same gun lying on the street and repeats the act on herself. If we accept that Shyamalan literalizes the environmentalists' theory, then the film's absurd circumstances actually make sense: because people threaten these plants, and such plants defend themselves through compelling people to commit suicide, the environmentalists' theory seems very literal; these people literally threaten nature and end up actually killing themselves. Dialogue further supports this idea: one prominent environmentalist in the film claims that trees talk to plants and plants to grass, creating a defense against humans. Because Shyamalan writes that such plants actually communicate with each other, we can certainly believe that he means to literalize the idea that plants have feelings and, therefore, hurt us to defend themselves, further underscoring the idea that, the more we hurt nature, the more we hurt ourselves. (Shyamalan evokes Philip K. Dick's science fiction, since this writer also and more famously literalized several theories.) 2. Shyamalan lampoons the film's nature-conscious characters: One man, who owns a green house, first mentions the idea that plants defend themselves against humans, and that's why people are dying. This guy, however, also uses binoculars to spy on neighbors; he loves hot-dogstheir shape and tasteand feels like people underestimate the food. Another woman, whom the main characters encounter much later in the film, lives alone, with no electricity; she makes everything herself, from only natural materials. Unfortunately, she also creates self-resembling dolls, hits children, and lives in paranoia; Elliot (Mark Wahlberg) repeatedly labels her "crazy." Because only the environmentally sensitive characters seem insane, Shyamalan suggests that these people are crazy because he means to lambaste environmentalists; "The Happening," then, amounts to a film that satirizes them.

3. Shyamalan compares environmentalists to Pinocchio: In the film's second or third scene, Elliot (Mark Wahlberg), a high school science teacher, wants one male student to develop more of an interest in science. He tells this "heartthrob" that every year his nose will grow a particular inch longer. Elliot's statement resembles the environmentalist's claims that the sea level rises a particular measurement every so many yearsan effect of global warming. If you really analyze this scene, though, you realize that Elliot, through saying that his student's nose will grow, subtly compares the pupil to Pinocchio: whenever Pinocchio lies, his nose grows. Perhaps Shyamalan insults environmentalists here: through evoking the argument about growing sea levels, and then conjuring up images of a liar, the director implies that such environmentalists lie.
