title: M. Night (over-rated and over payed.)
review:
I saw the 'Sixth Sense' and was amazed at how stupid M. Night must think the movie going public is. It seems that he doesn't figure on the audience asking themselves questions along the way, like...if Bruce Willis didn't realize he was dead...how was he able to ride the bus without paying? Why didn't anyone talk to him at the funeral scene? M. Night, do you honestly believe that no one figured out your 'twist ending.' Give give me a break...And as for 'The Village,' you mean to tell me that a blind woman can navigate her way through the woods and find her way to civilization? Are we really that stupid to fall for such an idiotic plot as that? I mean, did she secretly have a gps navigator telling her when to turn left or right? And why in the hell would anyone want to subject their loved ones to a 'terror' beyond the woods...rather than face the reality of day to day living. STUPID! 'The Village' was such an easy film to figure out. Hey! What about those ridiculous aliens in 'Signs.' I laughed so hard when I saw them. They were so intelligent...so smart...they couldn't even unlock a door! STUPID! And don't get me started on 'Unbreakable.' As for 'The Happening,' I was happy to see that the critics have finally decided to go the Simon Cowell route and tell it like it is. M. Night..you must have some dirt on Hollywood, 'cause they keep financing your disasters. Here's an idea...if you really want to add a great 'twist to one of your films, have Chubby Checker dance at the end of your next film.

Talk to you later....Mr. ('Next Spielberg'.......now that was a laugh) beto

title: What's "happening" to M. Night Shyamalan ?
review:
Okay, let me start by saying that I'm a HUGE M. Night Shyamalan fan: I loved his early movies and especially "Unbreakable" which is (by far) one of my favorite movies.

BUT... even if all his movies have flaws and I can understand people not liking them, I just don't understand what's happening to him...

He still managed to make me want to SEE this movie because I thought the story would be gripping and fascinating but as with "Lady in the water", it seems M. Night Shyamalan has lost his magic touch.

The beginning is good, very good... I liked the fact that nobody knows what's happening, I liked all the mysteries, I liked the graphic deaths (there's much more blood than in his previous films)... I liked everything about it... I was so happy to finally get the feeling I had when I watched "the 6th sense"... THEN everything went wrong... from the dialogs (which are by far some of the stupidest dialogs I have ever heard... everybody was just laughing in the theater) to the story itself which can not have been written by an adult...I like when a movie appeals to our inner child but here... come on, the end is PATHETIC!

Nowadays a lot of movies only rely on CGI and stunt scenes, so they hide their lacks of stories behind huge effects... here there's no CGI, almost no stunt scenes so since there's no story, the movie is just empty... it's like passing a beautiful gate to take a road which leads nowhere.

The revelation of the mystery is made half way through by one of the supporting roles (so what's the point of watching the rest?), there are COUNTLESS sub-stories that are really boring (what's the point with the lady in the house?, what happens to the people in the other house? What about the little girl) and it ends just like that, leaving a feeling of huge disappointment.

As for the actors...what can I say.... it just seemed to me that they were not concerned and bored throughout the movie... they must say those lines and you never believe one word of what they say...there's absolutely no chemistry between them and you can not believe those two are married. I love both of the leading roles but I have to say they have never been that bad in a movie.

So this movie has a good beginning but that's about it... oh yes, there's another good point in the movie... it is short...

Please M. Night Shyamalan, go back to what you were doing, I'm missing you so much and even though I still trust your ability to make good movies, I still hope you'll react in a good way and make movies you used to.

So for me it's probably M. Night Shyamalan's worst film to date...and it hurts me to say that !

title: Another M Night movie, Killed by a completely stupid idea
review:
I'm going to make this short, and sweet. Don't bother with this movie.

If you can get past the weak, emotionless acting, and somehow see the "greater picture" of " tapping into the paranoia of a post 9/11 world".... you'll probably still be crushed by the fact that, the entire idea, is incredibly STUPID.

Okay, so, somehow, the process of evolution takes place a million times faster than it actually does, and plants somehow learn to communicate with one another in a direct, intentional manner.

They release a toxin that causes humans to kill each other.

The protagonists have to avoid the wind, never mind that the toxin would be more potent in areas where the wind didn't blow....

Am i the only one that sees this? For the love of god, go watch a movie that's just a stupid, but doesn't try to take itself so seriously, like Kung-Fu Panda...

Or Ernest Scared Stupid for that matter.

title: It Happened One Night. . .
review:
As a writer, I enjoyed The Happening because I recognized it immediately as M. Night's tribute to Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds.

He pulls out headlines from the news--the disappearance of bees, the mysterious red tide, a lethal prehistoric bacteria discovered in Australia--and uses the real or perceived threats from these as the backdrop to develop fear. In fact, the three fears are shared and spaced evenly in the beginning, middle and near the end of the film.

Instead of killer birds, there are killer plants. Well, actually the plants emit the neurotoxin that induces people into a state of creative suicide. Instead of the caged peace-loving lovebirds in Hitchcock's film, there are small houseplants--like cactus and succulents present in the homes they seek refuge in. True, there is no icy blonde like Tippi Hendron to save, but Zooey emits a blue-eyed vacant look and she's emotionally detached. Instead of crossing over by motorboat to the sleepy community of Bodega Bay, the main characters enter the small town of Filbert, which coincidentally, is the name for a small nut. The action moves to smaller and smaller groups and locations until it centers on three main characters--the husband, wife and their friends' 8-year old daughter.

There are horrific and violent scenes implied in the movie. We see the calm movement of people intent on offing themselves via lions, lawnmowers, guns, ropes, broken glass, etc. Sort of reminded me of the Suicidal Bunnies book.

Most fans of Night are used to tidy endings wrapped up with a bow--endings filled with heightened emotion and resolution. But he left this film open-ended, much like The Birds. The first attack was a warning to mankind. The plants are mad, menacing and malicious. Are they out to rid the planet of mankind, because man has not been kind to the planet? Maybe. We kill plants, don't we? And eat them! Not me though. Really, if any plants are listening, I've never liked salad.

At the conclusion, the happy family is filled with the promise of life back to a semi-state of normal except with a lot less people on the streets. Also the promise of a positive pregnancy test. Life goes on, right? The conflict is over. Things are back to normal. . .or are they?

title: A good idea, but not allied to a strong story.
review:
Out of the films that M. Night Shyamalan has made that I have seen, "The Happening" is definitely the worst.

The dialogue is terrible. The acting is variable. (The worst culprit is sexy Zooey Deschanel, who is wide eyed and, actually, kind of dreadful. Also, no matter how good he has been in other movies, Mark Wahlberg is just not a high school science teacher. Think how good somebody like Tim Robbins or Jeff Goldblum might have been in the same role.) The plot meanders about, going nowhere in particular, and at no particular speed. It is true: "The Happening" is a disappointment. For M. Night Shyamalan the halcyon days of "The Sixth Sense" and "Unbreakable" seem a long, long time ago. (Can I admit at this point that I have liked all of his films, including "Lady In The Water"? Credibility blown, methinks!)

However...

M. Night Shyamalan is still a genius. (Yes he is, and I will get my Brother to fight anybody who disagrees with me.) Even a minor entry in his oeuvre is a little bit special and something to be savoured. There is not a Director today (OK, maybe David Lynch) who can match him for generating a mood of dread, disquiet and other worldliness. There are moments in "The Happening" where you literally hold your breath as you wonder what is going to happen next: The start and end sequences, the final moments of Betty Buckley and John Leguizamo's characters, the conversation with the railway staff, the wind moving through the trees...

"The Happening" has a good central idea and is an unashamed environmentally aware movie, made at a time where every Tom, Dick, Harry and automobile corporation is jumping on the Green bandwagon. It imagines a logical conclusion of the Gaia Hypothesis: If the Earth is a single organism, and is being threatened, what would happen if the Earth tried to defend itself against the aggressor?

It is a good idea, but sadly, "The Happening" has not allied it to a strong story. Such a shame, but M. Night Shyamalan will be back. Do not doubt it. He is a true original and we need more true originals.

title: Quite possibly the worst movie I have ever seen.
review:
First and foremost: This is the first movie I actually walked out of in a long time. After seeing the kids scream profanities at a few hicks in a shack in Pennsylvania and then getting their brains blown out in the most artificial, robotic way possible I instinctually left the theatre. The rest of the day I suffered the indignity of having the sequence of a slow-motion Whalberg running and yelling "Noooooo" burnt into my psyche. One of the worst moments in cinematic history.

The overall message of the movie was actually quite agreeable. Despite the horrific acting and shock effect like death scenes which the movie seemed to be using as a crutch, I ended up rooting for the trees not only because of the mindset of humanity inside and out of the realm of "The Happening" but also because of the lackluster effort that spawned this movie in the first place. Aside from the disastrous acting and dialogue, the directing seemed to be the worst aspect of this film with the emotional scenes coming at the audience like shrapnel, a completely awkward subplot consisting of some sort of dysfunctional relationship between the protagonists, and John Leguizamo fumbling with math riddles as the death potion is coming through a slit in the ceiling of his party's jeep to name a few. Where as Indiana Jones was targeting ten year olds, The Happening seemed to be targeting idiots in general with its asinine like presentation of what was a potentially promising plot. If you want to retain your appetite, I suggest staying as far away from this smelly turn as possible.

review: This movie is soooooo bad that I actually had to stay until the end to see how this horrible piece of crap ended. M. Knight should actually dig into his own pockets and offer me a refund, followed by a personal apology for misleading thousands of moviegoers into seeing this bad film. People please do not be fooled by other " so called reputable critics " such as Ebert. He lost touch with reality years ago and cannot be trusted as a reliable source for reviews any longer. title: It's not what you think- nobody else has said this.
review:
It does not matter what I think of his back catalog. M. Night has done something different in "The Happening", and I believe it should be seen as nobody has seen a Shamylan film before, and certainly not this one.

The trailers for this film made it look very ominous, mysterious, and downright scary. However when watching this film, I'd be surprised if the hairs on your arm stood up even once. There are a handful of tremendously well done scenes, eerily frightening- the construction workers throwing themselves off the building has to be M. Night's best shot in all of his work- however the rest of the film will leave you shaking your head in disbelief.

Why? Because the answer to what exactly is "happening" is presented very early on- in the first half of the movie. It's the plants, emitting a toxin causing humans to commit suicide, exacting their revenge on mankind for their mistreatment at our hands. The rest of the movie follows the main characters as they run through fields and towns, spewing ghastly dialog and witnessing people ending their own lives in disturbing fashions.

So why is the secret given away so quickly? Why the blatantly preachy dialog and ridiculous "save the earth" commentators seen on the televisions? Why isn't it all that frightening or suspenseful? Lets search our options. Did M. Night just flop and make a terrible, un-suspenseful movie with very few frightening sequences? I don't think so. M. Night has proved that he can make a scary movie with plenty of suspense and jump-out-of-your-seat moments. Was the script just awful? Yes and no. With a few exceptions, the script was boring, gave away the secret immediately, and felt way too preachy. So what is the answer? THIS FILM IS A SATIRE. A satire is defined as "the use of irony, sarcasm, ridicule, or the like, in exposing, denouncing, or deriding vice, folly, etc. " The Happening seemed to me to be mocking the modern day hysteria over "global warming" or "climate change", what with the "Go Green" movement hitting the accelerator.

I believe that instead of what appears to be a flop due to ridiculous acting, dialog, and overwhelming preachy-ness, M. Night Shamylan has created a masterful satire, brilliantly mocking modern day paranoia. Will anyone else see it like this, or is this even what Shamylan wanted to create? I don't know. Time will tell.

title: Hindu Philosophy 101
review: I'm not being bias here but I think one has to be raised with an eastern way of thinking or have some knowledge of it in order to appreciate a film like The Happening. For example, I'm a first generation American born Indian and I grew up hearing that we should respect all beings including plants even the microscopic beings we can't see. This means we shouldn't curse, fornicate like cats and dogs, and be violent with each other. Essentially, everything we do and say can affect our environment in either a positive or negative way, depending the way we behave. If you notice the film follows a formula in which the deadly wind follows those who break these rules...that is why if you are in a smaller group the chances of being around someone who is a threat is less. I also heard that Mahatma Gandhi used to tip toe around his house because he knew that with each footstep he was killing dust mites and other microscopic bugs underneath his feet. This may or may not be true but the point is that I can believe it because I was raised with this non-violent approach to life. It's a very Hindu and Buddhist philosophy that is new to people and hence, it is misunderstood. What M. Night is trying to say in his film is simple...respect nature. My mother once pointed out to me that one should be like a tree. At first I didn't understand because my environment (Georgia) didn't allow me to think outside of the box and that kind of talk would get you beat up because people would think you are a pagan or a tree hugging hippie. What my mother was trying to say is that nature deals with anything thrown at it and it never asks for anything in return. It just gives. A tree can go through the harsh winter and come back with leaves during the spring. I liked the film and for a change something we usually ignore day to day is speaking out. See the brilliant irony in it? The plants are fighting back. That's genius. It's not zombies or mutants. It's something we can't touch or run from. The only problem with the film was that I think M. Night should have put a little old Asian man or woman saying things about nature instead of the Caucasian guy eating hot dogs. It would have been more effective and the characters would have at least seen his advice as wise from an eastern point of view instead of cuckoo in the head. It's easier to hear Bruce Lee say something about nature versus any Tom, Dick, or Harry because it is coming from someone's mouth who is raised with that philosophy and it's more acceptable. Even Quentin uses an old Oriental man to say all the wise things in Kill Bill. Using an old and wise Asian man or woman would have reinforced the idea of showing respect to nature and perhaps by the end of the film, people would have began taking better care of the earth. Instead, the movie ends where it begins...with a bunch of clueless people walking around like a bunch of dopes not caring about anyone or anything. Perhaps, M. Night wanted to keep it unresolved...showing us that to err is human.

title: Worst movie ever. PERIOD
review: This movie was possibly the worst movie i have ever seen. Im not a fan of M.K.S, but it was rated R, and i thought id give it a shot.. What a waste of 19 bucks.. title: What happened to M. Night??
review:
He did it with "Lady in the Water". And now he did it with "The Happening". You walk out of the theater saying "what the hell was that?" M. Night has hit his peak and is now on the decline.

And his big twist at the end of "The Happening" could have been seen a mile a way. It was the same old formula that most horror movies use. The threat appears to be gone, but then reappears at the end with a new set of characters. It's been done countless times.

M. Night is known for his clever twist endings. (WARNING - Spoilers for other M. Night's movies) Bruce Willis is really dead in "The Sixth Sense", Sam Jackson's character is Willis' arch rival who created all those disasters in "Unbreakable", "The Village" was set in present day. These were all really well done. But this half ass attempt of a "twist" was a joke. Who knows? Maybe M. Night has just given up and went for the predictable ending.

And what was with the acting? At times, Mark Walberg felt like a dopey cartoon character. I thought I was watching Dirk Diggler. Walberg needs to stick to the tough guy roles, that's his strong suit. Not the dorky high school science teacher. And not to generalize, but mostly everyone else wasn't very convincing in their roles either.

The story had a good premise but could have been executed better. Walberg suspected that the plants and trees were the cause of all the unexplained deaths. So he says "I know, let's go hide in the woods!" Positives, there were some. The scenes where people did themselves in were good for some scares. Also when they came across those guys that hung themselves made me jump a bit. But overall not so good.

For Night's next feature, maybe he should hire a writer and get a competent casting director. Or better yet, he could revise The Twilight Zone or Tales From the Darkside and do half hour episodes on late night TV. I'd watch it.

title: mixed feeling
review:
Having just come from this movie, I cant help but get the feeling that the movie itself was indecisive. It seemed to attempt to combine Shyamalan's trademark suspense with more contemporary, quirky humor, with somewhat disheartening results.

I will say that when the movie creates suspense, it does it with amazing skill. This, however, is also the problem. This is only WHEN it creates suspense, and it rarely does. Less than a third of the movie held the thick atmosphere I came to see. It almost always seemed as though the unsettling atmosphere depicted in the trailers would last for about 5-10 minutes before the pace of the movie was broken by humorous moments.

Humor was quite prevalent through this movie, though half of it seems to be unintentionally delivered through awkwardly worded or poorly delivered lines.

The musical score, though enjoyable, was occasionally over-the-top, and altogether so dramatic that it even became amusing, especially in the beginning. This didn't happen too often, though, so it did not greatly hurt the film

The plot was nicely thought out, with references to real life scientific occurrences, and with the main plot itself actually bearing relation to factual phenomenon.

Make no mistake, this movie was not absolutely terrible, it simply could have been much, much better, especially when faced with what possibilities the plot held. Despite being nicely filmed, the movie does not deliver what was promised, and the combination of genres it seemed to attempt broke the pacing and atmosphere. Overall, these factors were severely detrimental to the overall feel of the movie and made it so that it was impossible to become truly immersed in the world of the movie.

title: Possibly the worst movie ever made
review:
This is, without a doubt, THE worst movie I have ever watched.

And yet, for some reason, it was worth watching because it has established my personal benchmark by which all bad movies I watch will now be judged.

"Well, it was bad ... but not as bad as The Happening!" I would personally encourage everyone to watch this movie and, following that, challenge you to find a worse movie.

I'm betting you won't be able to.

Please, do watch it and see for yourself how bad a movie can possibly get.

title: I'm loosing confidence in M. Night Shyamalan
review: I have to say after having seen the village and Lady in the Water i still had hopes for this movie. Afterall M. Night Shyamalan have made some pretty great movies earlier. This is after my belief the worst one. It seems like M. Night Shyamalan started at the top with the The Sixth Sense which was a great movie and has only being making worse and worser movies since. I still have hopes that it will be better, but one more movie like this, and I will not be watching him any more. I only gave this movie 2 because it's have a rather potential plot. However the filming and actors does not come up to what you should expect from the filmmaker and the casting.

title: So...what was happening?
review:
I went into this movie expecting a little action, suspense, and that weird M. Night Shyamalan twist. Not exactly what I saw. After watching Signs, which I found to be a quirky, fun, alien flick; The Sixth Sense, tragic, but touching; The Village, personally, it didn't interest me; and Lady in the Water, again, no personal interest, I've seen a digressive trend in script writing in the Shyamalan films. Each one becomes more strange and less enjoyable.

First off, in the opening scene the viewer is hit right away with a few disturbing suicides. Granted it does lay the ground for the rest of the movie, but it doesn't allow for any guessing at what's going to happen the rest of the film.

Second is the awful acting from all the characters. Don't get me wrong, I love the actors, but they were forced, painfully, into the script and their characters. Mark Wahlberg's character acted as if the world was coming to an end before he even knew the full extent of what the epidemic was. Not only that, he never got any more frantic or worried as the story developed. Zooey's character looked promising at first, with her nervous attempt to ignore her phone. But she never seems to wise up to the fact that her life is in danger, and life as she knows it now is going to change for the next couple days.

Okay, so the trees are taking their revenge. I can give the producer the benefit of the doubt that this will give the movie a sci-fi feel. Unfortunately too many elements of reality are left out. How come only some people at the site of attack are affected? If it's an airborne toxin, shouldn't everyone be inhaling relatively equal amounts? If the flora is so apt at communicating with one another, why don't they attack the entire globe? Quite frankly, it's never proved any where in the film that it was the trees, and the professor at the end who says that's what caused it comes off looking like a lunatic. Also, the toxin that is supposed to attack people's survival instinct isn't even what's presented in the movie. According to its portrayal, it appears to turn people into suicidal sociopaths

I understand some comments and review that state this was not meant to be a "good movie," and that it was meant to be "B"-rated. But let's face it Mr. Shyamalan has to understand that's not what the majority of his audience is looking for. For those of you who enjoy bizarre, anticlimactic movies that leave you wondering what the point was - this is the film to watch. But for the masses, many of us have learned appreciate what some call the 'unrealistic perfection' Hollywood has labored years to produce. It gives us a chance to escape from our own reality. Not that The Happening had even the slightest tinge of reality in it.

title: No wonder they were committing suicide
review:
Horrible film, but one has to wonder if it horrific for a reason, like a ridiculous commercial designed to implant a stagnant memory of a useless product in the minds of consumers. It has to be admitted that this will be a hard movie to forget, maybe that was the point. Also, did anyone note the number on the front of the school bus near the end of the film? 2010 probably as in the year 2010. Maybe Shyamalan the soothsayer is giving a heads-up to the keen observer. Watch it again and see what goodies you troll-up, then again, maybe Shyamalan is losing it.

title: What is actually happening???
