title: Loved the idea!
review: Absolutely loved the idea of the film. The general plot was amazing and the story would have made such a good horror/mystery film if it was done properly. Unfortunately it wasn't. It felt like a few horror scenes linked together loosely with a storyline that didn't have much substance. Some bad and wholly unnecessary CGI. If this were M. Night Shyamalans first film then it would have been a great start. I think he said it best in an interview after "Signs" when he said something along the lines of, music is a fill in for a bad/empty script. Way too much music. BUT, the horror scenes were very good, some great creepy scenes and as i said i loved the idea of it all. overall one of the better horror movies of this year.

title: Never go by the ratings. I found it interesting !
review:
I had some time before watching this movie so checked out some reviews. All of them were pointing me not to watch. I consider Shyamalan as one of the gifted and talented director so I watched the movie anyways and I was not a bit disappointed, at least if I go by the reviews. One must be able to appreciate the hard work put in by Shyamalan. Its a original story, made nicely enough to capture your attention throughout the film. New York city is suddenly attacked by some mysterious agents which drives people to commit suicides and this is spreading. The people are clueless. There is chaos. Elliot and friends try to get out of the city into a safer place but it doesn't always happen the way you want it to be. Elliot has to save his love and his friend's daughter out of this and then begins an adventure.

Its been Shyamalan's trademark that in his movies the characters are always above the story and same happened in Happening. Mark, I thought, was perfect for the job. The others were not much attractive but one must not miss that since Mark is the main protagonist and the movie completely revolves around him. Mark was excellent. With the occasional comedy and romance thrusted in, the movie was worth the time. The plot is good enough to hold you back and spasmodic thrills bring chills. I consider this another excellent piece from Shyamalan although it will be always below Sixth Sense or Unbreakable but I admit I have enjoyed every movie of him. It deserves a better review and rating than this. Take my word, never go by the rating and you will find it good enough.

review:

title: Best Shyamalan's movie since Unbreakable. Totally underrated.
review:
This film is Shyamalan's rebirth for me as film creator. I'm big fan of his movies, and tried not to see the decline of his recent works - 6th Sense and Unbreakable was masterpieces, Signs and The Village - had great ideas and suspense but was just good overall, while Lady in the Water had great atmosphere but lacked something. And then - The Happening...

I was watching this - after I already knew 5,4 rating - and honestly was expecting a disaster. But... this movie hold me in the edge of chair from the beginning till the end, and I just was wondering - "hey, when this 'collapse' will start? Which moment will be error or false?" And then - while the final scene in Philadelphia, I said to my friend - "body, - if this movie ends here - it's nearly perfect..." And it was... I can't understand reaction of people.

Bad acting? No, Wahlberg was great, and support - too. Directing? and script? If you prefer CGI of Emmerich's movies, or actions of Bay - hm... maybe it's not yours, but otherwise - just watch it, and try not to digress, not listen to other "laughing from the beginning to the end" - and you will be paid in full.

Vow. Best Night's film since Unbreakable.

title: See it for Yourself, Bring Your Brain.
review:
After reading all the negative critiques about this movie I almost didn't see it. I am so glad I did. I think people were let down by the fact that this movie was not a "surprise" kinda movie, like sixth sense or signs. This was a thinking persons movie. I can only assume the people who "didn't get it" are either stupid or didn't follow along close enough. I think this movie is saying what needs to be said, in movie form, not in a documentary by Michael Moore (whom I love).

Its all about.. Take care of the planet or it will start to protect itself.

Watch it and see for yourself! I gave it a 7 out of 10.

title: The Happening (look past the media)
review: Despite all the bad media surrounding this film I still went to see it. And I was pleased with what I saw. In previous work M. Night Shyamalan shows that he is a writer/producer/director like none other. He doesn't worry about how glamorous the film is. Instead he paints the picture as if you were there. His use of mainly one camera in all his movies make you feel like you are witnessing the events. For movies now-a-days we want the special effects and the gorgeous style of shooting along with a happy ending. M. Night Shymalan changes this. As I stated above his style is different. But in his previous writing he doesn't give us the happy ending we crave. (I will not say how The Happening ends) And the lack of closure in his previous work make the viewer think. The viewer can't just walk out of the theater and discard the story just witnessed. Instead they think about the film and forever remember the story. Overall I think you should look past the media and listen to how you feel. Don't be afraid of the unknown.

title: Crosses the line between entertainment and preaching.
review:
Mr. Shyamalan has crossed the line between entertaining the audience and preaching a green message. The movie holds almost no value as an entertainment. At most it is a Manifesto for being green. We have heard stories that the success of his other films had "gone to his head". Someone should have been able to intervene and the tell the director that the writer needs help. I was a loss as to why I should care about the Science teacher or the kid or even Zooey Deschanel's character, eveb with her incredible blue eyes. The movie should have been on SCI-FI with less budget and less hype.

In short miss this film and hope for better work in the future. Maybe studios should only give Mr. Shyamalan one job. He seems to do pretty well as a director. This movie is just wrong on so many levels that if there was an honest voice of decent some in the creative process then things might have come out differently. As it is being the king isn't so good for movie making.

title: First the 'Strangers' and then this....
review:
There are only two reasons I am giving this four stars: 1.) I got into the movie free with a pass 2.) I saw the 'Strangers' the week before

M. Night makes me think of a young director who is trying very hard to be a modern day Spielberg by covering a multitude of paranormal ideas. He seems to have the vision and imagination, but lacks the patience in terms of executing his original thoughts. I found a similar link in this movie to the Village: he gives us the twist way too early, making the last forty minutes or so a long, drawn-out conclusion. Had he the patience to wait the appropriate length of time to 'reveal' the twist, these movies might have had a stronger impact. The acting is not very good at all and the attempts at witty dialogue sound too much like a 'Scooby-Doo' cartoon. I honestly couldn't find one good moment of acting or dialogue that didn't feel like a cartoon. People are panicked by the wave of death, yet they really aren't. The Army guy who shows up is plain stupid and suggests an underlying belief by Night that everyone in the Army is ignorant. M. Night then throws out the 'if we were more nice to plants, this wouldn't have happened' politics, revealing his 'greener' side and appeasing Hollywood hippies and producers alike. Very sad. I love apocalypse movies, but this one certainly isn't one by my standards. Literally twenty four hours after the start of bad juju, love prevails and saves the day, ending the catastrophe. But wait, not so fast....it's happening again all over...no shock there. I would have rather seen the trees and plants come to life and kill everyone than have them run away from the wind. I suppose for my apocalypse flavor, I'll have to hold on tight for the film version of Stephen King's 'Cell' and hope that Eli Roth can deliver something more shocking, better acted and overall more disturbing than 'The Happening'.

title: Incredibly worthless
review:
Please, If you value your eyes, do NOT see this movie. You will undoubtedly try to claw them out at one point or another, either when faced with the pathetic excuse for a storyline or when witnessing some of the worst acting EVER. Seriously, It seems to me that director told his cast to do the worst they could.

SPOILER: The Happening is about plants releasing neuro-toxins in the air causing people to kill themselves, in order to stop pollution. More likely, the plants actually made THIS MOVIE as it almost had the same effect on me.

DON'T WATCH.

title: Not as bad as people say
review:
Alright, first off, I'm going to go ahead and possibly mark myself as insane and say: I liked this movie. Now, before you dismiss me completely and say I have no sense of movies or characters or what truly defines what should be considered a good movie (or that I will just automatically like anything by M. Night), let me explain.

No, it wasn't terribly scary. No, it wasn't the most easily interpreted movie in the world. No, not everything was laid out nice and neat and perfectly placed. No, it wasn't like so many horror/thriller movies out there that take part in gore-fests and naked screaming girls who are so ridiculously unbelievable that you want to throw popcorn at them.

But then, isn't that a good thing?

Everyone is constantly complaining about a lack of originality in Hollywood's latest plethora of movies, and then when one finally rolls around we write it off as 'stupid'.

Well, I don't think it was stupid. Not at all. It was a classic M. Night movie.

It was more about what 'you' brought to the movie than what he told you straight up. It's all in your head, and that can make a really good movie. I don't think that the actors were poorly cast or 'uninspired' (a word I've heard all too frequently when someone describes this movie). They played the parts as the parts were meant to be played.

Like real people.

They walked around, talked with friends, worried about things without necessarily saying they were worried and showed concern without necessarily voicing said concerns. They reacted in different ways-- which people do-- to an insane and scary situation.

People died in this movie. Everywhere, people died. They killed themselves. Because they couldn't help it. And so what if the cause was plants? It's just as believable-- and much more original-- as if it were the government or some germ warfare. And in the end, it wasn't about the fact that people were killing themselves or that plants were retaliating against mankind's treacherous actions against nature. It was about love. When you boil it all down, it was about love. And maybe the reason so many people don't like this movie is because they either don't understand it, were disappointed it wasn't part of the aforementioned gore-fest, or can't see the importance of reading the signs. Maybe the problem is no one wants to 'think' when they're watching a movie. No one wants to 'interpret' or walk away and mull it over in their minds. But if you don't do that, you lose something.

If you don't like kind of artsy, love-will-conquer-all, have-to-think-about-it movies, you probably won't like this one. But don't worry: there are plenty of people out there who agree with you.

title: It is not that bad! it is not bad at all!
review: I don't know what is the cause of all the negative critique. The movie is good, and if you don't like it then it is because you expected it to be something else I you expect to see something twisty like "the sixth sense" or some other M. Night Shyamalan films, then you will probably not like it. I can easily compare it to "children of men", or even "cloverfield" (not the camera angle or the action of course) where there is a story that you won't fully understand because the director doesn't want you to and it is not the focus of the movie, but rather the focus is on a small group of people who are experiencing certain events and you get to see how they react to them. It is a good film. Not M. Night Shyamalan's best, but definitely not the worst movie ever made like it said by some people!

review:

review: I am always angry at myself after watching such a stupid movie... My mistake :(

title: A nostalgic pleasure
review: I remember how fond I was of this one when I first saw it at the cinema and for purely nostalgic and personal reasons it deserves an extra star! It focuses on married couple Elliot and Alma (Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel) and father and daughter Julian and Jess (John Leguizamo and Ashlyn Sanchez) evacuating away from a rapidly spreading plague in which the afflicted are forced to commit suicide. Watching it again years later, it has lost its edge that I remember so well; but there are elements in it that I think still make it worth watching. The premise itself is quite a good one and I think explored pretty well with a very jarring opening sequence and the symptoms of the infected repeating themselves and walking backwards is still quite chilling. It is relentlessly violent at times and I admire that about it; it takes its subject and goes full throttle with it. James Newton Howard produces another memorable and spooky soundtrack; I haven't heard another one quite like it and the main theme has stuck with me all these years! On another watch, I realised just how great Zooey Deschanel is in it; I think it's her best performance and that's saying a lot considering she's good in anything she's in! John Leguizamo's delivery of the line 'Don't take my daughters hand unless you mean it.' still gives me shivers and perfectly encapsulates the desperation and intense mentality everyone would have during an epidemic like this. If you're expecting a good twist or big reveal at the end you'll be sorely disappointed but I think the randomness and mystery of it all is what M Night was going for; personally I didn't mind it but I understand how it may frustrate some viewers. Despite its flaws, it's a pleasure of mine due to the aspects I've mentioned and there are a couple moments of awkwardly delivered dialogue that are hilarious

title: Don't walk away from this one, RUN!
review:
This is easily a top 10 contender for worst movie of the millennium, and probably still will be once the year 3000 hits.

Seriously, do not waste your time on this one. Even if you find a DVD copy at a garage sale for .50 cents, it's not worth it. Your time would be better spent watching paint dry or directing traffic into an empty shopping center.

In conclusion: Avoid at all costs, and if someone you call a friend suggests this movie, consider throwing them through a window.

title: Bad acting and dumb
review: The only thing I can add to what others before me have said is that is that it seems like the actors must have been paid half their rate and therefore did half the acting they were supposed to. Yes, Mark Wahlberg included.

title: Terrible
review: Terrible. Although the idea has interest the story is basic and the performances are horrible and worthy of a SyFi movie despite the good actors that participate. The characters either express themselves as dumb or goofy in a comedy film. Despite being an apocalyptic film, sometimes it touches comedy in the most inappropriate situations, which is not enough to understand if it was intentional or simply incompetence and loss of notion of those involved in the film.

title: What. The hell. Happened?
review: 100%, this was written by aliens trying to impersonate human behavior after only studying them for about a month. That would not only explain the wildly odd dialogue and cadence, but why a movie called "The Happening" has so little, ya know, happening in it.

title: Proof that Shyamalan can do whatever the heck he wants and still make money out of it.
review:
First it was spirits. Then superheroes. Then aliens. Then came a village and a lady in the water. And now, in 2008 at least, the man himself, M. Night killed a ton of people with plants. PLANTS.

I usually start films with a certain expectation and end them with exactly that. I knew that The Happening would be bad, but not like this. The plot itself is dumb enough, but then you got poorly-thought-out death scenes, characters too easy to forget about, and let's not forget the scene in where Oscar nominee Mark Wahlberg starts talking to a (fake) plant.

And yet- i actually enjoyed for how horrible it was. That's what Shyamalan fims do to you- they disgust, yet satisfy you, making for an experience like no other. Thank you, Manoj, for making such a horrendous piece of garbage.

title: Something is clearly happening in this "movie", but the word "happening" is uttered more often than something actually happening.
review: "The Happening" (2008), who green lit this?! This "movie" is supposed to be a thriller film, right? Well, the "thrilling" part is what I'm questioning, it somehow got turned into a lackluster comedy! This "film" is yet another one of the top 10 worst movies I have ever seen. Dull cliched story, horrible acting, cheap special effects, boring sets/locations, and a generic predictable soundtrack to attempt to try and tie this diarrhea stain together. Usually, screenplays written by M. Night Shyamalan suck, and this is no exception. "The Happening" is, by far, his worst screenplay and "movie" he has ever made! But, the premise is actually sort of creative. A virus that infects people and causes them to commit suicide, that really sounds like a tension-filled idea! That was what intrigued me to watch this "film" in the first place. When I saw it, talk about a massive disappointment! But, saying that is an understatement. This is one of the most poorly executed movies that I have ever seen! Their basically running from the wind. Whee! The acting doesn't help matters either. That being said, most of the actors and actresses are great actors in other movies and shows. However, I think that the film makers forgot to tell them that before they went to act in this "movie". Probably the absolute worst performance in this "film", which surprised me, is from Mark Wahlberg. Now, outside of "The Happening", Mark Wahlberg is a great actor! But in this "film", what happened? The worst actress in this "movie" is Zooey Deschanel. Her line delivery is nothing short of a joke. Also, her neutral expression looks like a deer in a headlight face. Or, she just pooped her pants and she's trying to hide it. The rest of the actors and actresses suck too in this "movie". Being a movie made in 2008, you'd expect all the special effects to be great, right? Most of them are fine, but a lot of them are obviously CGI. Whenever M. Night Shyamalan produces a movie, he usually tries to maintain a PG-13 rating. However, at the last second, the other film makers convinced him to make it R-rated. Therefore, a lot of the shots with blood were digitally added. Granted, that can work if it looked realistic. But, in this "film", you can obviously tell it was animated and added in at the last second. The sets/locations are boring and accentuate the dull cliched plot of this "story". Finally, the soundtrack is generic and cliched. Honestly, I cannot remember a single note from this "film" score. For a soundtrack to work, it has to be good and memorable. This one is bad, and not memorable! "The Happening" had a fairly decent concept behind it, but once again, poor execution ruined it's chance to shine. There is nothing positive I can salvage from this waste of film making. I'm giving this "film" 0 out of 5 stars on my scale. If I could rate it 0 stars I would, but 1 is as low as I can go. Ignore the 1 star rating, my true rating is 0 stars. "The Happening" is a waste of cinema, and is not worth watching. Be warned, if you do watch it, make sure you don't have any dangerous objects nearby and that you're on the first floor. This "movie" may cause suicide! M. Night Shyamalan, I have to ask: what in the world were you thinking?!

title: What? No!
review:
... As stated by Mark Wahlberg in the 'The Happening'. This absolutely phenomenal and in depth dialogue really describes this film perfectly. It is obvious Wahlberg was breaking the fourth wall at this particular moment while referring to the film.

In all honesty though, i can and will never understand how this film is directed by the same director as the masterpiece 'The Sixth Sense'. M. Night Shyamalan isn't know for his consistency, but the difference in quality between these two films is just enormous. There is probably not a single other director out there that has a greater gap in the quality of two of his films. There is just no explanation how Shyamalan turns from The Sixth Sense to this bunch of nonsense. With the knowledge that Shyamalan is in fact actually capable of producing something amazing, the fact that this film is such utter trash really supports the suggestion that this was done on purpose.

Now for the substantial part... The Happening is horribly acted, lazily and poorly written & terribly framed and photographed. Now, Mark Wahlberg is an actor that in the past has proven himself to be an adequate factor in most of his films ( See his performances in either Boogie Nights or The Departed ), so his absolutely atrocious performance in this film is for the most part also thanks to Shyamalan, who also wrote the screenplay. Shyamalan's screenplay is full of illogicalities and unintentionally funny moments. There are so many scenes in The Happening where something bad happens, and never do any of the character seem to react to it. They just stand there, not moving, like a bunch of 'uninvolved observers!' as Zooey Deschanel states. This is a recurring theme throughout the film. There is for example a scene in which some people hear a gunshot from behind a hill, and they do absolutely nothing. They do not run away or run towards it. They just do nothing except stare in front of themselves. There is also a scene where two characters are blown away by shotguns from inside a house on a porch, after which two other characters sit in front of said porch for another two minutes while the shotgun guys are still in there. Wahlberg also talks to a tree, which is saying enough. There is also a lot of irrelevant newspaper exposition, which is ofcourse one of the most annoying forms of exposition because it involves characters nobody knows who talk about circumstantial things which do not tell the audience anything we did not already know. But hey, Shyamalan thinks his viewers are idiots, so why not? In short, all of these nonsensical character moments make this one of the worst screenplays ever made.

As for the acting, everyone is complete garbage. Mark Wahlberg, who as stated before is definitely not a bad actor, obviously doesn't look like he wants to be in this film, perhaps due to some feeling of shame as he must have already felt how terrible this was going to be. Unfortunately for him, this performance does really make him seem like a bad joke, although Shyamalan's dialogue doesn't help either. His immortal sarcastic utterly unconvincing line delivery of 'What? No!' really emphasizes his will of being in this film. Although once again there is a lot of dialogue that no actor could have pulled off convincingly. Zooey Deschanel is nearly as bad as Wahlberg, but i think if the screentime of both characters were reversed that these roles would also be reversed, since she is too absolutely terrible. 'Just when you thought there couldn't be any more evil that can be invented' is ofcourse a terrible line of dialogue by Shyamalan, but Deschanel's delivery is something else entirely.

The cinematography is plain bloated and ugly, with absolutely terrible framing. There are many weird choices of close ups instead of widescreen ( Especially in a sequence that is supposed to be intense when another group is being executed behind a near hill ) which really create an awkward and unintentionally hilarious situation. This is not like a Leone film where the close ups are so immersive and involving due to it being an emotional and visual responder to when something is going to happen, but just an awkward piece of framing that becomes an unintentional hilarity. These are dumb characters with dumb dialogue standing still like a bunch of idiots while people are getting slaughtered. Close ups here do not emphasize the intensity, but only emphasize the ridiculousness of the situation. Not to mention there are many shots where certain people are simply not in frame. The rule of thirds is almost never used and it results in many unremarkable and ugly shots.

The only positive about 'The Happening' is James Newton Howard's score, which was a superb emotional piece. Too bad for him it is wasted on such a terrible and forgettable film, although the unintentional hilariousness of it will still linger in a lot of minds.

The Happening is a terrible film. Yet it is still a very likeable terrible film, because of its laughably unconvincing line deliveries and horrendous dialogue. Unfortunately Shyamalan was really going for the psychological terror approach here in the context of Hitchcock's The Birds and thus this does not really work out since the framing and the deliveries of these horrendous line make this more like a comedy than something that is supposed to be disturbing or scary, because both are nonexistent in this film.

title: A New Movie From Shyamalan, And We'll Never Fully Understand It
review:
That is the explanation for this movie to exist. It's one of Shyamalan strangest movies, and that's not exactly a very good thing.

A mysterious chemical virus or something like that makes the people that is affected to commit suicide. Here are involved a science teacher, Elliot (Mark Wahlberg), his wife Alma (Zoey Deschannel) and a friend of them (John Leguizamo). The story started pretty well and for the first 40 minutes or so it was interesting and despite some very stupid things of the script and some average acting it was good. But then they start trying to run away from the wind and the movie started to fall down and the last ten minutes were just awful (sad ending but no, it's a happy ending, no, wait, it's a bad ending. What's that?) The logic for explaining the virus that is a mystery of the nature and we'll never understand it and that's it. Probably Shyamalan didn't knew how to end the story and how to give it a reasonable explanation and came up with this.

The actors were at parts good, specially the main three, but at other parts were bad acting. (Mark Wahlberg talking to a plastic plant like it was going to answer him...) Zooey Deschannel has some good moments and she is beautiful, but a pretty face don'd make an actuation good. And well, all the extras were just useless. Also, was it necessary to add all the disturbing and graphic deaths? Some of you may like it but I found it at parts funny and at parts disgusting, but no serious.

On the good side I have to say that Shyamalan is still able to create tension and give the movie the feeling it needs by the camera work he is used to (despite here being less noticeable). And also the score by James Newton Howard, not as good as in other Shyamalan moments but still provides some very good moments.

In general this is a very entertaining and interesting movie until it reaches the hour of duration or so, where it falls down a lot, but I'm pretty sure that if you're a Shyamalan fan you will enjoy it at most of it.

title: Embarrassing
review:
The career of director/writer/producer Shyamalan is something of a mystery. Neither Signs or The Sixth Sense are bad movies - at least not in a way that makes you regret that you've spent the time watching them. But then there are those of his films that make you feel exactly like that, and it makes me wonder why this guy still gets to make movies. After Earth. The Visit. The Happening. How can someone go from good to incomprehensibly bad and still have the continued support from the industry? I guess his name for some reason still makes money.

The Happening is a B-movie, or at least it feels like it. The characters are incoherent and act and talk like they're in an exploitation movie from the seventies, and it's not done on purpose - like Machete-on purpose. Most of what comes out of Mark Wahlberg's mouth sounds weird, and his reactions are constantly disproportionate to the situation. He's not a favorite actor of mine but I have never experienced his acting this disjointed before so I'm guessing it's a directorial issue. Zooey Deschanel's performance doesn't sit right either, and the fact that the two characters are supposed to be married is simply laughable. There is no chemistry between them whatsoever.

If the acting and characterization is flawed, what about the story? Well, I do find the premise of the film somewhat intriguing. Unfortunately, it's presented in such a way that it comes off as highly improbable - almost as a joke. The awkwardness of any dialogue concerning the underlying cause of "the event" doesn't make things better. Because of the bad writing the attempts to scientifically explain the infection falls completely flat.

Thinking about watching The Happening? Don't. Watch the 1978 Invasion of the Body Snatchers instead. Similar idea - much better movie. Heck, even the remake from 2007 will do.

title: Another failed half-baked steaming pile of..
review: Another failed half-baked steaming pile of ...By M.Knight Shallistopmakingmovies. God is this really the guy that made sixth sense?The way he structures his films keeps you watching until the end because you know the potential the guy has,that and you're simply too far into the movie to stop watching once it starts to get really bad.Between this,the village and The last air-bender I would say that he is by far one of the worst big-name directors to date.When watching his comedy,I mean "horror" movies you are guaranteed at least two things:Utter disappointment and a plot twist.Unfortunately for this movie,he excludes the latter.

title: laughable but with a surprising ending
review:
Now this movie didn't do much in the way of horror, in fact all of the scary parts in the movie were down right laughable. It was honestly one of the funniest movies I've seen in the horror genre, even though it was an unintentional comedy.

I saw this movie through a friend so I missed the twist ending in the theater showing. It was a particularly horrifying twist, which was at the end of the 90 minute long disaster when you realized that M Night had your $20 the whole time.

I rate the movie as high as a 3 because I have never laughed so hard at a plastic tree or wind in a field in my life.

title: An unintentional comedy
review:
Normally, I would never recommend a Shyamalan film... but my god, The Happening is special. Genuinely special. Indescribably bad, yet so damned funny, there are very few films I can honestly point to and say you should definitely see, because you will never see anything like it.

It's bad. It's absolutely, explosively bad, And you should watch every glorious moment of it.

The plot is insane, and never fully explained or justified. The acting? Tommy Wiseau would tell them off for it. People rib Mark Wahlberg for his performance, but at least he's fun. Zoey Deschanel on the other hand, acts like she's either on a powerful drug or a drama student hired out of college who would work for a corn dog. The dialogue is magnificent, like whomever wrote it was an alien who had only ever read theory on how human couples interact. The chemistry and characters? It wasn't until the end of the movie that I realised the two leads, Wahlberg and Deschanel, were playing a MARRIED COUPLE, and when I found out I had to look it up to see if it was true.

And don't even get me started on the guy who likes hot dogs...

I can't rate it higher then a 2, because a movie that tries to be so serious yet fails on every level, can hardly be called a good film because it makes you laugh. But I can't punish it too badly, because I enjoyed every stinking moment of this train-wreck. Give it a try if you're a fan of films lie The Room, Showgirls, Troll 2, bad films in general, because The Happening is a distinguished member of the "So Bad It's Good" club, in my eyes.

title: I went in expecting a movie like the triffids, I came out and something 'happened to me'
review:
I've finally started to do movie reviews, which I've wanted to do for quite some time. I decided to start off with in my opinion one of the worst but at the same time one of the best movies I've ever sat through, The Happening.

I only need to say the name of one man and you know how bad/good this movie is "M. Night Shyamalan." Anyone who's ever sat through at least one of this director's films know that he is famous for making good actors turn in horrible performances and it carries on over with the happening as none of the actors seem to be acting normal at all but easily the most entertaining is our main star, Mark Wahlberg. Like Shyamolon, if anyone has seen any movies with Wahlberg in it know how good he is as Wahlberg always seems to turn in brilliant performances, but the Happening is his exception. He seems to deliver his lines in this weird over emphasised tone. Now at first I didn't really think much of it in the first few scenes he was in as I saw he was playing a teacher so I was thinking teachers usually need to speak like this when they address their pupils but as I saw the movie go on, I realise that this is his whole performance. Zooey Deschannel is probably worse than Wahlberg's. Her delivery is about as equally bad but the thing that seems to put her that extra step in front of Wahlberg on the bad acting scale is her facial expressions. She seems to widen her eyes in a lot of the shots, some of them when it's even unnecessary to do it. Everyone else basically delivers the same sort of acting you would expect in a Shyamolon movie.

It's also really lazily written, particularly the script. It's hard to describe how lazily written the script is so what I'm going to do instead is quote a few of the lines from the movie.

"You like hot dogs right?" "Cheese and crackers!" Keep in mind that this is a sort of post-apocalyptic movie and there are just some random lines that are put in this movie about food for some reason.

"All we have left is cough syrup" "Look I don't know if you guys have read an article in the New York Times about honey bees vanishing." I think that should be enough to tell you that the happening is a really bad movie. When I was going into this movie, I was expecting some sort of "the triffids" esque movie, but I just got a poorly directed, badly written, horribly acted post-apocalyptic drama. Avoid this.

wow this film is just... bad and it has become a cult film, i can see why but man is it bad to watch on your own. before i get into the review this film is best enjoyed watching with friends and drinks. The original concept of this film is fine it could work it could be better as well. Mark Wahlberg's performance is weird its like that what he says comes across sarcastically. Zoey Deschanel just screams god knows what half the time and just sits there with her anime of eyes. She's absolutely gorgeous but i hated her in this film. the things that the characters do is so questionable. filled with interesting and a few quirky characters and some parts are good. but like i said enjoyable with a few friends and drinks. 4/10

title: Nothing Happens.
review: The Happening (2008): Dir: M. Night Shyamalan / Cast: Mark Wahlberg, Zooey Deschanel, John Leguizamo, Ashlyn Sanchez, Betty Buckley: Just when you thought M. Night Shyamalan couldn't get any worse than Lady in the Water, he manages to manufacture this happening piece of sh*t. What happened to the director who made The Sixth Sense and Signs? Was he abducted by one of his own space beings? This is a lame ass thriller about unexplained events. Starts out promising as people begin to commit suicide due to what's believed to be a controlling toxic substance. Mark Wahlberg plays a science teacher who tries to figure it all out but spends most of the film running from place to place with his wife while gruesome acts occur randomly. Zooey Deschanel plays his wife who is unexplainably clueless. John Leguizamo is featured as another teacher, as well as Ashlyn Sanchez as his speechless daughter. One must be speechless when you audition for a film and get thrust into this crap. One could say that this contrived idiotic farce is a reference to the rapture but for all the laughs being played out through suicide, it leaves the impression that no one was on the ball when this hit pre-production. title: Good Concept, bad result
review: This movie had a lot of potential. I know that people think the idea of trees causing people to kill themselves is crazy, but it's actually a good idea. Why do I think this? Well most trees are connected via roots. Now lets say that a tree connected to other trees is infected with the biological chemical that caused people to kill themselves. Because the trees are connected, the chemical could spread to other trees and release the chemical everywhere like in "The Happening". Even though the concept is good, the film is still bad because of it's horrible acting and screen writing. The acting is unbelievable and silly while a lot of dialogue has nothing to do with the movie. The worst of it being about the hot dogs. What was Shyamalan thinking when he added the scene about hot dogs? What does that have to do with the trees and events happening? In conclusion, if it wasn't for the screen writing and acting, this might have been a pretty good movie, but instead contributed to Shyamalan's continuing downfall.

Went into this film not really knowing what to expect, I remember there been a bit of hype for this film when it first came out however I do not understand how.

After about 10 minutes I could tell this film wasn't going to be great, the whole thing seemed slightly off from the start. The camera work seemed very poor with multiple close ups of everyones faces every 2 minutes, the acting wasn't great especially from Zooey Deschanel who had a blank face for the entire film, there was no substance to any of the characters and there were multiple moments in the film where it just felt awkward.

The film was almost like a comedy in places where I did actually laugh, the way in which the two boys were killed was just ridiculous and Mrs Jones' house was another weird inclusion to the film with a deranged old woman who was supposed to be creepy but instead found myself laughing at whatever she said.

The ending was stupid as was the whole plot to the film, I recommend not watching this film and it is by far the worst film I have seen Mark Wahlberg in.

title: There's a good film in there somewhere (I think)
review:
Okay, most of us film fans will say that we loved M. Night Shymalan's 'The Sixth Sense' and 'Unbreakable.' And 'The Village' and even 'Signs' were more hit than miss. However, when it came to 'The Happening,' something... happened.

Whereas his other films were all logical (or at least logic in a supernatural setting), had a good story, acting and pacing, The Happening didn't seem to have any of them. What it did have (and its main high-point in my opinion) was a very creepy premise. One day - for no reason at all - people start to commit suicide, en masse. Why? We don't know. They just do.

Therefore, Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel must do their best to unravel the mystery while at the same time trying not to succumb to the urge to kill themselves. And it doesn't really work. For those few people who try to praise this movie, they say that its high-point is that it is a MYSTERY and therefore not meant to be solves. Others just get frustrated by the little information we - the audience - are given concerning what's actually happening.

Oh, and that's another thing, people keep using the word 'happening' at least once in every conversation - presumably in case you've forgotten what film you're watching. And it gets annoying after a while.

Another low point is Zooey Deschanel. Don't get me wrong... I like her as an actress and she's been good in other projects. However, here, she delivers her lines with about as much passion as a tree blowing in the wind. There's an absolute lack of chemistry between her and Wahlberg, who, by his own admission, only took the part so he could play a teacher (as opposed to his usual roles as criminals or tough guys).

I've watched The Happening twice now. It's not anywhere as good as Shymalan's previous work, but - somehow - it retains enough weird and dark charm to warrant a second viewing for me. Don't expect every question to be answered and, if you can live with the frustration after ninety minutes then you may hate it a little less than most (a bit like me).

title: The Happening is an unfortunate mix of an undeveloped script with good potential and a haphazardly approached vehicle for an environmental message.
review:
Created in 2008, The Happening follows the adventures of Elliot Moore (played by Mark Wahlberg), his wife Alma (played by Zooey Deschanel), and for a great portion of the film, their more-or-less adopted daughter, Jess (Ashlyn Sanchez). Other characters make appearances, such as Jess's actual father (Julian, played by John Leguizamo), but none of them tend to stick around for very long. In fact, most of them feel forced, as if they were inserted into the film artificially in order to create more emotional content for the main characters and their situation, but this usually falls short. The main message of the film, that we are destroying the planet and it will eventually seek revenge, is told by way of a "natural disaster". As we eventually learn, the plants are upset at us for what we have done to the planet and are releasing toxins which coerce us into taking our own lives. This prompts cities on the East Coast (which is the main area of "attack") to semi-calmly evacuate and through this we follow our main characters on their quest for safety and a deeper understanding of the events happening to them.

In general, the impending sense of dread in this film is at odds with the rushed feeling of the work as a whole. We are given the sense that in this world the exact nature of the threat is not quite known, and as Elliot tries to determine this (through his scientific methods) the constant lingering chase of death creates a dramatic tension. There is good use of slow cuts and close-up camera angles to enhance the impending sense of doom, but at times the plot gets in its own way. Characters are haphazardly introduced sometimes seemingly for the sole purpose of having them taken away dramatically. For instance, we are heavy-handedly endeared to the two children who accompany Elliot, Alma and Jess for a short while only to have them graphically and violently taken away minutes later seemingly for the sole purpose of keeping the sense of dread heavy and palpable. Their introduction and subsequent deaths are nothing more than contrived mechanisms to enhance tension. We are led to believe that people are being broken down by the terror all around them (even though it is mostly unseen) and reverting back to baser, more violent instincts to protect solely themselves and their property. I suppose this speaks to the moral at the core of the film and to the opinion of the writer, which seems to be that for a majority of the population (the unenlightened perhaps?) when the dark times come, we are all just beasts inside. I feel, however, that with a bit more time and effort, these characters could have either been given more seamlessly integrated roles, or could have been removed completely and the plot reworked to express their ideas more coherently through further development of the main leads.

Still, there are redeeming qualities from a cinematic standpoint that keep this film above water. An emphasis on sound is used to good effect – as we learn more about the threat the plants pose, we are increasingly aware of the wind in each scene. As the intensity ramps up, so does the blustering threat of death, to the point that seeing the trees begin to waver in the background makes everyone, including the viewer, quite nervous. I would like to say that this film at the end of its journey completes its quest to make the viewer more aware of environmental issues we face, but unfortunately I feel that most viewers would leave the film instead wondering more about the other threads of story seemingly jammed into place. Other films centered around this theme, such as the 2007 film I Am Legend more elegantly expose the main issue of man's inability to survive in concert with nature (though this time by means of a virus), but the message remains clear: if we do not correct our divergence from nature we are doomed to be overtaken by it. The Happening just happens to stumble on its way to deliver this message.

review:
Well, in the words in another movie "we are"...

I watched this movie, just after watching "Lady in the Water" and "Hara- Kiri: Death of a Samurai" and "Pacific Rim" all in one day.

I came here on IMDb to rate all those movies and I was completely stunt. What's with these ratings people? Are we watching movies now only because of some bimbo like looking actress, crazy 3D special effects and 7.1 Dolby surround sound?

Here you have a movie with a nice story and a great message with a rating of 5?! while a stupid worthless story with no script like Pacific Rim gets more than a 7?!

Yeah, plants do have all the right to be aggrieved by us! That's all I have to say...

title: An amazing film
review:
Is it a scary movie? I don't know. I don't care. I wasn't scared at all watching this film, I was intrigued. I found the whole film fascinating for a variety of reasons. It was in a sense a parody of itself and yet not. Perhaps it is a good parody of a bad 70's b-movie. Something about this movie is lovely to me, maybe it's the luscious camera work, or the easy pacing, I don't know. It has space, it relishes in itself and its absurdity, and yet, it believes every word of what its saying, or does it?

There are few movies that can span the chasm between belief and disbelief whether by accident or intent, this one does so quite seamlessly.

title: Confused
review:
Yes like the title says... confused the whole movie is just confused. So there is an event it is weird strange things are happening and who is trying to prevent this? Well no one. I am going to keep this without spoiling ant thing at all but the manner in which many of the people die is totally preventable yet no attempt is made prevent any of them just film them and post them to news sites or youtube.

This the occurrence would be inductive more of a protest but no it is just, well no one makes an attempt to guess they all just kind of stare in confusion, not even fear just confusion. Speaking of confused M. Night Shyamalan must have shouted to Mark Wahlberg "you do not look confused enough!" every second of filming as that is literally the only thing close to emotion he ever shows and we know from an interview with Shyamalan Mark was told to not go to his default charter at all and to totally stray from it. Okay then why cast him? So the plot goes on and many figure out the "antagonist" very quickly as it is hinted out with no concern for restraint. It is a good antagonist? Well it was in quotes so no, in fact the antagonist is hardly even an antagonist. This paired with the constant confusion of just about every person in the film that come off as inept in every manner of speaking just make for a rather bad film. Not horrible but really really bad.

title: Started strong but did not go anywhere.
review:
Let me begin by saying that I am a fan of Night Shyamalan and quite several of his films are among my favorites. I loved the 'Unbreakable' and the 'Village'. I also thought 'Signs' was a very very interesting film despite some flaws. The 'Devil' (for which Shyamalan wrote the story) was also a noteworthy experiment.

The 'Happening', however, misses the mark (and quite badly so). It is a movie dealing with an unexplained epidemic spread in the northeastern United States pressumably caused by plants/trees. The epidemic forces the movie protagonists Elliot and Alma (the couple played by Mark Wahlberg and Zooey Deschanel) to take the train from the Philadelphia central station and reach safety somewhere in the interior of Pennsylvania.

I admit the movie started out strong and had a very eerie feeling. People started losing their minds and doing totally unexplained things including killing themselves. Initially authorities speak about terrorist attacks releasing chemical weapons but soon it becomes clear that hidden forces of nature are responsible and science cannot provide an answer.

About 30 minutes from the start I thought the film started to run into problems and it never recovered. Plotwise we expect (as audience) to understand and appreciate the danger and its origins (at least to some degree). Here, however, the story did not lead anywhere: the actors walked aimlessly in the countryside with nothing meaningful to say, with the (still) unexplained happenings not making much sense. Some of the dialogue was also becoming silly, e.g. when one of the characters attempted semi-seriously to speak to a plant failing to realize that it was plastic as if it mattered. It was a pity given the talented director and actors involved. A 6/10 from me.

title: "The Happening"- This is a great unintentional-comedy in the vein of Ed Wood, "Troll 2" and "The Room", but it fails as a serious film
review:
Whatever happened to M. Night Shyamalan? His first break-out hit, "The Sixth Sense", redefined the horror genre for its time, and it still holds up as one of the finest ghost stories to hit the screen arguably of all time. His next two films, the surreal and low-beat superhero fantasy "Unbreakable", and his emotional and contained alien-invasion neo-classic "Signs" were further examples of a brilliant director and a first-class writer. These three films remain, in my mind, modern classics, and I continue to watch them from time to time.

However, starting with his fourth film ("The Village"), each film he has made after has gotten progressively more convoluted, more messy and more pretentious. This all lead to his 2008 release, a nature-based 'thriller' entitled "The Happening." The film where M. Night's subtle visions and Hitchcock like twists and turns degenerate into a series of goofy jokes revolving around Mark Wahlberg making a fool of himself, and scenes where characters have to hold their breath to avoid breathing in poison wind that will make them go crazy and kill themselves. Uh huh. Sure.

Yes, unfortunately Shyamalan falls victim to the pretentious "save the rain-forest" genre, with a lame eco-based horror story about plants releasing a deadly toxin that drives people mad and makes them kill themselves, in order to lash back at people for hurting the Earth too much.

Wahlberg plays Elliot Moore, a teacher in New York City, whom has been having relationship trouble with his girlfriend. (Played by Zooey Deschanel, who I must say, has the most gorgeous eyes I have ever seen. But I digress) Moore is a sort-of optimist, goofy (even borderline "imbecile"), nice guy who you will both love and hate at the same time. He's borderline stupid, which makes him a lot of fun to watch, as he is constantly in over his head. Wahlberg is either giving his best performance ever, or his worst, depending on your take. John Leguizamo plays a supporting character as Elliot's friend, whom actually gives the films best performance in my mind. Whereas Wahlberg is extremely goofy (he reminded me of a Muppet, to be perfectly honest) and Deschanel is under-used, Leguizamo plays his role seriously and with a lot of heart.

After people inexplicably start to murder themselves in heinous ways all around the city (from leaping off of buildings, to stabbing themselves in the neck with needles, this film does have quite a bit of blood), Moore and the rest of the school is sent home, as city officials fear the suicides are being caused by a terrorist chemical weapon that turns off the brain's natural survival instinct. Moore and his friends try to flee the city, but are stranded in the middle of nowhere with a group of survivors, and must fend for themselves when they realize that plants are the most likely candidate for what is causing these events.

From there on, the film is a bizarre cat-and-mouse game where Elliot, his girlfriend and a few other survivors try to figure out a way to survive nature, which is hell-bent on killing them. There is more than one hilariously over-the-top scene where they must outrun the wind (which is laced with the plant-made poison), and there are plenty of gory deaths to satisfy gore hounds.

This film had a good intention- to be a creepy fun movie that also taught a lesson about respecting the planet, but M. Night seems in over his head, accidentally transforming the film into what feels like a parody and satire of his earlier films. I'm convinced, if M. Night had marketed this movie as a comedy parody of his own films, it would have been hailed as genius, because it honestly feels like he's making fun of himself. All of his trademarks- from his style of camera-work, to his odd and awkward dialog, to his silly jokes, to his trademark twists and turns, and his great use of eerie music they are all here, but they're just so goody and over-the-top, and none of it works. This is a hilarious film, for all of the wrong reasons- it's funny because its so incompetent and at times poorly written and made. I haven't even mentioned the "hot-dog guy", the "lemon drink" lady or the "cheese and crackers" soldier, but they are so insanely written and ridiculously directed, they will leave you howling with laughter.

Thankfully, this movie is not a total loss. It's blatant "bad-ness" has turned it into a prime example of a "so-bad, it's good" film for its unintentional camp factor. And as an unintentional comedy in the same vein as "Plan 9 from Outer Space" or "The Room", this works very well. I'm giving this a 5 out of 10 for it's unintentional camp factor. See it, laugh, and forget it.

title: Good premise, poor execution
review:
The premise is good, but idiotic dialogues and stereotypical characters usually don't help. The movie contains some of the worst lines and performances ever. Mark Whalberg aka the 'science teacher' is terribly insipid and that stupid wife of his is just obnoxious to the point that I wanted her to suffer a painful death. The acting is abysmal What's more to say?

The message is spelled out like to a 5 year old, just in case you didn't catch it the first time. Yeah, we got it. Nature – good, people- destructive. We get it.

The underlying 'love story' is uninteresting, distracting and clichéd. Did I mention 'annoying'? The ending is unsatisfying and there are inconsistencies throughout the movie. The creepy old woman was the only memorable character.

title: One of the strangest films i've seen
review:
I haven't watched many of Shyamalan's films but what I have realised from the ones I have is that they all have a certain style. This film was no different.

Although I enjoyed the settings of the films, the basic concept, and the cinematography, there were a lot of flaws with this film.

1. The acting was of a very low standard. I think someone in the casting department needs to think of a job change. Mark Wahlbeg delivered a very poor performance in this film to the point where you wondered if the acting was supposed to be intentionally bad. I think he should just stick to his cop roles which he actually manages to pull off. He doesn't make a good teacher. Zooey Deschanel wasn't much better either and she's normally quite good at acting as from the other films i've seen her in.

2. The storyline. Although I enjoyed the basic concept of a neurotoxin poisoning people and making them commit suicide, they got to the answer of why it was happening a bit too quickly. The plants did it? seriously, someone in the writers department should probably think about a job change too. And what was with Wahlbergs character reciting how to carry out a scientific investigation like he knew exactly what was happening? He's a high school teacher, not exactly a CDC doctor or something.

3. The ending was a little rubbish if truth be told. I expected something a bit more dramatic then, 'the plants must've stopped killing people just as we were about to give up, lets go home, everything is alright now.' Although on the other hand I did like the small part after that, set in Paris or wherever it was.

It seems i've talked about a lot of bad things with this film yet i'm still giving it a six, because although its not up there with some of the great films, its still worth a watch, for the storyline and settings mainly. Its nicely directed and sticks to the theme of a Shyamalan themed movie. If just a few tweaks had been made to this film though, such as improved acting and a bit of a better explanation for the neurotoxin, then perhaps it could have been up there with some of the great movies.

title: Good night, Shymalayan.
review: Mr. M should have given up after "The Sixth Sense." Watching this poor excuse for a bad TV movie was nearly as tedious as watching Mel Gibson catch an alien (an underpaid extra in a rubber suit) in his kitchen in the colossal turkey, "Signs." To expect any intelligent person to believe that plant life should suddenly wage war against homo sapiens after 200 million years is asking me to take a leap of "willing suspension of disbelief" that no one but an imbecile with the intelligence quotient of, dare I say it - a plant - would be capable of. If you want a great film about nature gone wrong, then catch Hitchcock's "The Birds." Or if lower life forms wreaking havoc on mankind is your cup of tea, Michael Crichton's "The Andromeda Strain." But how M. Night was even able to raise the capital to make a film of this stultifying dullness is a tribute to his brilliance as a huckster, and producers as the blind purveyors of doom that this film so abundantly supplies.

title: The answer to Shyamalan's roller coaster career... keeps blowing in the wind!
review:
Auteur M. Night Shyamalan's latest fantasy thriller borrows a great deal from "Invasion of the body snatchers" and "The stand" as mysterious, spectacular mass suicides spread across the American East coast. An increasingly smaller group of protagonists in Philadelphia flee into the countryside as the enigma points to biological reasons...

The opening hook is really something - and the first 45 minutes are equally tense, with unpredictability and moody visuals its biggest assets. But increasingly dopier (and ditto dialog) situations and character actions slowly drag this down, as the script digs itself into a big hole. The emotional content isn't entirely successful, either - it comes in moments where we don't know the characters yet to care enough (like Leguizamo's goodbye) or later on, when it has already crossed into the turkey farm one too many times.

Shyamalan's career is truly a roller-coaster, as this is one step up from "The lady in the water" but yet one steep step down from all his previous works. I do like the thematic matter, though, that the planet Earth has finally had enough of humans and finding a perfect, sinuous way to dispatch us all. That final message is also ambiguous; is it pro-natalist, or a scenario that spells an ultimatum from nature if we do procreate? The apocalypse answer, my friend, is blowing in the wind... and so does the Shyamalan enigma saga!

5 out of 10 from Ozjeppe

title: People Stopped Cold in Their Tracks
review:
What could be happening in "The Happening?" People begin to stop cold in their tracks. Next, we see people killing themselves. Some fall off buildings, some shoot themselves, others are seen hanging from trees and lying in roads.

It appears the people are under some mind control; as if, they come to a place where they are frozen in mind and death is the last resort. The winds blow. Some believe the wind is spreading some toxin in which is the death; but, later we see the wind blowing and one family who chooses to love are not affected by the wind of death.

The other people either seem to be ruled by fear, ignorance, or self-preservation to the point of murder. Some seem to have chosen isolation as a means to be separate from mankind, only to know the right thing to do, but their actions are not in love. "I suppose I should invite you to dinner." This woman is doing the right deed, but not with the right heart; her love has waxed cold.

The two teenage boys who began to curse and try to break into a man's house for food, acted not in love, even if getting the food for the little girl would be deemed right. The man who shot the two boys did not act in love. He acted in fear. He feared those outside his house would bring death to his house. He brought death to his house. The end result to his fear, was to kill. His love waxed cold.

Others succumbed to death by death overpowering their mind.

Jesus speaking of the conditions of the end times said, "And because iniquity shall abound, the love of many shall wax cold. But he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved." (Matthew 24:12-13) In "The Happening" we see many stopped cold in their tracks. Their love either waxed cold or they had no love to begin with. The winds of testing blow to test what sort of man man is. Many times, most men are found cold.

Jesus said, "But he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved."

title: Happens all too fast
review: The Happening starts off very tense and mysterious, the atmosphere being one of foreboding and terror. When people start killing themselves off it's really creepy for the audience as there is no explanation as to why and the following struggle to survive is exciting to watch. However, as the films nears its end the storyline twists and comes to a stop quite abruptly with not much of an explanation of why the happening actually happened or why the population seemed back to normal so quickly. There is also one other thing that bugs the audience's minds, how come some people don't get affected by the plants and they watch in terror at everyone else? The idea was chillingly brilliant and the acting, sound and filming for the past part very good, but the ending completely spoils the climax of what could've been quite a good film. The writers seemed to have made the ending up in a rushed five minutes...

title: So-so movie with so-so acting.
review: Considering the progressive decline of M. Night Shyamalan's movies, I guess it shouldn't come as a surprise that this movie was only so-so. The fearsome "happening" occurs because of something that is about as scary as my neighbor's bark-happy terrier. Even so, some of the moments did make me jump, if only for contrived movie experiences like sharp sound and quick visual takes. The characters are pretty well-developed, but the acting...could have been better. The hype about its being his first R-rated movie is really just that -- hype. I have a feeling it just toed the line over into R-rated territory. The violence, granted, is there, but it could easily have been toned down for a PG-13 rating. It was entertaining enough, but, overall, it suffers from what should usually be a positive thing -- a surfeit of expectations that it does not quite live up to.

title: Not the best movie ever.
review:
I tend to like M. Night movies, and most of them are incredibly well done. I think M. Night gets a little more flak than he deserves for his movies. But in this case, he gets what's coming to him. This movie is not by ANY standard the worst movie ever. Not even close. But this does fail to deliver in a couple places, and tries to push those discrepancies under the rug with cheesy dialogue and "scary" moments. Near the beginning, you get surprised and scared a lot more, but after about 5 minutes of people killing each other, the methods get repetitive and boring. Some people will get more chills out of watching the bodies just wait for their inevitable demise than others, but that's really the only scary part to the movie, and it gets old quick.

In closing, I just have to repeat that this is not really a horrible movie. It's just not as well done as other M. Nights, and doesn't really deliver the premise it lies under. I would recommend seeing it at least once, but no more than that. If you truly want to see a suspenseful movie with all components done right, go watch The Village (another M. Night film).

title: Do you like hot-dogs?....
review:
Elliot Moore is a high school science teacher who quizzes his class one day about an article in the New York Times.

It's about the sudden, mysterious disappearance of bees. Yet again Nature is doing something inexplicable, and whatever science has to say about it will be, in the end, only a theory.

Scientists will bring out more theories, but no explanations, when a more urgent dilemma hits the planet.

It begins in Central Park. Suddenly and inexplicably, the behaviour of everyone in a park changes in a most bizarre and horrible way.

Soon, the strange behaviour spreads throughout the city and beyond.

Elliot, his wife, Alma, and Jess, the young daughter of a friend, will only have theories to guide them where to run and where to hide....

So it's not what people were expecting, it's not on the same level as his first four movies, and some of the performances are pretty bad, and the subject of killer plants is laughable, but there is something about this movie that works.

The first ten or so minutes, are pure terror and is classic Shyalaman. The sense of dread and suicide is chilling and sets the tone for the movie.

But having an opening so strong is the movies biggest mistake. It can only fail from here, and it does, but only slightly.

The films major flaw though is Whalberg. e really is wooden and shows hardly any emotion throughout the movie. Him and Deschanel are more like robots than a coupe struggling to keep their relationship alive.

Luckily then we have such oddities in the support. From the man who is obsessed with hot-dogs, to the mental old woman who smashes her head through the window.

But where Signs was able to balance humour and horror with such a grandiose effect, it fails miserably here. One moment, you are laughing at Whalberg trying to befriend a plastic plant, the next scene, two of his companions are murdered in cold blood, and it feels wrong.

But the bottom line of the story, is about love, and keeping your cool when others around you are losing theirs. the plants in this can sense anger and aggravation, and this is why the two lead characters survive, no matter what is happening between them, their love is so strong, they will survive.

It's a daft movie for sure, with some confusing aspects, but it's no where as near as bad as the critics say.

Maybe because there wasn't a twist? Was that the twist?

title: Is this meant to be bad?
review:
I can not fathom how this is not universally considered the worst movie of the 2000's... At the very least. That is, if the whole thing is not some sort inside Hollywood joke that everyone else is aware of.

The plot is really moronic let alone the impressively horrible dialogue. But the acting is hands down what makes it so especially sh*tty. I don't think I've ever seen acting this bad from professional actors. It actually made me laugh out loud several times... And I was watching it alone.

So to sum it all up: Stupid plot, sh*t dialogue and really extremely sh*t acting makes this the worst movie I've seen in years. So, don't watch this movie. Or do watch it... Why do I care? Why should you care? I just wanted to slander this movie hard because it deserved it, and since people here are moronic enough to give it a mean score of 5,1. Sure it's kinda low, but not nearly low enough.

title: Almost nearly a complete waste of time.
review:
What a joke. Horrible acting, stupid predictable plot. No mystery. Even the gore was dumb and not gross.

The main female character has the most annoying face. Her dumb eyes are always opened as far as possible as in surprise. Always! lol

The little girl is cute, but only says 3 things the entire movie.

Plus everything is so fake. Almost laughably so.

Oh, and what is up with the writing?

Ex: 'Do you like hot dogs?' 'No response.' 'You guys like hot dogs right?' shake head and smile? What does that mean? Use English!!!

How could they let such stupidity like that slide?

title: Great Idea .. Poor Execution
review:
What can I say? The Happening has a great idea, but a very poor execution. The end result? A watchable film, but nothing outstanding, nor there are anything worth taking about.

I love the idea that one day, the plants, the trees, the flowers, and even the grass would stand up against humans. For all the things that we have done to them.

But this not what I have imagine. Totally! I mean, if this is all they can do, what's there to worry about? What's there to be of concern? We can just get rid of them using pesticide (which Mark Wahlberg has clearly forgotten to use in the film).

Not wanting to be a broken record, I's still have to say this. A great idea, but a poor execution. A measly 5 star out of 10 for this one. And that is being generous enough.

title: Dodgy B-pic continues the exponential decline of a once-great director
review: What if trees and bushes got together to plot the downfall of humankind? This is the premise of M Night Shyamalan's The Happening. Now, that is what some people might rightly call a "spoiler", and as such is not the sort of thing with which one should begin a review. But on the other hand, it could be argued that Shyamalan did a good enough job of spoiling his own film â€“ and the small matter of giving the game away here can't make it any worse. In fact, it may even make it better. At least a forewarned audience won't go into this film expecting another masterpiece along the lines of Sixth Sense, or even a decent-quality offering such as Unbreakable or Signs. No, the director has set the bar extremely high with his excellent earlier movies, and sadly he's routinely failed in his attempts to replicate his success: since Signs, his quality has dropped exponentially. In 2004's The Village, the cracks started to show. By 2006's Lady In The Water, it was clear he had begun to believe his previous hype. Critics universally panned the film, citing a lack of substance and an overall air of self-indulgence on the part of Shyamalan. Now we have The Happening. It's a B-movie with an A-list cast who're somehow acting at a Z-list level. Even the usually reliable Mark Wahlberg looks wholly uncomfortable here, but given the material he has to work with, that's hardly surprising. The final scenes are in no way, shape or form reminiscent of any of the director's previous trademark rug-pulling climaxes, and they seem to leave the way open for a sequel in a laughably obvious fashion. The Happening 2: The Reoccurence, anyone? 1/5

title: Good plot, well made, shame about Mark Wahlberg...
review:
I find this film a difficult one to review. It is not a bad movie but it is definitely not a great movie. The problem with M. Night Shyamalan is that he started off with one of the greatest psychological chillers ever (The Sixth Sense) and since then has not been able to produce anything quite on par with it. Signs and Devil were good and The Village had its moments but was ultimately disappointing. The problem lies in the fact that everything Shyamalan does now is compared to the Sixth Sense and, of course, nothing quite rivals that film.

The Happening revolves around a teacher and his partner who are witnessing mass suicides sweeping various states in America. They, along with others, are escaping from the affected areas and trying to find a safe haven. The cause of the devastating events are attributed to a neurotoxin released by plants that are threatened by the presence of humans.

I like the plot of the film and thought the suicide scenes were very well done and quite disturbing. The script and performances however are average. Mark Wahlberg (who I personally think is a terrible actor) is a weak lead and I find the actress who plays his wife a bit annoying. The reliable John Leguizamo delivers a good, but sadly short performance, as Wahlberg's friend. I feel Leguizamo would have made a far more competent lead. The best performance comes from the actress who portrays the creepy Ms. Jones, but yet again she has little screen time.

The ending is quite disappointing but overall the film does leave an impression.

title: The wind should blow this out the shop window!
review:
M.Night.Shynamalmamama has made one good film, "The Sixth Sense" and because of that success he now thinks he's God! He thinks that everything he makes is absolutely brilliant. He's notorious for his twist endings and so i kept on watching "The Happening" just to see what the ending would be. To see that I wasn't wasting my time, and wait for it to explain everything to me. There wasn't one.

So many things are wrong with "The Happening" and to be honest I was actually quite intrigued in the first 20 minutes or so, it was a nice introduction and it seemed as if it had some nice potential, but then I started to notice that not a lot was HAPPENING! (Pun is absolutely intended) It seemed to reflect a sort of zombie apocalypse film, without the zombies. Or the excitement. Or the suspense. Or the gore. Or the interesting characters. Or the... Yes I could go on and on and on. Truth is it was dull.

Another big problem is that it didn't know what it wanted to be! Was it trying to be a horror? Was it trying to be a drama? Was it trying to be a thriller? Instead of picking one of those genres and sticking to it, it decided to combine all three (and probably some others) making a loose story with a very dry execution. The story to me sounded like an eerie horror film, yet nothing much about it was horrific enough. M.Night.Shymanamamalam had some great opportunities to actually get some fantastic deaths (let's face it, that's all it had going for it) but instead all the gory deaths were off-screen, not giving us any chance of us seeing anything! ANNOYING! M.Night.Shylmanaman also thinks that he's some sort of Quentin Tarantino in the script department. He tries to mimic (unsuccessfully I might add) the great suspenseful dialogue which Quientin trademarks in his films, yet Mr.Shylanmanamama messes it all up by talking complete b***ocks all the time about plants talking to us and being in a large group effects the plants and all this nonsense. It's stupid an unnecessary. He also tried to be clever by blatantly making the characters say "happening" every minute, yeah, ha ha, here my genuine laughter.

Then there's the characters. Not one of them is likable and when "The Happening" rushes to its heart-felt tender finale (it's not by the way) instead of being on the edge-of-your-seat for them to live, we're egging them on to hurry up and die! (Well I was) the kids were really annoying as well. Although it doesn't help when the story actually doesn't go anywhere. Running away from the wind is something that isn't intense of frightening in the least. Then there's this stupid sub-plot with this stupid man going to find his wife which quickly goes down the pan! That was very unnecessary.

Probably the worst factory was the acting, I don't know why Mark Wharlberg is in so much stuff because he can't act for a toffee apple! The woman was really wooden as well (don't know her name) the love for each other didn't come across I'm afraid. That crazy granny was also actually unintentionally hilarious! When she was smashing her head through those windows it just looked insane, and completely daft.

So if you want a plot that goes nowhere, doesn't know what it wants to be and is as unstructured as this review, then get your glad rags on because you're in for the night of your life!

title: The ultimate downfall of M Night Shyamalan
review:
Before watching this, I remembered people saying that this was poor. So I kept that in mind before watching it. I then watched this with friends on DVD and what a waste of time it was.

The story had a very good start to it, but as the film went on, it just got ridicules and laughable. The virus spread through green life and the wind.There could have been a much better reason than that The filming and cinematography were great, I'll give you that.

The characters were utterly pathetic. That was the most annoying element to the film. I cant believe Mark Whalberg took the role. Because during moments in the film when times were stressful, for example, when the characters were trying to get a car from someone. The person tried to drive away while Whalberg was trying to get him to take him and his family with him. Whalberg was trying to convince with most pathetic tone of voice and calmed expression. This would not happen in real life at all.

Also, about the characters, when they find out how the virus spreads, where do they chose to stand? in a green field. Seriously, you must be joking.

The acting was pretty bad. Maby its just because of their characters were atrocious.

The only thing that gave me a bit of the shivers was the psychotic old woman living in the house by herself. I'm pretty sure that was used so many times in other movies.

I'm quite glad there was little use of special effects to make the film affective but you can't get over how bad the film gets.

I love M Night Shyamalan older films, The Sixth Sense, Signs and Unbreakable. Hated The Village but Lady in the Water was pretty good though. Haven't seen Last Airbender yet though.

This film really is his carer downfall, please don't bother wasting you're money on this. But I really recommend you his older films though.

title: A pile of $hit
review:
WTF??? Is what I was thinking when this turd ended. It is beyond bad.

Marky Mark can not act, he sounded ridiculous throughout the film, especially the hilarious close ups, the one scene where hes demanding a second to think, hahahaha it was so ridiculous.

And for all you gorky eyed dribbling men, Zooey Deschanel CAN NOT ACT!!!! Hey, I'm a man too and I could not stand the woman. How many times did we see some over acted, gormless facial expression when the camera was close up on her face? She ruined most of the film for me. She spends the whole time trying to be all angelic. Reading up on her bio explains it all really, mummy and daddy were already i nthe entertainment business and shes obviously got roles from her looks like most of the air headed bimbos in Hollywood. Let me say it again, she can not act to save her life.

And what was the deal with the teenage boys getting blown away by a shotgun? Would that really of happened? So over the top and unrealistic. and sick actually.
