I cant remember that little girls name whos with Marky Mark and the crap actress but there's a scene where they are running through a field and the kid is making that fake, badly acted crying noise. Irritating!

I will even admit I don't know what 'the happening' was,...the wind/farts/the plants/bad breath/the state of the economy because I didn't give a $hit. The director is a hack and I didn't like his previous works either. This film is so badly made its unbelievable.

The characters do the dumbest things and.....just don't torture your brain and watch this garbage.

I will leave it to another reviewer to explain this $hit movie in detail to you and all its intricate flaws, as I can not be bothered. Just heed my warning.

title: A brilliant comedy
review:
Mr. M Night does it again by delivering a staggeringly hilarious movie. The Happening is a clever and ironic title because nothing actually happens. Every scene is witty and comedic; a perfect example would be when our protagonists meet up with two young boys in one scene, and then in the scene directly after they are shot for no reason. The humour lies with the fact that this scene has no purpose other than to shoot children with a shotgun - brilliant! Of course M. Night includes one of his infamous twists partway through the film: What could be causing massive populations to commit suicide in horrendous ways? Trees! Yes, trees feel an environmental threat from humans so they release a deadly neurotoxin to kill people. I honestly never saw that one coming. No, the trees don't just release a chemical that kills people, it makes people kill themselves by jumping off buildings, running themselves over with lawnmowers and smashing their heads through glass. Hilarious stuff! I can tell you I was bent over laughing as soon as Zooey Deschanel said, "It makes you kill yourself. Just when you thought there couldn't be any more evil that can be invented." Indeed Zooey, I seldom consider the evils yet to be invented by trees.

There is one part that confused me though. Our heroes were on a train evacuating the area when it suddenly comes to a halt and everyone is forced to get off because the train conductors have, "Lost contact with everyone." It really is unfortunate that they lost contact with everyone whilst on a train track, thus are forced to get out of the train instead of continuing onward on a fast-moving, straight set of tracks that can only lead in one direction and does not pertain to contact with everyone. This is especially unfortunate because all of the passengers continue to text message each other and send each other videos of lions eating people. Those damn trees, mucking about with the communication technology of the train conductors! This was definitely one of the most memorable scenes in cinematic history, only because I was puking out of laughter.

Seriously though...what the f**k M. Night Shyamalan.

title: Watch it for fun
review: I like to watch bad movies, its a hobby of mine. But bad horror movies will always hold a special place in my heart. The Happening though will take the crown as THE WORST HORROR MOVIE EVER MADE. You have to understand that before you even attempt to watch this movie. Here are some reason why this movie is god awful. From the amount of money that went into making it. To the decent actors that were cast in it. But it was still awful. Mind blowingly awful. (these were to two that I felt were most important. There are still many many more reasons.) The whole plot of the movie is that nature has finally had enough and is now making all plants on earth let loose a toxin into the air that makes you commit suicide. Thats the plot twist for the movie FYI. The main characters are Elliot Moore (played by Mark Wahlberg) and Alma Moore (played by Zooey Deschanel) Elliot is a high school science teacher in Philadelphia who will constantly annoy you through out the rest of the film with his awful/awkward dialogue. Alma is Elliots boyfriend who she is having a affair with, and is the only character that seems half normal through the film.

title: More like The Crappening
review:
Is M. Night Shyamalan, the director of this flop, the same M. Night Shyamalan who made THE SIXTH SENSE and UNBREAKABLE? You'd be forgiven for thinking that the director of the earlier, classy fare had been replaced by a talentless clone after watching this hugely embarrassing environmental-disaster thriller. It's a film which opens with a handful of breathtaking set-pieces involving mass human madness, before swiftly descending into the kind of silly schtick that even a Sci-Fi Channel producer would think twice before greenlighting.

The blame is clearly fixed on Shyamalan's shoulders; he didn't only direct this tripe, but wrote it too. That indicates that the production was a labour of love, but what a misguided one! The script is appallingly bad, full of the kind of unreal dialogue that could only exist in a bad B-movie, and the whole film has a tired, subdued, seen-it-all-before air to it. As for the cast...well, words fail me. Mark Wahlberg is wooden and hopelessly, helplessly, miscast as a science teacher, delivering his lines with a kind of disbelief that he's been caught up in this mess. Zooey Deschanel, who I previously saw in YES MAN (and to be fair she was quite appealing in that) is abhorrently awful, her wide-eyed style of acting more suited to a pantomime than a movie. The only one who gives a decent performance is the reliable John Leguizamo, and he doesn't get a great deal of screen time at all.

THE HAPPENING lurches from one minor set-piece to the next, always promising more than it delivers. The plotting is basic and obvious, never less than contrived. Some moments, like when the two boys start going crazy, are so over-the-top and badly done that they become hilarious to watch. So, in the end, that's what this becomes: a so-bad-it's-funny experience, a modern day variant on the likes of ROBOT MONSTER and PLAN 9 FROM OUTER SPACE. Maybe audiences fifty years down the line will feel the same way...

title: Interesting And Original But Stilted And Confusing Eco-Disaster Thriller
review:
Elliot is a science teacher in New York who decides to go to rural Pennsylvania when an airborne toxin which seems to induce people to commit suicide hits the city. Can he figure out what this mystery threat is and how to avoid falling victim to it ?

This is a slight yet intriguing and intimate disaster movie, but it's unsatisfying because it doesn't answer any of the big questions. Perhaps that's the point - scary things happen for no reason and thwart all efforts to explain them - but the story is too interesting to leave all these details out. Why do people seem to freeze when an attack is coming, why is everyone affected in groups until Mrs Jones at the end, and how exactly do the plants synthesise this previously unidentified chemical ? With material like this it's better to either leave it unexplained (see The Birds) or have a go-for-broke answer (see Invasion Of The Body Snatchers), but Shyamalan treads an uneasy line between both which is ultimately frustrating. It's good fun though, with typically unconventional characters, an unusual bucolic atmosphere which contrasts with the menace, a strong cast, a highly original cello score by James Newton Howard and quality photography throughout by old pro Tak Fujimoto (Badlands, The Silence Of The Lambs). Wahlberg and Leguizamo both eschew their usual tough guy personas to play mild, bespectacled, white-collar Joes and Deschanel is consistently good, although the most interesting performance for me was the totally loopy one by Buckley (the nice gym teacher in Carrie thirty years earlier) as the crazy lady whose traumatic past is subtly alluded to. The movie is sort of a hotch-potch of sci-fi/ecological ideas from the novels of John Wyndham and also reminded me of an old Sidney Sheldon small-town-crazies Twilight Zone story called Need To Know. It's a bit thin for a whole film and doesn't come together but it's still affecting and atmospheric. Trivia - the director has a non-cameo as the creep who keeps calling Deschanel.

title: The Happening
review: From Razzie nominated director M. Night Shyamalan (The Sixth Sense, Unbreakable, Signs), after making The Village and Lady in the Water, and before winning Worst Director for The Last Airbender, there came this disaster movie. Basically high school science teacher Elliot Moore (Razzie nominated Mark Wahlberg) is giving a class talking about the unexplained disappearance of bees, and then all of the sudden a bigger unexplained phenomenon is occurring worldwide. Beginning in Central Park and then spreading, people suddenly freeze in the middle of wherever they are, momentarily confused, and then they have the sudden urge to commit suicide in the most brutal way they can think of. Knowing that this mysterious event is popping up in places nearby, Elliot gets his wife Alma (Zooey Deschanel), and takes Jess (Ashlyn Sanchez), daughter of his friend Julian (John Leguizamo), to whatever safety they can find. One amateur theorist says that it is flowers and plant life grouping together to create some kind of climate contagion that turns people this way, but what is definite is that people in bigger groups are what cause it. In the end Elliot, Alma and Jess do survive the devastation and two months or so pass with the deadly phenomenon seemingly gone, but of course it happens again somewhere in the world, so it could start again. Also starring Betty Buckley as Mrs. Jones, Spencer Breslin as Josh, Robert Bailey Jr. as Jared,Alan Ruck as Principal and Shyamalan as Joey. I will admit I was surprised by one or two of the bizarre suicide scenes, and I did giggle at how they occur, but this is unfortunately also one of the big reasons the film is so ridiculous, it isn't scary, thrilling or engaging, the acting is terrible, the script is stupid, it is all just a silly and not worth the effort science fiction thriller. It was nominated the Razzies for Worst Picture and Worst Screenplay. Pretty poor!

title: suicidal failure for shyamalan
review:
Disaster movie (in more ways than one).

People start committing suicide in New York, as if it were a plague. The authorities decide to evacuate the city... You only have to read those first two sentences to realise that you're heading into Turkey Land, into big-time garbage, into 'Is it the director and the writers and the producer and the actors who decided to blow their brains out, not the characters?' Wouldn't there be real chaos in your city or town if people suddenly decided to commit suicide for no reason whatsoever? I mean REAL CHAOS -crowds of people running for it, people getting drunk, people heading for church, looting, murders, blood, body parts... All you see in the mistitled HAPPENING is some people getting calmly into a train (there were even a few empty seats!) and - wait for it - heading off for Pittsburgh.

Mark 'I, like the director, have lost my mind' Dahlberg is a science teacher. Well, OK, it's not exactly typecasting, but he COULD be a teacher, with those irritating frown marks of his. Could it be that people are committing suicide because of 'a terrorist attack'? A TERRORIST ATTACK!? That's right, the (fill in your least favourite terrorist group) have concocted some 'toxin' that drives people crazy. The first 'attack' is in New York, so people head west. Dahlberg suggests it might not be a terrorist attack at all, but the side effects of something in the air. A bio-weapon that's gone astray? ('The Andromeda Strain') Something in the water? ('The Crazies') A mad scientist who's stolen a bio-weapon? ('The Satan Bug') No, it could be just something that's borne in the air. Turns out it's in the wind. So whenever the wind gets up again, they all scarper. 'They' are the group with Dahlberg.

Dahlberg is pretty dim, even for a science teacher. His wife, though, is dimmer still and makes him look like Einstein. Even when he IS having a conversation with a plastic plant. This priceless scene isn't amusing, just embarrassing.

Shyamalan is a director who is prone to sickly sentimentalism - and there are great lumps of it here. The last third or so of the film looks like bits left over from another script altogether - the kindly old lady who turns out to be like Kathy Bates in 'Misery.' It doesn't make much sense when slotted (very uncomfortably) together with the rest of the film. But since the film itself makes no sense anyway, what difference does it make? The deadly spores or whatever they are disperse. The shots of a scientist being interviewed on TV are sheer comedy. They're looking at a graph of the spread of the spores - no flashy graphics or anything, just a crude chart that belongs to Seventies TV. For not the first time, I seriously wondered whether THE HAPPENING was supposed to be a spoof - or even an elaborate conspiracy by everyone else in the country to drive Mark Wahlberg crazy. The ending is dreadful, along with the rest of it. Oh dear.

title: Plant's VS Human's????
review:
The first thing that i had in my mind when i saw this movie is CREEPY. They say keep your friends close enemies closer, but on this one, i bet you don't wanna be using that phrase anymore. how can you defend yourself when you don't even know whats there? i thought zombie's are creepy, when you got bitten you will turn into zombie yourself, but at least you get to run and survive most importantly you know your enemy.

The happening is just something, the plot is unique. I'ts funny in a way that the one's responsible for the attacks are plants. I don't know, but i have no idea if its true that plants can attack specific targets only, and in this case it is attacking non-other than us humans. The disease is airborne, and for us humans to live we need air. Now that's something to think about. But the biggest question is, what if this is possible? are we doomed?.

IMO this movie is somehow a wake-up call for us humans, i don't wanna sound like an environmentalist or what, but like one's said we should be somehow responsible and be sensitive when it comes to our environment, Mother Nature's wrath is not a myth it has been proved thousand times already, and the catastrophe that it caused is not something that should be ignored. Tsunami's, tornado's flash floods, earth quakes, thunder storm's and a lot more, this natural disaster's are just examples of what the earth is capable of, and to think that most of this events are unpredictable, which means it can happen anywhere in anytime.

The very thing that i like on this movie is indeed the plot, its very effective, but in the end you are looking for answers and IMO i don't like movies that don't have clear endings. The actings are great Mark wahlberg is a very versatile actor you can put him anywhere, to be honest I'm a whalberg fan myself, and this is one of the reason's why i decide to watch this movie. And of course Zooey Deschanel, always been a pretty face, i like her the first time i saw her in the movie yes man, great acting too. Overall i give this movie 6/10 stars, you can watch this if you have free time.

title: What's Happening?
review:
Don't expect to see Rerun, Raj and Dwayne hanging out at Shirleys diner.

I'm glad I heard the trashing of this film before I saw it, because I was able to go into it with low expectations. And this is the reason I found this film to be a slight enjoyment.

Moonwalking Madness, is what I would rename this film. This film was one big joke from start to finish. And by "joke" I mean funny as hell. Suicide has never been so funny to me until this film came along. You've got to be crazy to take this film completely serious. And you have no funny-bone if you can keep a straight face while viewing it.

Billie Jean is not my lover (moonwalk), and then *BLAMMO*.

Apparently, defenseless Vegetation (of all things) has decided to (for whatever reason) join forces in a Jihad against all of mankind. A Daffodil and an Oak Tree had obviously flipped a coin and decided to launch their first attack in the upper New England states, which put my mind at ease since I'm a Southerner. "The answer my friend is blowin' in the wind". I mean, literally....it was blowin' in the wind. It appears that the wind is an ally in this terrorist attack. I mean, what better way for toxic "plant-farts" to travel from point-A to point-B? Once a human gets a whiff of this fragrance, they become tranced. They take four or five steps backwards, do the hokey-pokey, turn themselves around and look around for something deadly to end their lives.....that's what its all about!!

"Hey, lookie there....a John Deere lawnmower. Lemmi crank her up and crawl under it....see if the blades are sharp enough for the lawn" or "That thar hand grenade looks awful damn delicious." or "I hope you left a bullet in that chamber for me, hon."

Mark Wahlberg stars, and is intentionally unconvincing as a high-school science teacher, appearing to look only slightly older than the students he teaches. He lives a few states over from the "plant-farts", but not for long, as the winds-of-change are quickly headed his direction. John Leguizamo also stars, playing an even more intentionally unconvincing mathematics teacher, however he does improve his performance during emotional moments. He travels with his 8 year old daughter who (thankfully) barely spoke throughout most of the film.

This is not quite a review, just my observation with rambling included. I am confused. Is this actually what Shyamalan was aiming for? Or was this humor just unintentional? Whatever his intention, I didn't care, because I was too busy having fun watching it. The suicides are completely hilarious, which wasn't a bad thing since nearly each suicide died with a different method....well....except for the people who were gathered together. If someone in a group had a gun, they'd all share the gun....each biting a bullet until there were no more bullets left. If someone jumped off a building, everyone around would think it was an excellent idea. So, to answer your mothers old question: "Sure mom, if Billy jumped off a bridge, I'd be close enough behind him to see his butt crack."

The problems I had with this film were major, but the humor made up for it. Like how Wahlberg and company never got infected, but others around him were offing themselves in herds. And like how the wind always seemed to blow in someone else's face even though Wahlberg sometimes stood only a few yards away.

Every now and then, they'd happen across a TV where the news is on, and there'd be some guy talking about this Happening, or trying to figure out the origin of it.....which I saw as a direct rip-off of G.A Romero's Night Of The Living Dead.

But this is all just my observation and opinion. You don't have to buy it. Just buy the movie and see for yourself.

7/10

title: The Happening......WHAT HAPPENED?
review:
In 2008, M. Night Shyamalan directed and wrote his next film, "The Happening" where weird things start to -- happen!! It was better than some of his past films, but it, like other films he directed, can not live up to the audience appeal of "The Sixth Sense (1999)."

Mark Wahlberg stars as a high school science teacher whose theory of bees disappearing is the premise for the film. The story is out there, somewhere! But that is what an M. Night Shyamalan film is based on, strange ideas and far out themes. This is however, not a film for children or the faint of heart. Many images and depictions of death are shown, and in graphic detail.

Shyamalan tries to live up to the wonderment of Alfred Hitchcock and Stephen King, but he falls short of their glory, and his films pay the price. Somehow though, his films continue to be released in amazement. But as long as they do, audience will flock to see them.

title: Could have done with a bit more happening
review:
Upon its release, The Happening received many negative reviews and was nominated for four Razzie awards including worst film but having viewed the film for the first time, I discovered that while it was far from being a great film, it was certainly not as bad as people say.

Made with the intention of being like a B-Movie, the story focuses on a married couple who discover that America has gone under some sort of attack where people are killing themselves. While not perfectly executed, the story does sink the viewer into what is happening and the plot does move at a swift pace for the majority of the film.

What really hinders the film from being good is the dialogue given to actors who can do so much more. Like the remake of The Wickerman, The Happening has now become a comedy in many people's eyes and if you search on the Internet, you will find spoofs and reedits. Some of the scenes are so bad, that you wonder what was going through the director's head. I would usually say that they could have been taken out and left on the cutting room floor but with a running time of 1hour and 20 minutes, they needed all the footage they could find.

On a technical level the film is good; the photography is good but there are some bad reaction shots which when up-close on an actors face, feel strange and out of place. The music by James Newton-Howard is very good and there are a few gruesome moments that will make the audience cringe. However there are not enough scenes that really emphasise how much danger they are in. We get the impression that the threat is deadly but as the audience, we need to see more as there are no scenes where we really doubt if the lead characters are in danger. This is after all a horror film.

While there are a few laughable scenes due to the dialogue or the acting, The Happening is not a terrible film but it is certainly not perfect. As a viewer, I never became bored or lost interest in the story. A good idea that could have been so much more.

title: Am I the only one that loved The Happening?
review:
I think I may actually be the biggest M. Night fan out there. I think he is brilliant! I love every one of his films and I am always amazing at his ideas. I, of course loved this idea as well. I was impressed by the mood, the idea, and how the idea was carried out. However, I was not impressed by the acting. The thing about this is that I am a huge John Leguizamo and Mark Wahlberg fan. Has anyone seen the Departed? He was brilliant in that movie! His acting was impeccable! I have not a clue what happened to these two in The Happening. The acting really did ruin the film. Everything in this movie was great besides the acting. Sadly, it brought it down terribly. I found myself laughing during serious, suspenseful parts just because the acting was so awful. I don't think this is the right genre for John or Mark. Maybe they will get it right the next time.Besides that, Keep 'em coming Shyamalan! I'll be waiting.

P.S: M. Night usually has a guest appearance in every one of his films. He didn't this timeor did I just miss it?

title: A Character Study in Human Nature
review: I am going to risk getting flamed and give this movie an EXCELLENT review. Why? Because what everyone hated about this film is exactly what I loved about it. We get so used to seeing larger than life heroes save the day and never break a sweat. We are used to seeing blood, guts, and entrails splattering our screens. People will forgive a weak plot (as many horror movies have) if you give them a big, bloody payoff. This film is not so much about "the happening" although that part is terrifying and exciting to watch; after all, how many of us are afraid of losing who we are or going insane? This film is about human nature. It is about how humans behave when everything normal is taken away. Yes, there are some awkward acting parts, but I think that this is done on purpose. I prefer to give Mr. Shyamalan the benefit of the doubt because I have said stupid stuff at the most inappropriate times. The fact is that humans are not perfect; humans do not always say the right thing, and humans can be selfish even when other people's lives are at stake. However, people usually do the right thing and come together. It's an excellent character study in human nature.

title: The Happening, it happened for me!
review:
Two years ago M.Night Shyamalan brought his awkward cousin; The Happening to the world. Of course this movie was promoted as the horror movie of the year for marketing purposes which came out on the typical day of Friday the 13th of July, if i remember correctly. After his latest movie; Lady in the Water which came out four years ago, it was obvious that Shyamalan chooses for the non-typical Hollywood-movie approach. After his successful movies like The Sixth Sense, Unbreakable and Signs, it became clear that with The Village and LitW Shyamalan wasn't making movie pictures for the 'crowd'.

With "The Happening" on it's way I was very excited. I'd assembled allot of friends that time to actually watch "The Happening" during premiere night in a dutch cinema nearby. My friends got excited by me and after seeing material from the trailer. It looked very promising and 'non shyamalanish' which could turner either both ways. I'd didn't really mind as long as it would entertain and surprise me and my friends.

My friends and the rest of the audience just giggled and laughed out loud during the entire movie, including myself. At first I didn't get the story at all. What is the message of this movie and what is up with the awkward and strange acting and dialogue flow in this movie? Well people, after two years I totally understand the meaning of "The Happening" and my creditability in Shyamalan has rises once again. The movie itself is just fine and a beauty to watch and listen to thanks to Shyamalans main cinematographer; Tak Fujimoto and composer and friend; James Newton Howard who arranges as usually amazing tense and emotional music to bring his movies to a higher level. But the story and all the dialogues kept bothering me for years, until a few days ago. Let me explain. (Do only read when you've seen this movie once or twice!) The movie starts with strange 'events' happening. People notice that these events occur in three stages of the human body. First lack of speech, movement and the full control of the mind and body In this picture we get to see Elliot, a teacher played by Mark Walhberg who teaches biology. His wife Alma (Zooey Deschanel) we get to meet later on struggles with herself and her relationship with Elliot.

The events that are happening, get spread worldwide by word and media. People assume at first that terrorist are at work by releasing toxic-gas, but later on other assumptions are being made, time after time. It's hard to explain but in this part of storytelling lies the 'twist' of this movie.

People just follow each other and show group behaviour, when they are in these kinds of unknown and strange situations. During there trip to avoid and try to unravel this 'happening' they get in contact with lots of other people who are on the same road as they are. A little girl who travels with them is one of these people who doesn't have a opinion yet, a innocent child that just experiences and observes all the theories and events they encounter. She stands in the middle of this chaotic chain of communications and interpretations of mankind.

Once Elliot thinks he knows what's actually happening, they enter a path which leads ultimately to a very mysterious and strange character named; Mrs. Jones. A old widow who lives isolated from the daily world. Once they meet each other strange things are happening once again.

The climax of this film looks incredible cliché and strange, but seen from the perspective of this characters it's obvious and understandable the way they react. The strenght of this movie lies as all the other Shyamalan movies in the human emotions and believes of each other. with one simple line i could spill the entire movie. But if u look further, deeper and with a non-standard movie scripting look, you will embrace this movie at a time. My advice is to start listening to the story by the very first lines and discover how magically this 'Happening' enrolls.

With this picture Shyamalan shows again what a brilliant storyteller and movie director he is. I am really looking to his upcoming trilogy of the anime series; Avatar and his other stories like "Devil" who will come out in 2011.

title: Good concept ruined by poor acting
review:
M. Night was something of a whirlwind in the early Noughties with his innovative thriller The Sixth Sense. Unluckily it has turned into a downward spiral since then, with this film being yet another drawback to his floundering career.

While I like the idea of the human race committing suicide in ever more devious and violent ways. The whole thing was marred by some truly pitiful acting on the parts of most actors. Mark Wahlberg seemed to just whine his way through each line with this falsified look of shock and horror. The only emotion I was capable of during the viewing of this film was embarrassment.

title: Be aware of what is Happening...
review:
Apparently, according to sources here on IMDb and on some other motion picture review sites, I am in a minority.

I liked The Happening and for the life of me I cannot explain why.

The cinematography was superb, the pace just right and the acting sublime.

Yes, it is a very good film but it is not a truly great film so I gave it 7/10 stars.

Mark Wahlberg does not fail to impress once again. I'm just a little concerned that he may become typecast in this type of role, yet he is totally believable.

Zooey Deschanel emanates emotion as her life appears to fall apart around her. There are times when I genuinely feel for her character Alma. She is being overwhelmed by what is happening in the world she inhabits and she is already tied up in guilty little secrets she has kept from her husband.

As for the other characters... well, it's not really about them, is it? It's about Elliott and Alma.

And as for the plot? When the cause was first put forward, I felt a shiver down my back.

As much as many people are writing off this storyline as too far fetched, even for Sci-Fi, I find it totally plausible and therefore very, disturbing.

There is a lot of screaming in places, but there is a lot of calm as well. Just try not to read the calm as 'nothing happening'. It's a mass calm that could only really come about as the people realise the enormity of the situation and how impotent they are to stop it.

title: Not perfect, but no where near as bad as people make it out to be
review:
The Happening opened in June of 2008, and over the past three years, it has gotten harder and harder to find a positive review for it, in fact every time I do see a positive review on youtube or something I like it immediately. Under no circumstances is the movie perfect, but I feel that it succeeds in what it is trying to be, a B-Movie. The trailers never really showed this, but days before the film came out, Shyamalan was being interviewed, and said, "We're making an excellent B movie, that's our goal." I would classify this film as a horror film, that never takes itself to seriously, and that's why I like it. I hate when a movie takes itself too seriously, sometimes it can work, but usually the movie just ends up being dull. While the film has some really graphic scenes such as the hair clip through the neck, and being run over with the lawn mower, it also has some really funny moments, like talking to a plastic plant, or the crazy old lady who wonders if Elliot is eying her drink. Because it never takes itself seriously, it is a fun movie, you get the graphic deaths that disturb you, then you also get the funny, stupid scenes that will cheer you up so that you never are too depressed.

Now that I've discussed the misunderstanding people have with this film, lets move on to some of the other things I like. The film really does look amazing, I'll admit Shyamalan was never that good of a writer (exept with Signs, but even in the Sixth Sense, it didn't take a master story teller to hide the twist), but he is a really great director. He never just sets up the camera, he doesn't shake it to add realism, cough "Hurt Locker" cough, and he doesn't jump cut every five second, cough "Wanted" cough. But there are other things I did like.

For example the acting is not nearly as bad as people make it out to be, seriously, on IMDb, a user called the acting cringe inducing. Now I will admit, Zooey Deschanel was HORRIBLE. She gave easily the worst performance, she was fine when she was silent, but when she talked, it was pretty terrible. However I think that Mark Walberg actually did a pretty good job, nothing outstanding, but he wasn't the completely wooden performance that people make him out to be. The rest of the cast is OK, even the little girl, she has only one line but she does so much with complete silence, maybe it's just because she so cute that I don't want anything to happen to her.

Which leads me to my next point, I like these characters, I don't want anything to happen to them. It's like Roland Emmerichs movies, everyone else says there nothing but eye Candy movies, but I actually do care about the characters. I can't say that I cared about Elliot and Alma's relationship problems that much, but I didn't want them to die, so something went right.

The film does have a few good jump scares, and it takes chances by killing people under 18, that actually look like their under 18.

Then theirs the ending, why do people have problems with it, what is so bad about the ending that pisses people off, is it the fact that it the fact that it shows the epidemic is happening somewhere else.

Under no circumstances is The Happening a perfect film, but it's a fun, creepy movie, with decent performances, cool death scenes, and likable characters, that I'm amazed that this film got so much hate, I mean, it got nominated for worst picture and Wanted didn't. Oh and one last thing, the film has probably one of the best tag lines of all time.

title: What's Going On
review:
"You know hot dogs got a bad rep? They got a cool shape, they got protein. You like hot dogs, right?"

The Happening is like hot dogs. It got a lot of crap when it first came out, and indeed, I thought I tactfully avoided more Shyamalan kitsch after hating Lady In the Water (though I now want to revisit it), but when I caught this on TV the other night, I was pleasantly surprised and captivated by how clever and funny it was. Satire on sensationalist journalism disguised as an almost slasher-flick styled thriller about killer plants? Um, yes please.

Seriously, that's what I think the movie is about. The characters say the word "terrorism" so often that it cannot be ignored. Just what are terrorists, what is terrorism? Nothing you can physically comprehend. Perhaps the best example is Global Warming, given the ridiculous (though admittedly genius) marketing scheme that is the "green" movement and the (also genius) antagonists that are killer plants -- but this is really just a placeholder. Fill in the blank with any case of invisible evil deemed apocalyptic by experts.

More importantly is what these candidates have in common: the current mass media business market that unhealthily and unnecessarily uses scare tactics for nothing more than to increase ratings; to increase the audience. Who is most affected by the plants' deadly toxins? Large populations, naturally. I kept waiting for a character totally cut off from society and entirely lacking in any knowledge of the epidemic. I got more than I bargained for: not only is there such a character (living quietly and inconsequentially in the country, surrounded by plants and trees at that), but there is also a faceless hillbilly who blows away two kids (one in the face!) with his boomstick, mistakenly thinking they are infected. Fear the plants. Fear them.

title: Not GREAT, but still not bad...
review:
Just finished watching it now, and it really makes a difference when you're watching something alone.

First off, I'll start with the bad. The bad was basically the underlying environmentalist world-view. Plants fight back! Well, I personally don't believe the plants are going to kill us all, and I resent the explanation given. It's downright ridiculous, and it insults the audience's intelligence.

Some of the lines could've been better, but I've seen every Shyamalan film to know that this is how he writes: like telling a story. Some of the reactions to certain events are quite unrealistic and could've been acted much better. For instance, someone falls off a building and the construction worker who sees this takes about 7 seconds to actually think about running over to the guy, not to mention the two other workers he's talking with. Various emotions given off are a bit strange for the situations... I resented the fact that the mean old lady who housed the protagonists at one point was subtly implicated as a hard-core Catholic...

But other than that I enjoyed the film. It's quite a thriller and will definitely have you jumping a few times. I now understand why it's rated R, for the fact that there are many, many instances of people killing themselves in various, horrible ways. But scratching the fact that this movie has an environmentalist lean on things, this was quite entertaining and I recommend it to hard-core M. Knight fans. Sure, it had many flaws, and the explanations were far from realistic, but by golly it was still entertaining! I've seen many others comment about the casting choices being "terrible," but I really can't see how they did a bad job at their roles they were given. Actors are actors, and they work the best they can at what they're acting for. The script was very interesting, and when M. Knight wanted some comic relief, he gave it with perfect timing. Conversations between everyone about everyday life was heartwarming and real, and gave you the sense that these were, in a small way, actual people in a real situation.

Camera angles and lighting were superb, as always Mr. Shyamalan. So all in all, for the quality of the film as compared with every other film made in history, I'd give this a 5/10. For entertaining quality, I give it a 7/10. Movies are almost always meant to entertain its audiences, and this movie did the job it set out to do: entertain. At least, it did it for me.

title: the happening
review: first off let me say that this is much much better than lady in the water, maybe not quite sixth sense or signs, but pretty good nonetheless. the eerie tension that builds up throughout the movie is very good M. Night said that he set out to create a "b" movie of the 70's well if that was the case he suceeded overwhelmingly. i thought that the horror and suspense were classic Night. The perfomrnace of John Leguizamo was pretty darn good. Zoey Deschanel not quite sure about her performance, felt though as if she wasn't really trying in her role. it is interesting given the situation with the world today that this movie comes out now.. greenhouse gases, global warming, swine flu, bird flu,, maybe M. Night foretells of things to come here on earth. overall i thought this was a pretty decent and very graphic movie.

title: Thought it was a B movie
review:
Another reader said he hated the movie because he was expecting so much from a Shyamalan film. I kind of liked it because I had a totally different experience: I picked up this movie at about 10 minutes on a hotel where I was staying the night just waiting for my connection flight the next day, and thought "cool, a B movie in a post-catastrophe world. Soon zombies are going to pop". I recognized Whalberg's face, but couldn't quite figure out where I had seen him before, so I just guessed it was from another low budget, specially because his acting was so laughable.

There were no commercials, so my illusion lasted till the final scene. I kept waiting for zombies, but settled for the crazy old lady with the pale face, and Whalberg yelling "why can't you give me just a minute" as if he had just entered acting school.

Campy, apocalyptic with half-baked environmental ideas. Not terrible if don't know that this guy also directed "Sixth Sense" and you are just passing time at a hotel. Don't recommend renting it, though. "Day of the Dead" is more gratifying.

title: The Crappening
review:
These comments may contain spoilers- if that's possible(?)

I wanted to like this movie more than I did. I dig M.'s movies. I like the actors. I loved that Brian 'I'm not even supposed to be here today' O'Halloran had a bit part- look quick and you might catch him driving the jeep. Poor Dante, that guy just cannot catch a break.

I saw the Happening in the theaters mostly because of the creepiness of the commercials and found myself rolling my eyes through a lot of it. I just caught the last 3/4's of it on cable tonight and found myself laughing a lot, which I'm pretty sure they were not shooting for. Sure there were some scenes that were pretty gruesome like what happens with the two boys that they are traveling with, others were Monty Pythonesque, like the lion scene at the zoo. That one had me in stitches.

Not any of the actors best work, nor was it M.Night Shyamalan's best, but it does have about a 5 or 6 on the re-watchable scale if only to make sarcastic quips if you are watching it with friends. Or if you are playing a drinking game and have to drink whenever a character says a form of the word happening (like 'what's happening here?' or 'what just happened?') You'd be surprised at how frequently this will happen. There, it just happened there. And again!

Just kidding about the 'Crappening' thing, it wasn't as terrible as some of the other ratings on here suggest.

title: M. Night Shamaylan
review:
Night is a fabulous, almost genius film maker. Signs, sixth Sense, etc. The only problem with Signs was the lack of Winchester Pump 12 gauge shot guns. Signs was filmed in rural farmland PA and EVERY FARMER has at least one shotgun. Those green guys would have been stacked like logs for the winter.

The Happening was simply not believable. Mark Wahlberg and John Leguizamo are solid actors if not super stars. They always deliver solid performances (even in Collateral Damage with Arnold he did great work). Their acting in Happening was a bit better than a high school play; however, Night gave them very little substantive material to work with.

The premise of the film, that humans are considered by Nature to be a virus on the planet is just more Lefty lunacy (Yes the Left actually subscribes to the foolishness – solution: all the Left cut themselves shaving and go swimming at Stinson Beach, North Ca). Somehow the plants are mad at us and accelerate their evolutionary processes (normally taking thousands of generations) and decide to release some "compound" (what an ominous word) into the air causing Humans to leap to their deaths, hang themselves, and pickup guns and shoot themselves, yeah, right! Maybe you but not me!

The Happening becomes one of those B films that you turn to at 2 AM and just HAVE TO SEE THE END desperately hoping that there will be one redeeming quality of the film (skin?).

Night better get his act together for his next project or he will drop from the "A List" to the "F List" (Forgotten). Most of his films, especially with Bruce, have been great.

The movie is simply not worth your time, watching C-Span at 2 AM is better time spent.

Yours truly, Thomas Capital Management, www.thomascapitalmgt.com

title: Light Night Shaymen
review: I watched this a couple of times.The first time as a move and the second to look for clues. The first time I watched it I had the following thoughts. Wahlbergs acting seemed "light" and breathless. the whole character lacked any depth, The female character was a bit starey and weird. The "Joey" subplot was wafer thin and extraneous. The young girl was emotional baggage and the emotional link to her "soon to be dead" parents very poorly described. The army guy? Didn't get him at all.Very poorly written and acted. Overall the characterisation in this film is very poor. No character is described to depth where you really care about anyone. Tagged the obvious shots with the power station in the background. If the idea was they are somehow to blame for nature's rebellion.this was a ham-fisted reference. What was the "Showhome sequence" all about? Was this some reference to the fake towns built in Nevada for nuclear testing in the 50's or an implication of natures rebellion against human encroachment? This felt a very shallow film. You tend to look for more with this director but I ended up falling int the kings new clothes territory. If this was intended to be a B movie as other's has suggested then that seems an excuse rather than a reason. The only reason i thought this film intriguing is that I thought there might be more,hidden image and intelligence like Sixth Sense. Unfortunately I was wrong.

title: What's Happening? M Night S is a one trick pony, that's what!
review: The Big Reveal... M Night S has been found out! The Happening is a poor, dawdling movie-absolute pants. Not to give anything away but, considering how "wooden" Mark Wahlberg is in this film, no wonder he survives! The (mightly overrated) M Night S starts off by creating a bit of drama, intrigue and genuine suspense and then kills it off completely. After 30 minutes this could be any TV movie seen on the likes of those free movie channels you get on Sky. Some woeful acting doesn't help but the problem seems to lie in MNS trying TOO hard to make an MNS movie, it feels forced as though it's another director trying to mimic his style. Could've been thought provoking but instead just irritating.

title: Surprisingly effective entry in a well-worn genre.
review:
First, I had to wonder if Shyamalan cut this rather short little film down from an intended earlier version that he had hoped would be more portentous, and deeper. I can see in this movie an idea for a deeper, more "serious" film, which he might have attempted without ultimately being satisfied with its effectiveness at the original longer running time.

Despite that impression, I would have to say that I join with those who felt that harsh treatment of this entry by the critics, along with weak box office returns was ill deserved. The very fresh feel, and unique magic, and whopping success of "The Sixth Sense", has apparently set this director up for such high expectations surrounding every new effort, that he has repeatedly been denied credit for his very substantial capabilities. The disappointing ticket sales for "The Happening" may result, in part, from the lack of major action sequences or dazzling special effects. Sadly, a lot of today's viewers seem addicted to all of that adrenaline-rush hyper-active film-making.

Objectifying this film quickly reveals that it is essentially a new offering in a very old genre. They were doing these creeping menace movies, wherein the threat emanates from some real danger that we have all been hearing about in the news in great numbers, back in the 1950s. Most were fairly mediocre. This one is so finely crafted, and so deftly laced with references to many sources of modern-day fear and paranoia, that it reminded me a bit of Francis Coppola's interspersing of history and fiction in The Godfather movies. For my money, Shyamalan played brilliantly on the embedded anxieties of this era to achieve a very creepy, chilling movie.

I've seen Wahlberg do better work. He is nonetheless, quite competent. In all, the cast, effectively comprised mostly of little known faces, did a fine job of bringing the story and its characters to life. Perhaps the characters could have been more complex and fully developed, but they served this little film very convincingly. To the director/writer's credit, this is a compact, scary thriller with a very serious message. I won't spell out the theme. It becomes fairly obvious when you view the film. It is hardly the first film to pitch this message; it won't be the last, but it struck me as a very well crafted, surprisingly powerful little horror show that ought to be widely seen, and widely discussed. If only a few holdouts among the partisans, who continue to deny that the threat at the heart of this story is real, might be moved to reconsider their folly, then Mr. Shyamalan's very engrossing show will be something for which we should all be grateful.

title: The intention was good...
review:
If you want to watch a great thriller that catches your attention through all the time, this movie won't suit for you.

The plot is very original, with scientific explanations and everything. On the other hand, it is badly-worked, in a way that makes you think it was a wasted story.

The acting is not convincing at all; Zooey Deschanel didn't do a good job (she made up for Yes Sir), and the other actors, excepting for Mark Wahlberg, also weren't that good.

The script itself has some failures, some free violence, some happenings that are not easily understood, and some that are just not explained, although the thing that really makes you feel you wasted your money is the end, which is not just predictable, but also charged with emotions and acts that you can find in the most romantic of the romantic movies, what is totally contradictory with the kind of movie.

All in all, just watch this if have nothing else to do or it's passing on TV; if you want to feel attached to your seat with your eyes goggled, try to find another thriller.

title: Not Happening
review: Let me get this out of the way: I haven't seen a film by Shyalaman that I didn't like. I find it unfair that everyone compares all his films to The Sixth Sense. Whenever I read a review of one of his films, there's always a reference somewhere to how it "wasn't as good as The Sixth Sense" or something like that, so I prefer to judge his films on their own merit. Unbreakable was probably the closest one I came to not liking, but it still kept me captivated. Signs I thoroughly enjoyed, partly due to the great performances (it was one of Mel Gibson's last films before he went crazy). I really liked The Village, even if the 'twist' was kinda dumb, but there was more to that film other than the surprise ending. Yes, I even liked Lady in the Water (especially the score by James Newton Howard). But The Happening? Not only is this the worst film by Shyamalan to come out, its one of the very few films where i came close to getting up and turning off the DVD player. I rented it knowing that people hated it, but people also hated most of the other Shyamalan films I liked. However I was very disappointed by The Happening. Everything about it felt lazy: the script, the acting, the story, the 'twist', the score (I almost felt like James Newton Howard was just as bored by the film, especially compared to his other excellent scores). Every actor and actress, not matter how good they are, end up being vastly under-utilized. Mark Wahlberg looks confused and barely able to hide his 'I can't believe I'm doing this' expression. Zooey Deschanel is just sort of 'there', but hardly. Only John Leguizamo manages to pull off a performance that elicits any emotional response, though it is very short lived. The way I see it, The Happening is a good idea gone wrong. It had the potential to be a great disaster film, but its hampered by silly ideas (Run away from the wind!) and characters you couldn't give a toss about. The biggest tragedy is that it doesn't feel like a Shyamalan film. The great cinematography is missing, as is the emotional score. The characters are one dimensional, most existing as a foil for another character. Even the 'shocking' death scenes are few and far between, and some border on either mundane (People hanging from trees; seen it before too many times) or downright silly (the guy feeding himself to the lions felt too unrealistic; it was a great idea, but lions would be more prone to jumping on you and tearing off your jugular rather than gingerly tearing off your arm). Hopefully Shyamalan can bring back some of the magic for The Last Airbender.

title: This movie blew and blew till it turned blue....then it sucked!!!!
review:
If ever there was an attempt to insult human intelligence, this movie would take the ticket. It starts off nicely with a nice intro to all the main characters, but then I don't know how it turns from a "happening " to a "crappening".

It just bogs down with conjectures and feeble twists and turns in a pathetic attempt to try and make this movie happen. It looks like there was a sale on blowers at some garage sale somewhere with all the windy scenes. Add the mushy love component that is thrown into the mix to make it human and .....Yecchhhhhhhh!

If there such an adjective to describe it , it would be SUCKERIFFIC! I gave it a 3 because it started out nice and drew me in.

Very disappointed.

title: Weird... really weird... maybe not that much...
review:
I usually don't watch movie trailers, but I saw the trailer for this one few months ago, and was looking forward to see it. It seemed like some weird episode of "The X Files". To bad, the movie turned out to be some kind of a crappy, weird, and maybe, advertising, video. It really seemed to me like SF ecological documentary. Lines in the movie are cheesy, acting is silly, plot is hmmm??? I really don't know how to describe it... strange, weird, confusing... but I liked picture, or to say, landscape and colors.

In one sentence, good intro, strange and unbuilded plot, there is no conclusion at the end... you won't miss a goddamn thing if you decide to skip it... it just lies there in the sea of unimportance cause, to be honest, anybody could make it. I just can get away from idea that it's advertisement. I won't say better luck next time, cause even if you didn't make an impression, you still made over 150 millions on movie about nothing special Mr. Shyamalan, dude.

title: Shyamalan Strikes Again... Sadly.
review:
When I saw the trailer for this film, I was reluctant to watch, but for the sake of supporting Mark Wahlberg's career and to avoid an argument with my girlfriend, I agreed to watch it. I figured, "Well, it can't get much worse than Signs, right?" Wrong. It got much worse.

Everything from the acting to the lighting was horrible in this movie. This movie has done to modern film-making and cinema what the Holocaust did to the Jewish. It was not only pointless to watch this movie, but torturous as well. Just to save some time, I'll narrow down the mind-numbing errors in this movie:

Errors: 1. M. Night Shyamalan had something to do with it. 'Nough said. 2. Mark Wahlberg, John Leguizamo and Zooey Deschanel (all of whom I enjoyed watching before this film)delivered absolutely dreadful performances. 3. If the premise would have been human, it would've had an extra chromosome. 4. None of the characters, situations, plots or events were believable. 5. M. NIGHT SHYAMALAN HAD SOMETHING TO DO WITH IT.

Honestly, after watching this, I considered breaking up with my girlfriend of two years for making me watch it. Not only that, but for making me PAY to see it. I could watch this movie for free and feel ripped off. I'd watch something more interesting, like watching the hair on my legs grow.

There you go, another unbiased warning by a frustrated and selfless human being. Don't watch it. Unless you hate yourself... then, you should probably watch it.

title: an improvement
review:
This director's films have been getting worse and worse...on the same slope as Elvis movies. I didn't think any movie could get worse than Lady in the Water, which ranks with Striptease and Exit to Eden amongst the worst films I have had the displeasure of viewing. At least I was smart enough not to waste my money at the theater for this goofy film.

This reminds me of an old Irish story about the priest asking for someone to say something nice about the deceased in his coffin before burial. A long silence followed before someone said "his brother was worse".

That's about the best I can say for the happening. It's slightly better than the last piece of condescending trash that this director foisted on the American public.

Can we just say good night to Night.

I see dead directing people.

This movie is infuriatingly bad.

title: It really IS as terrible as you've heard...
review:
The Sixth Sense was a decent enough movie. Unbreakable is probably the only M. Night film I ever really got into. Beyond that I think this guy is a terrible, terrible filmmaker. And the worse his movies get, the louder his fans seem to think they need to be in their support of him. And for some, it's not enough that they like his movies. They also have to point out that the anyone that doesn't is WRONG.

Well, you know what? It finally feels like a decent chunk of his audience is figuring out what I've known for a long time... this guy is totally overrated. Go ahead. Defend The Happening. You're only embarrassing yourself. Because no true student of cinema or fan of film could ever possibly believe this isn't an unintentionally hilarious disaster of unimaginable proportions.

It's impossible to throw the blame onto one thing in particular but the "acting" is most certainly a large contribution to this sinking ship. Say what you want about Mark Wahlberg but the guy is perfectly capable of giving a great performance. But this is a train wreck. The scene where he asks the house plant if it's okay to use the bathroom is so unspeakably bad you'll swear it's a joke. The skit on SNL where he talks to animals carries more credibility.

And Zooey Deschanel. WHAT HAPPENED???? She's a genuinely talented actress. But it's like she's not even trying. Which simultaneously makes her the worst actor in the film and the smartest person in the cast. John Leguizamo is the only one who manages not to look like a complete fool. The bottom line is all of the performers have been fantastic in other films. I blame the direction. It's always felt like M. Night's striving for something minimalistic or restrained with his actors' performances. Yet somehow it always nosedives into melodrama instead.

The script is ludicrous. A lot of people feel the premise is a strong one. I disagree. But I do feel another filmmaker could have taken the same basic story and done something much stronger and more resonant with it. Plot points aside, the dialouge is flat out horrendous. The very definition of cringe-inducing. Anytime the characters try to slip in exposition it feels clunky and awkward. And the rest of the time they simply tell us exactly what they're thinking or feeling instead of showing us.

There are some nice touches here and there. The model home billboard with the slogan "You Deserve This!" immediately comes to mind. And the scene at the construction site early in the film is pretty grotesque. But the rest of it fails to be remotely frightening, suspenseful, engaging, or insightful. I'm not sure what the goal here was but this is completely disposable work.

Sometimes movies are so bad they're fun. In this case it's just plain bad.

title: Rubbish
review:
Considering the thousands of films I've seen over the years and taking into account the huge budget, this is the worst film I have ever had the misfortune of sitting through. It is so bad it is laughable. Generally if the acting is even half decent in a film I don't notice it, but here the two main protagonists are simply wooden. You need only see the scene with Wahlberg and the pot plant to tell which of them is the better actor. In addition the scene with the man walking into the lion pit and the character comment afterwards is one of the funniest dead-pan set-pieces in history though not intentionally.

The best quote I have read for this film is that someone only realised halfway through that it wasn't a spoof. Yes, it is simply that bad.

title: Political/environmental horse poop
review:
First thing first BORING!!!!!!! Long Movie very little action. It appears to missing scenes, thank god! This movie blames pollution for trees and the wind for killing people. Sounds cool! Not Really. The characters seem like they are waiting for lines from Al Gore.

The claims in movie are there to prove a point about pollution.

Humans cannot really damage the earth. We are like ants occupying 10% of a large indestructible entity that has been here for billions of years and will be here for billions more when we are gone.

M.Night has made 2 good movies this is not one of them.

This movie gets a BIG "F".

Susan

title: You can't defend this...
review:
Firstly accept my apology for all the misspelling.

I've just seen the happening, and it's ranked right up there, as the worst **** I've ever seen. I had neutral expectations, and was literally blown away with the miserable screenplay, acting, script, and so on. The interaction between the characters are just weird, and no it's not in that intentional mysterious Lynch way, it's just bad professional work. My jaw hit the ground with astonishment as the movie progressed. It's an absolute embarrassment to watch.

I've read some reviews giving the film top votes, where the authors write about the many bad reviews. Stating that these are because of expectations of car chases, guns and explosions. Thats just dumb in my opinion. It has nothing to do with what this movie is missing, it has everything to do how it's crafted by a big group of professionals and how the final product is presenting it self for the viewer. I personally had no expectation other than a mystery thrilling movie. But it's take of achieving that for me, was just mindblowing bad.

I must give this picture 1 in terms of how bad it indeed is

title: Great idea, bad directing
review:
I just saw this film, one that should, at first glimpse, come with high recommendations. Instead, I was highly disappointed for numerous reasons.

At first I think the ideas that mold the plot were smart and original. Not only have I not seen something similar but it was a nice method to also pass some messages to the audience. However, although the idea was good, it was developed to an almost childishly plain and ridiculous scenario. The characters were shallow, predictable, too much of a "wiseguy" and abnormally trusting to science. What I mean with my latter remark is that when a normal person finds oneself in such a disturbing and dangerous situation, one cannot think and act in a logic manner. Even more, he or she doesn't try to explain "the happening" scientifically. People panic when in danger. So, seeing people act that way was very silly. Also, the scenario was "leaking" because too many things came conveniently, at the right place, at the right moment.

So, in general, it was a nice idea that submerged in a very poor and uninspired implementation and thus resulted in a not really enjoyable film.

title: this was bad even before I realized it was an M. Night Shyamalan film
review:
Let me start by stating I am an M. Night Shyamalan fan but haven't been keeping up with his film status. I didn't know he was part of the film until I got to the credits rolling ... and ohh god did that disappoint me.

I wondered about 25 minutes into this film why it had such a desperate cry to establish a hallmark. That moment never came for this film, and after 25 minutes, it started to come up with any trick it could to make up to the short coming.

As I stated, I am a Shyamalan fan, but even before I knew he had anything to do with this movie I was confused. Since it tried so hard, so many times, to give an edge, it just makes you shake your head and wish it was a bad movie.

title: Oh, dear.
review:
Oh, poor Mark Wahlberg. Poor Zooey Deschanel. Poor John Leguizamo. Poor, poor, POOR, dear Betty Buckley. Poor ticket buyers, and poor renters. Poor everybody associated with this film in any way.

20th Century has no excuse for ever letting this film out. After a private screening, and given the opportunity, I'd wager all involved would have been willing to pay shares adding up to whatever it would have cost to keep the public from ever seeing this - presumably with Shyamalan eagerly and humbly paying the largest share.

I know, not a detailed and reasoned review. There are a few hundred of those already. This is all you need to know.

The film is utterly, irredeemably, unforgivably awful. And a pox on those who chose to release it once they knew what it was.

title: Even worse than the horribly idiotic Lady In the Water - glorious!
review:
I won't delve too terribly deep into the point by point idiocy of this most idiotic of movies - other commentators have done a fine job. I was stimulated to put my own brief comments down after seeing The Crappening, and even registered with the IMDb solely for that purpose. I think I need some kind of purging.

Not too terribly long ago I decided Lady In the Water had to be the worst movie I'd ever seen. Lady In the Water was a masterpiece compared to the moronic The Happening. Of course, we all know there are far worse films, but Shyamalan's bad movies are unique in their affect. One responds to them in a very peculiar way - what is it? Probably his blend of ballooning pretension with a directly inverse diminishment in his capabilities.

I went to the DVD Special Features for some kind of explanation of the goings-on, and found the Making-Of feature. Expecting everybody involved to demonstrate awareness of the film's idiocy, I was shocked to find everybody in complete earnestness, especially Shyamalan. But there were cracks in the edifice - in some takes of a scene in which Wahlberg grabs a shotgun barrel to force it away from the teenager who in fact gets blown away (which was blessed), you finally see that he knows this film is terrible, but it's too late to cut loose.

Only if Shymalan is satirizing himself are his films redeemable. But he doesn't seem to be - unless of course, to appear to no be doing so may be part of the genius.

title: Worth watching if you study film.
review:
I may revisit this comment later, but probably not.

I would only recommend watching this film if you're a film student and want to learn how not to craft an entertaining thriller.

I'm sure a lot of the story that would have made this a real thriller is still in Shyamalan's head - it didn't make it to the screen.

And I'm REALLY surprised with the (poor) quality of the dialog, casting and direction. Ironically the recent parody of Wahlberg on SNL made this film more amusing to watch, especially when he talked to the plastic plant.

I'm sure the MST3k/RiffTrax kids are looking at this film for their purposes. (it would be worth watching again in that venue)

I feel sorry for Marky Mark - but I'll bet he can get an episode or story arc out of this experience for Entourage.

title: how can you write a spoiler for a movie with no suspense
review: This is a self-indulgent, poorly written, poorly written, and badly acted movie. It is barely worth a $1 rental from the local "Red Box". A literature professor of mine once said that "everyone has a story inside them that is worth telling - some writers only have the one and they tell that story again and again - to be able to tell other stories takes genius". Night is no genius - though he evidently thinks he is. The story is a hot mess - the people don't act like people - for instance, the "happening" is supposed to be a plague of suicides driven by some kind of neurotoxins emitted by plants yet at the end of the movie there is an epilogue that takes place 3 months after the epidemic of suicides - and nothing has changed. In every scene where the "happening" occurs everyone kills themselves - so how did the cities of the northeast recover any semblance of order? This is only one of the many absurd and unsatisfying elements in this hot mess of a movie.

title: The Debate in my Mind, Post-The Happening
review:
I am trying to determine if I found this to be the weakest of Shyamalan's films, or if I still hold Lady in the Water in that rank.

Lady was fairly dreadful, BUT it did feature the enormously good acting prowess of Giamatti, a saving grace. This latest venture stars Mark Wahlberg, who has turned in his most unforgivably laughable performance of his career.

The guilt is not entirely Wahlberg's. There's not a single, well-performed moment from any of the talent in this movie. It's a shame, but this entire cast stopped, look confused, and walked backwards through the entire film.

I am indeed a Shyamalan fan. I even enjoyed The Village...these last two works of his though...ugh!

It is not often when I'll honestly think to myself, "There's 2 hours I'll never get back". This is the second time I've thought that for Shyamalan's recent work, and a second time for Wahlberg too (first time being Planet of the Apes).

Just plain embarrassing. I'm not of the complaint department that screams for them to stop allowing Shyamalan to make films, but good God this dude needs to get it right again...quickly!

title: Disappointing
review: I am a big fan of M. Night Shyamalan AND the actors in this film but was very disappointed in this movies. The plot idea was interesting, but the graphic nature of the movie was a bit extreme. It seemed as if they wanted to focus more on "shock value" than on an interesting movie. I was also a bit disappointed that there wasn't a more creative ending. Also, I felt that the acting was awful. I know that both Zooey Deschanel and Mark Wahlberg are good actors, but not in this movie. Wahlberg seemed as if he wasn't really committed to the emotion which made Deschanel's character seemed a bit OVER played. I also felt that there were story lines that should have been expanded on but were left open ended.

title: A mediocre thriller that is messier than a babies dinner time
review:
Okay, firstly I would like to say how much this film attempts to be Frank Darabonts 'The Mist', a strange event is occurring on the east coast of the U.S. (once again, America gets it first) and is causing thousands to commit suicide, and a man and his family are attempting to save themselves from the terror.

Unlike The Mist, the idea of plants releasing a deadly toxin is both likely and almost a reality. The bad news is the toxin would most likely kill you than rather make you kill yourself.

It is where the gas causes people to kill themselves that I began to lose interest in the film, despite it having a great actor (Walhberg) and director. Sadly, Walhberg does not only fail to save this film, he strangely makes it worse. His acting skill varies in this film, on some occasions Wahlberg fits the role perfectly as the scientist trying to figure the event out, however, when the time comes for Wahlberg to save the day and try to help people, the scenes get messy. As a matter of fact almost all the actors in this film did quite an unnecessarily overdone and extreme job save for John Leguizamo (who did a great and almost moving job) and Betty Buckly as the insane and lonely old spinster. But a majority of the times, acting is messy.

What I found that also varied were the deaths scenes. On one occasion we had a vary well done scene in which a zoo keeper allows himself to be mauled by his lions, on the other, in the opening scene with hundreds of people are jumping off the buildings and the girl needling herself in the head.

As for directing I would give it say an average job, nothing too special, most likely something an unknown director would make. There was one occasion where 'shaky camera' technique was used and I found that quite irritating.

All in all a totally average film which I personally would fit into the rating scale of between 6 and 7.

title: What The F*ck
review:
OK I have to start by saying that the movie did have me interested throughout. I like the beginning and i liked certain parts as well. The ending just messed it up for me ......Killer Plants? If I wanted to see killer plants I go watch The Ruins ... which is another bad movie but that's not the case here lol.

I loved Signs and The Sixth Sense .....it just went downhill for Night in who I though would make some brilliant films for the future.

Let me tell you what happened..... NOTHING HAPPENED

I do give credit for his direction in the parts where suspense were featured. But once you see that lead actress so-called "act" if is another let down that makes the movie feel a little bit amateurish if u will.

title: yeah, it IS as bad as everyone says it is.
review:
The premise for this movie is great. They could've done something decent with this.

But, they didn't.

Wahlburg's acting was amazingly terrible, as was most of the other actors'. Everything seemed forced and fake with him.

The story really had no climax, no rising action, basically no PLOT.

We are thrown head first into the story right off the bat before we even know what's happening.

people die, hokey special effects.

it was just AWFUL. and it's hard to find a movie that I won't like. but ... i really hated this movie.

title: Really...
review: Really Shyamalan? So we're just going to sit here and write movies with misleading names and plots that appear to be deep but in actuality have NO underlying meaning at all so that we can squeeze in a couple of ticket sales...Dog saw cat. Dog chased cat. (enter weirdness)Cat eats Dog. The End. No explanation at all? How about some explanation Shyamalan? You started to explain your theory about the entity that was killing everyone, but you did not finish. Shyamalan is in debt for two counts of "philosophical value" and one count of "reading between the lines". This is, in my opinion, one of the worst movies he's made. And that is not coming from a movie buff. And yes counting his amateur movies...j/k. I'm just a recreational watcher. I wouldn't even advise you to waste your money on the DVD let alone a theater visit. Maybe borrow it from a friend or something. But only if you lift up their trashcan lid and see it there. No do not buy it from Blockbuster's preowned section because it's still not worth its weight in nickels...Great soundtrack though ^_^

title: I won't tell you the secret of The Happening...
review:
...because it just isn't worth it. I found myself initially curious, then almost bored to tears. I am so glad I did not see this in a theater as that would have been a waste of time and money.

So, by now you realize that I hated this film. I'm still trying to figure out how a brilliant writer/producer/director like M. Night Shyamalan could create masterpieces of film-making (The Sixth Sense, Unbreakable, Signs) and then give us little nothings of movies (The Lady in the Water, The Village, and now The Happening). To be honest, I felt sorry for Paul Giamatti, Joaquin Phoenix, and Mark Wahlberg in these latter movies because each of them has talent...at least Joaquin Phoenix got to work with Shyamalan on a good day (Signs).

I won't bore you with any plot details for two reasons:

1. You've already read about the "plot" of the movie

2. There really isn't a plot.

The story never really makes you to care about any particular character, and I found it to be dull rather than creepy or even interesting. If you are a huge fan of Shyamalan then rent this film...but please don't waste more than a dollar if you can manage it.

P.S. I'm sure that M. Night Shyamalan won't read this comment or very many others, but I hope that with his next movie, whatever that is, we find the real him again.

title: I didn't know this was a disaster film!
review:
Atrocious would be too kind. M. Night Shyamalan is too full of his own flakiness. The script, so called plot, direction, and acting were well beyond horrible. I think everyone involved with this bomb should go lick a tree and shoot themselves in the head!

Run and hide! Don't waste a minute of your precious life on this movie. Please God, if you are out there, don't make me watch anymore "films" by M. Night Shyamalan!

The only reason this movie got a two from me was it ended!

This is on par with Jabberwocky, Toys, and Hudson Hawk for being bad, bad, bad!

One of my worst ten movies ever!

title: $60 million budget, $55 million too much
review: The movie seems to have limited computer-generated effects. This could definitely have been a good low budget Roger Corman-type movie back in the day: lots of outdoor location shooting with natural light and a couple of industrial fans to blow the trees around;) Nowadays such a movie demands a relatively huge budget. One scene taking place in a tiger cage is pretty good. The film has a mild environmental message that is about as tame as the one found in "The Simpsons Movie." "The Day After Tomorrow" it is not. There is a generic romance. There is a creepy Tim Robbinsesque character ripped-off from "War of the Worlds." The movie is just not well written. Three stars for Mark Wahlberg's body, though.

title: Such a pathetic and disgusting attempt to get people to "go green."
review:
I never knew how totally disgusting M Night Shyamalan was until I saw this movie. He is part of the whole "go green" bull crap cult where they believe that humans must die in order to preserve the earth. There IS no global warming, it's yet another made up lie! This movie and all the in your face suicides disturbed me and severely enraged me! HOW DARE he devalue human life like that and shove suicides in people's faces to try and desensitize them to it and try and get them to devalue human life as well. If Shyamalan wants to commit suicide for his ridiculous "cause" then by all means he should feel free! He will certainly be making the world a better place by doing so! Not only did he have disturbing suicide images in your face for the majority of the movie but he even had CHILDREN getting murdered shoved in our faces!!!

****SUICIDE and MURDER ARE NOT ENTERTAINMENT!!!!!!****

I really enjoyed his previous works but now vow to never give this moron or his films another second of my life! I really hope he's lost all of his fans now! He certainly deserves to! Besides all the "kill people to save the planet" bull crap the movie itself was HORRIBLE!!! The acting was worse than any B movie I've EVER seen and the dialog was a complete joke! I realize that he didn't care about the plot or the acting since it was all just more global warming propaganda and unfortunately for some sheeple it probably worked. My God what a sad state this world is in and it will only get much worse...

title: Happening? Not so much...
review: It's not awful, but it is pretty lifeless. M. Night Shyamalan continues his slow descent from front line director to dullard with this outing. Mark Wahlberg is fine as science teacher (yes, somehow that's not as inane as it sounds) who, along with most of the northeastern US is trying to cope with some sort of plague that's forcing people to kill themselves. It's a promising premise that Shyamalan simply doesn't exploit to its fullest. The film is so slowly paced, it's difficult not to wonder if this shouldn't have had several additional rewrites before being filmed. It's like a short story stretched into novel length. Quirky actors like Zooey Deschanel, John Leguizamo, and Betty Buckley are in it too, with Deschanel just a bit too "out there" to be believable as the wife of straight-laced Wahlberg. Buckley has a particularly odd role as a stranger Wahlberg and Deschanel encounter. Nevertheless, THE HAPPENING does offer some great cinematography and a few truly shocking moments (one involving a very unfortunate zoo visitor).
