title: One of M. Night's worst.
review:
This movie has got to be one of the worst I've ever seen. The plot was stupid, the actors...wow, terrible. I'm a fan of Mark Wahlburg's so I definitely don't know what happened in this movie. It's as if the "toxins" affected his acting! It was seriously terrible.

I went in to see this movie expecting to be scared. Instead, I was confused, and sleepy. The movie was boring, and never exactly had a "climax point". It was predictable and stupid.

Oh and.**SPOILERSSSS**...what a crappy plot! Killer plants??? The plants are mad at the east coast so they kill them off in the craziest of ways?!?!? Wow.

Seriously, I would NOT waste my money seeing this. (Oh wait, I already did.)

title: running out of ideas?
review:
i donno. i so much appreciated M. Night Shyamalan's sixth sense, then slowly his ideas began running thinner and thinner...and he's ended up with water fairies and now plants, he's basically run out of Good Ideas.

i'm not looking for blow up bombs or super twists like sixth sense, but this really runs dry. plants releasing certain chemicals? OK, it could do, perhaps...with a smarter script to back it up...but the entire thing just fell a bit flat.

if u want clever, DAY OF THE TRIFFIDS (even though it was super old), provided a better plot.

title: Very stupid or very clever
review:
I read a lot of reviews of this film before I went to see it - some good, most bad - but being a Shyamalan fan I prayed that I would enjoy it. When it started, I felt myself agreeing with all the negative reviews. Zooey Deschanel's wide eyes staring at her vibrating phone made me want to hide behind the seat in front of me, it was just so awful.

However, as the film went on, I felt myself drawn into a style of film making that came across as cheesy (I think B movie has been used to describe The Happening), but at the same time strangely engrossing - weird characters, visible boom mikes et all. Before I knew it, the 90 minutes was up, which would suggest a good film as I'm terrible for clock watching in the cinema if the film is bad. You'd think Mark Wahlberg talking to a plastic pot plant could not be defined as good cinema, but for some reason it really sticks in my head as a clever scene. I don't know, perhaps they were releasing plant neurotoxins into the cinema, because I have this desire to see the film again - perhaps only to confirm that the film was indeed awful and I was just imagining things.

There are some very good shocks, and I liked the subtlety behind the many suicides - nothing overly gory, but shot in a way that suitably disturbed. On the other hand, why take a plausible scenario such as plants releasing neurotoxins, and spoil it by suggesting the completely implausible scenario that the plants can also create wind.

My 5 out of 10 rating is simply because I cannot decide if it was very awful or very clever. I would suggest that those of you haven't seen it wait for the DVD release, as I suspect a lot of you will begrudge the cost of your cinema ticket once you have seen The Happening. Myself, I'm going to watch Unbreakable again, if only to confirm that Shyamalan can make a good movie.

title: Not a disappointing film if you had no expectations like me and a lot of others.
review:
M. Night Shyamalan makes films that are visually and emotionally interesting.But his films have progressively become less intellectual and increasingly more moronic."The Happening" is no different. This film has MANY blaring inconsistencies. One moment you will be genuinely shocked by what you are seeing, perhapses even touched. Then another you will be laughing at the weirdness of the people you meet, the goofy dialog, and the implausible situations that either aren't funny in the way that the filmmakers intended, or are funny unintentionally.

For instance:

-Why does the happening start in parks and stay only in the Northeast? This is never explained. At least well.

  • There is a close up of a chalkboard in Elliot Moor's classroom with a quote from Einstein. "If the bee disappears from the surface of the earth, man would have no more than four years to live." This is true, but he never said this. Even "The Great Debaters" is guilty of this with the quoting of the erroneous Willy Lynch Speech hoax, but here it just does nothing but waste screen time. What a lack of integrity.


-Jillian gives Elliot the statistic that there is a 66.7 % chance his wife is still alive. Where did he come up with that? I don't care if he's a math teacher, its ludicrous; and to leave his child with Alma, a women he clearly doesn't trust, to go off and surely die which intern is depriving her of her father is inexcusable.

-When Elliot comes up with the idea that group size effects the pathogen in the air, we already know that this isn't necessarily the case. The first on screen death, a women stabbing herself in the neck with a hairpin, takes place in a group of two. Also this is stupid because it effects her and not here friend siting right next to her while it is effecting EVERYONE in the park at the same time. Elliot is in a group of 5 when he makes this conclusion. When Julian sub-comes to the happening, he is in a group of five also making the point moot.

-The characters at one point run from wind.

-Elliot latter talks to a plant in a room as if it were alive. He's a science teacher. He's alone. What were they thinking?

-Here is the biggest one of all. Why would a person who's cognitive functions such as memory and reasoning which are being eliminated have the intelligence to think of creative ways to kill themselves like :Untying a knot and pulling out a metal hair pin, getting into a lion cage, unholstering a pistol, slamming your head through a window, and especially turning on a lawnmower and knowing enough to lie down under it so it can kill you, aren't things I can imagine somebody doing who can even think a coherent thought, speak, and occasionally walking backwards for no reason then moving normally. Better yet, why not have the plants produce a gas that just flat out kills everyone. Why? Well, let me answer my own question. Because then it wouldn't be rated R and there would be no way to sell this film which I imagine originally was devoid of gore before the studios told M. Night the thing what boring so he needed blood to grab the audience. How cheap.I can clearly tell that this film's story could have easily done without most of these death scenes, including the opening.By the time you see a man lie down under a driving lawnmower this movie is stooping to slasher movie cliché. Considering Shyamalan professes this film to be some great statement on our effects on our planet and human nature, it surprised me.

I watched this film with a friend on opening day and I could tell the whole audience where treating the film as a B-movie such as I was. We would laugh at all the same inane dialog, the strange behavior of the wife, far-fetched plot, and bizarre character interactions near the end of the film. Also it was so predictable because we have seen so many films like it before. This is such an unoriginal film from the man who is known for making original films. I haven't read or herd this, but my friend told me M. Night Shyamalan was TRYING to make a B-movie with "The Happening". I told him that it made perfect sense when you think about it like that. This movie certainly is on the level of a Twilight Zone episode or some 50's end of the world movie. Now, do you think the movie going public WANTS TO SEE a B-movie? If that strategy is going to work, it would have to be something like "Grindhouse" or "Mars Attack" which makes fun of the genre its in. This film takes itself more seriously then it should have and thats its biggest failure, much like the movie "Hulk" which had a similar problem.

I give this movie 4 stars out of 10 because overall I was entertained and enjoyed picking this movie apart, kind of like a MST3K experience. Also, even though the Whole is less then the sum of its parts, it had its moments where It kind of worked for me and made me think about the things I was supposed to think about. If you are an M. Night Shyamalan fan you might like this, but I suspect his original fan base is dwindling so if you stuck with him after "Lady in the Water" why not this film? If you want to see a good movie with a similar theme, rent "The Mist" on DVD. I've read negative reviews for that said film, but I liked it and openly praise its tone and characters. Also keep in mind, I hate "The Ring" because I can't stand its inconsistencies. I can imagine somebody who liked that film likening this one.

title: When did it 'happen' and when it got over?
review:
As it happens with most of the movies that promise to deliver and come out short, "The Happening" starts out with a great assurance of an intense thriller but when you walk out of the theater you wonder what really "Happened" ?

The positives - It gets you right into the plot Without wasting much time and the plot isn't contrived. Although it may seem far-fetched but then there is no denying it may happen or happening even now. It's difficult to keep inventing new ideas of mass killing. There is a minimal amount of blood and gore, the only occasional scene to keep reminding what's happening (Oh that word). That's what was expected, that it wouldn't be like those slasher flicks with gallons of blood and gross-out scenes. It spooks you through silence, through strange acts by normal people without hideous faces. It has a fair amount of shock-treatment. To certain extent, it draws you into the plot. It's thrilling, evocative and original, yes.

Hmm now what's lacking - An occasional jolt of humor is fine, but there is a touch overdose of induced humor, which i didn't expect from Shyamalan. It lets you relax. It lets you cool off. May be he wanted to appeal to greater audience. MNS hasn't let the actors get inside their roles. May be he didn't want to divert from the plot, fair enough. But it doesn't get in depth in the plot too. Although he's captured the usual cliché's of the last dialogs when people sense they are going to die, i didn't find the people terrified enough. Where is the desperation to survive, the urge to hang in there till you are finally dead, the struggle of survival. People are surprisingly calm ! True that it looked like the 'happening' is beyond our grasp, but if you are evacuating a city, wouldn't people scream, crowd at stations, fight to be first ones out, even bribe. Where is the human emotion? Another one was getting the plot to some sort of conclusion, and i won't divulge, but it could have been better.

I can come up with a new idea of mass-murder flick, let's say the planets in our galaxy have formed a unique position and that's caused some electromagnetic flux along with strange gravitational pull that's causing people to die or go insane, animals are acting weird, crops have stopped growing. And it's a nice plot believe me, may be i can sell it to someone. But when i show it on the big screen, i need to make sure i take it to a logical conclusion on how we humans beat this. You got me ? And for God's sake i didn't realize why it was 'Rated R'.

Overall, it isn't a bad movie, it builds up the story, thrills you just enough, gets you into it and suddenly forgets there is an audience still waiting and brings down the curtain.

title: Brilliantly mediocre, as only Shyamalan can do it...
review:
M. Knight Shyamalan takes himself too seriously.

Apparently, M. Knight has come to the understanding that it really doesn't matter what his film is about. As long as his name is on the movie trailer, people will come & see it... all in the hopes of experiencing that sense of awe we all felt when we realized Bruce Willis was actually dead; or that Samuel L. Jackson was actually the comic-book nemesis who caused all those tragedies; or that Ron Howard's blind daughter was actually living in modern day...

Of course, with that hope comes the disappointment that there IS no mind-bending twist... that the aliens attacking the world look just like every other alien movie FX, or that the weird girl in the water is about as interesting as the drain-hair in the bottom of that pool.

Well, to quote one reviewer, The Happening should be titled The Crap-pening. Because it just lays there, stinking, floating-- waiting for someone to flush. But no one ever does.

Lets be honest. It was Shyamalan, so I was tense. The eery pace and ominous music built the perfect mood for a terror-ific payoff that never happened. Instead, The Happening was all about realism-- how would real people respond to such a 'happening'? There was no rioting in the streets. There was no grand battle to determine the victorious species. There was only the helpless hope of a man, as he faced uncertain death... at a less-than-frantic pace.

(***Spoiler Alert***) And while the cinematography was beautiful, and some of Shyamalans storytelling was effective, the story itself was just, plain stupid. The 'parable' (as some have called it) of this movie was that the plants were upset with humans, and were fighting back... SERIOUSLY?!? A global warming/save the planet message?? Give me an Al-Gore break!! And what about all the sub-plots that give a good movie nuance & depth? Oh, that's right. There were none! Instead, we are saddled with cheesy, suicide Special FX (yes, your ficus wants you to kill yourself), and a singular, unwavering story-line that was about as exciting as a Marky Mark & the Funky Bunch reunion tour.

One aspect of this flick that I have enjoyed, however, are the inevitable number of reviewers who explain to the rest of the world that we don't "get" M. Knight Shyamalan, because we're not filmmakers or we're too jaded by Hollywood. That may be. But I have yet to read a positive review that can effectively give me any poignant, redeeming quality of this film. Instead, they offer only condescension or rhetoric.

Still, I cannot say that I totally hated this film. Although I left disappointed, I sat through the entire film in eager anticipation and hope, searching frantically for the twist that would pull it all together ("Could it be the mood ring??? The honey bees? Maybe the hot dogs??"). There really was a lot of suspense.

At the very end though, my greatest joy in this film was the realization that, I got punked! I expected twists and turns, but was saddled with pretense and anti-climactic melodrama. And in the face of a public crying out to M. Knight for another "Sixth Sense", I can imagine "anti-climactic" was what he was going for, in an attempt to prove that he doesn't have to bow to public opinion or demands. He's M. Knight Shyamalan, for crying-out-loud. He can fart on film-stock and people will come to see it.

And that's exactly what "Happened"...

title: eh...
review: While more entertaining than The Village, this may be Shyamalan's worst film so far (perhaps I should mention that I am generally a fan of Mr. Shyamalan's films). There are some mildly startling moments, but mostly, the film is relatively predictable. It's not hard to figure out what's going on before any of the characters mention it, and well before the main characters grasp it. Not to mention, Shyamalan seems to have forgotten how to startle his viewers--you can see most of the shocks coming, and Shyamalan relies heavily on extreme violence to make an impression on the viewer. The acting is often not very believable--and there seems to be something weird going on with Zooey Deschanel's pupils. Plus, a shot is included late in the film in which a boom mic dips very obviously into the shot. Shyamalan also fails to provide any truly substantial explanation for the timing of the end of the 'event'--timing which seems pretty convenient for him as a writer. There's not much of a climax, it just kind of falls off. Finally, while some of Shyamalan's past films certainly seem to have a central message, even a message that is critical of some societal ill, he has now jumped on the bandwagon and taken up the ever-popular and almost cliché environmentalist's mantel.
